Dear John (and Friends & Family),

I wrote previously:

> >        Even though I understand it, it often frustrates me how much need
> >people seem to feel to relate to the accomplishments of others they
> >perceive as being like themselves, whether it be others of the same race,
> >or gender, or sexual preference, or what have you.
> >        Diversity is a wonderful thing and should be encouraged, but in
> >the end it does not really matter so much who does a good thing, as that
> >the thing gets done.  Hopefully in our desire to see more female DJs, we
> >will not lose sight of this and let it divide our unity.
> >
> >PLURally yours,
> >                                <<< Starchild >>>

And my computer tells me that on Sun. Mar 10, you responded; my comments 
are interspersed with your response below:

> 
> I have talked about this problem so much that it has become an excersize in
> tedium for me.  In short this scene is male dominated.  Females are
> relegated, often enough, as accesories to a party, or participating as
> paying patrons.  There is very real, and active discrimination of females
> here in SF (I cannot account for any other scene/locale).
> 
> Ask any female DJ's/Promoters (os/ns) if they have felt the pinch so to speak.
> 
> I would also like to point out that the need you cite is also very real.
> But since, I assume, you are not part of any underrepresneted group, you
> would have a very difficult time understanding this view.  

Underrepresented groups I am a part of (I'm interpreting 
"underrepresented" here as meaning at less than ideal representation):

-libertarians (more of us would mean less repression)
-ravers (no argument here, right?)
-agnostics (I see this as a healthy questioning of authority)
-people who appreciate hugs (naturally we could use more of these folk!)
-users of illicit drugs (everybody should at least try once, IMO)
-roller bladers (better if we did this instead of drove)
-non-macho guys (any representation of macho is too great, IMO)
-vegetarians (less suffering animals)
-people with full use of their limbs (wish everyone had this blessing)
-people who have somewhere to live (tragically underrepresented in S.F.)

Obviously I could go on here ad infinitum.  Equally obviously this is not 
what you meant by "underrepresented" John, but I don't necessarily agree 
with the premise of yours, which is that there is some ideal number of 
women (or any other group) that should be present in the scene.  
	If women who want to be DJs or promoters are unable to do so 
because of anti-female discrimination, this is wrong.  But I think to 
suggest that an equity of numbers means the problem is solved is wrong.  
	Imagine a situation down the road where there are an equal number 
of male and female DJs and promoters.  Problem solved?  Not necessarily.  
The story behind the numbers could be as follows:
	Some male promoters and DJs continue to discriminate against 
women.  Knowing this, a greater number of other promoters and DJs begin 
to discriminate in favor of women, against men, resulting in an 
equalizing of the numbers.  Discrimination is rampant; the men and women 
who were discriminated against because they (not knowing better) went to 
the wrong people, get discouraged and give up on the scene.  Women DJs 
and promoters who were booked or helped by men in the scene have the 
lingering doubt as to whether it was because of what they had to offer, 
or because they were female.  Result:  Virtually no one is happy, yet by 
the numbers, everything looks fine.

> I would suggest
> some serious time, in a country, where you are outnumbered 10, 20, 1000:1!

In many of the views that I hold, which I consider to be more important and 
more personal to me than my skin color, I would guess that I *am* 
outnumbered on the order of 1000 to 1, without ever leaving the country.

> (Africa for instance).  I am sure that after some time, it will be very
> pleasing to see someone who looks like you and shares a common culture.
> 
John, I don't agree that culture is based on skin tone.  I feel that I 
share more of a common culture with local ravers of all colors than with 
a group of Kansas farmers who might share my ethnicity.  As far as 
looking "like me," skin color isn't everything.  Ask Diana Greer.  ;)

> I have been to plenty, and I do mean plenty of parties.  It always suprises
> me to see Af. Am's go out of our way to introduce ourselves to each other.
> Kind of a relief to know that someone, just like you, likes the stuff you
> enjoy.  Someone, who in all likelihood had the same experience growing up,
> is there with you in the same spirit in the same space.  I can say it
> feels, more restful, and you can finally relax and get down, once you see
> the brown.
> 
> It is difficult to describe, you just gotta walk a few miles in my shoes I
> guess (I know gay/lesbian brothers and sisters must feel the same when they
> go to a primarily het event, or female DJ's must feel the same when they
> see one of their own at the dex).
> 
> As for it really doesn't matter...I dunno, I guess there are plenty of
> female DJ's and females in general who would disagree (one of the reasons
> YSH got started was due to lack of recognition, opps for females in the
> scene).
> 
For the record, I loved Your Sister's House parties, and went on a 
regular basis.  It was a great idea, and someone should start 'em up again!

> The last part of your statement is quite Machiavellian, and I quote
> "Diversity is a wonderful thing and should be encouraged, but in the end it
> does not really matter so much who does a good thing, as that the thing
> gets done."  I of course do not agree.  The ends do not justify the means,
> message, or messenger.  Respect of others is a necessity, and regard for
> others feelings is , IMO the only way we as a society can become more
> human.
> 
Machiavellian?  I really don't see how that label applies to what I said.
I don't feel the ends justify the means either.  The means I'm talking 
about are not anything that requires justification.  We're talking good 
deeds, whether it be creating enjoyable music or pulling someone from in 
front of a bus.  If I see a man pulling a woman from in front of a bus, 
I'm not going to say to him, "Excuse me, could you step aside and let a 
woman do that?  Not enough women are getting the chance to rescue people 
from accidents involving buses."  Again, the important thing is that the 
good gets done, not who does it, IMHO.
	As always, I enjoy conversing with you John.  You force me to 
examine my ideas and present them articulately, and you are a strong 
advocate for you point of view.

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 11 13:44:42 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA28070; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 13:44:42 -0800
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA27965; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 13:44:06 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id NAA05979; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 13:43:43 -0800
Message-Id: <v02120d28ad6a43724989@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 11 Mar 1996 13:43:43 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Clarification about drug talk.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Discretion is a funny thing, huh?  Especially as new technologies are
allowing us all to be reporters, authors, type-show hosts, and discussion
voyers.  That is, email is changing the way we communicate, because never
in our past have we had the opportunity to send little messages to 400+
people with the swift push of a button.  Not unless we were journalists, or
maybe steet-corner preachers.

I embrace fully the guidelines set forth in connection to this newsgroup.
In my review of the guidelines Brain put out, I found no specific reference
to the discussion of drugs.  This leaves it up to the individual to use
discretion when posting to SFR.

The topic of blatent drug talk has come up before and it seems that the
issue of whether or not it should be allowed (maybe that's to strong, how
about, excepted?) may never be resolved.  And that's why I recommend people
use discretion when they post.  You see, while we are all gatekeepsers of
our little forum, and while we all have the privlege to join in, the topics
discussed in the newsgroup reflect on every member of the newsgroup.  (Even
you, Mr./Mrs. Voyeur!  ;^)  As a proud member of SFR, and the SF rave
community, I am fully aware of the use of substances and their affects on
the individual and the whole at our parties.  I am not preaching for or
against drugs, I'm just saying that if someone has a question about drugs,
a message might read:  "I have a particular question about substances
(drugs, if you will) at raves in SF and I was wondering if someone might
offer me some advice.  Please email me privately for further discussion."
Of course, if the topic winds up being about a toxic substance being found
in a batch of local drugs, that might be an appropriate time to alert
people on SFR.

Now, I didn't mean to jump on Marisa for her post, in fact I mentioned that
I didn't mean to flame, I was just offering a reminder.  I'll even answer
her question:  There are very few faux pas one can make in the Bay area
rave community.  People here seem to embrace the old creeds, "Do unto
others, as you would want them to do unto you." and "Live and let live."
(but not "Live and let die.") and "I'm not gonna pass judgement on what you
do, as long as you don't pass judgement on what I do." and it's an
arragement that seems to work fine.  In short, no, you would not be
creating a faux pas.  Just ask the bearded guy next to you at the next
party.  ;^)

I love this reply:  "If you've been to raves in the SF area, then I'm
surprised if you haven't seen acid all over the place."  (Sorry Doug.)

Sadly, not long ago, a kid died after taking e at a local party.  His
father posted to SFRaves telling us the details surrounding the tragic
death of his son.  I was moved, as were a lot of people on SFR, I'm sure.
I couldn't help but feel that his curiosity surrounding his son's death
might pique him enough to subscribe to SFRaves and see just what kind of
people rave in the Bay area.  My premonition was suprisingly founded when,
about a month or so after his post, the father answered a question someone
asked on SFR.  I thought to myself, "Hmmm...there may be people on this
list that are very interested in who we are and what we do as a community."
I think of the father every time I post to SFR.  That's where I'm coming
from when I write that blatent drug discussions should be taken onto a more
personal sub-list.  I'm not saying we should curb our discussion because
someone outside the community might be watching, I'm just saying that we
should shut the blinds when we break out the scale.

Does any of that make any sense to you?  I'm not a flame thrower.  I'm not
an instigator.  I'm just a person who trys to communicate clearly,
concisely, and am concerned about how we are perceived as a whole.  There
are so many beautiful thing we have to offer, so many beautiful people, and
so much to shout about.  And then there are elements that only need a nod
of the head.

Cool? :^)

Tony

P.S.  Please, I beseech you, email me privately for further discussion.
This thread does not need to go on further in a public way.

P.P.S.  Discretion is not paranoia.  ;^)

My two pesos is that I don't care if the entire multiverse reads my posts.
Most times I know when to post publicly and when to post privately; if
someone misunderstands something I say, it's not my problem, but I'm ready
and willing to clarify it using the most appropriate method to the topic of
discussion.  If you want to say something, but aren't sure if it's
"acceptable", be cryptic.  It will be understood.  Works for me!

Thanx,

- E

I have to say, being a diehard househead, I've been going to Mecca on Fridays at
1015 every few weeks lately -- with Jeno, Markie, et. al spinning, I always go
with high hopes that good music will overcome a crowd that's not really my cup
of tea..  and once or twice I wasn't disappointed ....  but. ....

Last Friday, I was ready to throw in the towel ... just too alcohol-oriented,
bridge and tunnel, date-night for my tastes...  and way too cruisy....

BUT... the lineup and special guests for Nikita sounds SO GOOD...  so I just
wanna say, LET"S TRY TO SHOW UP THERE!  If we dancing raving fools can fill the
room, we can shift the vibe and help make it the place to go on Friday nights
(of course, unless there's a good underground thing goin' on...

So I'll give it a try ... if you all will too!  Look for flyers that let us in
free before 11 and we can start the place rockin' for nothin'!

Leslie  : )

At 9:56 AM 3/11/96, Amy R Starkey wrote:
>On Sun, 10 Mar 1996 Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:
>
>> Call me dumb or whatever but what does PLUR mean?
>
>P * Peace
>L * Love
>U * Unity
>R * Respect
>
>:)
>
        Hey there, here's something me and a friend did to hand out at
parties a while ago. Hope y'all like it :)
========================================

"We are all connected"
____________________________
and do you know what connects us all?  On the net it's called
PLUR.  No, it's not a dishwasher detergent, it's an acronym that
stands for Peace, Love, Unity and Respect.  These are big words
and may be difficult to define but here are some ideas:

        Peace: The calmness you find with those around you, and
also inside of yourself.  It's tough, we often have to work at it
but when you're at peace with others, with ourselves and with
our planet only good can come of it.

        Love: The caring you feel for friends, for strangers, for
those in need and also for caring you show for yourself.  It's
symbiotic, it's about sharing whatever energy you put into
something will be returned to you!

        Unity: This means we all share a lot of common things,
regardless of our age, gender, race, orientation, whatevah! We
are all human beings, we all need other people, & we're all in this
for the happiness experienced being around others.  Though we
may have differences, we all arise from the same source.

        Respect: This may mean respect for others, their ideas,
their music, & their lives.  It's also respect for one's self; one's
body and the needs that it has (food, sleep).  Educating yourself
on the substances you ingest shows love and respect for your
body; passing on the knowledge to others shows respect and love
for your fellow person.

ecto@magnet.ca & spooky@magnet.ca
==========================================

========================/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\====================
                ectographics: print design : HTML programming
    >>ecto@citenet.net >> ecto@magnet.ca >> http://www.magnet.ca/~ecto >>
"if your light's right, your night's bright" -the higher intelligence agency
======================\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/==================

within the Golden Rule.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 11 18:32:22 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA26405; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 18:32:22 -0800
Received: from netcom21.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA26387; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 18:32:15 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom21.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id SAA24042; Mon, 11 Mar 1996 18:22:18 -0800
Date: Mon, 11 Mar 1996 18:22:18 -0800
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v01540b00ad6a1af43fce@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: more about women in the scene
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Starchild, you said in response:

>Underrepresented groups I am a part of (I'm interpreting
>"underrepresented" here as meaning at less than ideal representation):
>
>-libertarians (more of us would mean less repression)
>-ravers (no argument here, right?)
>-agnostics (I see this as a healthy questioning of authority)
>-people who appreciate hugs (naturally we could use more of these folk!)
>-users of illicit drugs (everybody should at least try once, IMO)
>-roller bladers (better if we did this instead of drove)
>-non-macho guys (any representation of macho is too great, IMO)
>-vegetarians (less suffering animals)
>-people with full use of their limbs (wish everyone had this blessing)
>-people who have somewhere to live (tragically underrepresented in S.F.)
>

I am glad that you see things in more than a linear fashion.  I wish
society as a whole would do this.  Fact is, the majority do not.  We draw
conclusions by what we see.  Many of the traits you describe can only be
found out by conversation, surely something we should do more of.  But you
cannot tell any of the things above by mere sight alone, and THAT is what I
meant.  We as a society, base much on what we see.  And in THIS society the
two things most apparent are race and sex, and not in that order.  YOU may
choose to operate outside of this, and that is good, but society has quite
a way to catch up to your way of looking at things.  Which I *DO* think is
enlightened.

Discrimination is rampant everywhere and takes many forms.  I dare not tryo
to micromanage the problem, I would rather deal with the most obvious, and
go from there.  So yes, race and sex are most prominent, and thus my
argument holds from my view.

>Obviously I could go on here ad infinitum.  Equally obviously this is not
>what you meant by "underrepresented" John, but I don't necessarily agree
>with the premise of yours, which is that there is some ideal number of
>women (or any other group) that should be present in the scene.
>        If women who want to be DJs or promoters are unable to do so
>because of anti-female discrimination, this is wrong.  But I think to
>suggest that an equity of numbers means the problem is solved is wrong.

Did I say equity in numbers?  All I rebutted against was your lack of
understanding as to why people want to see one of their own at a party or
on the dex.  I never mentioned numbers at all.  The rest of your argument
is based on that assertion, so let us move on.

>        Imagine a situation down the road where there are an equal number
>of male and female DJs and promoters.  Problem solved?  Not necessarily.
>The story behind the numbers could be as follows:
>        Some male promoters and DJs continue to discriminate against
>women.  Knowing this, a greater number of other promoters and DJs begin
>to discriminate in favor of women, against men, resulting in an
>equalizing of the numbers.  Discrimination is rampant; the men and women
>who were discriminated against because they (not knowing better) went to
>the wrong people, get discouraged and give up on the scene.  Women DJs
>and promoters who were booked or helped by men in the scene have the
>lingering doubt as to whether it was because of what they had to offer,
>or because they were female.  Result:  Virtually no one is happy, yet by
>the numbers, everything looks fine.

By the numbers?  Well I can tell you the numbers are lower than previous
years.  Happiness, hard to guage on a party by party basis.  The world has
kept turning, and being in a place like SF makes my world view however
utopic, very skewed. Especially considering the reality of others.

>
>> I would suggest
>> some serious time, in a country, where you are outnumbered 10, 20, 1000:1!
>
>In many of the views that I hold, which I consider to be more important and
>more personal to me than my skin color, I would guess that I *am*
>outnumbered on the order of 1000 to 1, without ever leaving the country.

Exactly, you would guess, that is far from knowing.  Try being a real
outsider, where the rules are foreign, the ways are foreign, and the tongue
is foreign to your present reality.  I hate to harp on color, but it IS the
most obvious in this society.  Just a suggestion to understand my view.
You see, I have always lived in a foreign world, I have just learned
adaptation, as any African in America would, as any woman would in a male
dominated world, as any blind person would in a world built for the
sighted.

>
>> (Africa for instance).  I am sure that after some time, it will be very
>> pleasing to see someone who looks like you and shares a common culture.
>>
>John, I don't agree that culture is based on skin tone.  I feel that I
>share more of a common culture with local ravers of all colors than with
>a group of Kansas farmers who might share my ethnicity.  As far as
>looking "like me," skin color isn't everything.  Ask Diana Greer.  ;)

Color matters little to me.  Ask my wife and son.  However, I do understand
that I exist in something much larger and greater than the rave community.
I exist in the world, not in a relatively small camp.  I am a citizen of
the society in which rave thrives, as well as existing in the rave world,
as well as existing in the Eurocentric world. And in these other spheres we
are defined not only by how we look, but how we act, who we associate with,
and how much money we have.  It is the capability of duality that allows me
to not only understand how you see the world, but how others may see it
differently.  I cannot divorce myself from that by creating a set of rules
for myself and rules for others.  I need some consistency, and try to
change the world in any way that I can.  Usually by talking to people who
are , in many ways other than race, far different than I am.  This is a
good thing IMO.  And just because you have found that perfect place for
yourself, that allows you to see the truth, does not negate other peoples
truths, their emotions, and most importantly their experiences, that exist
outside of your rules or views of the world.  How can we as a people get to
any understanding unless both sides are willing to see each other's
perspective, and have some empathy for them (remeber, walk in my shoes...).

I guess being born into a duality is quite different than creating a
duality of living.

>
>> I have been to plenty, and I do mean plenty of parties.  It always suprises
>> me to see Af. Am's go out of our way to introduce ourselves to each other.
>> Kind of a relief to know that someone, just like you, likes the stuff you
>> enjoy.  Someone, who in all likelihood had the same experience growing up,
>> is there with you in the same spirit in the same space.  I can say it
>> feels, more restful, and you can finally relax and get down, once you see
>> the brown.
>>
>> It is difficult to describe, you just gotta walk a few miles in my shoes I
>> guess (I know gay/lesbian brothers and sisters must feel the same when they
>> go to a primarily het event, or female DJ's must feel the same when they
>> see one of their own at the dex).
>>
>> As for it really doesn't matter...I dunno, I guess there are plenty of
>> female DJ's and females in general who would disagree (one of the reasons
>> YSH got started was due to lack of recognition, opps for females in the
>> scene).
>>
>For the record, I loved Your Sister's House parties, and went on a
>regular basis.  It was a great idea, and someone should start 'em up again!
>
>> The last part of your statement is quite Machiavellian, and I quote
>> "Diversity is a wonderful thing and should be encouraged, but in the end it
>> does not really matter so much who does a good thing, as that the thing
>> gets done."  I of course do not agree.  The ends do not justify the means,
>> message, or messenger.  Respect of others is a necessity, and regard for
>> others feelings is , IMO the only way we as a society can become more
>> human.
>>
>Machiavellian?  I really don't see how that label applies to what I said.
>I don't feel the ends justify the means either.  The means I'm talking
>about are not anything that requires justification.  We're talking good
>deeds, whether it be creating enjoyable music or pulling someone from in
>front of a bus.

Good is a relative term.  Your good is someone else's evil.  Would I pull
Hitler out from an oncoming bus.  No, I would not.  And yes, I would keep
my eyes open to make sure fate was dealt.  Not good or bad, some things
just is sometimes.

>If I see a man pulling a woman from in front of a bus,
>I'm not going to say to him, "Excuse me, could you step aside and let a
>woman do that?  Not enough women are getting the chance to rescue people
>from accidents involving buses."  Again, the important thing is that the
>good gets done, not who does it, IMHO.

So, it would be fine for David Duke to champion Civil Rights by day while
at night bruning crosses on people's lawns?  See, relativisim has it's
extremes too.  And it does matter who does the good deed, and often it is
just important as to why one does good deeds.


>        As always, I enjoy conversing with you John.  You force me to
>examine my ideas and present them articulately, and you are a strong
>advocate for you point of view.
>
>Much love,
>                                <<< Starchild >>>


Peace out my man.  It is always a pleasure talking with you as well.  Good
points all around, and you have shaken my paradigm a bit and opened my eyes
to the diversity that exists on many levels.  I love good banter and
debate.

Peace out,
John

Starchild,

By no means was I toying with you!  As I said before, you are a 
beautiful human being, both physically and mentally.  Last Wed. night 
when we ate and talked after the film, I was thrilled with your spirit 
and the incredible amounts of _positive energy_ that emanate from you! 
Remember when I told you that the scene needs more people like you, 
because that is how change of any kind comes about.  The light in your 
eyes when you discus how the future can be is so inspiring!  

I was being little bit facetious with the groping offer a because on 
Wed. night you held the hand of another woman, and I could not ever come 
between two people.

Peace, Love, Unity & Respect

hi...

playing devil's advocate, does accepting yourself mean announcing 
everything about yourself to the whole world...even to those whose sole 
purpose is to seek out people who are like you and jail them or hurt 
them?  if there are such things you want to reveal about yourself is this 
correct forum?

compeled to send before they press the send button (or ctrl-x in pine, 
unix forever!) including myself!  like i said, i'm just playing devil's 
advocate.

>excuse my ignorance, but what is a mini thin?
>
>Czefir

Asthma pills... main drug ingredient- epherdine
  sugested medical dose 2 (25mg each)
  recreational usage 5 and up
mostly has a speedy effect for a few hours tingly arms - people I know who
take them a few hours after packing a bowl to rise up out of that drowsy
phase and stay awake at parties.  can still have a quite a down side after
the effect wears off =3D very tired.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>excuse my ignorance, but what is a mini thin?
>
>Czefir

Asthma pills... main drug ingredient- epherdine
  sugested medical dose 2 (25mg each)
  recreational usage 5 and up
  about $5 for 100 at your local convience story or gas station
Mostly has a speedy effect for a few hours, gives a little tweeky feeling,
tingly arms and other body parts.  I know friends that take them a few
hours after a bowl to rise up out of that drowsy phase and stay awake at
parties.  can still have a quite a down side after the effect wears off =3D
very tired.

	Kind of funny things...hugs.  It's really nice to be able to hug
people instead of just a hand shake or a nod of the head, but like any-
thing, hugs can be missunderstood.  I have no problem with hugging males
or females (I'm told I give pretty good ones too!) and I'm usually re-
warded with an equally warm hug.  But I have to admit, I think I've
recieved more confused or dirty looks from hugging another male than from
hugging a female.  The way I see it, hugs are hugs...just like a hand shake,
but with your whole body!  =)  If you should feel violated by a hug, it 
would prolly be best to avoid that person in the future, or tell him or her
to tone down their hugs a bit.....
man.....I gotta stop babbling......anyway...a hug is a terrible thing to waste,
and generally a wonderful thng to recieve.
                                  *HUG*
              ...heh heh...
Sabin!

hello all-  i've been lurking the past month, in contrast to my normal
participation- i have been rather busy, and i haven't had time to respond to
many threads that i would like to respond to.

just one comment - KEEP THESE WONDERFUL FLAME WARS GOING!  I DON'T KNOW WHAT
I'D DO WITHOUT THAT NEGATIVE ENERGY IN MY LIFE!!!!! (at last count, 2
strands of rather negative message posting.  not that disagreement is bad, i
revel in it.  i also revel in a certain civility and positive regard for
each other while disagreeing.)

if i'm overreacting, i'm sorry =) . but i've been using my delete key far
more than i'm normally comfortable with, i.e. deleting entire threads that
drain my life energy.

i love you all, but sometimes we, as a group, think that if we have PLUR on
our side, we can do no wrong (sounds familiar, doesn't it?)

peace, love, and more fucking love-

matt l.

smiling faces. I want this Picnic Party to be a good one for everyone here,

extended cab with 2 seats. If you don't plan to attend the meeting but can

probally in the last week in March or first week in April then maybe one a
day or 2 before the event to gather last minute details.
So let's make this a good one.
 
Tim (knucklehead)

Hey, I tried sending this before but it never showed up on the list (I think?) so 
here goes again.....


Hi, and what a miserable monday it is (rain 'n all). So to remove some of this 
miserableness here's a quick joke...

Once apon a time there was this raver wondering through the woods when suddenly he 
heard this tiny voice. He looked down 
and there before him was a slimy green frog. The frog said "If you kiss me, I'll 
turn into a beautiful princess and kiss 
you!". The raver shrugged then picked up the frog and put it in his pocket and 
wondered off. Soon after the frog 
interruped, "If you kiss me, not only will I turn into a beautiful princess, I will 
have sex with you!". The raver 
paused and continued on. Again the frog spoke, "If you kiss me, I will have sex 
with you for a whole year!". Again no 
interest. "I'll be your sex slave for life, you can do anything you want!!!". The 
raver kept on going. The frog finally 
preturbed asked, "Why won't you kiss me and change me into a person?". The raver 
stoped, "But I see beautiful people 
everyday; a talking FROG, now that's something special..." :]

--

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 12 11:39:35 1996

Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id LAA23511; Tue, 12 Mar 1996 11:39:18 -0800
Message-Id: <v02120d0ead6b7c0311f7@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 12 Mar 1996 11:39:18 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Quick review - Food Not Bombs
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Food Not Bombs (FNB) sponsored a small party last Saturday.  It rocked!

The space was fairly limited, and there was a sizable number of FNBers
there, so I guess word was kept pretty local to those close to FNB.  In any
event there was great music and a really nice, sort of mixed crowd, what
with ravers and FNBers all mixing into a big ol' melting pot on the dance
floor.

The location was a cool hidden studio space in Oakland.  Walked through a
gate and entered into a very cool, lush atrium.  Sliding scale tickets
($5-$10) at the door.  Through the atrium and into a greeting room with low
ceilings, sort of a nice lounge area with black lights and sofas.  Past
that and into the main room which opened up wide with high ceilings. The
walls were painted in this totally rad high-gloss black, orange and green
pattern that looked excellent in black light.  The dance area was about the
size of Komotion maybe (?).  Juice bar off the dance floor (excellent juice
bar, BTW and only $1!), through some thick drapes to an ambient area
replete with wonderful shrine.  One other chill area above that (up this
trippy stair case off the dance floor that had an indoor balcony off it,
making one feel like they were in New Orleans or a Spanish villa), that was
someone's bedroom and had mattresses all over it.  A puppy-pile magnet.
:^)

I believe it was Heather (of Heather, Todd and Sarah), who brought the two
groups together, and it seemed as if everyone hit if off.  The night
started with a great drum circle that served as a nice warm up.  Ethan
mixed in really well with the drums and then let a record fly and proceeed
to mix a great seamless set.  He was followed by Minor Minor who always
seems to be having so much fun back there it's hard not to smile when you
watch him mix.  Another great set.

Through it all the drums kept up.  They couldn't push the volume too much,
so it was interesting having the drums at an almost equal volume with the
music.  Most of the time that was great, but admittedly there were a couple
times, when the music was building, that the drums drowned it out.  It's
all good though, you know, and people kept right on dancing, and the
drummers kept right on drumming.

BIOJeff spun after Minor Minor and lit the crowd on fire with some really
nice mixing of old and new tunes.  Following Jeff was (I might get this
wrong) Michael Paul?  And after him Jimmy Hawkin.  I first heard Jim at a
New Moon party at Goat Rock and was so psyched to hear him spin again.
Excellent set.  Following Jim, Gabber Dave came on at about 7am.  You gotta
love gabber as a come down for the legs.  I mean, I'm sure everywhere else
in the world people work up to gabber and then slow it down, but somehow
Dave manages to hit the decks early in the morning, and thus we dance hard
at the end.  He spun a cool, short set to end it all.

All the while the ambient area had Claire, and Joe Rice spinning, plus some
others I'm not sure of.

All in all a great little party.  Lots of happy FNBers who seemed happy to
have their space invaded by freaks.  Thanks all, organizers, DJs, system
controllers, drummers, and revelers under the black lights.

:^)
Out!

Tony

P.S.  This party was special for a lot of us, for it was our last
opportunity to say good bye to Bill and Gaby who are heading to India for a
year.  Those that know them know how important a role they have played in
our community in the past years.  I think I speak for us all when I wish
them god speed and a safe journey.  Fare-thee-well, my friends,
fare-thee-well...

On Mon, 11 Mar 1996, Diana Greer added:

> ps  I have never said, nor will I ever say anything in this newsgroup 
> that will cause me to go to jail.  

	I think one of the most important points here is that going to 
jail is not what will happen to anyone who posts about drugs. What will 
happen, is you will be flagged down with supposed evidence, arrested 
(which produces an arrest number which goes on your TRW which is checked 
by prespective employers and landlords before hiring you or giving you a 
place to live), and then given a chance to bargain - you give us some 
names, you go free... This happened to a friend of a friend, so, 
is it paranoid to not blab around a public archived forum, or just 
watching your ass? I don't think it becomes a matter of what can be 
proved, it becomes of a matter of who you are suspected of knowing.

dave

It's important to remember that you can go to jail at any time, with or
without reason.  A police officer can come up with some "suspicion," and
lock you up for up to 48 hours, then either book you or release you.
They're not that eager to blemish someone's personal files, though.  I've
had lots of encounters with The Man, and I still have excellent credit and
no trouble getting work or housing.  Nevertheless, a little paranoia is a
very healthy thing!

If you can't be good, be careful...

- E

<HTML>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>LNT FAQ</TITLE>
<BASE HREF="http://www.nols.edu/LNT/">
</HEAD>
<BODY background="Images/paper05.jpg">
<BODY>

<a href="LNTHome"><img  src="Images/go_prev_btn_s.gif" border=0>Go Back</a><p>

<H1>Leave No Trace</H1>

<H2>Questions and Answers</H2>

<img src="Images/TornLine.GIF" WIDTH="100%"><P>


<H4>What is LNT's mission?</H4>
The mission of the Leave No Trace program is to create a nationally recognized educational system that promotes land stewardship, minimum-impact skills, and wilderness ethics.<P>

<H4>What is the need?</H4>
America's recreation lands, from state parks to vast wilderness areas, are being used and enjoyed by more and more people.  Their non-motorized use, be it hiking, camping, river-running, hunting, or other outdoor activities, leaves an individual and cumulative mark on the land.  Until now, educational efforts have lacked a common direction.  Leave No Trace will be that recognizable educational thread.<P>

<H4>What does it take to be involved?</H4>
First, it takes an interest in improving minimum-impact education on a personal and national level.  Are you interested in Leaving No Trace of your recreational visit to America's public lands?
Beyond that critical first step, the extent of your involvement with the national LNT program depends on your particular situation.  Become a LNT Member by filling out an application and educating yourself with free LNT materials.  If you are part of an organization that has a mission or structure that allows for displaying the LNT message and training others, or contributing financially, become a LNT Partner.  If your company or organization has a strong interest in providing energy, enthusiasm, resources and direction to the program, consider becoming part of the LNT Leadership Group.<P>
 
<H4>Why get involved?</H4>
Recall the character of the nation's backcountry when the 1964 Wilderness Act was signed and think about the plethora of fire-rings, trampled vegetation, unburied feces, and litter visible in popular areas today.  Now stretch your view into the future.  What regulatory and environmental changes will 30 more years of use bring to America's recreation lands?  The public's individual and cumulative marks on the land become more numerous with each season and so the restrictions and regulations placed on wildland recreation also increase.<P>

Regulations dictate behavior.  Education builds on ethics and personal experience to promote appropriate action.<P>

<H4>Why is the LNT program effective in educating the public how to recreate more responsibly?</H4>
Leave No Trace is first and foremost an educational program based on proven instructional models and scientifically researched principles.  We are marketing this substantive message to the nation.
Additionally, the four levels of LNT structure (federal Steering Committee, Leadership Group, LNT Partners, and Members) encourage diverse participation which utilizes an individual's or organization's particular strength while tying LNT together under a common and recognizable umbrella.  This built-in diversity will spread the message into the hearts and minds of the recreating public.<P>

<H4>What are the benefits of LNT involvement?</H4>
Besides participation in a positive educational program which works in concert with federal land management agencies and other industry-leading organizations, LNT Partners and Leadership Group members also receive approved use of the LNT logo, materials, and message, as well as public referral as a LNT source.<P>
  
Financial contributions will be magnified and matched by the synergy of partners in the nationally- recognized LNT marketing program.
Individuals, companies and organizations involved with the national Leave No Trace program have the knowledge and satisfaction that their contributions of energy and resources are helping to improve the level of minimum-impact education available to America's non-motorized recreationists.<P>

<H4>How is LNT information dispersed now?</H4>
Today, there are LNT pamphlets, posters, brochures, training curricula, and videos that fit the basic needs of our current target audiences (federal agencies, user groups).  But to become a truly national program, in which Leave No Trace ethics and techniques are a part of all recreationists' outdoor experience, much more needs to be done.  There is a great need for print media attention, outdoor product and retailer involvement, more regional curricula and an expanded training and materials catalog.  LNT needs television and video exposure.  Classroom teachers regularly request LNT curricula and non-English versions of LNT for school-age folks.  
The more we succeed, the more diverse our needs become.<P>

<H4>Is there a political agenda associated with the LNT program?</H4>
No.  Leave No Trace seeks only to educate non-motorized recreationists on how and why to minimize their impacts while enjoying public lands.<P>

<H4>Is LNT just a slogan?</H4>
Leave No Trace is already much more than a slogan and the program has immense potential.  Quality educational materials exist and are being distributed.  Hands-on field training is in progress through the Masters of LNT program.  Federal, educational, and outdoor industry partners are collaborating on the LNT program.  The public is hungry for LNT's message and the educational model works (as evidenced by the 30,000+ educational contacts LNT Masters made and the approximately 5,000 information requests received in 1993).<P>

<H4>How is success measured?</H4>
The ultimate goal of Leave No Trace is improvement in the condition of America's diverse recreation lands and thereby preserve the wilderness experience.  However, accurately measuring objective and subjective national conditions with the tools and resources available to today's recreation ecologists is essentially impossible.<P>

The best measurement of Leave No Trace is by national visibility and quantified industry, government, and public participation:  How many educational materials are distributed?  How many individual Scouts or Scout Troops are involved?  How many state and federal land management offices display LNT information?  How much outdoor industry packaging carries a LNT message?  Numbers and trends such as these will give us a reasonable measurement of the success of the program.<P>

Intuitively, we all know that the LNT message is important and that its concepts make sense.  Together we have the ability to educate the nation and reverse current trends of recreation-caused resource degradation.  America's recreation lands and waters are finite, and human pressure seems boundless...  We must do everything we can now to teach ourselves and others to Leave No Trace.<P>

<H4>Who are the federal partners?</H4>
Four federal agencies are partners in the Leave No Trace program. Representatives from each agency serve as the LNT steering committee.
<UL>
<LI><B><A HREF="http://www.esusda.gov/homeusda/usda.htm">U.S. Department of Agriculture</A></B>
<UL>
<li><LI><A HREF="http://www.fs.fed.us/">U.S. Forest Service</A>
</UL><P>
<LI><B><A HREF="http://info.er.usgs.gov/doi/doi.html">U.S. Department of the Interior</A></B>
<UL>
<LI><LI><A HREF="http://www.blm.gov/">Bureau of Land Management</A>
<LI><LI><A HREF="http://www.fws.gov/">U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service</A>
<li><li><A HREF="http://www.nps.gov/">National Park Service</A>
</UL>
</UL> 

<HR>
For LNT questions, please contact <A HREF="mailto:lnt@nols.edu"><I>lnt@nols.edu</I></A>
<P>

</BODY>

Precedence: bulk

As far as I know, laudanum is a depressant that was widely used in 
Victrian days and earlier to help calm you down and get to sleep.  In 
high enough doses it's a poison, like other similar substances.  it's 
mentioned in Interview with the Vampire too.  Also i think it was used as 
a sedative for people during operations way back when before they 
discoverd sodium pentothal ....

k

Dear Geoff,

My friend in Cincinnati is very new to the rave scene, and would like 
some recommendations of music to buy that would give him an idea of the 
broad spectrum of rave music styles.  The names of Cincinnati stores to 
buy them in would be appreciated also.  I know that this is a tall 
request, but hey, the rave community just grew by one today, and the 
industry will thrive thanks to his interest, and his disposable income 
that will now flow this way!  (Capitalism helps many good causes grow.)

Dear Friends & Family,

	Enough already... I'm willing to be the SFRaves canary.  I am 
publicly stating here, on the record, that I have taken Exstasy, LSD, 
mushrooms, pot, GHB, and speed, and with the exception of speed I expect 
to be taking these drugs again, for the simple reason that in my opinion 
the experience is worth it.
	There; it's said.  If I get arrested for exercising my freedom of 
speech, then we will know that it is not safe to speak freely of such 
matters on SFRaves.  If not, well, then I hope some of you will feel 
safer than you do now.  :)
	Just in case we are not now being monitored and in danger of 
being arrested, but may become so in the future, I will post this 
message periodically as the issue of self-censorship comes up.
	Obviously I am not expecting to get arrested for this, but if by some 
fluke I do, I hope those of you who care about freedom of speech (most 
all of you, I would hope), will take appropriate actions.

Yours in liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


For the record - many people misunderstand "freedom of speech"  while
it allows you to TALK about drug consumption, government overthrow,
racism etc.  it does NOT protect actions ( which are NOT speech )....

So you can talk about drug consumption in an abstract way all you want -
even William F. Buckley does that....  but a direct admission of drug
use and/or specific activity are definitely NOT protected by the speech
amendment... of course another specifies that you can't testify against 
yourself but by then the harm could be done....

  For the newbies on sfraves who haven't had it explained - it's been 
gone over several times before.... when on a public forum such as this
only say what you'd be willing to say in public ( how about the Mayor's
or police chief's office? ) and keep things abstract....

  SO it's fine to discuss the effects of E, LSD etc on the scene, or share
information about their effects on people... etc.  but it's prudent to
avoid specifics about consumption such as who , what, when and where.
Thus, No one ever said there can be NO drug discussions on sfraves - only
that specific details should not be aired publicly.... information NOT
disclosure....

If that makes sense....

Mike




 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

Mike,

> So you can talk about drug consumption in an abstract way all you want -
> even William F. Buckley does that....  but a direct admission of drug
> use and/or specific activity are definitely NOT protected by the speech
> amendment... of course another specifies that you can't testify against 
> yourself but by then the harm could be done....
	Actually, you are only protected against being _forced_ to testify
against yourself. Sending a public message to a forum like this isn't forced,
and so there wouldn't be any problem in using it as evidence against you.

> gone over several times before.... when on a public forum such as this
> only say what you'd be willing to say in public ( how about the Mayor's
> or police chief's office? ) and keep things abstract....
	Only thing is, what if what people say here _is_ what they would say
in public? Not everyone hides their chemical use...

> If that makes sense....
	Yep, it did.

				Marisa

> yourself but by then the harm could be done....
> 
>   For the newbies on sfraves who haven't had it explained - it's been 
> gone over several times before.... when on a public forum such as this
> only say what you'd be willing to say in public ( how about the Mayor's
> or police chief's office? ) and keep things abstract....
> 
>   SO it's fine to discuss the effects of E, LSD etc on the scene, or share
> information about their effects on people... etc.  but it's prudent to
> avoid specifics about consumption such as who , what, when and where.
> Thus, No one ever said there can be NO drug discussions on sfraves - only
> that specific details should not be aired publicly.... information NOT
> disclosure....
> 
> If that makes sense....
> 
> Mike
> 
> 
> 
> 
>  meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
>  Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.
> 

		        http://www.teleport.com/~shakti

Here's the deal, out of 6 or 7 people that said they would come to the
meeting only 2 so far has said the will be there, and the others can't make
it due to something came up or whatever, which is fine. I was hoping alot
more would want to show, and help with the planning of this picnic but I
also understand it is on a weekday and people are still working, live to far
away, or doesn't have a way of getting there. So, if you want to come to the
meeting pls let me know by at least 2:30 today. For those of you that
already emailed me saying you will be there don't worry about emailing me.
If by 2:30pm I don't get any other people to show I will reschedule this
meeting for either the end of this month or the first week in April. If this
is the case, I will take it upon myself to make most of the arrangements. As
far as location, food, and whatever it takes to get this Picnic Party to
happen. I don't really want to be the only one, because this is for everyone
here and would like input from others, but I will do it myself if I have to.
My other option is, to just forget this meeting all together and have the
first meeting be the first week in April. All the people that want to help
out just email me what you want to help with, food, drink, DJing, supplies,
equipment, offering rides, set-up, clean-up, and anything else you can think
of. I will make a list and put you on it for that. And then at the meeting
in the first week of April we will go over the list to make sure everyone
that said they would do something, will still be able to do it. We will see
if there is anything we missed and have someone cover it. The only major
concern is the sound system right now. This is what I plan on doing for this
Picnic Party. I'm going to bring my BBQ If needed, it is plenty big enough
to cook most everyones food together(same length as my truck bed) I'm going
to try to bring some ribs, hamburgers, hots dogs, and some stuff to make
veggie burgers and possibly some bbq veggies as well. I will bring some
potatoe salad and maybe some baked beans. I'm going to bring a portable sink
that has two basins in it to wash and rinse the dishes and what not. I will
also try and bring 1 or 2 other long tables to place things on, but not 100%
positive on that one, just 85% sure. Now of course I will NOT bring all this
food to feed hundreds of people. I'll try to bring as much as I can.
Possibly enough for 20-40 people, I'm not sure yet. This is what I need help
on. If we can get about 10-20 people to bring some kind of food for about 10
or more people as well as drinks then I think this will turn out pretty
good, it doesn't have to be anything fancy, something like some type of
salad, veggie stuff, meat stuff to BBQ, whatever, If you are willing to do
this, please let me know. Like I said before, I'll put it all on a list and
we can go over it when we have our meeting the first week in April. So let
me know what you all think. Let me this happen together and have a great
time doing it. Thanks.
 
Tim (knucklehead)

>Dear Geoff,
>
>My friend in Cincinnati is very new to the rave scene, and would like
>some recommendations of music to buy that would give him an idea of the
>broad spectrum of rave music styles.  The names of Cincinnati stores to
>buy them in would be appreciated also.  I know that this is a tall
>request, but hey, the rave community just grew by one today, and the
>industry will thrive thanks to his interest, and his disposable income
>that will now flow this way!  (Capitalism helps many good causes grow.)


moonshine has a _lot_ of good stuff... specifically:

*Psychotrance 1 (hardtrance, mixed)
*Concept in Dance 1 & 2 (goa)
*Drum&Bass collections (good jungle: esp. #3: the mixed-by-djHype version)
*United States of Ambience (1, 2, 3)

I've heard a lot of complaints that this label is too "commercial" or
whatever, but I've gotten some of my best comp CDs through them. Oh yeah,

*Rising High Trance Injection
*Artificial Intelligence 1 & 2

and some non-compilation good stuff:

*ORB - live 93
*Aphex Twin - classics
*Shamen - Axis Mutatis
*the Prodigy - music for the jilted generation
*FSOL - lifeforms

I have never been to Cincinnati, so I can't recommend any stores.

-m.

helped with our data base on where dj's are from...you'll be happy to 
know that from a list of over 600 dj's we didn't have cities for the list 
was down to 159...

we again need cities for.
As I have stated in the past our database is currently in the work 
process and hopefully, the first batch will be ready to be pressed into CD
Rom at the conclusion of the summer.

locations, dates, prices, dj's spun, lighting, sound and optics 
companies, production companies, telephone numbers and any e-mail 
addresses we may have...

Message-Id: <v02130508ad6d61fab0f4@[128.32.91.94]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 13 Mar 1996 22:06:00 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Heartfelt Plea for an Open Forum
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I'm disturbed by this trend toward self-censorship on our list.  If you
feel it's prudent to guard your privacy, use a pseudonym, or refer to
things obliquely.   But this thread raises a couple of issues for me:

1) "Raving and drugs have nothing to do with each other"
        In my last post "Harmonious Experience" I explored how, for me, a
fundamental part of the rave experience is collective mind alteration -
specifically, a group ecstasy experience.  The beautiful open and loving
mindset, the releasing of fucked-up mental baggage, is *INTEGRAL* to
creating the positivity of our subculture.  Raving and ecstasy are married,
happily.  No, they are not one, but they are complementary, for me.  I
don't want anyone else defining "raving" for *me*, and I would very much
like the right to share my definition to hear if others feel the same way.

2) Self- and group-censorship
        I am very upset at the counseling of many to avoid drugtalk on this
list (insert big unhappy face here).  I logged on here less than a week ago
in high hopes of finding a network of enlightened, beautiful people so that
we could openly share all of our thoughts and experiences on *every* aspect
of the scene.  I found the people, and now you're saying we have to limit
ourselves to "safe" topics!  Why not go to some random AOL chatroom if we
cannot discuss what we have in common as SFRavers?
        There is no-one monitoring this list.  Governmental bureaucracy is
completely overburdened and slow - the expenditure in time, money and
organization to have thousands of observors for the thousands of websites
on a system that they can't even figure out how to regulate (thank
God)....It's completely unfeasible.
        Yes, we may be researched in the future.  Hence, protect yourself
with anonymous accounts if you do indeed plan to run for President (in
which case, what are you doing raving?  There are many witnesses then to
*actual* activity!!  Many people have seen you having too good of a time!).


In the meantime, this is a heartfelt plea to PLEASE let this remain an open
forum for all of us to talk of any rave-related issue/experience.

P.S.  I thought we were creating alternative community.  WHY then are we
replicating the paranoia, closed-mindedness, and distance from each other
of the worst of mainstream culture??



Love is the Answer
Whatever the Question

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 13 Mar 1996 22:04:48 -0800 (PST)
From: 'David' M. Perlman <dump@u.washington.edu>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NON-RAVE net/extraterrestrial humor

I usually try to avoid posting random crap to the list, but I thought 
someone might find this as funny as I did....


>Has it occurred to anyone yet that the reason we haven't gotten any
>replies from Out There may be the same as the reason we don't often
>bother flaming AOLers?
>
>  "Oh, _goody_, Yendor---here's another one.  Let's see, it says
>   [*** --> MAKE FRIENDS FAST !!! <-- ***] on the front panel; how
>   _original_.  Two nudes on the plaque, scanned in at low res.
>   What do you want to bet they didn't get permission from the
>   copyright holder?  Hmm...address in pulsar distances, but they
>   mangled the Reply-To: line; I don't think `Sol III' is a fully 
>   qualified domain at all.  You would think all these spammers
>   out in Sirius sector would know about the anonymous reposter
>   at Fomalhaut by now, anyway...."
>
>  "Well, do we forward it to their sysop?"
>
>  "What's the point?  Look at the header; it's some dinky yellow
>   G2 dwarf.  The sector is lousy with them---if we have Her shut 
>   it down, they'll find another star before She even has time to
>   clean out the logfiles and reboot."
>
>  "But look at this bandwidth-hogging crap---this audio disk must 
>   have a couple of hundred incompatible languages on it.  I don't 
>   think this one is even the same _species_; it sounds more like a 
>   whale to me."
>
>  "Well, if they've got whales on-site, maybe they'll ask some
>   questions and eventually get a clue.  In the meantime, I can't
>   be bothered; I've got a whole globular cluster to upgrade to
>   4.0.2 this eon.  Besides, in the long run it only encourages
>   them.  The sort of pathetic race who starts these chain
>   letters craves any kind of attention at all."

jim

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA03492; Thu, 14 Mar 1996 02:17:43 -0800

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Devil's advocate #2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

quaker@netcom.com wrote:
>> > ps  I have never said, nor will I ever say anything in this newsgroup
>> > that will cause me to go to jail.
>>
>> Ouch, that statement scares me.  What happened to the First Amendment?
 [...]
>I mean, free speech is one thing, and the First Amendment certainly
>does protect your right to broadcast where you hide your stash...

These concerns about discussing illegal activity have nothing to do with
First Amendment rights.  An admission of criminal activity is not criminal
speech, but it may, without touching in any way on First Amendment issues,
be used as evidence in a legal proceeding.  It's just a fact like a
photograph, witness testimony, or a fingerprint.

That said, I think concerns about open discussion here are overblown.  The
associations between Internet mail messages and real-world individuals are
so tenuous (forgery is trivial, accounts may be used by multiple people,
transport errors may produce inaccurate attributions, intentional or
accidental misuse of accounts by unauthorized persons is common, etc.) that
any lawyer smart enough to make it to the courthouse on time would croak a
case based on them in about five minutes.  Messages under your name may
still, of course, affect your reputation in the eyes of the reading public.

anarch@scruznet.com

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear all,

I very much enjoyed Nancy's post describing her experience with 
you-know-what at Harmony.  Her eager prose refreshed an otherwise dull 
day in the life of this stressed-out graduate student.

I love to read about people's experiences with one of the most miraculous 
pharmaceutical inventions- ecstacy.  

If Nancy has the guts to tell all about her experiences, then more power 
to her.  I enjoyed reading her post and feel it was one of the most vivid 
accounts of an E trip that I've read in a long time.

It brought to mind the thought that people who have never tried the drug, 
or for various reasons never will, often read with great interest what 
other people say about their experiences with ecstacy.  Personal accounts 
such as Nancy's are often the only way that people can find out about the 
state of mind this drug creates.  

I only wish the law of the land would loosen up a bit so that upstanding 
citizens such as ourselves wouldn't have to sneak around like bandits in 
order to listen to music we love- outdoors and all night!!! and indulge 
in one of the sweetest pleasures our technology has created.

Best wishes,

Ann

Nancy: 
>         There is no-one monitoring this list. 

Around a year or so ago, there was an article in a local (but fairly
major) newspaper about this list, about the things discussed here, and 
about some of the people who post here.  Full names were used, without 
permission.  A journalist from the gaurdian has made his presence known 
here, as well as the father of a raver who died from ecstasy-related 
complications.  During a recent rave bust, a cop was overheard
bragging about recieving the sfraves calender.

>  - the expenditure in time, money and
> organization to have thousands of observors for the thousands of websites
> on a system that they can't even figure out how to regulate (thank
> God)....It's completely unfeasible.

Ever use a search engine?

> In the meantime, this is a heartfelt plea to PLEASE let this remain an open
> forum for all of us to talk of any rave-related issue/experience.

With freedom should come responsibility.  Would you argue in favor of
posting the locations of all underground parties (e.g. FMRs) here?
Party organizers tend to not favor this, and the community here has
respected that.

> P.S.  I thought we were creating alternative community.  WHY then are we
> replicating the paranoia, closed-mindedness, and distance from each other
> of the worst of mainstream culture??

Because we do not exist in isolation from the worst of mainstream
culture.  But I don't think we need to be too paranoid, because there 
hasn't been a lot of useful information about illegal activities posted
here.  And let's face it, raves are probably viewed as more a nuisance
than a major crime problem.  How much do the cops really care about a
bunch of (mostly) white kids making a lot of noise and getting stoned?
But still, flies are attracted to shit, so I think it is irresponsible
to post stuff like "I went to the "Love Xcretion" party and scored
some killer e."

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

hi everybody,

i have found this discussion to be very informative and interesting.  as
usual, the people on this list have shared their thoughts and feelings on 
a subject that affects our scene in a intelligent and though provoking way.

i honor all of your feelings on the subject.  lee, i liked this last post 
from you.  nancy, i loved your harmonious post and i'm happy i had a 
chance to read it.  i have mixed feelings about the whole issue.  it does 
remind me, tho, of a concept of "we are all connected."  and i think, if 
we all got to know each other in a more personal way we would be more 
aware of the fact that what may affect one of us affects us as a whole.

having said that, be true to yourself and stay on your path whatever that 
may be.

yours in peaceful anarchy,

bren



On Thu, 14 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Nancy: 
> >         There is no-one monitoring this list. 
> 
> Around a year or so ago, there was an article in a local (but fairly
> major) newspaper about this list, about the things discussed here, and 
> about some of the people who post here.  Full names were used, without 
> permission.  A journalist from the gaurdian has made his presence known 
> here, as well as the father of a raver who died from ecstasy-related 
> complications.  During a recent rave bust, a cop was overheard
> bragging about recieving the sfraves calender.
> 
> >  - the expenditure in time, money and
> > organization to have thousands of observors for the thousands of websites
> > on a system that they can't even figure out how to regulate (thank
> > God)....It's completely unfeasible.
> 
> Ever use a search engine?
> 
> > In the meantime, this is a heartfelt plea to PLEASE let this remain an open
> > forum for all of us to talk of any rave-related issue/experience.
> 
> With freedom should come responsibility.  Would you argue in favor of
> posting the locations of all underground parties (e.g. FMRs) here?
> Party organizers tend to not favor this, and the community here has
> respected that.
> 
> > P.S.  I thought we were creating alternative community.  WHY then are we
> > replicating the paranoia, closed-mindedness, and distance from each other
> > of the worst of mainstream culture??
> 
> Because we do not exist in isolation from the worst of mainstream
> culture.  But I don't think we need to be too paranoid, because there 
> hasn't been a lot of useful information about illegal activities posted
> here.  And let's face it, raves are probably viewed as more a nuisance
> than a major crime problem.  How much do the cops really care about a
> bunch of (mostly) white kids making a lot of noise and getting stoned?
> But still, flies are attracted to shit, so I think it is irresponsible
> to post stuff like "I went to the "Love Xcretion" party and scored
> some killer e."

Date: Thu, 14 Mar 1996 09:47:59 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Re: Heartfelt Plea for an Open Forum
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 10:06 PM 3/13/96, Nancy wrote:
>I'm disturbed by this trend toward self-censorship on our list.  If you
>feel it's prudent to guard your privacy, use a pseudonym, or refer to
>things obliquely.   But this thread raises a couple of issues for me:


This thread began when someone asked if they would "be making a faux pas by
taking acid at a rave."  She said that she had seen a lot of messages about
people dropping E at parties, but not acid.  So, of course, someone posted
"If you've been to raves in the SF area, then I'm surprised if you haven't
seen acid all over the place."

People, here's my plee:  USE FUCKING DISCRETION!  That's not saying, don't
talk about drugs, or the wonderful experiences we have with them.  As
Anthrax said, I too thought Nancy's post was very nice, poetic.  I have no
problem with that.  My stance is when we make enormously blatent comments
about the amount, size, quantity, proliferation, or inevitability of drugs
at parties.  And you know why!?

Because it is my dream as well, to one day have the law of the land
loosened up a bit "so that upstanding citizens such as ourselves wouldn't
have to sneak around like bandits in order to listen to music we love-
outdoors and all night!!!"

In making a case for ourselves, our archives may come into play.  Every
post MAY be a testament of our society.  Every person's words may be poured
over by our own children.  *OUR* children.  Show them the power of a good
thing, but let's try to avoid what the freaks did in the late 60s, and that
was come out touting the wonderful powers of acid, only to be eaten alive
by the media.  [Please, don't pick that bit apart, I don't want to be
responsible for that thread.  :^)]

I don't know if anyone knows how our email can be used, or searched in the
future; we know it can be searched pretty efficiently already.  I do know
that every email you send will inverably get stored on multiple servers and
that will get backed up on tapes, and those tapes will probably never go
away barring fire and brimstone.

I want to furthur [sic] our acceptance into the mainstream as much as you.
And I also want this group to be an open forum, free of censorship and
regulation, but I will continue to make an effort to let you guys know when
we are shooting our feet.  And without those, we can't dance.  :^)

Think about the impact of your posts on the group as a whole.  I just got
this as I was typing:  "Nancy's words ring so true, people!  Any of us
should be able to speak our minds and offer our perspectives without being
mistaken as representatives of the whole group..."  But you can't.  Don't
you see.  You can't!  Do you think that people (i.e., journalists, cops,
parents) who view this email will be able to pick you out as one who
doesn't necessarily represent the group?!  No!  They can't and if they ever
tried to make a case as us being a bunch of neo-hippies, who do drugs and
have nothing to offer society, then they won't want to.

Vision is an extremely valuable quality.  Vision, along with discretion is
not paranoia; it is making intelligent decisions about what you say and do,
and when you say and do them.

If I were to offer advice to the youth today, I'd say: Have vision and use
discretion.  And I'm saying the same thing to everyone on this list.
Envision raves as a part of mainstream society (if that's what we want),
and use discretion when discussion what might be percieved as negative
aspects of our community.

I promise you I will be part of the vanguard in our fight to garner the
respect we deserve as a positive force in society.  I will shout above all
in my attempts to be heard that we have so much to offer.  Together we will
take the music to the people, or at least to their children!  ;^)

Peace!

Tony

OK, so people are sounding like they think that they're right and everyone
else is wrong.  If we can at least agree that there's something right in
all the posts in this thread, we'll be able to piece together a stance that
we can all take comfortably.  So, what I get out of all this is: as long as
we're selective in the way we say something, we can talk about whatever we
want.
Are we to presume that we all own this list, and all call the shots?  Not
me!  If we can't reach a consensus, then it's time to appeal to the owners
of this list for a judgment call, IMHO.

Make love (in every way), not war :-)

- E

On Wed, 13 Mar 1996, Nancy wrote:

> 
> I'm disturbed by this trend toward self-censorship on our list.  If you
> feel it's prudent to guard your privacy, use a pseudonym, or refer to
> things obliquely.   But this thread raises a couple of issues for me:
> 
> 1) "Raving and drugs have nothing to do with each other"
>         In my last post "Harmonious Experience" I explored how, for me, a
> fundamental part of the rave experience is collective mind alteration -
> specifically, a group ecstasy experience.  The beautiful open and loving
> mindset, the releasing of fucked-up mental baggage, is *INTEGRAL* to
> creating the positivity of our subculture.  Raving and ecstasy are married,
> happily.  No, they are not one, but they are complementary, for me.  I
> don't want anyone else defining "raving" for *me*, and I would very much
> like the right to share my definition to hear if others feel the same way.
> 
> 2) Self- and group-censorship
>         I am very upset at the counseling of many to avoid drugtalk on this
> list (insert big unhappy face here).  I logged on here less than a week ago
> in high hopes of finding a network of enlightened, beautiful people so that
> we could openly share all of our thoughts and experiences on *every* aspect
> of the scene.  I found the people, and now you're saying we have to limit
> ourselves to "safe" topics!  Why not go to some random AOL chatroom if we
> cannot discuss what we have in common as SFRavers?
>         There is no-one monitoring this list.  Governmental bureaucracy is
> completely overburdened and slow - the expenditure in time, money and
> organization to have thousands of observors for the thousands of websites
> on a system that they can't even figure out how to regulate (thank
> God)....It's completely unfeasible.
>         Yes, we may be researched in the future.  Hence, protect yourself
> with anonymous accounts if you do indeed plan to run for President (in
> which case, what are you doing raving?  There are many witnesses then to
> *actual* activity!!  Many people have seen you having too good of a time!).
> 
> 
> In the meantime, this is a heartfelt plea to PLEASE let this remain an open
> forum for all of us to talk of any rave-related issue/experience.
> 
> P.S.  I thought we were creating alternative community.  WHY then are we
> replicating the paranoia, closed-mindedness, and distance from each other
> of the worst of mainstream culture??
> 
> 
> 
> Love is the Answer
> Whatever the Question
> 
> 
> 


               ("Nothing so gentle as true strength"
                "Nothing so strong as gentleness")
Ran @ Dionysus Dreams            /

                            =*=/

Sorry for the delay - there seem to be some network problems tonight.
If you read this in time, tonight's party is a good cause with a great
lineup - it's a benefit for our brother "A" Abbas Rezaei who has been 
fighting cancer for one year without medical insurance. It's his wish 
that all the profits from this party go to Cancer Research at UCSF.
Send me mail if you want an address to send a card to. 

Some rumors have cast a little doubt on Autechre's appearance tomorrow
night, but check the number or the venue to make sure.  Basics is
a great alternative on Saturday.

                               Radio/TV Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. [27]KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on
       [28]KUSF 90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise [29]KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. [30]flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, [31]KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday afternoon - [32]"Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs
       from SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. [33]KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. [34]KFJC 89.7
       - Los Altos Hills

                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, [35]send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   [36]majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to [37]majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   [38][39][40]
   
   
    [41]Derek Chung - [42]dhchung@hyperreal.com

           anymore, does it?  A friend of mine and I wanted to check it out
           this last Tuesday, and we didn't even go in.  The music that was
           coming out was anything but "house and cyber-trance".  It was a
           a live 80's rock band, and not very good rock at that.  So what's
           the scoop?

Something fascinating has occurred to me regarding the rave scene, and I
was wondering if anyone else experiences this:
I'm quite certain that, for the most part, not a single hour of the day
goes by without sexual thoughts crossing my mind.  So it's perplexing to me
that, when I'm at a party, and there are wall-to-wall beautiful, friendly,
sexy people, not a single sexual thought crosses my mind!  Can anyone
relate?  Any thoughts on why this might be?

Celebrating my strangeness,

- E

>>From ne-raves-approval@facteur.std.com Thu Mar 14 01:12:11 1996
>Date: Thu, 14 Mar 1996 00:40:28 -0500 (EST)
>From: lederjaso@urvax.urich.edu
>Subject: |NER| police on the internet is not a new thing...
>To: ne-raves@world.std.com
>Cc: dc raves <dcraves@american.edu>
>Mime-Version: 1.0
>Sender: ne-raves-approval@world.std.com
>Precedence: bulk
>Reply-To: lederjaso@urvax.urich.edu
>
>
>just to let you know, any monitoring of the assorted rave lists has been
>happening for at least a year-and-a-half by now; if you thought that we
>were safe in our little e-mails, then i have a story for you...
>
>back in summer, 1994, i threw a small outlaw party in new jersey by the
>name of "forward". some of you might remember this, as it was a pretty
>fun party once everything got settled down. the original location was
>busted early on by the police (apparently, a pissed-off parent called the
>infoline, got the directions, and called the cops on us), but the party
>rolled on once we got to the second spot.
>
>anyway, about two weeks after forward, i was called in by the police for
>questioning. right away, i got hit with $200 in fines for having an
>unauthorized, uninsured party. that was pretty simple. but then the
>officers pulled out a sheet of paPER and gave it to me.
>
>"what is this?" they asked.
>
>what they had was directions to the party, printed from a post on
>se-raves. apparently, the police were very busy the night of forward,
>pulling over cars that were driving to the original site. apparently,
>quite a few of those cars had drugs in them - in some cases very *large
>amounts* of drugs. and with that, they found posts printed from the rave
>lists.
>
>cops are not fools; they can put 2 and 2 together to make 4 as well as
>anyone. and though i tried to downplay the importance of the lists in the
>whole forward affair (there was absolutly no solid link between the
>lists and whatever illegals they found), it didn't really make a whole
>lot of difference.
>
>long story short: details of the lists were faxed up and down the east
>coast as a possible link to drug usage. i'm almost certain that we have
>been under some form of monitoring ever since - it's the most logical
>conclusion to be made from the circumstances.
>
>i'm not telling anyone what to do (or not to do), but i want to let you
>all know about what happened back in summer '94...
>
>lets all be careful out there!
>
>
>jason/method one
