I haven't had any sexual thoughts since July!  Except for the last few 
weeks that I have been seeing someone new, so it is quite a nice change 
of pace for me. Higher states of consciousness don't really involve 
feelings of sexuality.  It involves the higher chakras such as the heart 
and mind (I'm sure Diane T. could elaborate better about this.) That is 
when you notice the beauty in all people in nonsexual way.  But the 
sexual part is nice, too, in the appropriate environment! ;)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar 15 10:42:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA00520; Fri, 15 Mar 1996 10:42:02 -0800

Date: Fri, 15 Mar 1996 10:36:34 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Does this happen to you?
To: "Eric P. Peterson" <epaul@Synopsys.COM>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v0213051ead6f54ed44a3@[146.225.72.168]>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9603150926.B12889-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I can totally relate.  I am at my most asexual at raves, which is very 
funny.  For me it is the state of being I get to when I listen to the 
music and dance my heart out.  It is a sense of sharing with others.  
Sexuality can often be selfish (don't flame me for that:) in an instant 
gratification type of way.  At raves, I frequently find myself very 
sensual or sense oriented.  I enjoy being with people and sharing whether 
it be a hug or a kiss, whether it be a man or a woman.  Fixating on sex or 
sexual relations often creates weird tensions.  Instead I concentrate on 
individuals and personalities and the music and emotions and thoughts and 
on and on.  As I've said millions of times, the lack of sexual tension is 
very freeing for all involved, and is one of the reasons I was attracted 
to raves myself.  Frequently we are unknowingly forced to objectify people 
when we see them in a sexual way.  When we free ourselves from that, we 
allow the objectification to disappear and we can see the person as just 
a fellow human being.  

Please, don't get me wrong, sex ain't a bad thing :)  But, I 
find that sexual objectification is quite negative.  Sex is a very 
natural thing.  I don't understand why we have such hang-ups about it.  A 
lot is social conditioning and religious conditioning, we being a 
nation with a protestant history and all.  My friend, who is also on this 
list, always chides me about how I judge a party.  If I don't get hit on 
(by this I mean sexual objectification) then I think the vibe was great.  
When I start to get hit on in a negative manner, it somewhat distracts 
from the vibe for me.  I feel the ones who have objectified me and 
invaded my space (and I speak from only MY point of view), are not 
letting themselves go of societal and personal pressures.  They don't 
contribute to the vibe in a positive way.  (this is all gender neutral as 
it goes both ways between men and women or even members of the same sex)

I also want to add that being physically attracted to another human being 
is a wonderful thing and can be very complimentary, but only when it is 
heart-felt.  Objectifying them for your own selfish sexual reasons is  
very negative, and something that personally bothers me.   
Human beings can be attractive for a number of reasons, and not only 
because society says you should look one way. I find the most attractive 
people in the world are those that are confident and love themselves.  
You can tell these people when you see them, but they are few and far 
between in my experience.  I wouldn't necessarily consider myself that, 
but at times I think I do achieve it.  But, that is probably one of the 
lessons life has to teach me.  

Raving has treated me so wonderful.  I've shared so much with many 
people, and a lot has been because I opened myself up to people of both 
genders in a non-sexual way.  It allowed me to truly see what a 
friendship could be about.   I am reminded about the half naked woman at 
the sunset boat party.  It was wonderful that she felt free enough in 
that environment to do as she pleased.  I didn't see anyone reacting at 
all.  Both my SO and I commented on how lovely she was and what she must 
be feeling.  It challenged the assumptions I had made about everyday life 
and the feelings about sex I had grown up with.  I was taught that the 
body is something to hide, at least certain parts, because they are "dirty"!  
Just imagine if someone had done the same thing at a bar or other public 
event.  S/he would have been thrown out and been an object of many 
peoples' attention.

Those are my feelings on the topic.  I hope I have been clear enough and 
not offended anyone because that was not my intention!!! :)

luv n sex,
kc


kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*

Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id KAA09515 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 15 Mar 1996 10:48:13 -0800
Date: Fri, 15 Mar 1996 10:48:13 -0800
Message-Id: <199603151848.KAA09515@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Kids in the work place...
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Someone just brought their 2 year old into work.  He had his toy truck with 
him. Short little man with a flat top hair cut, cool jeans and denim jacket, 
and tiny little high-tops.  Quite the stylin' chap.  Big brown curious eyes. 
 Well of course everyone stops what they're doing and comes out of their 
cubicles to see.

At first he was glued to mamma's leg, but then as people asked him the 
standard questions, "How old are you?", "Is that a truck?", "Do you have a 
401k plan yet?", he began to brighten up.  And it's kind of surprising how 
many people, stark, cool, professional people, have toys somewhere in their 
cubes.  There were Elmo dolls, Koosh balls, squishy tension relieving toys.  
The IT director even had crayons... <?>... hm....  Anyway, I'm not sure who 
had more fun, the kid or the people whose workday he'd interrupted.

Then it was time to leave.  Everyone took their toys back to their cubicles, 
tucking them back into a corner of the desk, or up on a shelf next to some 
manuals, or into some drawer.  And everyone went back to work.

But it felt different.  It was a good morning.

S

On Mar 7,  1:26pm, Sean Nomura wrote:
>
> Also, look inside of the men's room at most (or all) of the raves that you
> may have attended. I've seen as many as 5 females at once in the men's
> room... while there were guys in there trying to relieve themselves. And I
> noticed that not one male in there felt embarassed, violated, or even cared
> less. If anything, they actually seemed to enjoy their presence.

	i doubt this is always true.  i think it's pretty damned rude
	for one gender to invade another genders bathroom.  not that
	it bugs me personally - i had coed bathrooms in college.  but
	i do think that it bothers some people.  it would certainly
	bother more females than males... though perhaps not.  after
	all, wommin aer not expected to stand aginst the wall and hang
	their dinger out to pee.

> Take a glance as you walk by the female's restroom and there won't be so
> much as a single male in there.... and most likely not one male will enter
> there throughout the entire night. Should a male decide to enter... well,
> I've never seen this happen in a rave-female restoom so I can only
> speculate... I do, however, think that it would not be positive event
> overall.

	i agree, but i want to say that i do not think this is a
	problem that the girls have.  if a bathroom is established
	as gender specific, it should be respected.  plumbing emergencies
	aside, of course.

> Now honestly... I think that these double standards do exist for a reason.
> First of all, women don't 'get off' on seeing male flesh the way that men
> are turned on when they see female flesh. *stop grinning ladies*. When it
> comes to arousal, women are conventional ovens and men are microwaves. If
> you were to walk a group young men through a female's locker room while
> they were showering, you'd most likely end up with a group of torridly
> horny young men upon exit.

	i would be real careful with your generalizations.  there is an
	amazing variety of sexualaties out there.  what you say may be
	true for many, but don't be so blanketing in your statements.

	i know wommin who have sexual appetites and attitudes that you
	would probably associate with men.  quite a few, in fact.  i
	know men that have attitudes you would see as being very female.
	girls get insanely horny, just like boys.  many fantasize about
	faceless strangers, or in objectifying manners - read nancy
	friday's person by person research on male and female sexual
	fantasies, i think you will be suprised (and it has the caveat
	of being rather good, true erotica).

> Change the gender in this case, and I hardly think you'd get the same
> reaction out of the females... if anything, they'd probably start laughing
> as they walked away.

	again, watch your generalizations, even though they are somewhat
	based on your perceptions of gender-reality... well whatever.
	wommin are the ones who are most objectified in our society,
	therefore your locker room theories hold some water - but i
	think you are reinforcing the undersides of the very objectification
	by making these distinctions... make sense?  smash it *all*,
	not just the oppression.

	there to flame you in person.  have all the years i have been so
	conscious to lift that seat been wasted?

	it is not MEN (which imples me as well) who pee on the seat.
	it is inconsiderate assholes who do.  i am offering you a
	clue right now, please step forward and take it.

If guys (and some women, I must say) could pay a
> little more attention to hitting the mark, this would surely work -- I mean,
at
> lots of parties, there are only single restrooms, and we all use 'em -

	you are getting better.

	one thing i have adopted is that i *always* put *both* seats down
	(if there are two available - seat and lid).  this has two uses:
	1: someone who is going to pee standing up who has to lift the
	lid will probably lift the seat at the same time
	2: people who complain about the seat not being left down for them
	(many of whom also complain that it is not clean and tidy) will have
	to lift the lid anyway.  it's kind of vengeful, but in the end
	it sort of smooths out balances.  that way *everyone* has to
	move the damn thing.

> And the modesty issue should be minimal really, there's not much to see when
> guys are using a urinal --

	and there's not much to see when a girl is on the can.  hey, i
	think i am a total stranger to you.  mind if i hang out in your
	bathroom next time you pee?  *inside* the stall.  nice comfy stall.

	and, if on the off chance you really *don't* care about that (lots
	of people don't) then i should remind you that regardless of how
	silly it is, people who want a little privacy to do their number
	are entitled to it.

> Anyway ...  we surely are straying into interesting territory here, aren't
we?

	oh yeah.  we certainly are.  gender politics is such a fun topic.

Hello Rocky...

Thank you for your response. Your post, I felt, was unthreatening as far as
igniting an ego battle and showed no signs of a condescending attitude. I,
therefore, feel open to respond.

To begin, I'd just like to say that whatever rebuttles you may have had...
you're probably correct about each and every one of them. What I offered
WERE, in fact, generalizations, and I realized that when I made the post in
the first place. With any generalization, you will always be able to find
exceptions... but that's why they're generalizations. And, if you read
closesly, you will find that I've made no comments concerning these issues
stating absolution whatsoever... had I done that... THEN the statements I
made would have been incorrect because I knew that the exceptions existed
when I made the post.

Should you refer either to this post, or any post I've written in the past,
you will see that I have always taken great care to provide extreme
clarity. And, as far as THIS particular subject is concerned, you will find
that I have been extremely careful about what I define as 'general'(gray)
and as 'absolute' (black and white).

The psychological references that I made came from three females.... the
first, Dr. Barbara DeAngelis, the second, author Brenda Venus, and the
third, believe it or not, actress Sharon Stone. I would hope that the
generalizations that I've stated DO hold some water, because I respect and
admire these women a great deal.

I offered this information hoping that it would make someone smile. It
looks like I really DO have a lot to learn about human nature because I've
failed miserably. And believe, me, I say that with a smile....

Again...

Thanks for your tact.

Peace.

Sean

> board?

	about 60db.

> are they calibrated to handle levels differently?

	yes.

> could I plug a CD player into the phono line if I have to?

	do not do this.

	handbook/ is a great bible.  also, there is a textbook called

	and beyond.

From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Funny thing...i.e., drug talk
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So, not to belabor the point, but a funny thing got relayed to me last night....

You see, I work at a very cool, small software company in Berkeley called
Xinet.  To make matters better, I work with a friend, who also raves, named
Rhea.  (You may have seen posts from her.)  Anyway, I guess Rhea came into
work one day and Doug, a cool guy, but not a raver, had on a huge
shit-eatin'-grin.  Doug greeted Rhea enthusiastically, and Rhea, a little
betwixed asked what was up.  Apparently, Doug had done a search on Xinet
using AltaVista.  (URL:  http://www.altavista.digital.com/cgi-bin/query)
What came back were, amongst other things, posts Rhea and I had made to
SFRaves.  He had fun reading them all.  No damage done, but...

Your boss, your future boss, your mom, dad, aunts, uncles, friends, lovers,
strangers, et al, can search for things that you write on the net, and get
them very easily.

I say this only as an example of how insecure the electronic environment
really is.

That's it!

Tony

Hello,

I have been appointed as somewhat of a Northern Califonia Dune Represenative.

I am here to answer all your questions about the upcoming Dune event in
a vast Southern Califonia desert next weekend, Saterday, March 24th.

I was lucky enough to attend the first Dune that occured last fall.  Words
don't do this event justice.  You will not be disappointed.  This event
is fully permitted, and the utmost care is being taken so that this
event will not harm the natural lands we will be using.

The promoters are wonderful people who are well-known and well-respected
"socal-raves@ucsd.edu" peopole.  The event is free if you haul out 1 bag
of trash.  Otherwise, it is five dollars.

Please check out the Dune homepage.  Even if you don't plan on going,
the page is still very interesting.

http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen/

Burning man?  Full Moon Rave?  Moontribe?  I honestly beleive
Dune is better than them all.

If you have any questions, please feel free to e-mail me.

Dune... the spice flows.... again.

-troy

E.

MDMA is an empathogin.  "Empathogins seem to encourage physical contact, 
yet make that contact less specifically sexual. The need to achieve 
orgasm is decresed, but the pleasurable feelings associated with body 
contact are increased....Another common theme found in accounts of MDMA 
and sexuality stress that it demands authenticity in love-making unlike 
cocaine, alcohol,and Quaaludes which have a reputation as seduction 
drugs..."

Reprinted here without permission from the authors,J. Buffman,Pharm.D., 
and C. Moser, Ph.D.,in their paper "MDMA and Human Sexual Function,"
pub. 1985 Journal of Psychoactive Drugs, and in _Ectasy: The MDMA Story_ 
by Bruce Eisner.

Hope this little bit helps explain your situation.  

Diana 



Eric P. Peterson wrote:
> 
> Something fascinating has occurred to me regarding the rave scene, and I
> was wondering if anyone else experiences this:
> I'm quite certain that, for the most part, not a single hour of the day
> goes by without sexual thoughts crossing my mind.  So it's perplexing to me
> that, when I'm at a party, and there are wall-to-wall beautiful, friendly,
> sexy people, not a single sexual thought crosses my mind!  Can anyone
> relate?  Any thoughts on why this might be?

At 10:36 AM 3/15/96, KaySEE wrote:
>Raving has treated me so wonderful.  I've shared so much with many
>people, and a lot has been because I opened myself up to people of both
>genders in a non-sexual way.  It allowed me to truly see what a
>friendship could be about.   I am reminded about the half naked woman at
>the sunset boat party.  It was wonderful that she felt free enough in
>that environment to do as she pleased.  I didn't see anyone reacting at
>all.  Both my SO and I commented on how lovely she was and what she must
>be feeling.  It challenged the assumptions I had made about everyday life
>and the feelings about sex I had grown up with.  I was taught that the
>body is something to hide, at least certain parts, because they are "dirty"!
>Just imagine if someone had done the same thing at a bar or other public
>event.  S/he would have been thrown out and been an object of many
>peoples' attention.

        I had an experience similar to this at new years at the cybertrance
party, i was just sitting there in the sand with this person i'd met and
she was saying 'whoa' and looking off to my right and this woman had just
jumped out of the hot tub and was smiling and dancing and i actually almost
blushed :o
        Then i though, wait, what's there to blush about? She's happy,
noone is ogling her like in a circus, she's just at the state that we were
all in before (metaphorically) eve took that bite from the apple. (ps, i
think that myth is bs and is used too often in a sexist way but it's just a
metaphor here). Just like when we were all born, completely nekkid and
happy! Nothing wrong with that :) It was at that point that i remembered
what is so cool about this scene; people can be human and the social
conventions that create abberant sexual behaviours can (hopefully) be left
at the door.
        peace,
                brad

OBrandomtechno: does anyone know of a cure for goa? i seem to be addicted.
:) Methadone perhaps? A cold shower?

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi!
  This is Ran from Dionysus Dreams. I've made a few postings and thought 
that maybe I could introduce myself.

  I first attended a rave called Mr. Floopy's Fractal Funhouse as part of 
the sound crew (we had a eight channel sound system on the main floor). I 
really did not "get it" that night, although the 'enhancements' handed 
out by Ollie Wisdom and crew made the event a tripsters delight ;) .
  My next one was Craig Larson's Lighthouse Two, Halloween night at 
Jose's Cantina in Santa Cruz, where I did the sound design for that event 
(I was NOT responsible for the band that played however). I got it that 
night; the warm internal glow coincided with watching a beautiful dancer 
moving in just the best way possible-- I had to dance and before I knew 
it I had entered an ecstatic dance trance modality of conciousness =) =) !
  Well I was hooked!! My next step was to go to some more shows (Shamen 
at the Warfield being a key event!!). Eventually I realised that I had 
the desire to be an ambient designer/performer. I started at the 2nd Mr. 
Rogers Neighborhood (at the Santa Cruz Civic Auditorium) and just Knew 
that this was perfect for me. Not only do I play ambience, I also mixed 
in a lot of live material (processed voice, percussion, unusual 
instruments) and usually set up slide projectors, lighting effects and 
sculptures. Essientially my focus is as a multi-media, interactive artist 
with the desired goal of assisting group transcendence. I think I've even 
come close :).

  My educational prusuits are aligned with the purposes that I bring to 
the ambient room. Hence the notice on the essay I promised a few days 
back. I should have that posted really soon-- I'll let ya all know when.


Ran
                                  (Peace)
                                     /
                                 =*=/
                                  ~

PS-- by the way, I've been told that Ran is the Japanese word for chaos
PPS-- Dionysus is the god of (among other things) ecstasy and agony

At 4:11 PM 3/16/96, ecto wrote:
Just like when we were all born, completely nekkid and
>happy! Nothing wrong with that :) It was at that point that i remembered
>what is so cool about this scene; people can be human and the social
>conventions that create abberant sexual behaviours can (hopefully) be left
>at the door.
        Just took another look at this and thought i'd mention that
'abberant' to me is not based on any 'objective' model of what is sexually
normal or not. I suppose i shoulda said "IMHO". I think being socially
deviant in some areas is more 'normal' than anything, but i was referring
more to the social method of reification of women (as in billboards and
advertisements that use women as 'things' and not as 'people') and the
subsequent ways that we all view and treat each other. I was meaning that
those kind of mindsets would be left at the door, but it's tough to explain
all that with these &&%&*# little words we use :(
        Hope i've clarified something somewhere! Does anyone really care?
Did i take too many poststructuralist linguistics courses? i think so!
        peace,
                brad

Subject: evolution review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I didn't have a lot of fun at this one. I showed up kind of late
(1 am) and there was still a line. It took me about 20 mintues to get
in. At the door three beefy security guards were patting down everyone.

When I got in, I noticed the good lights and some other psychedelic
decorations. But not too many people were smiling, and quite a few
were obviously drunk. They were serving alchohol and this seemed
to have an effect on the vibe.

I got down to the dance floor and starting having some fun. The group
around the turntables seemed more ravalicious. One woman gave me a
smiley faced sticker, which I put on my cheek. Most of the people
around me seemed faintly amused by this, especially the big tough
guys. After about an hour, one of the guys who had been dancing near
me decided to grab his stuff, that he had placed in the corner near
mine. It turned out to be covered in this brown goo, some combination
of beer and who knows what else. As he brushed past me and some other
people nearby, we all got smeared with the vile smelling stuff. Ugh.
I picked up my jacket and it had some of the same gunk on it. I went
to the bathroom to clean up. 

Afterwards I sat down and watched for awhile and realized that no one
around me was smiling or friendly. It was 3AM and I was getting tired,
so I decided to go.


On the plus side, the music was great. The lighting was fun, but a
little too bright for my taste. And the venue was not overcrowded
or too hot. But the vibe was missing, at least for me. None of
my friends were therere, and this probably had something to do
with it. Eric, I looked for you but didn't seee you. Did you 
make it? Waht did you think?

Peace and Love,
Jim

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 17 19:13:44 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA25742; Sun, 17 Mar 1996 19:13:44 -0800

Received: from tgrigsby.vip.best.com (tgrigsby.vip.best.com [205.149.169.221]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id TAA12961 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 17 Mar 1996 19:09:05 -0800
Date: Sun, 17 Mar 1996 19:09:05 -0800

X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Nikita & Tahoe
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, sit back and get ready to be jealous as I relate to you the events of 
the weekend...

Friday.  This day started good, got *really* bad, and by the time I was due 
to leave to begin my evening festivities, I was in a seriously ^&*( mood.  
First stop: Nikita with Doc Martin.

DAMN!  What else can I say?  1015 had that funky camouflage netting across 
the ceiling and a blue/green laser that made the lighting even better than 
usual.  Too damn much smoke IMHO, but that was the only down side.  Finally 
met Doc Martin -- a *very* cool guy.  Doc started spinning around 12:30 and 
the boy was all the way ON.  Saw many friends from other raves -- wassup 
Keith, Patricia, Erin (and many others).  Danced my ass off, (pretty much) 
forgot all about the negativity from earlier in the day.  I just can't tell 
you how bad I needed that...  

Left about 3am for....TAHOE!

Saturday morning.  Rolled in around 7:30am.  SteveO and the gang are all out 
cold.  Must have been good :)  We threw down on the floor and started to try 
to get a few winks, but just then everyone started getting up... oh well.  
Walked around and met so many FANTASTIC people!  Unfortunately, my energy 
was spent so I and my crew took one of the then-vacant rooms and crashed for 
a couple of hours.

Saturday afternoon.  Everyone had left to go snowboarding.  I've never 
snowboarded or skied, but I decided to try my luck with a sled.  YEEHAW!  
Got completely out of control once and scared the living daylights outta 
myself, but whatta gas!  Took some great pictures.  About the time I was 
winded and done with sledding, Matt Lanier and Becca showed up.  We kicked 
back on a huge boulder, snow all around us, ski slopes behind us, and a 
spectacular view of Lake Tahoe below us, and talked and laughed like we were 
old friends.  It was great.

Saturday night.  The sun sank slowly across the water from us, providing 
some breath-taking photo opportunities.  Then the festivities began.  We had 
a communal dinner in the middle of the living room floor with ambient 
playing in the background.  Lot's a veggies, huomos, guacamoli (sp?), and 
some serious pasta provided by Matt and SteveO.  WOW!  After dinner, the 
toys came out.  It was so great to play like a bunch of little kids.  

Then the live performance began, courtesy of Eric and Rick Riffle.  Folks, 
the best musical advice I can give you is, Get The Tape!  Oh man, everyone 
was just enthralled.  I could have listened to and watched these guys all 
night.  Absolutely beautiful ambient sounds.

Then Moonpup came on with such a weird and fantastic mix of different tunes. 
 I really think the theme from "2001: A Space Odyssey" was the perfect way 
to start off his set!  ;)  That boy had me jumping all over the place!  And 
what a GREAT guy to party with!  Down to earth and intelligent, but what a 
big kid!  People, I can't tell you how sorry I am that he's going to the 
UK...  <sniffle>...

Somehow along the way I became...DA DA DAAAAA!  Camera Man!  I was snapping 
shots left and right -- a set of which will go to SteveO and will hopefully 
be posted to Hyperreal (?) -- and folks started handing me their cameras and 
asking me to take pictures!  I wore my poor shutter finger out, but there 
are going to be some great shots going around!

Later I became...DA DA DAAAAAA!  Lotion Man!  Yes, disguised as 
mild-mannered SDream, when the call for lubrication goes out, I 
become...Lotion Man!  We had a chill room thang going on downstairs with 
lots of hand/back/foot rubs.  Becca was the queen for the night, getting 
both feet, both hands, and her back rubbed all at once!  Daaaaaaang.....

Then there was the hot tub.  Soooo relaxing, but that's not the part that 
will stick in my mind forever.  At some point, Matt started humming, just a 
single monotone note.  Soon the rest of us picked it up (Becca: "What's that 
noise?").  But then Trish began to sing to it, there in the darkness lit 
only by candles, the stars over the lake behind her through the glass door.  
High, lilting, notes without words, crystal clear and beautiful.  We were 
all amazed at what happened during those few moments.  And when the wonder 
was too much, we clapped and marveled at her voice.  Wow.

Then it was back upstairs for more dancing!  Then back for more backrubs!  
More people DJ'ed, each one twisting the darkness of the night into the 
light of love!  Dancing!  Hugs! Rubs!  Dancing! Hugs! Rubs!  

Geez, it just doesn't get any better than this...

Beyond that, the evening was a blur.  Saw Alex, KC, Will, Mark, dang, so 
many people I can't recall all the names...

And people, it was beautiful.

Sunday morning.  Ouch.  Could someone ask that the sun be turned down just a 
tad?  Geez.  Time to clean up.  That went fairly smoothly, although somehow 
there were a couple spots of body paint in the carpet... oops...  Most of  
it was all over the Twister game pad.  And as we moved the furniture back, 
we kept finding the Day-Glo super balls we'd been throwing at each other the 
night before.  We kept joking about, wouldn't it be nice if we got snowed 
in?  Oh darn!  That would just be awful, wouldn't it?  Stuck here partying 
for a couple more nights?  <big phat grins!>  Once we were done getting 
everything out of the hosue, we got a dozen shots of the whole group and 
then loudly and roundly applauded SteveO for an absolutely unforgettable 
weekend!  That man gets my Raver of the Month award!  It just couldn't have 
been any better.  That was, bar none, the best event I've ever been to.

Then it was off to the Wildflower Cafe for breakfast.  No one wanted to part 
company just yet.  We sat, ate, joked a little, smiled a lot, and zoned out 
quite a bit.  Zero energy, just happy warm glows.  If you're ever there, 
they make very good Swedish pancakes with strawberries.  Num, num...

And then it was time to go.  This sucked.  Nuff said.

4 hours later and we're back home.  This also sucketh mightily, although the 
hamstas were happy to see me.  They'd been raving while I was gone, but one 
of their turntables broke and they had to make do with one t-table and a 
tiny little CD player.  What's more, DJ Log Cat didn't play -- he's on tour 
in Singapore.  I fixed the damage, and they're already planning an ambient 
session for tonight.  Now to finish the laundry...

But wait!  There's MORE!  Or there will be, this coming Sunday at Sunset... 
hehe...

S

Message-Id: <v02130501ad72aa361e60@[128.32.91.98]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 17 Mar 1996 22:26:50 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Weekend Recap
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thursday - last midterm.  Party week-end!!

Thursday: 1015, for Tribute to a Friend.  Did anyone else go to this??
Incredible line-up: about 10 awesome dj's, and Astral Matrix, Freaky Chakra
and DubTribe live.  Wow.

BUT this amazing event was indeed held in a CLUB.  I arrived bedecked in
sparkles and bearing special gifts for the ravers I was sure to find.  I
searched and searched for a day-glo outfit, ponytails, glitter, anything,
but instead found only shirts-and-ties and dresses-and-heels.  Oh no, the
bridge-and-tunnel crowd!!  Not a whistle, not a handclap to be had.
ATMOSPHERE is what makes the party.  I danced in the main room with my
friends to Jeno's set, getting a little happier.  The sound and lights
there kick ass - better than any warehouse.  The injustice...

Later on the drunken suburbanites found their way home.  I entered the
second room to find DubTribe playing live, and this went off!  I danced in
front of the percussionists in total joy as Sunshine rapped his theme...you
know, "There's so much love in this world!!"  It seemed half the people
there knew the anthem, and we chanted along, arms in the air, cheering.
This was the highlight of the evening for me!

Then a bizarre thing happened.  I got really sick (which never happens) and
left the oppressiveness of the club to go lie in the gutter.  There I met
many people who stopped to take care of me.  In a haze I heard one of them
ask me where my friends were, telling me the club had closed 20 minutes
before!!  A new friend who had sat with me all night led me to the EndUp,
home of the tweakers, where we stayed until we bummed a ride to Berkeley.
In retrospect I see it was really dangerous to lie on a street in the
middle of the night in San Francisco, completely incapacitated, but so many
people took care of me!  Getting me water, looking for my friends, sitting
with me...  There are good people out there.

Friday: Big party at my big student-housing co-op.  A DJ from "In da
Mix!"/KMEL spinning very mainstream house.  Helicopter lights, fog machine,
dancing on top of tables.  Fun, but not deep.

Saturday: private warehouse/loft party.  60 people, dj's (Mars closing out
the night), orange slices.  This one was cool because I actually got to
*talk* to people as we kicked back in bedrooms.  A house party rave!  Nice,
except for some reason everyone was floored and couldn't get up for the rad
deep trance.  I pathetically bobbed my head, wishing for energy.

Sunday: e-mail raving.
Monday: see you all at Mad! :)

I heard Basics went off.  It's been sooooo long (a month!) since I
experienced the full-on, all-night, total rave.  Any suggestions for this
week-end??  Any thoughts about Aborigine?  When is Chrysalis??!  And I want
to meet all of you!

BTW, I apologize for the length of my posts.  I hope no-one is pissed.  I
just can't stop myself!

Love to everyone!! Nancy

Precedence: bulk

 
WOW !!! 
 
I'm just waking up (6am monday), and I can't get rid of some of the tunes
dancing around in my head.......and I can't forget the incredible time had
by all at this wonderful and positive event. 
 
I arrived on Fri nite about 10pm or so, and we (melissa & chrishna) were
some of the first to arrive, so we picked out a bedroom and made camp....I
set the sound system up and was pleased that every one had brought there
stuff (speakers, amps , etc.....)           slowly until late in the early
morning others arrived and we all began to jaccuzzi together.....Fri nite
was a mellow affair with everyone wanting to save there energy levels for
the next LONG day ahead........ 
 
A lot of people were going snow boarding in the am so most of us went to
bed. 
Rick riffle and I played music with each other and talked music and shared
some quality time together, we turned each other on to music that the other
had, and enjoyed trainspotting all night long. (it's a beautiful thing to
share musical Knowledge with another DJ, it needs to happen MORE
OFTEN.....I'm sick of DJ's who hide there labels or protect there music,
like it belongs to them only, as far as I'm concerned the music belongs to
all of us. I buy music to share with others and if a DJ wants to know what
track I'm playing, I am honored that he likes my choice and am glad to
relay that info to them). 
 
While my first reaction was that there may have been an inordinate amount
of guys verses gals, it became apparent to me (through-out the weekend)
that ALL the men had massive amounts of female energy, and all the women
had an equal amount of masculine energy, and the result was a party full of
PEOPLE who were in touch with their masculine and femanine sides. It was
truly inspiring. 
 
As we all woke up Sat morning, the Snow people went boarding and the
remainder of us went for a very long walk.......we had a brilliant time
talking and getting to know each other..........we eventualy found a
dicusting little restaurant and had some discusting food, (we were too
tired to find another spot). we eventualy headed back UP the hill and with
the exception of Becca (tribal power woman) we pooped out half way up the
hill..........Becca showed up with a car to take us all home again.........

 
Some of us went shopping for food while some of us cleaned out the murky
depths of the jaccuzzi........we refilled it and re heated
it..............we mostly crashed out and woke around 6pm.........All the
snowboarders were back and we began to make the communal dinner.........an
excellent job by all.......pasta a plenty.........fried goobies, and hot
fresh garlic bread.......plus more........ 
 
we then cleaned up and began to play coosh ball wars, we were like a bunch
of kids....... 
lots of fun........meanwhile we were treated to an excellent ambient (LIVE)
set by Rick and Eric.  There was a gathering of people getting into the
Jaccuzzi and we relaxed for a while. 
 
We went back upstairs and I began to play my first set (if you don't count
Fri nite) 
I  began with the  2001 space oddessy theme, and had an incredible
response, and the rest of my set was rocking (if I don't mind saying so
myself). It's parties like this that bring out the best in me and I feel so
relaxed, that even my mistakes sound good....... 
 
I was followed by a wonderful suprise in DJ Jason D (from Santa Cruz) he
was incredible.......his music was inspiring and very mature.......great
great set...........beautifully mixed and fresh........ 
 
At this time there was a E-athon going on in one of the bedrooms and I
joined in, it was a wonderful touchy feely session with lots of sensualness
(and no sexuality I might add).......we all decided the jaccuzzi was in
order....so off we went to flood the jaccuzzi floor.........we all ran
outside and flirted with the idea of making naked snow angels, but we were
all too chicken, (not to mention too cold)...... 
 
Some of the snow boarders went to bed while others stayed up as Jason D and
I began to mix back and forth........I eventually played again getting into
deep acid tones..... 
 
unfortunately one of us got sick and spent the next couple of hours in the
bathroom, but she had many visits from friends, and was taken care of with
love and respect..... 
 
Mark played some excellent ambient and  beats,  and so did Steve.......I
played again  
tripping out the crowd with my trip hop acid phsycodelic shit.......groovy
man......... 
It felt good to sub-concsiouly get inside the heads of those crashed out on
the floor.... 
 
I eventualy quit at about 6am or so.........no one left to party with boo
hoo hoo...(*bunch of lightweights).........so I began to take my only
pictures...........of every one crashed out.........it was fun to sneak
around getting scrunched up sleepy heads on film........ 
 
...........we all woke up around 8:30 am and helped to clean up the mess we
had made 
 
and by 10 am we were all on our way either snow boarding or coming
home........ 
 
I would like to add that there were 100% responsible people there and we
left the house in great condition.......smokers smoked outside, and we
never had a complaint from anyone......... 
 
This was truly one of the greatest events I have ever been involved with,
and cudos goes out to SteveO for a magnificent job of organizing. 
 
a good time was had by all......and I especially enjoyed all the new
friends I made (and in particular one special new friend).......... 
 
.........It's events like this that make me sad that I'm going away in May
to the U.K. 
I will miss you all, but if all goes well I'll be back for Burning Man in
Sept, with all my new records I get in europe.....can't wait.........I love
you all and thank you..... 
 
                                    moonpup    415-337-MOON (6666) 
 
P.S. -Rick pointed out that not once did he go to the bathroom and find pee
on the seat 
well done boys. lots and lots and lots of respect..........

From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@mailhost.hooked.net>

WOW !!! 
 
I'm just waking up (6am monday), and I can't get rid of some of the tunes
dancing around in my head.......and I can't forget the incredible time had
by all at this wonderful and positive event. 
 
I arrived on Fri nite about 10pm or so, and we (melissa & chrishna) were
some of the first to arrive, so we picked out a bedroom and made camp....I
set the sound system up and was pleased that every one had brought there
stuff (speakers, amps , etc.....)           slowly until late in the early
morning others arrived and we all began to jaccuzzi together.....Fri nite
was a mellow affair with everyone wanting to save there energy levels for
the next LONG day ahead........ 
 
A lot of people were going snow boarding in the am so most of us went to
bed. 
Rick riffle and I played music with each other and talked music and shared
some quality time together, we turned each other on to music that the other
had, and enjoyed trainspotting all night long. (it's a beautiful thing to
share musical Knowledge with another DJ, it needs to happen MORE
OFTEN.....I'm sick of DJ's who hide there labels or protect there music,
like it belongs to them only, as far as I'm concerned the music belongs to
all of us. I buy music to share with others and if a DJ wants to know what
track I'm playing, I am honored that he likes my choice and am glad to
relay that info to them). 
 
While my first reaction was that there may have been an inordinate amount
of guys verses gals, it became apparent to me (through-out the weekend)
that ALL the men had massive amounts of female energy, and all the women
had an equal amount of masculine energy, and the result was a party full of
PEOPLE who were in touch with their masculine and femanine sides. It was
truly inspiring. 
 
As we all woke up Sat morning, the Snow people went boarding and the
remainder of us went for a very long walk.......we had a brilliant time
talking and getting to know each other..........we eventualy found a
dicusting little restaurant and had some discusting food, (we were too
tired to find another spot). we eventualy headed back UP the hill and with
the exception of Becca (tribal power woman) we pooped out half way up the
hill..........Becca showed up with a car to take us all home again.........

 
Some of us went shopping for food while some of us cleaned out the murky
depths of the jaccuzzi........we refilled it and re heated
it..............we mostly crashed out and woke around 6pm.........All the
snowboarders were back and we began to make the communal dinner.........an
excellent job by all.......pasta a plenty.........fried goobies, and hot
fresh garlic bread.......plus more........ 
 
we then cleaned up and began to play coosh ball wars, we were like a bunch
of kids....... 
lots of fun........meanwhile we were treated to an excellent ambient (LIVE)
set by Rick and Eric.  There was a gathering of people getting into the
Jaccuzzi and we relaxed for a while. 
 
We went back upstairs and I began to play my first set (if you don't count
Fri nite) 
I  began with the  2001 space oddessy theme, and had an incredible
response, and the rest of my set was rocking (if I don't mind saying so
myself). It's parties like this that bring out the best in me and I feel so
relaxed, that even my mistakes sound good....... 
 
I was followed by a wonderful suprise in DJ Jason D (from Santa Cruz) he
was incredible.......his music was inspiring and very mature.......great
great set...........beautifully mixed and fresh........ 
 
At this time there was a E-athon going on in one of the bedrooms and I
joined in, it was a wonderful touchy feely session with lots of sensualness
(and no sexuality I might add).......we all decided the jaccuzzi was in
order....so off we went to flood the jaccuzzi floor.........we all ran
outside and flirted with the idea of making naked snow angels, but we were
all too chicken, (not to mention too cold)...... 
 
Some of the snow boarders went to bed while others stayed up as Jason D and
I began to mix back and forth........I eventually played again getting into
deep acid tones..... 
 
unfortunately one of us got sick and spent the next couple of hours in the
bathroom, but she had many visits from friends, and was taken care of with
love and respect..... 
 
Mark played some excellent ambient and  beats,  and so did Steve.......I
played again  
tripping out the crowd with my trip hop acid phsycodelic shit.......groovy
man......... 
It felt good to sub-concsiouly get inside the heads of those crashed out on
the floor.... 
 
I eventualy quit at about 6am or so.........no one left to party with boo
hoo hoo...(*bunch of lightweights).........so I began to take my only
pictures...........of every one crashed out.........it was fun to sneak
around getting scrunched up sleepy heads on film........ 
 
...........we all woke up around 8:30 am and helped to clean up the mess we
had made 
 
and by 10 am we were all on our way either snow boarding or coming
home........ 
 
I would like to add that there were 100% responsible people there and we
left the house in great condition.......smokers smoked outside, and we
never had a complaint from anyone......... 
 
This was truly one of the greatest events I have ever been involved with,
and cudos goes out to SteveO for a magnificent job of organizing. 
 
a good time was had by all......and I especially enjoyed all the new
friends I made (and in particular one special new friend).......... 
 
.........It's events like this that make me sad that I'm going away in May
to the U.K. 
I will miss you all, but if all goes well I'll be back for Burning Man in
Sept, with all my new records I get in europe.....can't wait.........I love
you all and thank you..... 
 
                                    moonpup    415-337-MOON (6666) 
 
P.S. -Rick pointed out that not once did he go to the bathroom and find pee
on the seat 
well done boys. lots and lots and lots of respect..........

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 07:58:31 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id HAA00561; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 07:58:31 -0800
Received: from vanbc.wimsey.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id HAA00545; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 07:58:24 -0800
Received: by vanbc.wimsey.com 
	(Smail-3.1.29.1 #32) id m0tyhJk-0007GCC; Mon, 18 Mar 96 07:57 PST
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 07:57:56 -0800 (PST)
From: Karen Hardie <eidrah@vanbc.wimsey.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: (long) The Evening That Almost Wasn't
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.960318075205.24348D-100000@vanbc.wimsey.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is actually a message i posted to nw-raves, but even though it has 
not much to do with the sf community i had such a blast i wanted to share 
it with you guys ........ :)

========================= 
Well!  i'm sure some of you will be amazed to hear that i did NOT attend 
the Dose party as planned.  Things transpired against us in getting 
there, and you know what? 

 I HAD MORE FUN NOT GOING THAN I WOULD HAVE HAD IF I'D BEEN THERE!!!!!

Myself and two friends went to a fundraiser which was being put on by 
Wondertree, an alternative elementary school in Vancouver.  We had  no 
real idea of what to expect ....

Picture if you will:  you're getting far up there on some nice e (if you 
do e) and walk into a warehouse filled with insane Alice in Wonderland 
drawings with small children in fairy costumes running around playing 
with bubbles and sparkles while amazingly good trip hop rumbles through 
the UV-lit atmosphere.  As the evening progressed the music got better 
and better, we got higher and higher, and the crowd got stranger and 
stranger.  There was a seventeen-year-old boy who was on NOTHING, walking 
around wearing nothing but a fur loincloth, his glasses, and some 
fluorescent poster paint.....

Tippy A Go Go played live and they were UNBELIEVEABLE.  get their cds if 
you can, they are to be treasured!

After they left, DJ Shine (aka Jesse) came on and was laying down some 
SWEEEET house.  By this time there were abut one hundred fifty people, 
from 15 to 57 years of age, most of whom were candyflipping.  Keep in 
mind that this was a FUNDRAISER FOR A SCHOOL!!!!!

we and around three hundred insanely happy vibing people went strong until 
5 am and it's now 5:30 pm and i have not been to bed yet.  i simply had to
share my unbelievable story of the evening that nearly just didn't happen!!!

very tired
k


p.s. i should stress that the people who organized the fundraiser 
(Wondertree) had NO IDEA what was going to happen and were definitely NOT
responsible for any substances that showed up.  By the time they realized 
what was going on, things were sailing merrily along, and rather than 
send a bunch of squirrely people out into the streets of Vancouver at 
4am, they decided to let things happen and only escort out the more 
obvious troublemakers.....



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 09:28:20 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA10563; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:28:20 -0800
Received: from chronos.synopsys.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id JAA10545; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:28:08 -0800
Received: from atropos.synopsys.com by chronos.synopsys.com with SMTP id AA02100
  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:27:31 -0800
Received: from clotho.synopsys.com (clotho.synopsys.com [146.225.100.24])
  by atropos.synopsys.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with ESMTP id JAA02080
  for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:27:30 -0800
Received: from [146.225.72.168] (epaul-mac.synopsys.com [146.225.72.168])
  by clotho.synopsys.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id JAA16458
  for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:27:27 -0800
X-Sender: epaul@macpo-1
Message-Id: <v02130506ad73499e2cac@[146.225.72.168]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:31:09 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Devolution
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        First of all, let me say that James Ausman completely hit the mark.
I got to Evolution around 10:30pm, and saw a guy and gal with whom I had
breakfast at Denny's after Vision, so I thought, "Cool, I know some people
here already."  Good sign?  Not really.  First thing in the door, a
security guy took my water from me :(  I got in and immediately noticed the
bar (boooo!).  Someone asked if I knew anyone looking for E.  I checked the
place out.  Too small and too bright for my taste.  In the bathroom,
someone asked if I was looking for E.  Someone in the crowd asked if I knew
where he could find any A (!).  As if I'd know.
        There were a few dancers out on the floor, and as the crowd grew,
the floor filled up.  Mostly seemed like more hardcore and/or
old-schoolers.  There was a bit of a gangsta vibe.  I wasn't inspired to
dance.  The dj (either DLX or Karizma) spun mostly heavy bass beats, fast,
with little else added.  Not exciting to me.  I met up with Jonathan, and
we hung together for a while.  We waited for the vibe but it didn't happen.
A few in the crowd made eye contact, and one gal even smiled, but there
was just too much of a clubby atmosphere, too many good-time drunkards.  We
decided that things weren't going to improve, and didn't bother indulging
in anything Exciting, so we bailed around 1am or 1:30am (not sure which,
Jonathan?).
        It was the first time since Tribal Funk at Santa Cruz that I
attended a party I didn't enjoy.  Lesson learned.  I wish I could have
heard the rest of the djs, since the lineup was impressive, but I couldn't
endure the scene (or lack thereof).  I would have gone to Basics the next
night, but I didn't call the vm till 10:20pm, and knew that tix would be
gone by the time I found the map point.
        Now I'm hoping the time will fly until the next party I go to, so I
can find that happy, silly, childlike, tripped-out vibe I crave...

I'm feeling much better now!

- E

Eric P. Peterson
Financial Assistant
N&CS Materials Management
Synopsys Inc.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 09:36:24 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA11632; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:36:24 -0800
Received: from pandora.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA11566; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:36:15 -0800
Received: from  by pandora.ucdavis.edu (8.6.13/UCD3.5.1)
	id JAA20625; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:36:03 -0800
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 09:36:03 -0800
Message-Id: <199603181736.JAA20625@pandora.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Tahoe fun (long)
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Best party I've ever been to.  Very sorry to all those who could not make
it.  Very happy for all those who did.  The small crowd vibe really made it
family oriented.  Everyone was really nice and very respectful.  Marcus, the
39 year old snowboarder/raver....you inspire me.  We snowboarded with this
guy all day Saturday on practically no sleep....partied hard all night with
even less sleep...and the man goes snowboarding again on Sunday.  By Sunday,
my 25 year old body had no more energy left to give.  I was inpressed.  

Had a great time meeting Moonpup.  We spun ambient and slow beat stuff till
about 4:00am on Friday and that was really fun.  I got some of my first real
experience trying to beat match with a cd mixer.  Fun stuff.  Not too
terribly difficult, just different from records.  He's a great guy, sorry to
know he's leaving so soon.

Moonpup....please enlighten me as to what "trainspotting" means.

Snowboarded all day Saturday with a tribe of people.  This was the first
tribe riding I've done in years, and there were more of us this time than
I've ever rode with.  Thanks to all.  One of the best days of the year so
far....as far as snowboarding goes.

Came back that evening and began to prepare my portion of dinner for the
family.  I made vegetable pakora (east indian stuff).  And to my delight, it
all got eaten.  I was suprised cuz I made tones of the stuff.....or they
hated it and through it out the window....I guess I can never be sure.  All
of the food was wonderful...and all that extra spagetti was sooooo great
Sunday morning.  

I didn't really get to participate in the communal dinner eating portion cuz
my friend Eric and I were setting up the equipment for our live set.  Just
about the time were were ready to go, everyone had finished eating and
cleaned thier plate ......such responsible ravers.  We played a totally
unrehersed set for about 1.5 hrs and had a blast.  It was really fun and we
got a good response from the family.  

Moonpup went on after me and I headed for the spa to soak.  Somewhere
between the spa and the end of moonpups set I lost my mind...and probably
won't find all the piecies for years to come......or was it that I found my
mind....it's all relative....

Jason D played and an incredible set although I wasn't much up for dancing
at that point.  

Then Moonpup played again and eventually asked me if I wanted to play again,
but I declined because there were others that wanted to play....nor was I
really in the right state of mind to perform well.....ya know....so tired
from no sleep,  snowboarding, and the live performance ;)  

Marcus came on I think, then Steve from Bolinas.

Steve is super cool and we really bonded.  Thanks Steve.

I eventually passed out to the ambient tunes of moonpup again, who guided my
dreams.  Slept for an hour or so then got up in a total daze and began
cleaning and restoring order to the dismantled three story cabin.  The
cleaning ritual really brought me back to reality, and by 10:00 or so
everything was done.  

We found a full pint of coffee icecream in the freezer about 9:55 and dove
for the spoons to eat as much as possible.  I ended up with the leftovers
cuz I brought an ice chest.  I ate about half of it when i got home.

Stopped off at Donner lake to chill out by the water with my good friend
Eric.  I touched the water that at some time may have been snow I slipped
across on my board.  What a concept.

Thank you SteveO for generating the idea and taking the initiative to make
this experience happen for us.  It will not be soon forgoten.  

Thank you Moonpup for bringing your turntables, cd mixer and dj mixer.

Thank you Mark Camp for bringing the monitors and monitor amp. (also for the
tape you gave me of your live stuff)

Thank you Eric Degregario (my buddy from Sac, and musical companion) for
deciding at the last minute to attend the event and donating your speakers
and amp.  Without your attendance, the sound just wouldn't have been the same.  

Thanks Steve from Boninas for bringing your speakers although we had no
speaker wire to hook them up.

Thank you Multiverse for fixing it so all of the cabins surrounding ours
were empty all weekend and for never getting a noise complaint.

Thank you all that attended for all of your love and friendship.

This event will live on for quite some time.

Love,

Rick

hello all-

i, matthew david peter kyle lanier, do pronounce myself to be a different
person that i was when i drove up to tahoe on friday.  here's how:

1)never, in my right mind, would i get naked with someone other than a
significant other.  i found, this weekend, much to my delight, that that is
not true any more.  i love hot-tubs and the feeling of having nothing
between me and other people, as clothes tend to do.

2)never, in my right mind, would i have spent a weekend with people i didn't
know well yet.  that's not true anymore.  nuff said.

3)never would i do so many things that i know i can now do...thanks to the
love i felt up at tahoe this weekend.

thanks all!  love to all!  i love you all!!!


matt l.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 12:02:14 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA27001; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 12:02:14 -0800
Received: from ecf2.puc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA26992; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 12:02:09 -0800
Received: (from amdice@localhost) by ecf2.puc.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) id MAA25166; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 12:02:27 -0800
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 12:02:27 -0800 (PST)
From: Tinsau <amdice@puc.edu>
To: sfravers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Basics and new music(psych/goa variety)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960318113445.22399A-100000@ecf2.puc.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone! Just finished my final for the day and came to give my 
review of Basics. I have to heartily agree with Jondabomb and the other 
Austin, all the Basics were covered. At first with only 800 tickets I 
thought it might endup in a little crowded sweatbox, but this was definately not the case. 
Very good ventalation overall, easy to find location, and just a nice 
space. They should use this one more often if they can. 
I went with Crunchman and we got there at about 11. Very short line and 
we got right in. There was still plenty of open space then but it soon 
filled up more (never too crowded). People were moving all night with a 
nice vibe pouring out. Music covered the whole spectrum and 
it was all top notch. I danced til 5 then had to take frequent rests but 
it was wonderful even from a sitting position. It ended a little after 7 
with several funky records and fresh fruit, then I had to head home. I 
met Tom, Cami (sp), and Knucklehead, glad to have met you. 

Last week when I got the Basics tickets I also picked up a couple CD's at 
F-8.  Platypus Records vol. 2 and Distance to Goa 3.  If you like 
goa/psychedelic trance at all you will want to look for these. Platypus 
is a non mixed comp. and starts with Robert Miles 'Children' which is 
completely beautiful music, then plows right into the trance that will 
eat away large chunks of your brain. The tracks by Union Jack and 
Salamander alone make this worth buying. Completely wonderful, with weird 
sound effects and many lovely levels of sound. Distance to Goa is a Dou 
ble CD (one nonmixed the other mixed by DJ Xavier from Amsterdam). Both 
are full on psychodelic trips with mental music from start to finish. Man 
with No Name, Infinity Project, Technossomy, and Hallucinogen all are 
represented with excellent music.

  Austin                             
  Tinsau                    

            S.F. Born and Raved!

Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 12:19:22 -0800

X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Amateur Night Rookies vs. Ravers
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Y'know, just a little observation:  It seems to me that, on holidays with 
some amount of drinking attached to them, ravers have the worst time finding 
a party with a good vibe.  Even events that have been good in the past will 
suddenly have a certain percentage of folks that have a non-rave agenda and 
an unfriendly vibe.  I went to Nikita Friday night, and even though I found 
a lot of friendly faces, most likely drawn by Doc Martin's attendance, there 
was definitely a large suit contingent.  Fortunately the clubby set didn't 
affect the good time I was having... much...

Anyway, my point is, holidays like St. Paddy's or New Years or July 4th or 
[fill in any holiday associated with drinking too much] seem to draw out a 
crowd that is less into feeling good and being friendly, and more into the 
meat market thang, drinking until they puke, brawling, and feeling hungover 
the next day.  The vibe is zero to negative.

POSSIBLE SOLUTION:  I guess my move will be to look for small gatherings 
with a known raver element on national holidays.  And stay overnight -- and 
off the drunk-infested freeways.  The Tahoe trip that went off this weekend 
is a PERFECT example of this.  Just a safer way to go, y'know?

Peas,

S

sides.  Anyone else going to that show?

Mr. Jake

Dear F&F,

	I haven't had a chance to post or even read mail in a few days, 
but I just wanted to reassure you all that it's not because I'm in jail.  8)
	Actually I had a very full, intense, and interesting weekend 
taking a 45-hour intensive workshop called the Landmark Forum.
It's kind of like an EST course, I'm told, although I've never been 
exposed to EST and don't know anything about it.  There was no talk of G
od or religion or anything like that, but some of it gets pretty heavy as 
far as forcing you to reexamine your life and way of thinking, so if you 
aren't prepared to do this, I wouldn't recommend it.
	Anyway, my final evening is on Tuesday (tomorrow) from 7pm to 
1045pm.  We are allowed to bring family, friends, guests, anyone who would 
like to learn more about the program.
	Although I didn't agree with all aspects of the Forum, it did give me a 
whole lot of new insights into life, relationships, etc., and I think it 
was worth the rather pricey (for me) $290.  Some of the other people I 
took it with (there were about 90 enrollees all together) had a much more 
profound change take place for them, on the level of what some of us have 
gotten out of raves.
	I could talk a lot more about it, but I don't want to waste space 
here.  The Tuesday evening session is free -- if any of you are curious, 
I invite you to give me a call and I'll bring you as a guest. 
	The location is the corner of 5th & Howard, South of Market in S.F.

Peace, Luv & Grooviness,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Phone: (415) 270-7887 [page/voicemail] or (415) 626-3036 [home].

P.S. - I'm not getting any kind of incentive for signing people up for 
this or anything, it's just found it an interesting experience that 
others might like to sample.

Subject: E. P.: The Intro

        OK, here it is.  Please allow me to introduce myself.  My name is
Eric Paul Peterson.  I was born 11/8/95, in the L.A. area.  I've lived in
the South Bay since I was four, grew up and went to schools in Santa Clara,
graduated from Santa Clara High, and went to West Valley College for a
while.  I attend Saint Andrew's Episcopal Church, where I perform as part
of an acoustic guitar/bass/mandolin army on the first Sunday of each month
(playing music during the communion).  A very cool Protestant Christian
family of faith.
        I'm a mild sports fan, I'm not associated with any political party,
and I'm a very selective omnivore.  My main interests in music are:
progressive, artistic, or bluesy rock; some metal; some "alternative";
reggae; classical and such.  I play guitar, bass, mandolin, and
keyboard/piano.  I'm fluent in French, and know some German, Japanese,
Mandarin Chinese, Welsh, Spanish (learned on the streets like a proper
Californian), some Italian and Russian words, an eastern Indian greeting,
and can count to ten in Dutch (yeah, that'll come in handy!).
        Every summer, I am the archery director at a camp for
underprivileged children.  during the other 51 weeks of the year, I work as
a contractor for the high-tech companies, doing database mantenance,
accounting support, or customer service, wherever there's a need for my
skills on the Mac.  I play bass guitar, and sing backing vocals (and lead
on the one song I wrote) in my band, Sydney Page, a Bay Area band that's
been together since 1991, in various incarnations.  I also enjoy hiking the
hills, visiting the beach (and our Mother, the ocean), and spending time
with my friends and family, which are ever-growing, and which I consider to
be one and the same, since the unity of my immediate family dissolved
several years ago.  Last, and far from least, I immensely enjoy raves!
        My first rave was in September '94.  It was an E-ticket party,
hosted by Jeremiah.  I was introduced to the scene by my friend Jason.  He
asked me "Do you like to party?"  Yes.  "Do you like techno?"  I'm not
sure.  He then convinced me to go to the party.  I discovered that
wonderful white happiness there, and was overwhelmed (Crescent Moons)!  The
whole experience blew my mind: the intensity of the music, the crowd
response, those oh-so-tricky moves, and especially the people, who are
(almost) all so friendly and ready with smiles, handshakes, and the
ever-controversial hugs!  I was completely drawn in, and have since been to
such wonderful parties as Basics (not the last one), Organic, Friends and
Family, Harmony, Beautiful People, Tribal Funk (the one at the Cow Palace),
Begin Again ('95 kick-off), and others.  I don't get out to nearly enough
parties, but it feels much better when I've gone without for a few weeks.
Now I gotta figure out ways to incorporate the friends I make through
raving into the rest of my world.  I'd like that very much, as I love every
person, want to be the best kind of friend to all that I can be, and I just
plain dig all you beautiful people!
        Oh, yeah, I'm 5'10" tall, weigh 140 lbs., and have long, curly,
light brown hair and hazel eyes.  I'm usually clean-shaven, but now I'm
experimenting with a silly little goatee :)
        That's me in a nutshell.  Any questions?

Peaceloveunityrespect to all!

- E

 ------ From: Tony Rotundo, Thu, Mar 14, 1996 ------ 

At 10:06 PM 3/13/96, Nancy wrote:
>>I'm disturbed by this trend toward self-censorship on our list.  If you
>>feel it's prudent to guard your privacy, use a pseudonym, or refer to
>>things obliquely.   But this thread raises a couple of issues for me:


>This thread began when someone asked if they would "be making a faux pas by
>taking acid at a rave."  She said that she had seen a lot of messages about
>people dropping E at parties, but not acid.  So, of course, someone posted
>"If you've been to raves in the SF area, then I'm surprised if you haven't
>seen acid all over the place."

>People, here's my plee:  USE FUCKING DISCRETION!

>...Show them the power of a good thing, but let's try to avoid what the
freaks >did in the late 60s, and that was come out touting the wonderful
powers of >acid, only to be eaten alive by the media.

I would like to respond because I am that "other person" who made a statement
a little too blatant for some people. I agree that there are many people in
various forms of law enforcement reading this list. They have been reading
everything on the Internet for years now. They have also been listening to so
called "undergound" info lines for Raves and attending Raves for years now.
Nothing that is put on this list could ever be a news to them because they
have been seeing it firsthand and making their own judgements about illegal
activity. In the same way, people have been searching the net for years, ala
Kibo, and have been able to find out about people's posts for years. So, I
fully support the previous posts reminding us of the above, and to remind us
of alternatives if you don't want something you post to be attributed to you
if you worry about employers, police, family, pissed-off parents, etc. 

So, what we have are really two issues:
A. I don't want people to find out about my posts.
B. We don't want to tip the authorities off to what goes on in this list.

The first one we have taken care of: use an anonymous remailer.

The second point is a bit more thorny. How do we have an open forum of
discussion where we present the truth, and at the same time not let the
"wrong" group know what is going on. 

First, I would like to point out that there is very little talk of illegal
activities on this list. Raves are not inherently illegal, and not everyone
breaks the law when they go to one. So, I would doubt that there has been much
that would incriminate anyone from their postings on this list. I bet that
many of the "authorites" who read this list give up soon afterwords because
there is very little that they can get out of it. How long can a cop stand
virtual hugs?

When it comes to discussions about drugs, it becomes very much like
homosexuality. It is one of the biggest lifestyles that people still need to
be "in the closet" and not even talk about things that would make us appear to
look like a drug user, or that you even associate with them. So, like gays, it
is a personal decision about when to "come out" or how much you want to even
associate yourself with drug users. I won't attack anyone personally for their
own choices in this matter. But, this kind of self-censorship further
marginalizes people who have a legitemate right to speak the truth, in
addition to creating hysteria and misinformation.

On the other hand, I've made the decision not to be intimidated about who I
associate myself with. I have seen drug use; it exists; we cannot change that
fact. What will change other people's opinions is showing that there are real,
normal people that do drugs and have positive experiences. Showing how
fundamentally wrong the conventional ideas about drug use are will do more to
make the situation better than trying to crawl under a rock when someone
shines a light on us.

That doesn't mean that you should go ahead and describe drug transactions, or
your plans to rob a bank. I don't think anyone is stupid enough to do that;
that is the kind of discretion people should use. But to not talk about a
particular subject is pretty insidious, since you are now doing the job of the
police for them. They don't even need to lift a hand, and they have censored
you.

With that said, perhaps I will take back some of my previous assessment of
drug use. When I said acid was everywhere, that must be taken contextually.
When compared with someone wondering whether it is done at all, yes, it is
fairly prevalent. But, what relative percentages to the total attendance at
raves? That would probably be pretty small. Anyways, I will try to temper my
statements a bit more in the future.

But, I hope people use discretion about what they admit or who they name, not
what they see and know to be truth. 

Doug

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 16:31:31 1996

Received: from [128.32.160.183] (wmf59.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.183]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA30294 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 16:31:22 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130507ad73a7d8cf45@[128.32.160.183]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 16:30:13 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Appropriate RaveWear?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Anyone can and should wear whatever they are most comfortable in.
Acceptance, comfort, and freedom are some of the values of the scene that,
IMO, make us cherish it so much.  Why else would we spend hours daily on a
discussion list unless we reveled in how raving makes each one of us feel??
Exclusion and conformity have never in my mind been associated with
raving.

That said, I happen to LOVE the look!  I'm absolutely delighted when I see
someone with bright colors on, sparkles, blinky lights, stuffed animals and
a big smile.  What that means to me is that that person LOVES the scene.
They have embraced it wholeheartedly.  They have cared enough to become
another dazzling spectacle in the night's continual trip of swirling color.
And their cheerful return to babydom (pigtails, pacifiers, and primary
colors) means they understand one of the deepest aspects of rave and e: a
return to the innocent lovingness of childhood, before society twists us.
To be like a child, in the moment constantly, open, excited, pure heart.

They are like costumes for the ritual.   I do not venture out in full
regalia, but I know that the act of applying glitter to my face has become
ritualized for me - I  am immediately in anticipation, and feel naked
without it on.  I want to shine in the night, happiness sparkling on my
face.  My hair in braids keeps it out of my face.  My shiny lights become
toys.  My sneakers let me dance all night.

Rave is not homogenous.  There are trendy ravers, teenagers, technophiles,
rockers, Deadheads, and many others.  They are each individual and all
united in the communal experience.  Clothing is exterior, let's not have it
separate us.

Like I said in my earlier post, at 1015 I simply needed an easy signifier
(where were the laminates? :> ).  At school I'll sport my huge plastic
blinky ring, and strangers will nod and give me knowing smiles - we know
what it means.  Rave adornments sometimes allow us to identify and connect
with each other - isn't that what it's about?

Much Love,
   Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 17:53:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA10095; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 17:53:50 -0800

	id UAA18649; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 20:53:02 -0500
Date: 18 Mar 96 20:50:26 EST
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Appropriate RaveWear?
Message-ID: <960319015026_71165.755_GHL81-2@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Though the way I try to identify and connect with other ravers is through their
vibe (are they smiling? dancing? happy to be there? comfortable with the music?)
I have strong opinions on clothing as an avenue to personality expression....
 
As someone who loves to herself through clothing, HATS, jewelry, HATS, body
adornment (tattoos, pierces) and HATS - I always love to see people dress to
express themselves through their clothing when they go out -- (and note, that's
EXpress, not IMpress -- I personally don't care if other people like what I'm
wearing, I care about if I like it and it makes ME feel good)

And isn't raving (and life in general) about being who we are and being willing
to express it openly?

It doesn't matter what you or I wear..  it may be tie-die and jeans, and it may
be glam-rock-club-kid silver lame with 20" custom-made platform shoes -- but it
hopefully expresses which part of you you're feeling like that night!  It gives
people a first clue of who you are (along with a big smile, of course, without
which we're never really dressed).

I was in Phoenix this weekend and went to a big party in a cool old hotel
(Derrick May and Stacey Pullen rocked that house) and was SOOO happy to see so
many of the Phoenix kids (very young scene there, maybe they like to move here
when they're old enough) all dressed up!  Two beautiful sisters in shiny wigs
and silver fake eyelashes, wearing the biggest most glorious smiles...   Lots of
glitter and painted faces, lots of personality being expressed...   One amazing
pair of huge furry yellow pants (I want them!)...   and a huge purple feather
wig...

If you're someone who feels that what you're wearing isn't part of who you are,
I encourage you to try dressing up a little -- maybe just a different kind of
hat, or a pair of pants a little bigger, brighter, funkier than you usually wear
-- some sparkles on your eyes -- whatever it is, when you put it on, you should
feel a little like "this is too cool (or too weird, or too sexy, whatever), I
can't get away with this" -- then when you go out in it, some little part of who
you really are might get expressed.  Go for it!  Dressing up is fun!  See you
out there!

Leslie   ; )
