From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 18 18:36:10 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA13882; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 18:36:10 -0800
Received: from ix3.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA13843; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 18:35:45 -0800
Received: from  by ix3.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id SAA01498; Mon, 18 Mar 1996 18:35:05 -0800
Date: Mon, 18 Mar 1996 18:35:05 -0800
Message-Id: <199603190235.SAA01498@ix3.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Basics Review! (very long & blithery :) 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Woohoo!  Wotta humdinger!  Originally approached the idea of attending 
this party with a little trepidation, sorta unsure how it would go off, 
or if it would go off at all.  Sorta far to start off with (ok, ok, you 
SoBayers & sac people, I know I'm whining! :), didn't like the idea of 
driving to Hayward from Concord.  Wasn't sure of the dj line up, didn't 
know many of them.  Didn't expect to see anybody I knew there except 
maybe Wayne (& you all know how hard he can be to track down at a party! 
:P), cause the other people I expected to show sounded like they weren't 
going to after all.  But I thought a few days in advance that I would 
give it a try anyway.  During the day of the party, it seemed that things 
just couldn't go wrong!  Had travelled to Seattle & San Diego to visit 
friends & family (as many of you know), had just gotten in at something 
like 1:30 am early Saturday morning, so was relaxed & happy seeing people 
I loved & having the week off from work, so this helped set the mood for 
the day anyway.  Then I realize my friend from out of town is in town 
this weekend for his birthday, and I also realize that my bestest of 
friends Sam (some of you have met him! :) should also be in town cause 
the friend who is having a birthday is Sam's brother!  So I call their 
family's house to see if Sam is indeed in town, and sure enough he is.  
Then while talking to him, he puts me on hold for a sec, then comes back 
to tell me the whole family has invited me to go with them to this phat & 
phancy restaurant (excellent food & company!) for the big birthday dinner 
for Howard (Sam's brother), on them!  So we all end up going to this 
restaurant together, the family & several old friends.  So I'm sitting 
with numerous friends that I have known & loved for over a decade (Sam's 
family totally treats me like a family member) at a big table where we 
have a huge view of the Bay, San Francisco, the G.G. bridge, & the hills 
where we watch the sun make a spectacular departure while eating.  
Afterwards we go home & have cake & coffee & presents, & afterwards I 
hang out with Sam & my friend Joanie (whom I've known since 3rd grade!) & 
we just sit & talk & hang out, definite good quality time.  After a day 
like this, I just couldn't hold back a feeling of complete happiness and 
I just knew that going to basix would be the right thing to do, cause my 
whole day's vibe was so right on, and I couldn't lose!  Right, right, 
right!!  :D

So I get there, and in spite of my original fears of not seeing one 
person I knew, almost as soon as I walked in there I found a big ol' 
love-puddle of many of my friends (along with several people I had not 
yet but would soon incorporate into my group of friends!)  I hear "There 
you are! I was wondering when you were going to show!"  I run into 
another friend and he just gives me a nifty partee favor out of the blue. 
The music is rocking!  Everybody is so friendly!  And it was held, of all 
places, in the conference-type room of a bowling alley (what is it about 
bowling & raving?)  It never got too crowded, it never got too hot (& 
when it did get hot, the doorways were all open for you to get fresh 
air), the dance floor was never too packed, there was a chill area to sit 
in where you could hear the music plus there was a quiet little chill 
area in the far back where you couldn't hear the music if that's what you 
wanted, and it was just all there for me.  Part of what made it a little 
different from my usual rave is that for some reason, my whole group of 
friends I was with pretty much stuck together as a group for the duration 
of the rave, rather than how it is normally for me where we all wander 
around & occasionally run into each other as the party progresses.  Even 
when some of the people would go off & dance, they would come back to the 
group & the group retained its cohesiveness.  It was an awesome family 
group ExpEriEncE!  

I also just discovered something at Basics, or not so much discovered it 
as finally found a way to put into words what I've been experiencing.  I 
must admit I nowadays find myself doing things I would never have thought 
in my (foolish) past that I would do (much like how Matt Lanier described 
in his review of the Tahoe trip)  This doesn't necessarily refer to 
"sexual" things, simply things requiring a much more free state of mind 
than I once upon a time had.  When I found myself doing all those things 
that once upon a time I thought I wouldn't do, what I discovered was that 
it felt completely like coming home!  What I mean by that is that I feel 
like how we interact with people at a rave is how we were born, this 
behavior is completely natural in us, and it's almost instinctive to do 
it.  However, after we're born, society/parents/rules/etc are forced into 
our heads, we're taught how we "should act" because that's what society 
expects from us, and if we do these things anyway (sexual or whatever 
other type of "non-norm according to society" behavior, like I said, 
behavior that requires more freedom of thought & acceptance), society as 
a whole looks down on us & thinks we're "weird" or "deviant" or whatever 
word society uses to describe the way most people don't behave cause they 
think they're not supposed to.  After years & years of this conditioning, 
we easily fall prey to that way of thought, we're stuck with these 
bizarre ideas & thoughts of how we're *supposed* to act, and natural 
behavior like you see at raves is completely out of the question for many 
people.  But!!  Once you do realize that it's all good (with continued 
respect for others of course), you find yourself doing all these things 
as naturally as breathing, and I for one actually feel lighter & more 
buoyant (you C.P. people may know about that!) as the load of years of 
conditioning is lifted off of me (I may have described this feeling 
before), and I feel like I must have felt when I was born & the world was 
new!  Hence the feeling of coming home, of coming full circle back to 
where I should have been all along, & my family is there to share it with 
me!  God I feel like I've changed so much in six months!  Very nice to be 
experiencing it, & nice to be experiencing it with all of you!  :)

Ok, ok, I'm done rambling & blithering now!

Love,
Shawna

stickers, and bits of grass from our yards. =)

Joe

>> searched and searched for a day-glo outfit, ponytails, glitter, anything,
 
> Uuuummm...does everyone have to wear ponytails and glitter to fit in with 
> this crowd?  If so, guess I just better stay home!  What about jeans, Doc 
> Martins and a groovy shirt, is that not hip enough?


You can wear whatever the hell you feel like!  That's one thing I like about 
raves, you can dress as normally & boring as you want, or go all out & get 
dressed up in funky costumes & hats & stuff.  For me, I like to be both 
comfortable and also find some interesting way to entertain other people with 
the clothes I wear, not because I'm trying to impress them, but just because 
I enjoy doings that please other people & giving them something fun & nifty 
to look at is fun for me! (like shirts that do nifty things in the 
black-lite, etc) :)

Love,
Shawna

i COMPLETELY agree with your statements about clothing at raves - you 
should wear whatever you feel best in and no one else should judge you 
because of it.  For myself, I only wear full "regalia" to something i 
KNOW is going to be a wild evening, and i feel i'd like to have my outer 
appearance suit my inside mood of crazy happy bouncy fun.

I also love to check out other people's attire, as some of the things i 
see completely delight me (except the GODDAMN WHISTLES - boy sometimes 
I'd like to just ram em down their wearer's throats!) and I like to get 
tripped out on watching some of these incredibly creative folk obviously 
having as much fun as me.

Clothes don't make the person!

k

	[ On Fridays Nikkita & the holiday drunk-set ]

	While its true that an alcohol drenched crowd seldom does much
	for a party - I thought that Fridays 1015 was a welcome 	
	exception. Yes, the crowd was mixed, as many people in suits
	as there were 'Raver' types - but for me, the overall vibe
	was nothing short of excellent (if not quite incredible).

	Its not the suits themself, or even the alcohol, its the 
	attitude that seems to be prevelant when a party has a 
	(un)healthy mix of these ingredients. At Nikkita, even if 
	these things were present, the attitude wasn't.

	Why not ? Who knows. I'd put it down to some serious music, 	
	and a core of great people having what looked like a really 
	good time. From my side, I was in a seriously good mood, so
	that no doubt helped.
	
	Good party - I'd go again.

	All the best,
	Gary

6s in Xs boys and girls! I hope ya'll had as good a time as I.  Moonpup,
Sdream and Melissa reviewed it well, so I'm just going to say thank y'all for
making it happen.  May we remember to let the truth and beauty of these kind
of memories shape our reality.

I'm not much good with names, or even sometimes faces, but for some reason
I've got a remarkably clear picture (with name) of each beautiful person I
met this weekend.  Even more enlightening, are the clarified pictures of
faces I assumed I knew.  Conversation has this remarkable ability to expose
common ground that is all too applicable to ones current issues (Rick- You're
appreciated.. big time!)

Moonpup- I hesitiate to let you know how much we're going to miss you, for
fear of you questioning you're decision to travel, but I'm doing it anyway.
 End of may is a ways away though, eh?
Trisha- You are heaven sent, your talent and beauty amazes me, and my only
regret for the weekend was not being able to chant with you more.  To be
continued?

Yikes, I better stop for now or I'll be up all night praising you folks!

Keep yer peepers posted for the next event.  Rumor has it there's this quaint
mountain retreat home overlooking some lush valley in Yosemite, and I hear
it's awful nice there in the spring time! ; )

Love & More Love,
Steveo

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 19 00:33:58 1996

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Mar 1996 00:14:52 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu>
Subject: please read for a fellow sfraver
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

this message is for a fellow sfraver (me) who is currently in a tremendous
amount of pain.  i'm assuming a huge amount of trust in you, but that's what
i've come to expect and live for.

tonight, i was told by a person whom i care for very much, that the world is
a better place when i'm not around.  not that she needed space, not that she
didn't think we should see each other, that the world is a better place
without me.  i cannot think of a single more hurtful thing to say to another
human.  i feel my life energy has been permenantly damaged, and that i have
been hurt beyond repair by this person with whom i was planning to spend the
rest of my life.  i no longer feel complete, and i'm not so sure that any
amount of raving can fix that.

because of this, i am taking some time off from my current life.  i'm most
likely taking a leave of absence from school for a semester, and i'm trying
to distance myself from the (many) things, places, and occurences that
remind me of this hurtful person.  i'm looking for work to support myself
through this leave.  i do not have the mental or physical energy to
contribute as much to this wonderful sfraves family as i have in the past.
thus, for the next comple months, i may ask for more energy, support, and
love than i am capable of giving back.  i hope everyone understands that i
have tried to give as much as i can to the wonderful individuals in this
community.  because of that, i'm asking for as much support and love as you
are capable of giving to help me through this darkness and pain.

i think you all for being part of raving, the activity that has changed my
life.  i hope i can change my life again, and i love you for whatever
support you can offer.

peace, love, and much pain-

matt l.

Hats off to the SPUNDAE people in their effort to establish a quality weekly 
event in NIKITA.  Last Friday I wasn't even thinking about "The Suits" (does 
anyone wear suits to 1015?)  It was strange, I left the main room for a while 
and when I came back the place was electric-on-fire, obviously Doc had come 
onto the scene and proceeded to deliver the beats in climatic waves.  It was a 
real pleasure to look out and see pretty much the whole room getting off!  
Actually, I found it more positive than my trip to Evolution later that same 
evening. I can't wait for DJ Dimitry (Dee-Lite) this Friday, my B-Day! I'm only 
worried that the room is too small to get enough space to get a groove on. 
Things were pretty tight last Friday, and things have never been the same 
"basswize" since they reconfigured the soundsystem a while back due to noise 
complaints from the new development next door. But it is comforting to have a 
quality weekly to fall back on.

It's always interesting to tune in to sfraves the following week and find out 
that so many of you were at say a place like 1015.  There were three of us from 
Solle Clothes in attendance and we're all on sfraves (I had a new Solle 
"SanFrandisco!"-T)  Anyway, if you see us in the future please say hello. We're 
all three laminately challenged(P.C.) but members of the tribe none the less.

See Ya Out!

Matthew,

        My heart hurts when I read the words you posted.  We don't give
love and we don't take love; we circulate and recycle love, so it's always
abundant, always shared.  Stay close to the people who truly care about
you, and you'll find what you need to refresh and regenerate yourself.  You
are a vital part of this family, as are we all, and though I've never met
you personally, we connect on a certain level.  Don't dwell on the ignorant
and hurtful words of someone who obviously doesn't get it.  Let us lift you
up, fill you with light and love, and share our open hearts with you as you
do with us.

PLUR, with big hugz & smiles,

- E

I don't know, Leslie...the whistle-blowing is a lot like the clapping.  Are
you opposed to clapping to the music?  Those who know what's up will blow
their whistles as a complement to the music, to add a little something
extra to the vibe, and try not to deafen anyone.  Maybe some people get
carried away, but as long as they're having fun and not dissing anyone,
it's all good, IMHO.
BTW, I'll never bring a whistle to a rave :)

- E

When I went to my first party, I thought I'd be scorned and ridiculed
because of how I was dressed.  I wore a Rush concert tee-shirt (from
Presto) with the sleeves cut off, black 501s and black harness boots.  My
hair was down some of the time, if not all.  I was the epitome of a
dirt-head rocker, but no one gave so much as a sideways glance at me!  I
was impressed, and quickly understood by the fact that everyone was wearing
something completely different, that anything's appropriate ravewear!  And,
every time I think I've seen it all, someone in a completely new and
different outfit catches my eye.  It's fun.  I don't think I own anything
that I could wear to a rave that's not funkier than my everyday wear, but
I'm inspired to go through my stuff and find something interesting,
comfortable, and fun (I do love my SHROOMARAMA shirt, and everyone gets off
on it, but I don't want to wear the same thing all the time).

Clothing...what a concept!

- E

Dear Matt,

> hello all-
> 
> this message is for a fellow sfraver (me) who is currently in a tremendous
> amount of pain.  i'm assuming a huge amount of trust in you, but that's what
> i've come to expect and live for.
> 
> tonight, i was told by a person whom i care for very much, that the world is
> a better place when i'm not around.  not that she needed space, not that she
> didn't think we should see each other, that the world is a better place
> without me.  i cannot think of a single more hurtful thing to say to another
> human.  i feel my life energy has been permenantly damaged, and that i have
> been hurt beyond repair by this person with whom i was planning to spend the
> rest of my life.  i no longer feel complete, and i'm not so sure that any
> amount of raving can fix that.

What kind of a hatred, evil, and cruelness is boiling in this person? It
is understandable that at times in ones relationship, things may not be
as expected, but I cannot see that anyone in the right mind would have
the 'guts' to say such a thing.

Matt, from your letter it is obvious that you are a kind-hearted and caring
person. Eventhough your energy is dented at the moment, it will be restored,
and think your plan to take a break is probably appropriate. Been there,
done that, and must say that I am more alive than ever. Hang in there.

It seems that this person you cared for very much, had a lot of negative
energy in her life, and for some reason released it all on you. It may
have nothing to do with you at all, but it was probably some kind of
'release valve'.
> 
> because of this, i am taking some time off from my current life.  i'm most
> likely taking a leave of absence from school for a semester, and i'm trying
> to distance myself from the (many) things, places, and occurences that
> remind me of this hurtful person.  i'm looking for work to support myself
> through this leave.  i do not have the mental or physical energy to
> contribute as much to this wonderful sfraves family as i have in the past.
> thus, for the next comple months, i may ask for more energy, support, and
> love than i am capable of giving back.  i hope everyone understands that i
> have tried to give as much as i can to the wonderful individuals in this
> community.  because of that, i'm asking for as much support and love as you
> are capable of giving to help me through this darkness and pain.

Eventhough I do not contribute as much as most of the people, I am sure that
you can count on all in order to support you in this and bring you lots of
love and energy.

> 
> i think you all for being part of raving, the activity that has changed my
> life.  i hope i can change my life again, and i love you for whatever
> support you can offer.
> 
> peace, love, and much pain-

Hang in there bro... I'm sure that your energy will be restored with time,
and that you will rise high above the people that bring negativity to this
world....

Peace, and Love.

Michael Albers
mal@zoom.com

From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: whistles or????
Message-ID: <960319191936_71165.755_GHL116-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

woooo woooo did I push some buttons responding on the whistle issue?

Eric P. asks if I mind people clapping ... c'mon Eric, I'll put a whistle-blower
(loud, constant and with no breakbeat, so we can get the true effect) on one
side of you in a crowded room, and a hand-clapper (dancing, of course, and
hearing the music) ... and you tell me which one you want to be next to ..
I'll be movin' on the side of the hand-clapper real quick, let me tell you!

And Kenji asks if I'd rather have cat calls --again, no comparison on volume and
annoyance -- so, yes, if I had to choose, maybe I would rather have any sound
generated by a human voice...  

Next time you see me out, come dance with me, I'll scream and whoop it up with
the best of 'em -- but I promise never to do something that hurts your ears or
intrudes on your appreciation of the music .... unless of course  you don't like
how I dance, in which case you may have to close your eyes..   ; )

a new can of worms might be my feelings on some live drumming....  what can be
worse that being in the middle of the sound of a dj who's creating an
unpredictable, artful and evocative breaking beat -- and an enthusiastic, but
not quite tuned-in conga drummer (often not the one who brought the drum in) who
thinks that the live drum should set the pace -- and then the battle begins....
hmmmmm...  live drumming, when it's good, it's very VERY good, and when it's
bad, we feel like we're on two different planets....  

over and out on this one!   Leslie  : )

to matt and anyone else in pain:

mu name's theron and i'm a Ph.D. student in clinical psychology and
expressive arts therapy (i.e. music, poetry, sandtray, visual arts,
dance/movement, ritual, etc...). i am currently practicing
psychotherapy/counseling and expressive arts. if anyone (you too matt) needs
some help, PLEASE do not hesitate to contact me for help or referals. i
understand what's it's like to be in that state and it can realy help to
discuss these issues with an empathic and nonjudgemental who can show you
unconditional positive regard. hang in there!!!

peace, love, and understanding,
-theron kagnoff, Ph.D. Cand.

She was probably on the rag or PMSing ... (ooh, those nasty things men
aren't supposed to say ... phttthhpppttthht!) ... It's best to assume
that about 1/2 the actions of any male or female are actually lame and
irrational hormone-driven crap that is ultimately inexplicable --
perhaps the thoughts and actions of that person felt like a solution to
the problems of humanity *AT* *THAT* *MOMENT*, and the next day, it was
just a hoot and a knee-slapper. Whaddya expect from a bunch of crazy
monkeys anyways? The Design specified that we were only supposed to try
and reproduce more ... and now we've got all this excess neural,
sexual, and hormonal energy, which most of the time, in some of the
people, spells trouble. 

That's why I suggest everybody get a lobotomy. Let's start over and make
the world a saner place. Visualize World Electroshock!

-- Niels.

         Reply to:   RE>please read for a fellow sfraver

Matt,

I dont know how anyone can say this to such a wonderfull person.  I dont know
what kind of relationship you have with this person, but she certainly does
not know what she is talking about.  After briefly meeting you this past
weekend, I know that the world is a much better place with you here.  Your
happiness and quest to make everyone else around you smile this past weekend
will live in my heart for ever.  You have changed the way I view my
surroundings.  When you are feeling a little down, just remember all the new
friends you met this weekend, and how much we all love and care for you.

One of my favorite raving quotes came from a good friend of mine.  We were
getting ready to leave a 4th of July Gathering party a few years back, and
trying to gather up our gang so we could head home.  Everyone was accounted
for but one, our friend Courntey was no where to be found.  As we were looking
for him, a friend said "What an night, we lost one friend but made a hundred."
 We eventually found our lost friend, but I will remember this quote forever. 
Remember this as your pain heals.  Remember all the truley wonderfull
friendships that were made this weekend.  Friendships that will last a
lifetime.  Friendships that, in time, will replace the emptiness you feel now.

-M   

--------------------------------------
Date: 3/19/96 12:37 AM
To: Mark Camp*
From: matthew d. p. k. lanier
hello all-

this message is for a fellow sfraver (me) who is currently in a tremendous
amount of pain.  i'm assuming a huge amount of trust in you, but that's what
i've come to expect and live for.

tonight, i was told by a person whom i care for very much, that the world is
a better place when i'm not around.  not that she needed space, not that she
didn't think we should see each other, that the world is a better place
without me.  i cannot think of a single more hurtful thing to say to another
human.  i feel my life energy has been permenantly damaged, and that i have
been hurt beyond repair by this person with whom i was planning to spend the
rest of my life.  i no longer feel complete, and i'm not so sure that any
amount of raving can fix that.

because of this, i am taking some time off from my current life.  i'm most
likely taking a leave of absence from school for a semester, and i'm trying
to distance myself from the (many) things, places, and occurences that
remind me of this hurtful person.  i'm looking for work to support myself
through this leave.  i do not have the mental or physical energy to
contribute as much to this wonderful sfraves family as i have in the past.
thus, for the next comple months, i may ask for more energy, support, and
love than i am capable of giving back.  i hope everyone understands that i
have tried to give as much as i can to the wonderful individuals in this
community.  because of that, i'm asking for as much support and love as you
are capable of giving to help me through this darkness and pain.

i think you all for being part of raving, the activity that has changed my
life.  i hope i can change my life again, and i love you for whatever
support you can offer.

peace, love, and much pain-

matt l.

god.

and wondered,                      ++++                    with all your heart
would jesus have been catholic?"   ++++      and i will bring you back."

     -me, 1996                                    -david haas, deep within

Date: 3/19/96 12:37 AM
To: Mark Camp*
From: matthew d. p. k. lanier
hello all-

this message is for a fellow sfraver (me) who is currently in a tremendous
amount of pain.  i'm assuming a huge amount of trust in you, but that's what
i've come to expect and live for.

tonight, i was told by a person whom i care for very much, that the world is
a better place when i'm not around.  not that she needed space, not that she
didn't think we should see each other, that the world is a better place
without me.  i cannot think of a single more hurtful thing to say to another
human.  i feel my life energy has been permenantly damaged, and that i have
been hurt beyond repair by this person with whom i was planning to spend the
rest of my life.  i no longer feel complete, and i'm not so sure that any
amount of raving can fix that.

because of this, i am taking some time off from my current life.  i'm most
likely taking a leave of absence from school for a semester, and i'm trying
to distance myself from the (many) things, places, and occurences that
remind me of this hurtful person.  i'm looking for work to support myself
through this leave.  i do not have the mental or physical energy to
contribute as much to this wonderful sfraves family as i have in the past.
thus, for the next comple months, i may ask for more energy, support, and
love than i am capable of giving back.  i hope everyone understands that i
have tried to give as much as i can to the wonderful individuals in this
community.  because of that, i'm asking for as much support and love as you
are capable of giving to help me through this darkness and pain.

i think you all for being part of raving, the activity that has changed my
life.  i hope i can change my life again, and i love you for whatever
support you can offer.

peace, love, and much pain-

matt l.

I'm still trying to comprehend this weekend.  I'm able to type because my
fingers are the only muscles in my body that do not hurt.

Snowboarding on Saturday was a blast!  Only my second time on the slopes and I
think I got the hang of it.  I'm actually able to turn both ways and not fall
every 10 feet.  I cant wait to go again.

Hitting the hot tub Saturday night after a long day of boarding turned my body
into mush.  My muscles decided to go into full shut down mode so most of the
evening was spent relaxing on the couch listening to some of the most
incredible music i've heard in a long time.  Rick and Eric, you guys are
awesome!!  Your set of truley beautifull ambient sounds soothed my aching
bones.  We definatly need to hook up soon.  Moonpup, I hate to see you leave
and can only hope that I get to see you spin as many times as possible before
you're off to the UK.  Matthew, Your constant smiles and quest to hug everyone
as much as possible was truly inspiring. Jason, You used your little crate of
records like a box of magic.  Your set was brillant.  A special thanks to you
and to Robert for the company on the drive up and back home on Sunday.  What a
beutifull drive it was around the lake and thru the hills to Kirkwood.  We
couldnt have picked a better weekend to visit one of the most beutifull areas
in the world.  Kirkwood on Sunday was great.  I ran into my good friend and x
roommate from Santa Cruz, Mary, who was up for the day.  Our two other x
roommates from SC, Chad and Jeff, work and Timber Creek resturant at Kirkwood,
so it was a short, but nice reunion.  We arrived at Kirkwood much too late to
purchase a lift ticket.  30 bucks for 2 hours of boarding just didnt seem
worth it.  Mary was nice enough to lend my her lift ticked becasue she was
taking a break.  I only had enough energy for one run.  My muscles were in
soooooo much pain!!  Jason borrowed a lift ticket as well and went up for a
few runs.  

There are so many more people I'd like to thank for a wonderfull weekend, but
as usual, names have slipped out of my head for the time being.  There were so
many to remember, and I'm sure I'll be seeing all of you soon (Sunset next
weekend!!).  My quietness got the best of me this weekend, so I unfortunatly  
didnt get a chance to really chat with everyone there.  Everyone added to a
woderfull experience that will stay with me as one of the best raving
experiences I have ever had.    I'd especially like to thank SteveO for
putting all this together and for finding the best cabin in Tahoe. 

Thank you all, Love to all.

-Mark

>When I went to my first party, I thought I'd be scorned and ridiculed
>because of how I was dressed.  I wore a Rush concert tee-shirt (from
>Presto) with the sleeves cut off, black 501s and black harness boots.  My
>hair was down some of the time, if not all.  I was the epitome of a
>dirt-head rocker, but no one gave so much as a sideways glance at me!

okay this is my first post to sfraves, but i'm form the midwest so you
know.  and all i gotta say is damn, this would have never happened out
here.  a thread just went through mw-raves a coupla months or so ago about
stuff like this.  the fashion here, *especially* in chicago, is cliquey as
hell and definitely outta hand.  if someone came to a party in chicago
dressed like this they would without a doubt be made to feel outta place.
it seems to "fit in" out here you gotta have the latest styles, huge phat
grinds and q's, big polos and sweaters...i dunno.  i can't really decide.
on the one hand i think anyone that comes out to party should be able to
wear whatever the hell they want to without feeling out of place, but i
also love being at a party and looking around and seeing all these cute lil
kidz in their phat pantz and huge sweaters and bleached hair and facial
piercings etc etc.  there's also the point someone made that they felt like
they came to parties to escape the normal world and they don't wanna see
those kinds of clothes around them, and how if they, say, went to the
opera, they wouldn't wear their phat gear, they'd dress appropriately for
that situation.  i dunno...  i guess y'all are just more open-minded when
it comes to style out there than the midwest kidz are.  oh well.  just
wanted to kinda introduce myself and hopefully shed some light on what the
style thing is like elsewhere...

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael
allroy

On 19 Mar 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> Eric P. asks if I mind people clapping ... c'mon Eric, I'll put a whistle-blower
> (loud, constant and with no breakbeat, so we can get the true effect) on one
> side of you in a crowded room, and a hand-clapper (dancing, of course, and
> hearing the music) ... and you tell me which one you want to be next to ..
> I'll be movin' on the side of the hand-clapper real quick, let me tell you!

	For what, 3 years now, I have had people coming up to and 
pulling my whistle out of my mouth when I wasn't even playing it. I had 
someone at a Wicked come up to me and tell me I didn't get something or 
other cuz there was a flourscent orange thing in my mouth. Funny thing 
is, no one has ever pulled it when I have been blowing it. Some of 
this behavior is founded on the fact that some people do not play rhythms 
that go with the music and because of that it does grate on people's 
nerves. But if someone plays a whistle, a drum, a pair of sticks, a dige, 
or what have you with a little something, and that little something makes 
it fit, I will definitely be right where I was standing dancing hard with 
a big grin on my face cuz right about then, the energy levels are going 
to really high and that's what I like... 

dave

When I was in college (Antioch in Ohio) we used to have nude dance parties
all the time..Actually, they were a lot like saunas.. we would seal off
the (co-ed!) showers with plastic and duct tape, aim the hot jets at the
wall..and usually, bring in a keg..and lots of other refreshments...  :)
!!!!! These parties were trly a blast... Still legendary among those who 
were there... High density fun  :)
  We would usually have a DJ next door in one of the common rooms..
It was great.. There's nothing like a beer shampoo while listening to 
your favorite tunes.... Sort of like the soap thing, which I don't think 
has made it here.. (it's popular in Ibiza, especially)
Basically, the dance floor is waterproofed, and foam is pumped down over 
the dancers..Raving nude (or in swim gear) would be great.. if only it 
wasn't for the sexual harassment issue.. (which is significant..)
What can I say, Filters can be devised..

On a similar (soapy) theme..
I understand that a new "foam" based lubricant which also completely 
kills the HIV virus is in final beta testing... If this makes it through 
the FDA tests.. it may change the party scene forever.

-Chris.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 19 16:33:17 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA25249; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 16:33:17 -0800
Received: from dons.ac.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA25225; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 16:33:02 -0800
Message-Id: <1.5.4b11.32.19960320001347.0070ca38@dons.ac.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4b11 (32)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Mar 1996 16:13:47 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu>
Subject: clothes, whistles, it's all good
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

first thing, i'm alive, regardless how doubtfull that was last night.  the
messages of support and love i have received today have been overwhelming.
it reaffirms why i'm in this scene (family is a better place to put it) in
the first place.  i'm feeling closer to my old self, and hope to be my
smiling, hugging, boppin' self soon.  i wouldn't have jumped back so fast
without all your support.  consider all youselves hugged RIGHT NOW!!!

second thing-  whistles, clothes, it's all good.  this recent thread about
the whistles makes me wonder- do we have the right to tell someone not to do
something at a rave?  when i entered this scene, i was amazed by the
diversity of color, thought, and action.  i love the whistles and the energy
they provide.  yes, as a musician, their common lack of rhythm annoys me,
but who am i to buy into the mindset that says the dj is the only person
allowed to set the rhythm and the rhythms of others don't matter?

my advice - if the whistle annoys you - realize that that's another person
blowing it.  that person is capable of love, pain, joy, creativity, and all
the other emotions you are capable of.  don't take it out of their mouth,
don't glare at them, don't curse them for being tweeked out, appreciate
their rhythm and their contribution to life.  some people have a trained
sense of rhythm, other's don't.  both are good, and both are needed for a
good community.

i love you all.

peace, love, and plastic baby whistles-

matt l.

fist off, here's a cross-thread flame bait idea... If someone is playing 
thie rwhistle and it's bugging you, don't get angry, just go up and hug 
them until the stop :D  They will either be so overwhelmed by your love 
that they'll stop whistling or they will be so offended at your groping 
that they'll stop.... 

On a more serious note, many of you might have heard about the disco 
disaster in the Philippines.  They say 105 people were killed after a fire 
broke out in the booth of this disco and there was only one door to exit 
through.  I think that we should send our vibes out to those folks as 
well because they were trying to have a good time, vibin' down there to 
whatever grooves that DJ was spinnin and the next moment it was hell and 
chaos.  And think of the poor DJ!  Something kind of mythical though 
about going up in flames with your wax....  But seriously, it really 
isn't a funny issue and I think we should take a couple fo moments to 
think about the people who lose their lives trying to keep a vibe going.
Peace!

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---

                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor
           "Mr. Kirk, you'd better come down to the station-house."

Date: Tue, 19 Mar 96 17:24:24 PST

In-Reply-To: <Pine.APO.3.91.960319144845.14814B-100000@blizzard.berkeley.edu>; from "Dave Bayer" at Mar 19, 96 3:36 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dave:
>this behavior is founded on the fact that some people do not play rhythms 
>that go with the music

Some?  There aren't many people who can keep time with a drum box.

>and because of that it does grate on people's 
>nerves. But if someone plays a whistle, a drum, a pair of sticks, a dige, 
>or what have you with a little something, and that little something makes 
>it fit, I will definitely be right where I was standing dancing hard with 
>a big grin on my face cuz right about then, the energy levels are going 
>to really high and that's what I like... 

I respect your taste and there have been (rare) occasions where I've
actually enjoyed little skilled conga playing along with the DJ.  
But many of us really prefer to trance out to the otherwordly
sounds and machine-driven beats that take us beyond the limits
of human performance.  Vocals, drum breaks, acoustic instruments
are fine as long as they are sampled, chopped, pitch-shifted and 
looped.  

So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back 
into the protoplasm and goo from which we sprang.  This is great
for our inner child/infant that craves to wallow in its own spew, 
but it's mostly a primordial drag for the psychonaut seeking 
to soar amongst the cosmos.

Looking forward to 2morrow's "Light".  
I'm not as pretentious when I'm dancing, so pls come and say hi.  d:)

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Just wanted to let everyone know that I'm glad the sun is staying out
longer.  I get so damn depressed during the winter when it starts getting
dark at 4:30.  I guess this means more outdoor events (sunsets!!!) and such.
For some reason, I always feel happier in the afternoon in Spring and Summer
- kinda that happy, lazy (and dare I say pretty damn near stoney) feeling.
I've always wondered why.

Happy spring to y'all,

Mr. Jake

...who hasn't been to a party in waaaaaay to long.

>I think that everyone should go back to the days of wearing crazy hats.

Please wear them Noah!!  I miss hats, too.  The only way to make the scene
what we want (as stimulating as possible!) is to do it ourselves!  I
realized this recently as I wandered around a rave wishing for more smiles,
more toys, more characters.  One of the lessons of raving, for me, is that
we cannot search  outside of ourselves for what we want.  WE make it happen
- and that means bring out the hats!

I hope to meet you at the next party.  I'll look for the guy wearing the
3-foot-tall Dr. Seuss hat! ;) .

>So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance

Regardless,this makes me wonder if you've ever fully participated in a drum 
circle as fully as you would participate in a rave.  I suppose that if you 
are more into transcendance through technology, then a "self-indulgent 
performer" may distract, but personally, I've had much more uplifting and 
transcendant experiences while wacking away at congas (especially in drum 
circles) than any dj set that I've ever heard.:)  If you're not into the 
"primordial de-evolved indulgence of our inner child/infant protoplasm" 
thing, that's fine, but to belittle it the way you seem to be doing it is a 
little like making fun of your mother because she likes to reminisce about 
your childhood. ;)

no offense intended!
hugs,
kenji

Hello fellow sfravers,
  A friend of mine, Allen Cohen, is working on an interesting new project.
He asked me to forward this to the list.
-Chris

Forwarded message:

The SF Oracle was the leading underground psychedelic newspaper
published in the Haight Ashbury in ths 60s. It innovated content and
graphic revolutions in print media, and was a guide and chronicler
of the ideas and and ideals of the 60s. Allen Cohen, one of its founders
and editors, wants to put a new Oracle for the 21st century on the WEB.
We are putting together a team of multimedia and WEB innovators to make
this a reality. We are looking for web wizards and witches who
would like to play a major role in creating a consciousness
expanding and socially significant force on the WEB. We also need
financial angels, sponsers and marketers to establish a financial base
for this launching. Please if you are interested send e-mail to
oracleweb@lists.best.com. Thank you

On Tue, 19 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> Dave:
> >this behavior is founded on the fact that some people do not play rhythms 
> >that go with the music
> 
> Some?  There aren't many people who can keep time with a drum box.
> 
> >and because of that it does grate on people's 
> >nerves. But if someone plays a whistle, a drum, a pair of sticks, a dige, 
> >or what have you with a little something, and that little something makes 
> >it fit, I will definitely be right where I was standing dancing hard with 
> >a big grin on my face cuz right about then, the energy levels are going 
> >to really high and that's what I like... 
> 
> I respect your taste and there have been (rare) occasions where I've
> actually enjoyed little skilled conga playing along with the DJ.  
> But many of us really prefer to trance out to the otherwordly
> sounds and machine-driven beats that take us beyond the limits
> of human performance.  Vocals, drum breaks, acoustic instruments
> are fine as long as they are sampled, chopped, pitch-shifted and 
> looped.  
> 
> So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
> is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
> For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
> ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back 
> into the protoplasm and goo from which we sprang.  This is great
> for our inner child/infant that craves to wallow in its own spew, 
> but it's mostly a primordial drag for the psychonaut seeking 
> to soar amongst the cosmos.

Hi!
 The ability to trance out is essientially what SOME of us are seeking. 
However the trance state of mind can be achieved on ones own under any 
enviromental situation. I certainly try to help create spaces that allow 
for the trance state but it is up to the individual to go there (leading 
a horse to water and making it (or not) drink). This ability to trance 
demonstrates the power the individual has over their internal state. 
Yogi's have been teaching this for a looong time. I feel that many of us 
are creating new territories in order to teach one another this vibe. 
Ideally then we can take this vibe to other situations that need it =)
Also ideally we should be able to invoke this state within ourselves 
under most (if not all ;) ) conditions.
 I suggest focusing on the vibe rather than the disstractions if at all 
possible (sometimes impossible it seems) and perhaps you can reach the 
disstraction with your vibe. Also keep in mind that the disstraction 
(bells, whistles, foghorns) may be helping to drive someone to their own 
trance state. If nothing else I find that putting my fingers in my ears 
and kinda grinning and grimicing at the oft times TOO LOUD whistle blower
will work miracles.
PS I seriously appreciate all ya's input  :)
                                  (peace)
Ran                                  /
                                 =*=/
                                  ~

Disclaimer... one of my few nerves have been touched here...

On Tue, 19 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
> is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
> For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
> ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back 
> into the protoplasm and goo from which we sprang.  This is great
> for our inner child/infant that craves to wallow in its own spew, 
> but it's mostly a primordial drag for the psychonaut seeking 
> to soar amongst the cosmos.

	And for others, the group experience where we are all pulled to 
the same state is focal point. Here, those who seek to trance out into 
their own separate worlds only drain the party of the vital life giving 
energy which we seek to cultivate until it explodes outward, carrying us 
with. What would a party be without the yells and screams of the 
crowd (do these ruin the music as well)? That building of energy in 
the dance room, the building of the tribal, primitive intensity; this is  
the reason I got involved in parties. It is why I like the faster, harder 
music that is so hard to find in this city. It is also the topic I happen 
to take the most shit on from people who have never experienced it which 
is how I percieve the comment about how whistling is great for the inner 
child that "craves to wallow in its own spew".
	I still do not understand why whistling come not possibly mimick a
drum machine. I have been involved with music (both computer controlled
and performed by organic means... Basicly both people
breathing/pounding/strumming out music but I don't know how to phrase this
without someone misinturrepting what I mean) since I was about 10 years
old. Over this time, I have been a part of small groups, solo projects,
and 100+ person bands. I have seen groups that are as tight as a computer,
and I know how it feels to be playing along with a drum machine because I
cannot tell that I am necessarily playing (and as soon as I think about
it, it stops and I fumble, and the line that what rolling off my tongue
dies). So why do I whistle if I cannot tell I am doing it? Well, first,
the cycle of breathing, and tongue movements and basicly everything that
goes into playing a whistle I do with or without... It's just what
happens. So the whistle fits naturally in there and gives that slight back
pressure to my breath which feels so nice. In addition to at feeling, it
usually makes people hoot and holler and jump around which sends that
energy up just another notch that I was talking about before. Which is
"right"? Can both of our interpretations exist at the same party? 
Probably, because I don't keep whistling if it doesn't feel right... 

dave

>So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
>is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
>For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
>ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back 
>into the protoplasm and goo from which we sprang.  This is great
>for our inner child/infant that craves to wallow in its own spew, 
>but it's mostly a primordial drag for the psychonaut seeking 
>to soar amongst the cosmos.

WHOOOAAAA, there, tiger.  I think this is being just a tad bit reductionist.
I respect your opinion on the matter, but I think that's taking it a little
too far.  If someone enjoys dressing up at a rave and you don't like how
they look, should they then not dress that way (this isn't hypothetical, I
know people who look down on people who dress certain ways at raves)?  I
don't think sight is any more intrusive than sound.  One might say, "well,
it's easier to shut your eyes than your ears.  But lets face it, most raves
are big places and if you don't like what you hear around you, given the
volume of the music it isn't too difficult to move thirty feet away (or even
just a few towards the speaker) and be out of range of that person's
whistle-blowing or conga-playing or what have you.

Just my 2.5, 
Jake

who really wishes they sold Samoas all year...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 19 18:46:12 1996

Received: from [128.32.160.187] (wmf63.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.187]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id SAA20195 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 18:45:37 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130501ad751c1ce15e@[128.32.160.187]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Mar 1996 18:44:27 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Hooray for Whistles!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wow, I'm really surprised at the prevailing attitudes towards whistles on
this list.  I had been sadly wondering why whistles had been
disappearing...I guess the vibe of severe peer disapproval (check
yourselves!) has something to do with it.

Hey everyone, for *this* vibe-crazy raver, whistles are the ultimate!
There is an incredible moment when the energy builds so high that even our
fevered dancing can't contain it... a sudden whistle at the moment of
greatest energy brings our expression higher.  I *always* follow the sound
to go dance with the whistler, encouraging them with smiles to continue to
build on the vibe.

Whistles are part of the dancers' contribution to the music.  It is about
COLLECTIVE experience - not *just* the dj, *just* the records spinning, but
what we ALL bring to it.  For the same reason drumming and handclapping
make me ecstatic.  We all become part of the creation.  With cheers and
claps and whistles and stamping feet we offer all of our energy to build an
even greater experience.

BTW, come find me at a party:  I'm the one with glittery face, dancing in
front of the drums (or speaker), clapping like a maniac! :)

On Tue, 19 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> I respect your taste and there have been (rare) occasions where I've
> actually enjoyed little skilled conga playing along with the DJ.  
> But many of us really prefer to trance out to the otherwordly
> sounds and machine-driven beats that take us beyond the limits
> of human performance.  Vocals, drum breaks, acoustic instruments
> are fine as long as they are sampled, chopped, pitch-shifted and 
> looped.  

Yes.  To add, I like it when people _voice_ their enthusiasm on the 
dancefloor, but within certain bounds.  A hoot or a "yeah" is fine with 
me because they express emotion, simply, almost involuntarily.  What I 
prefer not to hear is anything articulate.  I'm not too into people chanting 
"pump, pump, pump it up" or the dj's name, or whatever.  A side note:  
pre-articulate sounds can also _mean_, either explicitly or implicitly.  
Take "eweh-eweh," which I associate with drunken revelry in the 
disco/funk/vocal-house vein.  Nothing inherently wrong with this -- just that 
it adds to certain contexts (e.g. 70's night), while detracting from others 
(e.g. trance-floor).  

Rok, 
who won't be chanting "whomp there it is" 
to announce the arrival of the next momentous breakdown,
and whose opinions are subject to change.  

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 19 19:09:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA11605; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 19:09:41 -0800

Precedence: bulk

Just some notes on Basics...

As always, I had a wonderful time here.  It might just be
my sentimentality, but I get such a feeling of family and
togetherness at martin's parties.  It was a nice thing to feel again
because I haven't felt it that strong for several months now.

Technical Details:
The venue was really comfortable... It's good to know that there are 
still new nice places waiting to be discovered out there.
The sound was powerful and crisp... maybe a little loud, but it could
have also been an acoustical phenomenon with the space.
It was neat to see the party build up.  To see three people start
dancing and then just watch it build up until there are hundreds
of people thick in a vibe.
The music was overall very good.  Seemed to start a bit shaky and get better,
never wowed me, but stayed solid through the night.

Philosophical Details:
All or Nothing.
My life seems to be taking on a rather extreme transformation
lately.  It seems to do this every year about this time, my birthday,
but especially in these last three years... each one gets more and
more intense and powerful.  Somedays I feel like I'm still in the womb,
waiting to be born.  I don't want to go into all the details here,
but I do want to share my sense that we have nothing to worry about.
We are getting closer and closer to pure free will and true freedom.
The future has every one of us in mind and is always looking out for us.
Infinity is a realm much greater than any of us ever give credit.

So, my heart to all of you and wishes of the warmth of spring.

-john.
http://he.net/~swoosh

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 19 19:17:56 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA12434; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 19:17:56 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA12419; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 19:17:49 -0800
Received: from [128.32.160.187] (wmf63.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.187]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id TAA13374 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 19 Mar 1996 19:17:43 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130502ad7521a32c8d@[128.32.160.187]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Mar 1996 19:16:33 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: MAD Rocks the Cabana!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Everybody, forget partying on the week-ends.  Monday is the night!!

Went to MAD last night for the second time.  First time was a month ago
(Ethan, Astral Matrix live - heaven), but never could get my ass in gear to
make it there again (well, work in the morning and midterms had something
to do with it).

MAD is the shit!!  (Articulate vocabulary is a good thing, but sometimes
slang just says it all :> ).

THIS is a special party.  All ravers, all there just to get inside the
music.  What's especially beautiful to me is the sobriety.  A random beer
here or there (the bar noticeably neglected for a "club"), but folks is
just there because they love the music, they love to dance, and they love
each other.

I got there just after Ethan had finished (huge unhappy face).  Mars took
the wheel to deliver us all into haaardcore land.  Everybody moving with
the relentless beats.  Others sprawled out, talking, cuddling, drinking
water.  Many Berkeley folks in the house.  Jon Santos closed it out with
fast deep chemical-sounding techno.

We were drenched with sweat on the dancefloor, flying high off that natural
drug, endorphins.  So fun!!  The only downside was that a dance circle
emerged on the teeny-tiny dance floor.  About six huge guys flinging
themselves around and taking up as much space as possible.  Yes, they were
good dancers (hmmph!  I've seen better, though), but DAMN!  Whatever
happened to RESPECT for others?!

I obstinately decided to "claim my space."  My usual naive response to
injustice is to confront the perpetrator, expecting shame and contriteness
once they realize their transgression.  I kept my dancing spot, even as it
progressively became the middle of the circle, and others who had been
dancing around me were pushed into huddled masses along the walls.  Instead
of having my space respected, I was pummeled in the side by a huge muscled
arm and a flying foot came down hard on my bare ankle, taking skin off.  I
was effectively bullied into submission, and abandoned my space to dance
off of the floor.

I actually like circle dancing in the middle of a huge arena.  That's where
the best dancers are, and they tear it up!!  But MAD is a small, gentle,
little place, that people come to TO DANCE.  :(

Aside from that, an incredible evening!  Several times I looked around the
crowd, wondering if any anonymous emailers danced around me.  I'm going
back next week --  hopefully meet up with some of you!!

Til next time, N.

i dunno bout all that.  call me "repressed" or whaddevah, but i just like
the way ppl look in really dope gear, mebbe slightly revealing like all the
half shirts that show off cute lil tummies, etc, than i do the way they
look in the buff.  just a personal opinion.  IMHO, most ppl don't have
really beautiful bodies and they look cuter in clothes...besides i think
it's a lot of fun to be basically swimming in excess fabric while you
dance, and i like a baseball cap to play with while dancing too...

> A hoot or a "yeah" is fine with
>me because they express emotion, simply, almost involuntarily.  What I
>prefer not to hear is anything articulate.  I'm not too into people chanting
>"pump, pump, pump it up" or the dj's name, or whatever.

does this happen for real in sf???  people chant shit like "pump, pump,
pump it up"??? oh man....yikes.  *cringe*  hmph.  i do *love* it when ppl
scream spontaneously tho, and it seems to spread around to a lot of other
peeps who scream as well.  especially at those dingy-ass dirty grungy
warehouse detroit-style parties.  yum.

far as the whistle thing goes, i don't hear whistles that often so they
don't bother me that much.  if they are done in a manner which compliments
the musik, i'm all for it.  :)  there's this guy tc in detroit that has a
really weird whistle, it sounds all tweaked like if roland made a tb303
that hung around your neck ;)  anyway....we had to wait in 20 degrees for
an hour and a half to get in to jak-olantern in october and he was near the
front of the line and started blowing his whistle, in the manner he always
does which i can't explain except by emulating it wif my mouf.  the whole
line started cheering and jumping.  that was pretty bomb IMO.  well i've
rambled enough....

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael

saw the empty seats        /       ++++       \      but on your heart
reserved for the wealthy, /        ++++        \      follow me,
the bread reserved for   /         ++++         \      i will bring you back
the full, the wine for  /          ++++          \      you will be my own,
the drunk, the roof    /           ++++           \      and i will be your god.
for those with homes, /____________++++____________\      return to me, 
and wondered,                      ++++                    with all your heart
would jesus have been catholic?"   ++++      and i will bring you back."

     -me, 1996                                    -david haas, deep within

hello all-

i, the resident rebellious catholic of the list, must take issue with a
statement of michael's-

>IMHO, most ppl don't have
>really beautiful bodies and they look cuter in clothes...besides i think
>it's a lot of fun to be basically swimming in excess fabric while you
>dance, and i like a baseball cap to play with while dancing too...

i believe that every person has a beautiful body.  one of the best things
about this weekend at tahoe was the wide range of shapes, sizes, colors, and
textures of the bodies that i saw while in the hottub.  there were people
whom mainstream society would consider beautiful, people who would be
considered average, and people who would be considered large.  and you know
what i found out?  THEY WERE ALL  BEAUTIFUL, BECAUSE THEY WERE HUMAN AND
WERE SHARING THEIR ENERGY WITHOUT THE BARRIER OF CLOTHING IN THE WAY!  i
don't choose to buy into the notion that some people are beautiful and some
people are not.  i believe that that notion has been drilled into our
collective heads far too many times by far too many advertisements.
everyone is beautiful when they're naked.

michael, if you choose to keep your clothes on, more power to ya'.  i get a
little offended when some people who choose to reveal their bodies, their
flesh, their physical selves are considered more or less beautiful than others.

peace, love, and nakedness-

matt l.

Subject: Re: whistles or????
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i seem to be in a responding mood tonight, so here goes another one on this
thread discussion the merits of a dj-centered or a people centered rave
experience.  i need to respond to lee's statement-

>So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
>is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
>For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
>ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back 
>into the protoplasm and goo from which we sprang.  This is great
>for our inner child/infant that craves to wallow in its own spew, 
>but it's mostly a primordial drag for the psychonaut seeking 
>to soar amongst the cosmos.


lee, i believe we've gotten into this conversation before in response to a
proposed drumming circle that i suggested about 6 months ago.  different
people rave different ways.  when i go to a party, i'm not being guided
toward a transcendental experience.  i'm there to exist and to enjoy myself.
drumming helps me do that.  whistles help some other people do that.
dancing naked (cf other thread) helps some others do that.  this scene, for
me, exists to help as many people be happy with their lives as possible.  if
my drumming offends you, come to me and tell me, and i'll gladly go to
another location where i won't bother you.  i hope that other people will do
that, also.  just like you prefer a certain experience to help you get to
where you want to be, so do other people, and we need to respect how they
wan't to get there, however different it might be from our own way.

dance on-

peace, love, and respect-

matt l.

Subject: whistles n' stuff
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9603200106.A10022-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


assorted thoughts:

about whistles: I vote for their continued presence in our scene, but 
  would advise people to practice their timing at home to a mix tape
  before tooting away at top volume at a party. Basically, if you can 
  whistle, go for it; if you can't, practice some more.  One time I 
  was at an outdoor party, wearing a whistle round my neck, and some
  random guy asked me if he could borrow it for a bit.  Sure, I said,
  and I handed it to him, and he proceeded to tweet-tweet-tweet away
  --actually, more like TWEEEEET TWWETtweet TWWEEEEET...tweeeeeet, 
  tweeet, tweet.  TWEEET TWEEET TWEEEEEEEEET, etc.  Not even close to
  complementing the DJ's music. I felt kind of bad, because he was
  obviously having fun, but everyone around him had these pained expressions
  on their faces, so I had to ask for it back.  Then on the other hand,
  there are people out there like Dave Bayer and Alex M. who can 
  really whistle.  So, I guess I'd just tell everyone to practice.  That
  sounds kind of dorky and unspontaneous I suppose, but at least it won't
  result in that many people getting annoyed.

As for drum circles, I love them. I wish every rave had three rooms,
listed here in personal order of priority: dance room w/ DJ's, ambient room,
and drum room with percussion, sticks, whistles, bells, chimes, etc.
How cool would that be?!

hope to see you all at Light on Thursday!

best,
Timothy

>what we ALL bring to it.  For the same reason drumming and handclapping
>make me ecstatic.  We all become part of the creation.  With cheers and
>claps and whistles and stamping feet we offer all of our energy to build an
>even greater experience.
>
Excellent point, Nancy!  If people just want to watch a performance, they
should go to a concert.  That's what I do.  Going to a "show" and going to
a rave are very different, in my experience, in that at a rave, there's
much more interaction, whereas at a concert, about the only audience
participation is their noise-making to show appreciation.

Clappin' to da beat,

- E

creation....  try that store on 15th and Valencia that has the pink "thrift

In-Reply-To: <Pine.APO.3.91.960319173424.14814E-100000@blizzard.berkeley.edu>; from "Dave Bayer" at Mar 19, 96 6:34 pm

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Disclaimer... one of my few nerves have been touched here...

oops!

> On Tue, 19 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:
> 
> > So much of the music we rave to, from acid house to trance
> > is crafted to guide us toward a transcendental experience.
> > For me, the self-indulgent performer (for whom the music just
> > ain't enough) does little more than work to de-evolve us back [...]
> 
> 	And for others, the group experience where we are all pulled to 
> the same state is focal point. Here, those who seek to trance out into 
> their own separate worlds only drain the party of the vital life [...]

There are many ways to share the infinite frequencies of energy that
exist within us.  Just because we may not resonate with someone who's
doing it differently doesn't mean that it isn't happening.  Alas,
it is my own shortcoming that I cannot fully empathize with the joy 
of a whistler, just as I am unable to completely savor the unbridled
enthusiasm of a dancer who repeatedly smashes my face with hir elbows.
Fortunately, coexistence is not a problem because I can usually
find a space that caters to the kind of energy exchange that seems
more harmonious to me.

> It is also the topic I happen 
> to take the most shit on from people who have never experienced it which 
> is how I percieve the comment about how whistling is great for the inner 
> child that "craves to wallow in its own spew".

Apologies.  The fun I get from poetic metaphor isn't really meant to hurt.

> 	I still do not understand why whistling come not possibly mimick a
> drum machine. I have been involved with music (both computer controlled
> and performed by organic means... 
> [...] 
> and I know how it feels to be playing along with a drum machine because I
> cannot tell that I am necessarily playing
> ... It's just what happens.

Sorry to chop that up so much, but I think I know what you're getting at.
As someone who's been making music most of his life, I agree that there
are few feelings that can compare with the live creation of music,
*especially* jamming along with drum machines, sequencers, etc.  The
programmed backdrop becomes a foundation you can synergize with by
bringing to it a part of life, a part of the Now within you, through an 
act of creation that forms a larger Whole that would otherwise not exist. 
You become lost in it as the sense of self dissolves into a greater force
signified by the dissolution of the boundary between you and the Universe
Beyond.

But as wonderful as this is *experientially*, when I record it and
respond to it as a listener it very often sounds like crap, and I 
wouldn't expect anyone else hearing it to be able to share my bliss 
of making it.  Now if we were all jamming together, like in the shared
experience of a drum circle, that's something else.

>  In addition to at feeling, it
> usually makes people hoot and holler and jump around which sends that
> energy up just another notch that I was talking about before. Which is
> "right"? Can both of our interpretations exist at the same party? 
> Probably, because I don't keep whistling if it doesn't feel right... 

Ultimately, all of us coming together to do what feels right is what
makes the party, and it would never make me feel right to tell you
what to do or not do.  I can only tell you how I feel.  The most 
disturbing thing for me about whistles comes from something you mentioned
in a previous post; about people who actually yank the whistle out of 
your mouth.  Violence at raves is something that thankfully very rarely
happens and is probably never justifiable.  That someone whistling
could provoke people into acts of physical aggression at a rave bothers
me more than the shrill screeching of the whistle itself.

In a strangely perverse way, I find myself now curious to hear a small
sampling of what your whistling sounds like.

Take Care,
Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.  What's being referred to in this
thread is physical beauty, which is entirely subjective.  So naturally,
everyone will have a different perspective on it.  Inner beauty is another
thing entirely, and applies to many more people than physical beauty does.
Remember, dear friends, that the way you look has nothing to do with the
kind of person you are, though unfortunately some people are made to feel
superior or inferior in some way because of appearance.  I have a big nose,
big ears, crooked teeth, and inverted arches, and am too thin due to
undernourishment, but I focus my attention more on my inner self than on my
outer self, and my inner self shines so brightly that other people usually
focus their attention on it, rather than how I look, too!

Peace to all you beautiful people!

- E

     in May.  And so far, the more I read the more I get excited!

     say much this soon.  But already I sense a strong community and a bit 
     more of a mature attitude than that of the dcraves list.  To me, it's 
     all about the music!  ...not the party --That's secondary.

     here.

     so far.  And whatever that is, I already feel drawn to it.

Hey Sarah, dancing is indeed a cure for cramps, as is any form of 
upright strenuous exercise, i.e. I studied the martial arts for seven 
years and that always worked, but sometimes it was a bitch to just get 
my ass on those days to the dojo...  reference the above 'upright' I 
believe this works best when the entire body is pumpin'  --Mau

>i believe that every person has a beautiful body.  one of the best things
>about this weekend at tahoe was the wide range of shapes, sizes, colors, and
>textures of the bodies that i saw while in the hottub.  there were people
>whom mainstream society would consider beautiful, people who would be
>considered average, and people who would be considered large.  and you know
>what i found out?  THEY WERE ALL  BEAUTIFUL, BECAUSE THEY WERE HUMAN AND
>WERE SHARING THEIR ENERGY WITHOUT THE BARRIER OF CLOTHING IN THE WAY!  i
>don't choose to buy into the notion that some people are beautiful and some
>people are not.  i believe that that notion has been drilled into our
>collective heads far too many times by far too many advertisements.
>everyone is beautiful when they're naked.
>
>michael, if you choose to keep your clothes on, more power to ya'.  i get a
>little offended when some people who choose to reveal their bodies, their
>flesh, their physical selves are considered more or less beautiful than others.

>It's sad to know that society has taught us (me included...but I'm working
>on it) to only think certain humans are beautiful :(


okay, let me straighten something out here.  i hardly think that one's
physical beauty has anything to do with whether they are a beautiful person
or not.  someone can be beautiful on the physical tip and be an asshole, by
the same token someone can be a beautiful *person*, but i still don't want
to see 'em nekkid.

i think everyone is beautiful in their own way.
i just don't want their bare ass waggin' in front of me at a party.

my 2 cents...

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael
allroy

Subject: noisemakers, drums, and springtime
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

i think the best thing to realize about any sort of noisemaker is if it's
done reasonably, it can add to teh vibe.  if not, it may detract.  but as
someone pointed out, you can always move...

drum circles, i think, are best left to themselves.  maybe in the ambient
room or at a multiple day outdoor event far away from the main sound
system, etc.  out of time drumming can be annoying...and with the acoustics
of warehouses, etc, and the delay, it's nigh impossible to drum
accurately...but i guess if you can, you can.  kewl.

btw i'm envious of all y'all already having outdoor parties (i *love*
outdoor parties!!!)...it took me a half an hour to get my car started and
the snow cleared off of it this morning...first day of spring indeed
*grumble*

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael
allroy

At 02:31 PM 3/20/96 -0500, you wrote:
>i think the best thing to realize about any sort of noisemaker is if it's
>done reasonably, it can add to teh vibe.  if not, it may detract.  but as
>someone pointed out, you can always move...
>
>drum circles, i think, are best left to themselves.  maybe in the ambient
>room

I speak for myself ofcourse, but I have not liked it when I've been dj'ing
ambient at a party, and a drum circle is started in the ambient space.  Alot
of ambient has rhythm, but not necessarily drums...and the drummers I've
encountered, don't try to follow the rhythm of the music....If they did, I
might be into it since I drum myself.

And on that "drums with electronic music" note....when I put live drums in
my electronic music, I often run them through delay that is matched up with
the timing of the music, and it sounds really good to me.

Rick

>From: jderrick@infobahnos.com (John Derrick)
>Subject: VOTE NO AGAINST HATE LITERATURE
>
>Dear Fellow Teachers on the Net
>
>I am pasing on this message that was received  from a prof at Concordia
>(David Mumby), who received it from a prof at Waterloo (Colin Ellard)...
>
>This is an important message which requires your urgent attention.  This is
>NOT a HOAX.  Please take it entirely seriously.
>
>A group of neo-nazis are trying to form a newsgroup on Usenet called
>rec.music.white-power, so that they can get their message of hate out to
>young people using the Internet.  Newsgroups are public discussion areas on
>the Internet and their formation requires enough support from the Internet
>community.
>
>EACH AND EVERY ONE OF YOU HAS ONE VOTE when it comes to creating a new
>Usenet group. I hope you will vote NO and thereby tell these Nazis you
>don't want their stuff on the net.  Below is the procedure, please repost
>my plea and get the NO vote out.   This is my personal opinion.  If you
>want to see the official call for votes, you can read in news.group or ask
>me for a copy of the notice calling for votes.
>
>Do _not_ vote twice - that would constitute voting fraud.
>
>HOW TO VOTE:
>
>Send E-MAIL (posts to a newsgroup are invalid) to:
>
>    music-vote@sub-rosa.com
>
>This is an impartial, third-party vote taker.
>
>Do not REPLY to THIS message, if you are trying to vote.  Please do not
>assume that just replying to this message will work. Check the address
>before you mail your vote.  Your mail message should contain only one
>statement:
>
>I vote NO on rec.music.white-power
>
>I REALLY HOPE YOU VOTE NO!
>
>Vote counting is automated.  Failure to follow these directions may mean
>that your vote does not get counted.  If you do not receive an
>acknowledgment of your vote within three days contact the votetaker about
>the problem.  It's your responsibility to make sure your vote is registered
>correctly.
>
>Here's what Canada's George Burdi, of the neo-Nazi Heritage Front, had to
>say about this vote, on February 21, on his RESISTANCE mailing list:
>
>  "There is a call for votes
>  coming on rec.music.white-power in the next week
>  or so, and you will be notified in a special issue of
>  RREN exactly what to do.  FOLLOW THE
>  INSTRUCTIONS TO THE LETTER.  Let me be
>  perfectly blunt and state that we have more than
>  enough "net-nazis" to win this thing hands-down.
>  But every one of you must vote YES!  And just
>  voting yes means nothing unless you do it properly.
>  So you have been forewarned.  The instructions
>  are coming to your email box soon, and they
>  are not complicated.  Just follow them as told,
>  and we will have a WP music newsgroup finally!"
>
>If Mr. Burdi's confidence disturbs you, please give this letter the
>_widest_ possible distribution, and help us deliver the largest NO vote in
>the history of UseNet.
>
>If you would like more detailed information on why you should vote no,
>check out http://nizkor.almanac.bc.ca - although it should be noted that
>the Nizkor Project has no connection to this personal plea.
>
>Thank you for reading this.
>
>
>Colin Ellard
>Department of Psychology
>University of Waterloo
>Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1
>

Message-Id: <199603201956.LAA12350@norway.it.earthlink.net>
X-Sender: cnielsen@earthlink.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Cortney Nielson <cnielsen@earthlink.net>
Subject: "The L.P. Tri-Tone Samba Whistle"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here's a compromise: 
At musical instrument stores everywhere -
In the percussion and/or accessories dept. there is a whistle called the
"tri-tone samba whistle" by Latin Percussion.
It's fairly cheap (about 10-12 bucks), its pretty, and it plays three tones
(and they are all in tune!). I'm giving out this vital info for all of you
who have to whistle at raves (I understand), but this whistle sure beats the
hell out of a coach's whistle, which is meant solely to give a signal. The
samba whistle is an actual musical instrument.  I draw a picture of this
whistle but my ASCII art sucks (but the whistle looks sort of like a brass
cross).  I used to be a whistle blower myself until I went to this rave
called Sharon a long time ago and there were so many whistles that you truly
couldn't even hear the DJ...
(my friends are going to kill me for leaving this message...)
