Someone asked me for directions :
> 
>      Sounds like a fun party today....but, where exactly is the berkeley 
>      marina if coming from SF?  Baybridge east, 80 north...then where??? 
>      thanks -jc
> 
> 
 Get across the bay and get on HW 80 North. Take the University exit,
and take the right hand road that goes under University. You will have
to drive in a big right hand turn ( a couple of blocks ) , with the
goal of getting onto University going west towards the bay. 

 Once on University west , drive over HW 80 towards the bay. At the end of
the road , turn right and drive to the corner and around it . Find
parking where you can. Walk towards the beats ( not the beatniks ).

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

this matter, considering that acceptance and free speech seem to be preached 
here on a regular basis, with respect to raves....does this apply to Nazis 
too?  
 
Myself, I believe, to paraphrase Chomsky, supporting free speech means giving 
a voice to the opinion you despise........ 
 
later----------------->aaron

 Hey everybody, it's time to formally let the cat out of the bag (or the 
ravers out of the city)and announce our plans for another Mendocino
Mountian Jam on the 1st of June.  We will have pre-sale tickets on sale 
at Ameba by April 1, we will be working together with Greenpeace on this 
one as the first of a series of "GreenHouse" parties. 
  Folks who came up last October will remember what an awesome spot we 
have , it's sure to be in rare form this June. The full moon falls right 
on Saturday night, the organic gardens will be in bloom , people 
percolating in the wood fired hot tubs....... 
  So start planning your campout now, people who want to be early birds 
can show up for camping as early as Friday ,May 31. This party will kick 
well into Sunday night . We'll be posting line up and extra goodies 
shortly. If anyone has questions or wants to be involved e-mail Mark at 
Ameba or call us at 750-9368. 

                        THANKS Y'ALL ...HAPPY CAMPING !!!!!!!

to the readership of this group, especially in light of various recent 
threads...

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---

>>
>>

>>> >Attn. All,
>>> >
>>> >The FBI (Federal Bureau of Investigation) has decided that
>>> >in the interest of tracking down terrorists and criminals, it will 
>>> soon
>>> >engage  with the phone companies to place a random tap on 1 out of 
>>> every 10
>>> >phone  lines in the United States of America.  It justifies this with 
>>> the
>>> >logic that  incidents like Waco or the World Trade Center Bombing 
>>> might
>>> >have been prevented  had the FBI tapped their lines.  They plan on 
>>> logging
>>> >each call made from the  random line, and searching with a computer 
>>> for
>>> >certain catch phrases that  indicate illegal behavior.  This allows 
>>> them to
>>> >monitor almost any aspect of  your personal, business, or professional
>>> >life.  Senator Phil Gramm has  stated in letters to the author of this
>>> >alert that he will monitor the situation, but the government and the
>>> >congress are ignoring what the FBI is  doing.
>>> >
>>> >As citizens of the United States of America we *MUST*  protect our 
>>> freedom
>>> >of privacy and our right to free speech.  Keep in mind this could 
>>> include
>>> >computer communications as well.
>>> >
>>> >I urge you to spread this letter to at least 5 people you know, and 
>>> ask
>>> >them to continue it.  If the FBI admits to 1 out of 10 lines, it could
>>> >have the capability to monitor nearly 9 out of 10.  I myself commit no
>>> >illegal communications over the telephone, but I refuse to let the FBI 
>>> to
>>> >tap my phone line without a warrant approved by a judge.
>>> >
>>> >Do not let the FBI make you guilty until proven innocent. Do not let 
>>> the
>>> >FBI make you a part of a giant fishing expedition for criminals. Do 
>>> not let
>>> >the FBI become the KGB or the Thought Police.
>>> >

>>> also

>>> >congressmen, feel free to mail me.

feasible. Also a good clue is when you get a message saying 'pass this on 
to XXX number of people.'

On Wed, 20 Mar 1996, Cortney Nielson wrote:

> At musical instrument stores everywhere -
> In the percussion and/or accessories dept. there is a whistle called the
> "tri-tone samba whistle" by Latin Percussion.
> It's fairly cheap (about 10-12 bucks), its pretty, and it plays three tones


At camping stores everywhere:
In the survival dept. there is a whistle without a ball. They are 
survival whistles with multiple pitches. 
They arefairly cheap (about 4-5 bucks), its flourscent orange and so you can be
spotted from far away when you fall off a ledge while eating lunch without 
being tied in (silly rock climber, you should know better than to fall 
and have your brains go spat on the ground cuz you didn't stay tied in) 
or I guess so you can find it if you drop it at a party...

dave

Weird day on the internet....

Yesterday, when I saw moonpup's post about spinning in his b.d. suit, I replied
(to the whole group).....

     Hey moonpup, I thought you promised to spin for us in drag.  That's
what I wanna see..  will you do it before you go to Europe?  

the header on the message was "Re: Nudity and ?????"

then this morning I come to work, sign on and .... here's a message from ... the
BIGGEST and most important client at my company right now, not known for a sense
of humor.... and it says (dum da dum dum) ...  "interesting message, Leslie, but
I have no idea what it means!)

Yikes, who needs the feds to monitor us when we can create indiscrete havoc all
on our own just by hitting the wrong address on our address list?    I swear to
be more cautious in the future!

Anyway, I promise you'll never see me out dancing naked with a whistle in my
mouth!  On my way to Berkeley to catch the last of the light!  Happy spring!

Leslie  : )

From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Beautiful Light!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi, everyone!  Went to the joyous, beautiful, happy, munchy Light today!!
And what can I say but SPRING IS HERE, Sunsets are starting up again, and
the feeling was in the air today at the Marina.  We've come full circle
again, it's time to emerge from the darkness of winter and celebrate
together out in the light of the coming spring and summer...

The feeling for me today was "begin again", and total joy.  Grassy hills of
the Marina dotted with many colorful beings, speaker stacks booming, the
sky turning its shades of pink and purple, the bay deepening into electric
blues...  Dogs cavorting, ravers hugging, baby toddling, people lining the
ridge at the top of the hill looked like they were dancing in the sky.
Many familiar faces made me realize how many friends I have made since the
quiet (for me) Sunsets of last year.   More faces were unfamiliar, but as I
looked out over probably 200 people, all there for the same reason as I
was, I felt the connection.

Thank you Gateway!  And see all of you Sunday! -- Nancy

Hi everybody,

It's me, volt, again.  I must first say that I haven't really been to a rave
thingie before, and I don't know if tonite counts (I was at Light at the
marina).  But anyways, I was just wondering, was that a typical gathering?
I had a good time, despite the fact I could scarcely get my friend to come
and dance as well, but I enjoyed sinking into the crowd and just losing
myself somewhere in front of a speaker and buried deep under a relentlessly
pulsating beat.

So anywayz, the reason I feel kinda goofy is that when I was there dancing,
I kinda stayed in my own little thing, kinda not turning around and shying
away from eye contact, and although I know it's probably quite silly to feel
so inhibited among such a spirited and spiritual crowd, I couldn't bring
myself out of "I am a rock, I am an island" mode.  I guess it just takes a
little getting used to???  I hope that's it, cuz I do want to try it out
again.  Can anyone suggest any parties of particular interest for the
weekend?  That Sunset thing sounds kinda promising, maybe I'll check that
one out.

Strength and harmony to all,

volt
the guy who feels a little goofy  ;)

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996 volt@best.com wrote:

> It's me, volt, again.  I must first say that I haven't really been to a ra
> So anywayz, the reason I feel kinda goofy is that when I was there dancing,
> I kinda stayed in my own little thing, kinda not turning around and shying
> away from eye contact, and although I know it's probably quite silly to feel
> so inhibited among such a spirited and spiritual crowd, I couldn't bring
> myself out of "I am a rock, I am an island" mode.  I guess it just takes a
> little getting used to???   

I felt a little isolated yesterday as well.  I found light to be a great 
way to start the spring.  It seemed that most of the people were more 
into hanging out than dancing until it started getting dark.  When its 
dark, I start to feel a little more isolated because i can't see anyone 
that well.  I did feel the vibe better when it was dark last night, 
probably because people were dancing closer or at least it seemed  that 
way, and maybe because I liked john howard's set the best.
I know its easier to open up to those around me, when i been dancing with 
them for a few hours.  There are other parties that are more dance 
focussed imo.  Those parties are easier for me to feel less inhibited on 
the dance floor.
Thank you all for that nice start of spring yesterday.  Yesterday felt 
like I was beginning to open up to a great season of outdoor parties as I 
felt the spring vibe blooming.  By sunset sunday I'll be more in full bloom.

:)
peter

I think that anyone who is trying out something new will be rather timid 
about it.  You don't really know what to anticipate and you probably 
don't know very many people (one of the good things about this list - 
meeting new friends!). Once you get more comfortable with the scene,  you 
will loosen up, so no worries. 

Good parties for the weekend?  Well, personally, if Chrysalis isn't 
happening, then I will be attending Something Special.  And of course, 
Sunset on Sunday.  Since there are so many new people on the list now, I 
will post a personal description tomarrow so you all can look for me @ 
Sunset.:)

love,
Amy

I want to thank everyone at Gateweay for putting on such a beautiful afternoon
for us yesterday!  

We got there at twilight, climbed right to the top of the hill where we could
see 360 degrees of twinkling lights around me, stars overhead, Venus shining
upon us, the crescent moon, and the most beautiful music I've heard in a long
time.. it was so perfect for the moment, I'll never forget it.  I actually saw
two shooting stars (hope I get my wishes!)

People were dancing everywhere, from the beautiful altar with candles and
flowers to the tops of the hills, total happiness!

Am I correct that it was Jon Howard spinning around sunset?  And then Galen?
Can someone post the lineup for me?

Thank you all for an amazing beginning of spring!

Hey, Goofy-feeling one!

        You should seriously consider going to Sunset!  It will be my first
one, but I've been to many other raves.  As far as typical goes, the common
denominators are usually:
Darkened indoor venues
Black lights and fluorescent painted tapestries
Cool lights, maybe some lasers
Hella phatt-to-the-max beats
Happy, smiling, loving, hugging, clapping, whistling, shouting ravers

You can go up to just about anyone, introduce yourself, share a handshake
and/or hug, and embrace this wonderful family, as they embrace you, into
each other's hearts.
        Did I get this right, people?  That's been my experience, anyway!

:)

- E

> doing.  A group of teenagers did that with an aryan bbs and tricked them 
> into giving them information such as people they were targeting,etc.  The 
> only problem is what we do to them could be done to us.
> 
> On Wed, 20 Mar 1996, 
> Cortney Nielson wrote:
> 
> > A neo-nazi group on our turf????
> > 
> > I GOT IT!!!!!
> > When they start up let's all log on and screw them all up!

> Cassandra


What the original poster proposed was not monitoring.
 
What if some self-righteous ass decided that ravers were just a bunch of 
drug-using and dealing miscreants who had no respect for property 
rights(tresspass) and decided they would come on to S.F. Raves, that den 
of inequity, and "screw them all up?" 

There is a little document called the Constitution that seemingly means less 
and less as time goes on. Study it. 

Going onto someone elses newsgroup with the intent of "screwing them up" 
makes you little better than they are. 

Also you will find that the Internet as a whole is not very tolerant of 
censorship of materials posted in their appropriate place, and many 
owners and operators of Internet-connected system, myself included, would 
not hesitate to boot you for this kind of childish crap.

                                             Black Adder

             <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960321091706.9072A-100000@value.net>

BlackAdder writez:
>There is a little document called the Constitution that seemingly means less 
>and less as time goes on. Study it. 
>
>Going onto someone elses newsgroup with the intent of "screwing them up" 
>makes you little better than they are. 

Argument, discussion, and disagreement, etc are not unconstitutional.
Preventing any group from assembling and discussing their views is.
That's why I'm not voting on the white-power rock newsgroup.
Furthermore, since this group is open to everybody, "screwing them up"
could be as simple as having a majority of nay-sayers step in and
trample all over their shoddy thinking, false logic, and lies. This is
different than having to listen to Joeseph Goebbels over a megaphone
(because we all have equally loud megaphones) or having a dangerous
non-interactive web site that spreads lies (which I've posted about in
the past, with requests to e-mail-bomb and hack their site).

Note however, that "hate words" and "incitement to riot" are illegal,
though scant case history in these areas exists to make the application
of the law clear. If the white power groups are using these forms of
communications, then perhaps it might be worthwhile to press charges on
those grounds. <<Sound of can of worms opening>>...

I'm personally waiting for those fucks to go on-line, so I can flame
them (not with "hate words" or "incitement to riot") but rather with
idiot-baiting argument and discourse. Since they have guns and are
psychotically stupid, one would be wise to do it via an anonymous
remailer...

Also note that the arguments that "white power" is not a subcategory of
"alt.rock" (or whatever) are false, since there's plenty of
"white-power" oriented metal, hardcore, oi, and "punk rock" (RIP).
Please note that a lot of this white power oriented music has strong
appeal to the god-squad -- I posit we'll see a strong fascist/christian
movement appear during the next recession, lead by folks like Pat
Buchanan and his neo-nazi/christian buddies like David Duke, Tom
Metzger, etc. (Tom Metzger, incidentally, is one of the leading
organizers and promoters of "white power" music --  even Hitler knew
the power of mass spectacle, music, and rhythm to hypnotize and
brainwash the minds of "followers" (that is, people too stupid and too
unalalytical to think for themselves)).

I personally want to hear what everybody has to say. If it annoys me
I'll change the channel or not read the newsgroup.

PS: More conspiratorially, it is possible that this whole call for
votes thing is simply a case study perpetrated by the FBI -- to see how
powerful and far-reaching the internet can be in terms of getting
people to rally for (or against) a morally, ethically, and racially
divisive cause. Then they'll apply the internet clampdown as
appropriate in preparation for the times when they're called to enforce
fascism....

Hi all,

	After sending a few messages to the list, I realized I hadn't
introduced myself to the group... not wanting to break any traditional
rules of this 'oh so cool group' :) ... here I go. 

	I am Michael Albers, and was born on March 13 1971, in
Amsterdam (the Netherlands), I moved to the US (california) 6 years ago.
Why you ask? Well, I felt I had to escape the pattern
I was falling into there, so thought I'd go ahead and attend school here,
and now... before it hit me, I'm graduating from San Jose State (finally!).

	Before I moved to the US, I went to some raves in Amsterdam, 
but weren't that great. I am absolutely thrilled and very
fascinated with the 'phat' parties I've been to here, I love every minute
of it... the music.. the people.. the peace.. the love.. ... too groovy
for words.

	Well, won't make this too long, but at least wanted to introduce
myself... next time your at a party, look for a tall 6'4", Brown haired,
blue eyed Dutch dude going completely bonkers on the tunes.. :)

	Keep the peace and love flowing ... I love this group! :)

Peace and hugz,

Michael
mal@zoom.com
http://www.zoom.com/personal/mal

Reminds me of a Scorpions lyric:
Oh, no - don't make no promises
Oh, no - your body can't keep

I think it's a good idea to avoid making a promise whenever possible.
That's because if I make a promise, I'll do whatever I can to fulfill it.
A promise should be the same as giving your highest word on something, and
since we can't predict enough of the future, it's iffy to make the kind of
promise Leslie made (no disrespect to you, Leslie!).

Ever the rocker - I promise!

- E

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

[snip]> 
> I'm personally waiting for those fucks to go on-line, so I can flame

> I'll change the channel or not read the newsgroup.

  Niels:

  I really hope that neither you, nor anyone else from SFRaves, goes into
that list with the idea of badgering them or treating them like loathsome
insects. They are human beings too, and have come to their positions
through some experience in their lives that drove them to adopt the
position they have. 
  Practically speaking, I hope that you don't do this because of the old 
adage:
     "Don't ever get into a pissing match with a skunk."   :<)

  On a higher level, why not adopt a rave attitude: accept who they are 
(not what they believe in) and dance with them. Show them your good 
moves, and the reasons why harmony feels better than dissonance. I 
guarantee that if you dump all over them, you'll only harden them in 
their racism. Be kind, try to find a wedge of agreement -- 
African-American contributions to American music = a good start, and work 
from there.
  All this assumes that you would like to help them out, and not just 
scream at them, or bait them and treat them with disrespect.
  Just my thoughts.
--------------------
  "To rave is to affirm."

Light was a beautiful gathering, so much diversity and love.  Being 
outdoors and in the daylight for your first dance party 
can be a little distracting.  At indoor parties the enclosed dance floor 
is more conducive to making that spiritual connection with the 
people around you.  Lasers, projection screens, candles, ambient rooms, 
are nice additions to the experience.  
I tottaly understand what you said about being unable to connect with 
the vibe.   Feeling awkward on the dance floor pretty much describes the 
majority of my experiences at raves. (I tend to wobble and move too 
fast)  It's especially hard when your friends are rooted and you have to 
venture  out on your own.  The best thing to do IMHO is dance, dance hard 
and dance often. and don't forget to smile.  Everyone  gets into the 
groove sooner or later.


Love harmony and positivity
Jack Chang

>

> >There is a little document called the Constitution that seemingly means less 
> >and less as time goes on. Study it. 
> >
> >Going onto someone elses newsgroup with the intent of "screwing them up" 
> >makes you little better than they are. 
> 
> Argument, discussion, and disagreement, etc are not unconstitutional.
> Preventing any group from assembling and discussing their views is.
> That's why I'm not voting on the white-power rock newsgroup.
> Furthermore, since this group is open to everybody, "screwing them up"
> could be as simple as having a majority of nay-sayers step in and
> trample all over their shoddy thinking, false logic, and lies. This is
> different than having to listen to Joeseph Goebbels over a megaphone
> (because we all have equally loud megaphones) or having a dangerous
> non-interactive web site that spreads lies (which I've posted about in
> the past, with requests to e-mail-bomb and hack their site).

I have no problem with this. Absolutely, 100%. When someone says "let's go 
screw with them" however, I generally do not take this is as "let's go 
engage in debate."  
 
> I'm personally waiting for those fucks to go on-line, so I can flame
> them (not with "hate words" or "incitement to riot") but rather with
> idiot-baiting argument and discourse. Since they have guns and are
> psychotically stupid, one would be wise to do it via an anonymous
> remailer...

Find a hobby. ;-)

> 
> Also note that the arguments that "white power" is not a subcategory of
> "alt.rock" (or whatever) are false, since there's plenty of
> "white-power" oriented metal, hardcore, oi, and "punk rock" (RIP).

The entire Usenet is based on categorization and sub-categorization, so 
this argument doesn't float. There is a lot of metal, hard-core, and punk 
that is *not* white-power oriented, so lumping them all together does 
everyone a disservice. 
> 
> PS: More conspiratorially, it is possible that this whole call for
> votes thing is simply a case study perpetrated by the FBI -- to see how
> powerful and far-reaching the internet can be in terms of getting
> people to rally for (or against) a morally, ethically, and racially
> divisive cause. Then they'll apply the internet clampdown as
> appropriate in preparation for the times when they're called to enforce
> fascism....

No, the request for votes is a tradition for additions to Usenet. The 
only reason this one got so much press was because of the controversial 
nature of the subject matter. I wonder where everyone was when they were 
taking votes on alt.binaries.pedophilia.....

                                         Black Adder

Living in the Netherlands (Utrecht) myself I was kinda curious what 
makes the SF-vibe that different from the one in Amsterdam/the Nether-
lands. Could you elaborate on that? I'm sure ravers in San Francisco 
want to hear what makes them special too.  


By the way, seeing everyone introducing themselves,... 
...
My name is Bart Meijerink (27-12-72). At the moment I study Urban
Planning in Amsterdam and live in Utrecht. I dj now for about six years  
(I'm not famous or anything though). At the moment I'm organising parties 
(200-300 pp) in Utrecht at a place called Ekko, as well as dj-ing there. 
I became interested in housemusic in '88/'89 when I heard tunes like 'Voodoo 
Ray' by a Guy called Gerald and 'Bounce your body to the box' by Kevin 
Saunderson. I'm mostly into Detroit-techno (especially by Robert Hood/
Jeff Mills) and acid, but I also like some of the harder stuff as well as 
the more cluboriented music (people over here call it 'mellow', dunno why) 
as well as some jungle. I also make music myself (on my own as well as with 
friends).
Around the time I got my internetaccount I read about this list 
somewhere and became interested. I'm on the list for about 3 months now, but 
have rarely posted anyting. Due to the lack of time I don't read all e-mails, 
but I enjoy the ones that I do read.
Oh yeah, I'm heading for Prague in a few weeks together with bands 'the 
Human Beings (dv8)', 'Acid Junkies (djax-up)' and 'Human in Paradize (music man)' 
(betcha have never heard of them). That will be fun.

I hope I'll get a chance to visit SF in the future to taste some of that 
sfrave flavour.

Bye!
(by the way, did you know 'gabber' is a Dutch word?)


Bart

The reason the kids went on-line with the group to begin with is the 
aryan group was compiling an dress list of gay mn and lesbian in their 
rea which they could bash. The boys simply asked for tht information by 
logging on so as to warn the people.  I am not against the group being on 
the internet; that is their right.  I am also worried tht if we rely on a 
government agency to monitor the internet, we ll will lose our rights to 
free speech in this medium. Ravers are feared by the government as any 
other non-mainstream group.  It is up to us to make sure we know what is 
going on for hell, let's face it, groups such as the one we are talking 
about 
aare dangerous.  I stopped going to a lot of punk shows in new york 
because of violence caused by skinheads. Luckily I found raving. . 

Anyway, I hope to see people at Sunset and making a show that we all are 
not members of any the groups we have been discussing

> Argument, discussion, and disagreement, etc are not unconstitutional.
> Preventing any group from assembling and discussing their views is.
> That's why I'm not voting on the white-power rock newsgroup.
> Furthermore, since this group is open to everybody, "screwing them up"
> could be as simple as having a majority of nay-sayers step in and
> trample all over their shoddy thinking, false logic, and lies. This is
> different than having to listen to Joeseph Goebbels over a megaphone
> (because we all have equally loud megaphones) or having a dangerous
> non-interactive web site that spreads lies (which I've posted about in
> the past, with requests to e-mail-bomb and hack their site).
> 
> Note however, that "hate words" and "incitement to riot" are illegal,
> though scant case history in these areas exists to make the application

> communications, then perhaps it might be worthwhile to press charges on
> those grounds. <<Sound of can of worms opening>>...
> 
> I'm personally waiting for those fucks to go on-line, so I can flame
> them (not with "hate words" or "incitement to riot") but rather with
> idiot-baiting argument and discourse. Since they have guns and are
> psychotically stupid, one would be wise to do it via an anonymous
> remailer...
> 
> Also note that the arguments that "white power" is not a subcategory of
> "alt.rock" (or whatever) are false, since there's plenty of
> "white-power" oriented metal, hardcore, oi, and "punk rock" (RIP).
> Please note that a lot of this white power oriented music has strong
> appeal to the god-squad -- I posit we'll see a strong fascist/christian
> movement appear during the next recession, lead by folks like Pat
> Buchanan and his neo-nazi/christian buddies like David Duke, Tom
> Metzger, etc. (Tom Metzger, incidentally, is one of the leading
> organizers and promoters of "white power" music --  even Hitler knew
> the power of mass spectacle, music, and rhythm to hypnotize and
> brainwash the minds of "followers" (that is, people too stupid and too
> unalalytical to think for themselves)).
> 
> I personally want to hear what everybody has to say. If it annoys me
> I'll change the channel or not read the newsgroup.
> 
> PS: More conspiratorially, it is possible that this whole call for
> votes thing is simply a case study perpetrated by the FBI -- to see how
> powerful and far-reaching the internet can be in terms of getting
> people to rally for (or against) a morally, ethically, and racially
> divisive cause. Then they'll apply the internet clampdown as
> appropriate in preparation for the times when they're called to enforce
> fascism....
> 
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> ==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>

RaveSlang Dictionary Volume 1


the bomb     really good
candyflip     combining acid and ecstasy
hippieflip     combining mushrooms and ecstasy
peace!         "good-bye"
phat            cool! (adjective, not an interjection)
the shit       the best
spin            1. what a dj does
                  2. smoking pot while drunk
went off      was good


can you add to the list?

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996 volt@best.com 
wrote:

> Hi everybody,
> 
> It's me, volt, again.  I must first say that I haven't really been to a rave
> thingie before, and I don't know if tonite counts (I was at Light at the
> marina).  But anyways, I was just wondering, was that a typical gathering?
> I had a good time, despite the fact I could scarcely get my friend to come
> and dance as well, but I enjoyed sinking into the crowd and just losing
> myself somewhere in front of a speaker and buried deep under a relentlessly
> pulsating beat.
> 
> So anywayz, the reason I feel kinda goofy is that when I was there dancing,
> I kinda stayed in my own little thing, kinda not turning around and shying
> away from eye contact, and although I know it's probably quite silly to feel
> so inhibited among such a spirited and spiritual crowd, I couldn't bring
> myself out of "I am a rock, I am an island" mode.  I guess it just takes a
> little getting used to???  I hope that's it, cuz I do want to try it out
> again.  Can anyone suggest any parties of particular interest for the
> weekend?  That Sunset thing sounds kinda promising, maybe I'll check that
> one out.
> 
> Strength and harmony to all,
> 
> volt
> the guy who feels a little goofy  ;)
> 
>

                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, [34]send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   [35]majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to [36]majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   [37][38][39]
   
   
    [40]Derek Chung - [41]dhchung@hyperreal.com

Hell, as long as everyone is introducing themselves, guess I will, too:

My name is Tony Mizukami. I'm new to the Bay Area, having just moved here
from Japan, where I've been living for the past 3+ years. I'm originally
from Atlanta. There is no real rave scene in either place (as far as I
could tell!), but I've felt strangely attracted to it ever since first
hearing about it several years ago. I've been lurking on sfraves for a few
days now, and from what I've seen everyone seems to be really groovy. I'm
looking forward to meeting you all.

BTW, I'm not Japanese (I took the name "Mizukami" from my wife), so if you
were to look for me, oh, I don't know, say at Something Special and/or
Sunset, then I'd be a 5'8", 28 y.o. caucasian male, blue eyes, short brown
hair, glasses, looking lost 'cuz I don't know anybody yet! I'm a bit of a
shy one, so please come up and introduce yourself.

See 'ya then,

-Tony  (^_^)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 21 17:35:47 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA16163; Thu, 21 Mar 1996 17:35:47 -0800

Received: from tgrigsby.vip.best.com (tgrigsby.vip.best.com [205.149.169.221]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id RAA03517 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 21 Mar 1996 17:33:05 -0800
Date: Thu, 21 Mar 1996 17:33:05 -0800
Message-Id: <199603220133.RAA03517@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Hate and the White-Power newsgroup
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've seen quite a bit going around lately about this white-power newsgroup.  
Here's my take on it:

1. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech.  I'm not telling anyone 
anything they haven't heard before with that statement.  My contribution to 
this old line is: the First Amendment is a nice beginning.  One thing that I 
don't think should be protected is Hate.  Period.  And to that end I think 
that someone, somewhere, should draft a new amendment to the constitution 
that qualifies the freedoms under the First Amendment to not include, 
specifically, Hate.

2. Given the current status of the Constitution and it's Amendments, I think 
they absolutely should have a forum in which to express themselves.  This 
will make it easier to identify them and add their names to my Anti-Hate 
page.  This is something John S. Lee and I chatted briefly about a couple of 
weeks ago.  I'm going to donate the disk space and web domain for a page 
dedicated solely to exposing people who indulge in Hate propoganda and/or 
are members of Hate-oriented or supporting organizations and political 
groups.  This white-power forum will save me a lot of time and trouble 
finding individuals that fall into that category and getting quotes from 
them.  I'll simply monitor their forum, along with other forums, pull quotes 
from their own writings, and post them along with their identities if 
possible, their e-mail addresses at the least.  I intend to hold them up, 
sans the white hoods, for all the world to see.  I hope to keep this 
coverage objective, allowing others to formulate their own opinions.

Also, as part of this Anti-Hate page, I want to begin some kind of 
discussion on a legal definition of what constitutes Hate so that this may 
be available to interested legislators.  And I want to recognize and support 
all Anti-Hate organizations, carrying web links, phone numbers, addresses, 
etc., for those groups.

I think the major difference between this and mail-bombing/hacking their 
news forum is, I'd be darned proud if they put an alert against me on their 
page.  I doubt they'll feel the same if I do that to them.  They'd have to 
be a little more creative -- and illegal -- than simply fight fire with fire 
to strike back at me.

One last thing: I highly respect the views of the people on this list.  I 
would invite any input on how the Anti-Hate page should look and what it 
should include.  I hope to have a first draft of it up and available some 
time over the weekend.  It will be overly simple at first, I'm sure, but 
with everyone's help, it will grow.

Todd Grigsby

Precedence: bulk

Fellow groovers...

    I am in need of a flavor...

          The deliverer of which shall go down in history,

                        and receive the everlasting posi-vibe...
My story... 

There was this tape...not just any tape... but a special tape. You know, 
one of those tapes that you can let autoreverse over and over and over 
and it sounds better each time.  Well, this tape belonged to a very good 
friend of mine and I *borrowed* it from his car one night >;)   I 
grooved to it for quite some time, embracing the high energy and awesome 
saxophone licks. A few months later I was on my way to a halloween party 
in the Santa Cruz mountains and brought the tape with me to listen to in 
the car we were going up in.  Well, when we got there, I forgot to get 
the tape from the girl driving (not a direct friend of mine) and when I 
tried retrieve my grooves, I found out that she had moved to 
NEW MEXICO!!! No address, no phone, no nothing.  

I have tried to locate this tape since then and nobody has it. It is 
fairly old (probably '93/'94ish) and was part of the VISION set of 
tapes. (I think there were 5 or so DJ's that had tapes made from that 
party but I'm not sure...)

It is called "DJ GARTH: VISION"

Anyway, If anyone has a copy of this tape, I will gladly pay 20$ for a 
copy of it. Or, just some info on how to get it would be greatly 
appreciated.

                        Thank you all for caring....
May you all find that missing track/tape/CD you've been searching for 
and gave up on...

        Jah!
                                
-Steve
smorgan@best.com

Although I disagree with neo-nazis, this (the net) is a 
public forum. Free speech is more important than rabid opinions.

Basically, nobody forces anyone to forward _any_ newsgroup anyway...
Thank God, it's a free country. Gives the feds an easy way to keep tabs 
on them too..

I don't think most net people like neo-nazis.. so their 
newsgroup will probably be unpopular.. But it has a right to exist.
That makes me a little sick too, but I have to say it.

Some people probably have strong feelings about ravers.. Would you want them 
to have the power to remove alt.rave from the net?

The net.cops already are out of control..

Just my opinion.


-Chris.

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996, SDream wrote:

> I've seen quite a bit going around lately about this white-power newsgroup.  
> Here's my take on it:
> 
> 1. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech.  I'm not telling anyone 
> anything they haven't heard before with that statement.  My contribution to 
> this old line is: the First Amendment is a nice beginning.  One thing that I 
> don't think should be protected is Hate.  Period.  And to that end I think 
> that someone, somewhere, should draft a new amendment to the constitution 
> that qualifies the freedoms under the First Amendment to not include, 
> specifically, Hate.

	I wonder if hate is illegalized, if it will follow the road of 
our parties and move a bit more underground where the stock pile of 
weapons and random murder increases?
	Making something illegal does not squash it (look at us, legal or 
illegal party, is that a consideration when you choose which you are 
going to?) and more importantly, it never addresses the root of the 
problem, which happens to be fear (at least in my opinion). How can you 
make fear illegal? You cannot sit down with someone and say,"you will not 
fear me taking your jobs away or the purity of your race because I am not 
going to take YOUR jobs away, and I am not making your race impure". I 
don't what else they preach, but by passing a law, you are not going to 
address these issues and before you can get rid of hate, you have to 
address them. Otherwise, you are going to push them into the shadows to 
mull over and over how they are being "repressed" and when they do act, 
it will be from the stand point of a corner or caged animal trying to 
free itself (in a much more hostile way).
	So how you go about addressing these issues? I don't know yet...

dave

For those who thought that Pack-a-bowl was a strange concept...there's
an interesting article in this week's Newsweek about something called
"Cosmic Bowling" (I think).  It describes techno, fog, uv-lights, and
glow in the dark bowling balls and pins.  Apparently hundreds of
bowling alleys across the country are changing over to this new
format.  Although the r-word was never used, there was the
unmistakable influence...

David

P.S. A search produced an amusing article on the subject at
http://www.tpc1.com/asrg/cedar.html#cosmic  (a bowling alley's web
page!)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
WWW:  My URL is http://www.crl.com/~davidmin/
This website is not yet rated.

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996, SDream wrote:

> I've seen quite a bit going around lately about this white-power newsgroup.  
> Here's my take on it:
> 
> 1. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech.  I'm not telling anyone 
> anything they haven't heard before with that statement.  My contribution to 
> this old line is: the First Amendment is a nice beginning.  One thing that I 
> don't think should be protected is Hate.  Period.  And to that end I think 
> that someone, somewhere, should draft a new amendment to the constitution 
> that qualifies the freedoms under the First Amendment to not include, 
> specifically, Hate.

Well, you're wrong. Like it or not, for better, and sometimes for worse, 
much of what this country was founded on was hate. Hatred of religious 
persecution, hatred of a monarchy, and hatred of the dearth of rights 
possesed by the colonists(which admittedly makes the treatment of the 
native peoples and minorities all the more puzzling,) all helped lead to 
the founding of this country.  

Hate, like unconditional love, can be healthy. It can also be one of the 
most destructive forces in the universe. It is all a matter of 
application, direction and motive. Have you ever in your life seen an 
injustice, and been so incensed that you were moved to speak out, or 
take action to help correct the injustice? 

You cannot simply legislate hate away. It is the equivalant of sticking 
your head in your nether regions. 
  
> 2. Given the current status of the Constitution and it's Amendments, I think 
> they absolutely should have a forum in which to express themselves.  This 
> will make it easier to identify them and add their names to my Anti-Hate 
> page.  This is something John S. Lee and I chatted briefly about a couple of 
> weeks ago.  I'm going to donate the disk space and web domain for a page 
> dedicated solely to exposing people who indulge in Hate propoganda and/or 
> are members of Hate-oriented or supporting organizations and political 
> groups.  This white-power forum will save me a lot of time and trouble 
> finding individuals that fall into that category and getting quotes from 
> them.  I'll simply monitor their forum, along with other forums, pull quotes 
> from their own writings, and post them along with their identities if 
> possible, their e-mail addresses at the least.  I intend to hold them up, 
> sans the white hoods, for all the world to see.  I hope to keep this 
> coverage objective, allowing others to formulate their own opinions.

While I totally support this, and am sure I will visit your site, by 
your own words you demonstrate that you are *not* objective. You, like the 
groups and individuals you hope to expose, have an agenda. 

> Also, as part of this Anti-Hate page, I want to begin some kind of 
> discussion on a legal definition of what constitutes Hate so that this may 
> be available to interested legislators.  And I want to recognize and support 
> all Anti-Hate organizations, carrying web links, phone numbers, addresses, 
> etc., for those groups.

The first thing I would propose is that you not call yourself an 
Anti-Hate group. From your words, you aren't. You don't plan on "loving" 
these hate groups away, do you? 

> One last thing: I highly respect the views of the people on this list.  I 
> would invite any input on how the Anti-Hate page should look and what it 
> should include.  I hope to have a first draft of it up and available some 
> time over the weekend.  It will be overly simple at first, I'm sure, but 
> with everyone's help, it will grow.
> 

Here are a few suggestions for inclusions(apologies for possible spelling 
errors): Bnai Bnai, The PLO, The IRA, anything to do with Metzger, and Louis 
Farrakahn for starters.

                                           Black Adder

On Thu, 21 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > Anyway, I hope to see people at Sunset and making a show that we all are 
> > not members of any the groups we have been discussing
> 
> Here's a loaded question for you:  Could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?
> 
> Lee
> 
Dear lee,

Good Question, I guess it depends on how you define a raver.  Once, 
because I had not gone to many raves, i would not identify myself as a 
raver because I did not feel i could claim the label legitimately. My 
 boyfriend, however, stated he felt that was a stupid choice becausw he 
felt what values you held defined whether you were a raver or not: a 
raver he argued understands the importance of consciousness, diversity, 
and holds mother earth in the ultimate respect (his point being how could 
you otherwise achieve transcendence outside dancing if you do not 
appreciate what you are seeing)!  Whether a neo-nazi could be a raver or 
not depends on whether you wish to make a value judgement on what rave 
is.  My impulse would be that they're not, just partiers, if they happen 
to attend the events because they don't hold the value of respect for a 
value of rave that I deem essential : the value of 
diversity at the parties and the variety of experiances that comes out of 
a melee of cool and different people sharing the music.  But as long as 
they did not hurt people or caused trouble I guess it would not be in the 
spirit to bar them from attending an event.  I don't know......What are your 
thoughts?

  Cassandra

I use to go to to a place in Livermore(E.Bay) near my home town that had
midnight bowl on friday and saturday nights a year or two ago...They had a
DJ spinning top 40, requests, but mostly hip-hop...Lights were off except
for the lanes, of course, and they had colored pins (no glow-in-the-dark
stuff though).  A great time was had by all - boogie n' bowlin' the night
away...till some dumb-ass wanna-be gangbangers shot someone, out in front
one night(over a bowling match and a girl).  They closed it down shortly
after that.
      Never been to Pac'a'bowl yet but I haven't had the SPARE (he-he) time.

On Fri, 22 Mar 1996, Eric P. Peterson wrote:

> >Well, you're wrong. Like it or not, for better, and sometimes for worse,
> >much of what this country was founded on was hate. Hatred of religious
> >persecution, hatred of a monarchy, and hatred of the dearth of rights
> >possesed by the colonists(which admittedly makes the treatment of the
> >native peoples and minorities all the more puzzling,) all helped lead to
> >the founding of this country.
> 
> I wouldn't say that hate was the motivation for the above.  I'd say it was
> a feeling of persecution, or righteous indignation.

Was there a great amount of love felt for King George and the British? 
Don't think so. 'Righteous indignation' and  'hate' can both be used to 
adequately describe what was going on.

> >Hate, like unconditional love, can be healthy. It can also be one of the
> >most destructive forces in the universe. It is all a matter of
> >application, direction and motive. Have you ever in your life seen an
> >injustice, and been so incensed that you were moved to speak out, or
> >take action to help correct the injustice?
> 
> Compassion dictates that we love our enemies.  Moral integrity demands that
> we hate only that which is evil.  It's difficult to reconcile these ideas.

*Your* compassion, *your* moral integrity. My moral integrity allows me 
to hate things that are wrong. Something being wrong does not make it 
inheriently evil. You are correct, reconciling these ideas is difficult.

> >You cannot simply legislate hate away. It is the equivalant of sticking
> >your head in your nether regions.
> >
> Sounds like there is no "answer," except to leave "them" alone as long as
> they leave "us" alone.  Adopt a vigilant, defensive posture, but provoke
> nothing.

> >Here's a loaded question for you:  Could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?
> 
> Anything's possible, although I think such a person would be turned off by
> all the PLUR...

Y'know, a *lot* of people are turned off by all "the PLUR".  The real
strength and magic of raving is not PLUR, it's what happens when we 
allow the MUSIC to take us to a higher place.  PLUR separated from
a tangible source can start to feel contrived, especially amongst
diverse people who don't really have that much in common.  It's our
love and connection with certain kinds of music that unites us and gives
us the means to harmonize our minds and bodies with each other.  I 
sometimes feel that people who are into the rave scene mainly for the 
PLUR actually weaken it in the long run if they don't participate in 
activity that truly creates it - namely, dancing your ass with
everyone around you.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

>Well, you're wrong. Like it or not, for better, and sometimes for worse,
>much of what this country was founded on was hate. Hatred of religious
>persecution, hatred of a monarchy, and hatred of the dearth of rights
>possesed by the colonists(which admittedly makes the treatment of the
>native peoples and minorities all the more puzzling,) all helped lead to
>the founding of this country.

I wouldn't say that hate was the motivation for the above.  I'd say it was
a feeling of persecution, or righteous indignation.

>Hate, like unconditional love, can be healthy. It can also be one of the
>most destructive forces in the universe. It is all a matter of
>application, direction and motive. Have you ever in your life seen an
>injustice, and been so incensed that you were moved to speak out, or
>take action to help correct the injustice?

Compassion dictates that we love our enemies.  Moral integrity demands that
we hate only that which is evil.  It's difficult to reconcile these ideas.

>You cannot simply legislate hate away. It is the equivalant of sticking
>your head in your nether regions.
>
Sounds like there is no "answer," except to leave "them" alone as long as
they leave "us" alone.  Adopt a vigilant, defensive posture, but provoke
nothing.

That's my two francs.

Peace,

- E

To: senator@leland.Stanford.EDU (Cassandra Ann Thomas)

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.960321215925.25470A-100000@elaine13.Stanford.EDU>; from "Cassandra Ann Thomas" at Mar 21, 96 10:16 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> > Here's a loaded question for you:  Could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?
 
> Good Question, I guess it depends on how you define a raver.

Yep, and to open an even bigger can of worms, it depends on how
people define themselves.  I.e. I may call myself a "raver", but
that is not ever *just* what I am.

> [...] what values you held defined whether you were a raver or not: a 
> raver he argued understands the importance of consciousness, diversity, 
> and holds mother earth in the ultimate respect (his point being how could 
> you otherwise achieve transcendence outside dancing if you do not 
> appreciate what you are seeing)!

I hold the view that if someone is at a rave, and is having a
transcendental experience (i.e. leaving behind ego, connecting with
the group vibe, etc.) then they are raving.  

>  My impulse would be that they're not, just partiers, if they happen 
> to attend the events because they don't hold the value of respect for a 
> value of rave that I deem essential : the value of 
> diversity at the parties and the variety of experiances that comes out of 
> a melee of cool and different people sharing the music.

I'd like to think that there is a universally seductive appeal to
the experience of the values you have described, and that if a Neo-Nazi
went to a rave just to party and started having a good time...

To argue with a Neo-Nazi is a waste of time.  At best, you win,
make them feel stupid and make them hate you more.  On the other
hand, tell them that you respect their feelings as something real and
genuine.  But show them something better; love that rivals the
comradary of their fellow hate-mongers, adrenaline rushes more
intense than an act of violence, a light show more dazzling than
a burning cross...

Perhaps a Neo-Nazi, like any of us, will not be able to shed all
their shit just because they rave.  But if they become ravers on
the dance floor it would be the first step towards loosening the grip
ignorance holds over them.  I think this is possible.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Even though I am new to the list, I have been on the fringes of rave for a
few years, thanks to my son (and friend).  Here's my story - the short form:

My name is Paul Keen - been doing music for decades, mostly big band, shows,
movies and stuff like that.  I guess I am proof that rave has no age limits
either way - I'm nearly 50 - so you can add creaking bones to the list of
noisemakers.

After following everyone's action from the list for the last week or so, you
all have reminded me that rave is not a music form, but a state of mind.
 Maybe in this election year the only important question to ask the
candidates is "do you rave?"  After all, it's awfully hard to dance out there
with a nuke in your pocket.

If there is any question about rave's legitimacy, I found out about the
website from the "Official Netscape Navigator 2.0 Book" in Chapter 11 - "Our
Favorite Net Resources."  Does this mean you are all mainstream now?
(Shudder).

Please help me with a perplexing problem - I have not heard from DJ
CHRISTOPHE for over a year.  I pray he hasn't gone to the big party in the
sky - but maybe is seeing the world - this time without the help of the Navy.
 If anyone has any info, please give me a shout.  It will calm my nerves a
whole bunch.

You've been a lot of fun to follow.  Hope you don't mind if I stick around a
little while.

pk

I guess you dont pay much attention to this list-ya we all have different
reasons for going out, but there are still many of us who are somewhat
politically aware!!
*Any* government(corporation) fears *any* group of people who are
organized(even if only on weekends) and regulary disregard"laws" they see
as hippocritical and wastefull, Any government also hates any group that
even try's to be multiracial, pluralistic and outside commercialy allowed
constraints,b/c  as always change comes from *outside* the mainstream,
otherwise it would'nt be change!! and those in power be definition*hate*
change!  
We ARE feared, but maybee not for long i.e. Ive been seeing some fliers
lately(space children) that are blatent addvertisments for record labels
and even Virgin,a HUGE  multinational corporation, thats NOT a rave but a
10 hr. commercial!!-fuck that! But thats a whole diff. topic
Mark
 

>> Ravers are feared by the government as any
>>other non-mainstream group.
>
>don't bank on it.
>
>i honestly don't see why the government would fear us.  someone said this
>awhile ago, and i think they pretty much hit the nail on the head:  most
>ravers care about how good the party was on saturday, how fucked up they
>got on saturday, who was at the party on saturday....and where are they
>going this saturday?  who is gonna be there?  how frucked up are we gonna
>get?  etc etc, and that's pretty much it.
>
>i don't really see how any of us could inspire fear into anyone, especially
>the u.s. government.
>
>love, luck, and lollipops,
>michael
>allroy

>*Any* government(corporation) fears *any* group of people who are

would?  when you see yourself as the most powerful organization in the
world, you tend to get a bit arrogant.  at least, i would imagine....

From: Marc Pfister <mjpfister@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez045207@rocky.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Review : Diversity
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960322121849.20164A-100000@rocky.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, Me and the man like Jerecho made the drive from Davis up to the 
north end of Sac to check out a new party to the area, Diversity.
The virtual flyer said trance and jungle, and being a junglist myself, I 
had to go check it out. Jungle in Sacramento? I thought I was the only one...
After a somewhat roundabout drive we finally got to the Boardwalk, which 
as far as I know is one of Sac's long running rock band -type bars. As we 
got out of the car we were greeted by lots of bass coming through the wall.
Cover was $5, a little steep for my taste, but considering the people who 
were running it was worth the investment to help out our scene. I was 
greeted at the door by  Flash and Mia, two long-time Sac scenesters. I 
also met DJ Wizrd, one of the promoters and he was really friendly. Also 
me Chris, fellow SFRaver, another great guy, sorry I didn't get a chanve 
to chat with him more.
On the decks was Dj Adrian. Later on I found out that it was the frist 
time he had played breakbeats out to a crowd, but I never would have 
known. This kid was smooth. When we got there we was playing sme wacked 
out breakbeat, around 140 bpm but with heavy basslines, almost jungle-y. 
A few records later I started to recognize some old drum 'n bass tunes 
from '93 but they sounded really slow. We were trying to figure what 
exactly he was playing, if this kid was on some new breakbeat style, 
slower than jungle but with the same production style, when Adrian 
dropped "Let it Roll" by DJ Crystl. I know the song well,and we finally 
figured out that he was pitching all his his jungle records down to the 
older hardcore tempos. But as his set progressed it sped up. He played s 
variety of jungle, mostly older Moving Shadow-type tracks (Lord of the Null 
Lines) to some more recent releases (Lemon D, Solo & Aura). It was  great 
to hear some jungle up here. The samll crowd didn't seem to totally get 
it though, but after a bit more exposure and some more people, it should 
get jumping like the Top on Saturdays.
After Adrian Flash came on. He played one jungle song to pay homage to 
the junglists and then switched to more of a house/trance type set. I had 
to leave midway because I'm still in finals week, but Flash was doing a 
good job while I was there.
The crowd was sadly rather sparse, but for a  first night in Sac I would 
have been amazed if it was packed. With a bit more promotion and some 
more word-of-mouth it could grow to decent proportions. Even if things do 
not end up succesful at that venue, the promoters should find some 
success in the future. Their goals seem to be motivated only be love for 
the music and their growing scene. I saw not one bit of attitude from any 
of them and they actually seemed happy to chat about things.
They said they plan to try to throw another in two weeks. If you live in 
or near Sac I highly recommend going. Sac has a small scene, very young, 
but it can definately grow. There are a lot of enthusiastic people ready 
to make things happen. Lets do it!

hannibal selecta

On Fri, 22 Mar 1996, michael mccusty wrote:

> i honestly don't see why the government would fear us.  someone said this
> awhile ago, and i think they pretty much hit the nail on the head:  most
> ravers care about how good the party was on saturday, how fucked up they
> got on saturday, who was at the party on saturday....and where are they
> going this saturday?  who is gonna be there?  how frucked up are we gonna
> get?  etc etc, and that's pretty much it.

	Whether or not they fear the average "raver" is one thing, but a 
culture which tends to head toward the break of free of capitalistic 
normals (before I am sorely corrected on this, I will have to limit my 
statement - While some people are moving away from the capitalist based 
culture, most of us are moving away from a culture from which the govt 
can draw its funds) is something they mostly will attempt to stomp out 
whether it is from fear or from greed or in "defense" of good America. If 
our govt cannot pull money off of people gathering, why should they let 
us gather (Oh, forget about that silly constitution thing, this is now 
damnit)? And there is really no reason that we shouldn't pay the 
gathering tax you know, it is public land after all - just thnk of the 
money the govt could make if they sold all the corner parks to the 
highest bidder... Anyway, my sarcastic point is that they will attempt to 
stop any subcultures which try to break the economic bonds we are held in 

dave

Subject: Directions to DUNE
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

____________________________________________________________


Feel free to copy and/or retransmit....

>From San Francisco...

Take the 5 South all the way past Bakersfield.  When you get to the town of
Gorman (fill your tank in Gorman cause there aren't many places for petrol
until Victorville), you will exit and travel EAST on HWY 138.  After about
5 miles you will veer right and head south-east on HWY N2 (that's right...
N-2).

After about 50 miles on N-2 you will pass thru the town of Palmdale where
N-2 magically becomes HWY 138 again.

Continue east on 138 for 36 miles when 138 magically becomes HWY 18 (to
Victorville).  Stay on HWY 18 for 23 miles when you will hit I-15.

Take I-15 SOUTH (Toward L.A.) for 3 (three) miles and exit BEAR VALLEY RD.
and drive due east for 13 miles where you will hit HWY 18 again (It's magic
I tell you... or we're "folding space").  Continue east on HWY18 for
another 11 miles where you will hit HWY 247.  DO NOT GO RIGHT TO THE 18
SOUTH...

You will go straight thru the highway 247 Junction and continue heading
east on 247.  You will drive approximately 13 miles further east when you
will need to slow down and look to your left (north) for the upaved
BESSEMER MINE ROAD.  There will be a sign reading -JOHNSON VALLEY O.H.V.
AREA- where you turn in to the left.

SET YOUR ODOMETER...Drive north on Bessemer (any car can make this unpaved
road) for 5.5 miles and look to your left (West) where you will see a LARGE
naural rock amphitheater.  Drive toward the rocks and PLEASE PARK ON THE
NORTH EAST SIDE OF THE ROCKS... BEHIND THE ROCKS.


Quick Notes-

-The DUNE crew will start loading in the sound and lights at about 4pm on
Saturday (if you beat us there then go exploring the desert for a while BUT
SAVE SOME ENERGY).

-Dinner music will start at around 9pm.

-Lots of folks are coming out and having cook-out dinner there at the site.

-The closest semblance of civilization is in Lucern Valley about 20-30
minutes west of the site.

-Park Rangers will be there to "observe" this thing called "desert raving"
and will empty any Nitrous tanks they see... so PLEASE don't even bring
nitrous.






FYI-HERE'S THE INFO THAT ALL THE LAers ARE GETTING TODAY.

DUNE will begin precisely at 11pm..
        11-1am  Kc
        1-3     Lee
        3-5     Christopher Lawrence
        5-7     Doran
        7-9     Thee-o
        9-noon  Wildcard Guest sets
        Admission is $5 per person with half of the money going to the
Bureau of Land Management federal fund.  By entering the area, you  agree
that you enter at your own risk and that you will act responsibly.
        Please read everything carefully and remember to bring the
following for you and new friends:

blankets, lawn chairs, water, candy, hugs, flags, sunscreen, sunglasses,
tents, sleeping bags, good vibes, kites, drums, fruit, smiles, change of
clothes, etc.
 -Water and candy will be available at our concession booth-

        Please caravan and carpool BUT PLEASE DON'T draw attention to
yourself in any of the little towns that you drive thru on the way to the
site... it will only make law enforcement officials upset.  Along these
same lines, National Park Rangers -the law in the desert- will be coming to
witness our peaceful gathering... DO NOT bring anything as obvious as
Nitrous to this event... they WILL enforce the law.
        The drive is 1.5 to 2 hours from LA so grab some friends and
mixtapes and fill your fuel tank.   Any car can make the roads.
Forecast.... Clear    Temperature....    Lo- 43     Hi- 85

The comet will visable from 3am till 5:30am

-You SFers.... PLEASE DRIVE SAFE...

On Mar 21,  5:51pm, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > Anyway, I hope to see people at Sunset and making a show that we all are
> > not members of any the groups we have been discussing

> Here's a loaded question for you:  Could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?

Well, in Holland especially the large gabber raves are usually attended by
working class kids and soccer hooligans who would fit the description of
being skinheads quite well and many of them do not think too friendly
about the coloured people living in their country. They're right-wing,
not very clever and into hardcore 250 bpm gabber, raving all night and
taking whatever dope they can get their hands on.

I guess that answers your question.

Subject: Dictionary Vol. 2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

RaveSlang Dictionary Volume 2
dedicated to Eric ;)
with all additions (thanks for reminding me!)

badass          very, very good (usually applying to people)
the bomb        really good
candyflip       combining acid and ecstasy
clubkid         self-explanatory
dope            very good
fresh           very good
hippieflip      combining mushrooms and ecstasy
Hella/hecka     a lot of, very
hippie crack    Nitrous
nervous         bad, see "sketchy"
peace!          "good-bye"
phat            cool! (adjective, not an interjection)
the shit        the best
sick            1. very good (as in the best at something)
                2. a good track; i.e. "that beat is sick!"
sketchy         uncertain (a bad feeling about something);
                   description of someone on speed;
spin            1. what a dj does
                2. smoking pot while drunk
spun            coming down; not being able to sleep
sweet           very good
went off        was good, was "happening"


can you add to the list?


Bobbie Ohs
Assistant to the Director
University Art Museum/Pacific Film Archive
University of California at Berkeley
2625 Durant, Berkeley, CA 94720-2250
ohs@uclink2.berkeley.edu   voice: 510-643-7410  fax: 510-642-4889
http://www.uampfa.berkeley.edu/

Unfortunately, I don't have a copy of the tape that you're looking for.  But,
you brought to mind a beloved tape that I am missing . . . Jeno's Bang the
Drum.  Perhaps someone on this list could tell me where I can find another one?
 Perhaps Ameba does mail order?  Let me know, please.  I really miss that tape
alot!!!!

Speaking of tapes and distribution, why don't we put together a web site for
DJ's where they can sell their tapes?  Perhaps Ameba or a similar store would
like this capability added to their existing site?  That way, people all over
can get ahold of those missing tapes.  Also, DJs would be able to get their
mixes out to a wider audience and thereby increase thier popularity.  This way
a dj could easily go to another state and still draw a major crowd.  Perhaps we
should do a web site for DJs?  I can implement this if anyone is interested.
 Lemme know.  Any ideas are most appreciated.

warmly

Kinda hard to pronounce "PLURQ", tho! (PLURK? PLUR-QUE?)  I would like to
see "PLUR" or whatever widen beyond the maillist to become a motto of the
entire scene...found on fliers, banners at parties, etc.

True values underlie the scene but sometimes I think just the people on
this beautiful list know that...at your average major party I only hear
about who's spinning or how fucked-up some-one is...:(

On Fri, 22 Mar 1996, Nancy wrote:

> RaveSlang Dictionary Volume 2
> dedicated to Eric ;)
> with all additions (thanks for reminding me!)
> 
> badass          very, very good (usually applying to people)
> the bomb        really good
> candyflip       combining acid and ecstasy
> clubkid         self-explanatory
> dope            very good
> fresh           very good
> hippieflip      combining mushrooms and ecstasy
> Hella/hecka     a lot of, very
  ^^^^^^^^^^
This is a decidedly Nor-Cal word.  Everyone from So-Cal always gets 
annoyed when they hear this!! :)

> hippie crack    Nitrous
> nervous         bad, see "sketchy"
> peace!          "good-bye"
> phat            cool! (adjective, not an interjection)
> the shit        the best
> sick            1. very good (as in the best at something)
>                 2. a good track; i.e. "that beat is sick!"
> sketchy         uncertain (a bad feeling about something);
>                    description of someone on speed;
> spin            1. what a dj does
>                 2. smoking pot while drunk
> spun            coming down; not being able to sleep
> sweet           very good
> went off        was good, was "happening"
> 
> 
> can you add to the list?
> 
Well, as far as drug terms go, the following was forgotten:

tweaker	  someone on speed 

And we can't forget all of the ones refering to the event itself:

renegade, space, event, party, etc. etc.

And what about:

chill, as in cool, i think!

I have a friend that did a linguistic study of drug culture; where the 
words came from, how they had invaded minstream vernacular, and what they 
meant.  It was very interesting, and this slang thing reminded me of that!

cheers-
kc

Ameba has on their web page a complete list of all their mixtapes 
(www.ameba.com) plus a description of the music & price. 

The Friends & Family homepage (I forget that address) has a page where 
the F&F dj's list their mixtapes, description & price.  You can order it 
directly from the web. (I think).

Hope this helps a little. :)

I just read Amy's post and thought it would be a good idea to introduce myself!

I'm Carol Saldana originally from Sacramento and just moved last month to
the Bay Area and became very lucky and got a great job with an internet
publishing co. in Sausalito.  I've been raving since early 92' and have
done everything from the big 'Sharon' and 'WhoopieBall' parties to the
lovely 'Friends and Family' 'Gathering' and 'Sunset' parties.  Its been
interesting going on about 5 years of this great past time and like
everyone else, I'm looking forward to another great spring/summer of
terrific parties and gatherings.

I've had my highs and lows over the past few years and throughout my
struggles I always found that I had solidarity in raving.  I can remember
when I went through stages of thinking I was to old for 'it' any more (I'm
27 will be 28 this June) but I'd somehow I meet someone new and would
instantly remember how special raving truly is.  I met that special someone
back at Burning Man last year and we met up again at a 'Friends and Family'
party last October.  We've been together ever since!

Well, I'm looking forward to Somethin Special on Sat.  I'll most likely be
wearing my psychadelic long vestdress and my "Friends and Family" laminates
with my hair up in a high ponytail.  If you recognize me say hi!

Love to all
and have a great weekend!!!


P.S. Glad I subscribed!
XX
00
C.

Precedence: bulk

Let me make one statement that should address most of your arguments, and 
then I'll try to do a point-by-point.  John Lee's a little better at this 
than I am, but bear with me.

You can't illegalize Hate any more than you can illegalize Fear, and I guess 
I assumed I wouldn't have to make that specific point.  What you can 
illegalize is institutionalized Hate.  Right now we only have laws against 
discrimination, but you can spout any hate-related propoganda you wish.  I 
would like to direct something against that propoganda and the people and 
organizations that propagate it.  And I'd love to go into detail about how 
such a law would be worded, but that's partly why I'm creating this Web 
page, so that the People can decide for themselves what they would prefer to 
see in the way of legislation.

>	I wonder if hate is illegalized, if it will follow the road of 
>our parties and move a bit more underground where the stock pile of 
>weapons and random murder increases?
>	Making something illegal does not squash it (look at us, legal or 
>illegal party, is that a consideration when you choose which you are 
>going to?)

Y'know, folks like to draw some kind of connection between the freedom to 
print Hate-based propaganda and the existance of the rave culture.  I myself 
see no connection whatsoever.  Stockpiling of weapons and random murder are 
already illegal, and one might say underground, activities.  Raves 
themselves are not illegal and I have a hard time believing they ever will 
be.  Some of the activities that go on there may be illegal, but that's a 
separate issue.

> and more importantly, it never addresses the root of the 
>problem, which happens to be fear (at least in my opinion)

In my opinion it's ignorance, but your point is well taken.  What it does 
address is the effects of ignorance and fear.  There's no law that says that 
people have to be sane -- hell, I think we're all crazy up to a point -- but 
crazy people shoot up malls and office buildings all the time.  It's the 
murder and mayhem that's illegal.

>Otherwise, you are going to push them into the shadows to 
>mull over and over how they are being "repressed" and when they do act, 
>it will be from the stand point of a corner or caged animal trying to 
>free itself (in a much more hostile way).

How does one break a given cycle?  I won't go into a lot of text here on 
that, since we're all aware of negative cycles and how they're broken.  In 
this case, I'm looking to break a cycle of Hate.  Ignorance and (baseless) 
fear are jobs for the educational system.  What I dream of doing is having 
people stop using lies to teach others to hate and fear people around them 
simply because they are different.

S

>> 1. The First Amendment guarantees freedom of speech.  I'm not telling anyone 
>> anything they haven't heard before with that statement.  My contribution to 
>> this old line is: the First Amendment is a nice beginning.  One thing that I 
>> don't think should be protected is Hate.  Period.  And to that end I think 
>> that someone, somewhere, should draft a new amendment to the constitution 
>> that qualifies the freedoms under the First Amendment to not include, 
>> specifically, Hate.

>Well, you're wrong.

I don't see how.  Reread my statement, then reread yours.  You didn't 
address anything I said there.  This country was not founded on Hate.  Hate 
may have been present during it's growth, but it was not founded on it and 
you will find no basis for your argument in the Constitution or any other 
founding documents.

> Like it or not, for better, and sometimes for worse, 
>much of what this country was founded on was hate. Hatred of religious 
>persecution, hatred of a monarchy, and hatred of the dearth of rights 
>possesed by the colonists(which admittedly makes the treatment of the 
>native peoples and minorities all the more puzzling,) all helped lead to 
>the founding of this country.

That's not Hate, it's injustice and anger at injustice.  

>Hate, like unconditional love, can be healthy. 

No it cannot.  By definition, hate is a negative emotion.  Well-directed 
anger may be what you're referring to, but I'm referring to Hate in it's 
purest and most evil form, hate for hate's sake only with no other basis.

>Have you ever in your life seen an 
>injustice, and been so incensed that you were moved to speak out, or 
>take action to help correct the injustice? 

Of course, many times, and I was never motivated by hate in doing so, I was 
motivated to do what was right.

>You cannot simply legislate hate away. It is the equivalant of sticking 
>your head in your nether regions. 

(heavy sarcasm on)
Well, that statement certainly aided this argument.
(sarcasm off)
I am not so ignorant that I think Hate can be legislated away.  I am not so 
stupid, either, to think it's effects cannot be legislated against and 
severely curbed.

>> 2. Given the current status of the Constitution and it's Amendments, I think 
>> they absolutely should have a forum in which to express themselves.  This 
>> will make it easier to identify them and add their names to my Anti-Hate 
>> page.  This is something John S. Lee and I chatted briefly about a couple of 
>> weeks ago.  I'm going to donate the disk space and web domain for a page 
>> dedicated solely to exposing people who indulge in Hate propoganda and/or 
>> are members of Hate-oriented or supporting organizations and political 
>> groups.  This white-power forum will save me a lot of time and trouble 
>> finding individuals that fall into that category and getting quotes from 
>> them.  I'll simply monitor their forum, along with other forums, pull quotes 
>> from their own writings, and post them along with their identities if 
>> possible, their e-mail addresses at the least.  I intend to hold them up, 
>> sans the white hoods, for all the world to see.  I hope to keep this 
>> coverage objective, allowing others to formulate their own opinions.
>
>While I totally support this, and am sure I will visit your site, by 
>your own words you demonstrate that you are *not* objective. You, like the 
>groups and individuals you hope to expose, have an agenda. 

You're correct.  I do have an agenda, and that's exposure of their agenda.  
On the other hand, I'll make no statements regarding the quotes I post 
there.  I'll let the reader make his or her own decision on whether the 
statement warrants a response.

>> Also, as part of this Anti-Hate page, I want to begin some kind of 
>> discussion on a legal definition of what constitutes Hate so that this may 
>> be available to interested legislators.  And I want to recognize and support 
>> all Anti-Hate organizations, carrying web links, phone numbers, addresses, 
>> etc., for those groups.
>
>The first thing I would propose is that you not call yourself an 
>Anti-Hate group. From your words, you aren't. You don't plan on "loving" 
>these hate groups away, do you? 

Well, I see your point but I'm lukewarm on any other name.  No, I'm not 
going to go over and give each and every person mentioned on the list a big 
hug and a sloppy smooch, but I will hold them up to public exposure.  When 
their private lives suddenly become their public lives, they may reconsider 
how strongly they feel about taking the stands they do.  I'm sure Buchanan 
has had plenty of reason in the past couple of months to regret statements 
he's made regarding race, sex, and religion during his life.  No, this page 
would be 100% against Hate crime and organizations.

On the other hand, if anyone has a better suggestion, please, feel free...

>> One last thing: I highly respect the views of the people on this list.  I 
>> would invite any input on how the Anti-Hate page should look and what it 
>> should include.  I hope to have a first draft of it up and available some 
>> time over the weekend.  It will be overly simple at first, I'm sure, but 
>> with everyone's help, it will grow.
>> 
>
>Here are a few suggestions for inclusions(apologies for possible spelling 
>errors): Bnai Bnai, The PLO, The IRA, anything to do with Metzger, and Louis 
>Farrakahn for starters.

Thank you!  I was beginning to wonder if you'd offer anything positive in 
this post at all :)  Yes, you have a good point, and I guess I should have 
included this in my original post.  I don't want to limit this new page to 
any one specific group.  I'd like to think that the people that contribute 
to this new page will help in exposing ALL Hate-motivated groups.

Black Adder, I'm sure you have much more to say, but if we're going to 
discuss politics ad nauseam, let's not post this thread to the whole list, 
ok?  I'm interested in what you have to say, I'm just not sure everyone 
wants to watch us spar over political definitions and minutae.  I hope I've 
shown the general direction I'd like to go with this, and I hope you'll be a 
part of the effort to shape it.

S

"Hella" is a specific Northern California slang term that is completely 
NON-EXISTENT and unheard of in Southern Cal. and other parts.  IMO this 
should not be included; teknically not a 'raver' word. Before living here, I 
had never heard of this term.  It is close to "totally" however.
