---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 21 Mar 1996 09:55:34 -0800
From: Kc <sarahtonen@earthlink.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: SF Directions to DUNE

I lost track of who needed directions from SF so excuse me while I post
this to everyone... sorry.

Feel free to copy and/or retransmit....

>From San Francisco...

Take the 5 South all the way past Bakersfield.  When you get to the town of
Gorman (fill your tank in Gorman cause there aren't many places for petrol
until Victorville), you will exit and travel EAST on HWY 138.  After about
5 miles you will veer right and head south-east on HWY N2 (that's right...
N-2).

After about 50 miles on N-2 you will pass thru the town of Palmdale where
N-2 magically becomes HWY 138 again.

Continue east on 138 for 36 miles when 138 magically becomes HWY 18 (to
Victorville).  Stay on HWY 18 for 23 miles when you will hit I-15.

Take I-15 SOUTH (Toward L.A.) for 3 (three) miles and exit BEAR VALLEY RD.
and drive due east for 13 miles where you will hit HWY 18 again (It's magic
I tell you... or we're "folding space").  Continue east on HWY18 for
another 11 miles where you will hit HWY 247.  DO NOT GO RIGHT TO THE 18
SOUTH...

You will go straight thru the highway 247 Junction and continue heading
east on 247.  You will drive approximately 13 miles further east when you
will need to slow down and look to your left (north) for the upaved
BESSEMER MINE ROAD.  There will be a sign reading -JOHNSON VALLEY O.H.V.
AREA- where you turn in to the left.

SET YOUR ODOMETER...Drive north on Bessemer (any car can make this unpaved
road) for 5.5 miles and look to your left (West) where you will see a LARGE
naural rock amphitheater.  Drive toward the rocks and PLEASE PARK ON THE
NORTH EAST SIDE OF THE ROCKS... BEHIND THE ROCKS.


Quick Notes-

-The DUNE crew will start loading in the sound and lights at about 4pm on
Saturday (if you beat us there then go exploring the desert for a while BUT
SAVE SOME ENERGY).

-Dinner music will start at around 9pm.

-Lots of folks are coming out and having cook-out dinner there at the site.

-The closest semblance of civilization is in Lucern Valley about 20-30
minutes west of the site.

-Park Rangers will be there to "observe" this thing called "desert raving"
and will empty any Nitrous tanks they see... so PLEASE don't even bring
nitrous.






FYI-HERE'S THE INFO THAT ALL THE LAers ARE GETTING TOMORROW.

DUNE will begin precisely at 11pm..
        11-1am  Kc
        1-3     Lee
        3-5     Christopher Lawrence
        5-7     Doran
        7-9     Thee-o
        9-noon  Wildcard Guest sets
        Admission is $5 per person with half of the money going to the
Bureau of Land Management federal fund.  By entering the area, you  agree
that you enter at your own risk and that you will act responsibly.
        Please read everything carefully and remember to bring the
following for you and new friends:

blankets, lawn chairs, water, candy, hugs, flags, sunscreen, sunglasses,
tents, sleeping bags, good vibes, kites, drums, fruit, smiles, change of
clothes, etc.
 -Water and candy will be available at our concession booth-

        Please caravan and carpool BUT PLEASE DON'T draw attention to
yourself in any of the little towns that you drive thru on the way to the
site... it will only make law enforcement officials upset.  Along these
same lines, National Park Rangers -the law in the desert- will be coming to
witness our peaceful gathering... DO NOT bring anything as obvious as
Nitrous to this event... they WILL enforce the law.
        The drive is 1.5 to 2 hours from LA so grab some friends and
mixtapes and fill your fuel tank.   Any car can make the roads.
Forecast.... Clear    Temperature....    Lo- 43     Hi- 85

The comet will visable from 3am till 5:30am

-You SFers.... PLEASE DRIVE SAFE...

The Spice Flows... Again!



-Kc

DUNE homepage at:

  http://home.earthlink.net/~sarahtonen/

Voice Mail:
  213/694-0615

On Fri, 22 Mar 1996, SDream wrote:

> >> >You cannot simply legislate hate away. It is the equivalant of sticking
> >> >your head in your nether regions.
> >> >
> >> Sounds like there is no "answer," except to leave "them" alone as long as
> >> they leave "us" alone.  Adopt a vigilant, defensive posture, but provoke
> >> nothing.
> >
> >EXACTLY!!!! :-) 
> 
> I'm sorry to hear you both take that stand.  I would like to refer to BA's 
> statement about sticking your head ... tell ya what, how about we change 
> that to "in the sand"?  Anyway, by leaving them alone, you risk doing 
> nothing, and this is a problem where doing nothing has proved completely 
> ineffective.  I choose to, not so much attack, as expose.
> 
> S

Nothing should be done to these people unless they do something illegal. 
They can talk about whatever the hell they want. That is their right 
under the Constitution. I do not support their views, and I would be one 
of the first to speak against their opinions, but they have the right to air 
their views, just as I have the right to say they are full of shit. 

But I have do not support their opinions, nor do I have any interest in what 
they have to say, unless confronted with it. This is not tantamount to 
sticking my head in the sand. I watch, I attempt to keep informed on the 
issues, and most importantly I am willing to protect myself and others 
against those that would deny me my rights(which seem to be shrinking 
daily.)  

And what has been ineffective are all the attempts to legislate hate away.
It doesn't work. I saw Pat Buchanan with a huge number of supporters 
early in the run-offs, and I thought "Damn, are there still that many 
racists in the U.S.?" Of course the numbers speak for themselves. These 
are largely blue-collar workers, who wouldn't voice their race opinions 
in public, but you can see it in their votes. 

Rather than trying to shut these people up, we need to *UNDERSTAND* them. 
I see people on S.F. Raves talking about how everyone should try to 
understand each other. I agree. Try to *UNDERSTAND* what has brought them 
to their views. Expose them...great, what does that get you. You get 
brownie points for exposing a hated hate-group, and if you're lucky, 
maybe you will get their medium of discussion shut down. BUT WHAT GOOD 
DOES THAT DO ANYONE ULTIMATELY???? Do the people that have these views 
simply go away and fade into nothingness? 

Taking a symptomatic approach to these issues is why worthless fucks 
like Buchanan receive the support they do. You are doing nothing to 
change the core issues, the reasons for the hate, but rather just 
pushing it underground.      

                                        Black Adder

In light of some recent posts on freedom raving/skinheads/etc...saw this on
Dr.FreeClouds web page...(more info on
http://www.drfreeclouds.com/latest.html)

_____________________


 Ron D. Core received a last-minute fax on March 15th, from the promoters of=
 the
       Rotterdam, Holland Megarave gig that was scheduled for March 16th,
1996. The fax from
       Rige Entertainment BV, addressed to Lenny Dee, Ron D. Core, Don
Demon, Reign and
       Mickey B, who were also booked, stated that the Mayor of the City of
Rotterdam feared
       that the rave may attract "a major group of 'Fascists'", and
subsequently revoked Rige's
       permission for the highly anticipated rave.

       Apparently some raves in that country and much of Europe, especially
raves of a more
       hardcore/gabber nature, attract a large number of "fascists", more
commonly known here
       in the U.S. as skinheads. Rige said that they are attempting to sue
the City of Rotterdam
       for retracting their permission for the rave. Rige Entertainment has
also informed Ron D.
       Core that they are also attempting to restage another "megarave" in
the next cumming
       months. Even with this seemingly bad news, Ron D. Core is still
enthusiastic about
       playing his first European gig in the city where much of the music
he plays (gabber)
       originates, and is looking forward to hearing from Rige
Entertainment on his next booking
       date. Stay tuned here for late breaking news and for your curiousity
____________________________________

Before I leave work, just adding to the list for who/what to look for at Sunset!
I'm planning to wear my big vintage 60's pillbox white and pink hat with big
fake flowers on it -- if you miss this, you ain't lookin' -- and for you shy
people, don't worry, I'm REALLY nice and will introduce you to some other REALLY
nice people....

It's my friend Jim's 26th birthday, so come on over and say h.b. to him please!
Toys and games may be available for all, who knows, maybe even a big cake!

And if you're interested in being part of putting on the SFR BBQ and BEATS
picnic, let me know, several of us volunteer organizers are gonna be there, and
we'd love to know who all is interested!  

Have a wonderful weekend....     Leslie  : )

oh, and thanks to those who reminded me NEVER to say NEVER ... even if it is to
the possibly least likely activity you'd find me engaged in, namely dancing
naked with a whistle in my mouth!...   those who know me are fully aware that I
know WAY better than that -- so many things I said I'd "never" do are totally
part of my life now... and I appreciate being reminded when I slip back into old
habits!!

Hey Bart,

	Coolness! Another Dutch dude on SFraves, any more???!

	When I used to go to the raves in Amsterdam, I was still
a 'rookie'... and even then the scene was a little different I'm sure... (as you can tell haven't been to a Rave overseas in a while!)

	I guess I appreciate the finer things in live now I'm older.. 
:) Also, the people at the raves here are peacefull.... loving... caring
... amazin' and a cozy crowd.  My experiences in Amsterdam were
not as positive 6 years ago.

	C-ya later, Hope this explains it.  (Guess I'll have to go
to a rave next time i'm back in Amsterdam).

Michael

From: 	bart meijerink[SMTP:bart.meijerink@pi.net]
Sent: 	Thursday, March 21, 1996 11:44 PM
To: 	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 	RE: Hi, I'm Michael. 

Living in the Netherlands (Utrecht) myself I was kinda curious what 
makes the SF-vibe that different from the one in Amsterdam/the Nether-
lands. Could you elaborate on that? I'm sure ravers in San Francisco 
want to hear what makes them special too.  


By the way, seeing everyone introducing themselves,... 
...
My name is Bart Meijerink (27-12-72). At the moment I study Urban
Planning in Amsterdam and live in Utrecht. I dj now for about six years  
(I'm not famous or anything though). At the moment I'm organising parties 
(200-300 pp) in Utrecht at a place called Ekko, as well as dj-ing there. 
I became interested in housemusic in '88/'89 when I heard tunes like 'Voodoo 
Ray' by a Guy called Gerald and 'Bounce your body to the box' by Kevin 
Saunderson. I'm mostly into Detroit-techno (especially by Robert Hood/
Jeff Mills) and acid, but I also like some of the harder stuff as well as 
the more cluboriented music (people over here call it 'mellow', dunno why) 
as well as some jungle. I also make music myself (on my own as well as with 
friends).
Around the time I got my internetaccount I read about this list 
somewhere and became interested. I'm on the list for about 3 months now, but 
have rarely posted anyting. Due to the lack of time I don't read all e-mails, 
but I enjoy the ones that I do read.
Oh yeah, I'm heading for Prague in a few weeks together with bands 'the 
Human Beings (dv8)', 'Acid Junkies (djax-up)' and 'Human in Paradize (music man)' 
(betcha have never heard of them). That will be fun.

I hope I'll get a chance to visit SF in the future to taste some of that 
sfrave flavour.

Bye!
(by the way, did you know 'gabber' is a Dutch word?)


Bart

Someone was asking about trainspotting, it refers to people in Britain
whose hobby(life?) is writing down numbers of passing trains...  So, a
raver who is more concerned with finding out  the names of the songs
that are being played rather than enjoying the music is called a
trainspotter.

I always disliked the word sketchy, I have found it to be vague and
overused.  I love "hella", use it myself to mystify people in my own
(non-teenage) age group.  Its use seems to cross all youth cultural
lines that I have seen in this area.

On Fri, 22 Mar 1996 13:45:21 -0700, you wrote:


>
>can you add to the list?
>

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)

Good point.  Many ravers it seems are turned off by all the PLUR..and 
certainly many are not interested in the opening and closing ceremonies 
at some parties.  Last Wednesday during Light, the opening circle 
contained roughly an equal number of people to two other groups of folks 
sitting higher up on the hill....The common ground is the music, the 
dance and the trance it induces...when we are all dancing our asses off, 
the differences dissolve and the walls come down...some permanently, some 
a wee bit, and a wee bit more next time....

As to the loaded question, could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?  Good chance..
The music we listen to is 'high' energy music, it is often intense, 
deep, penetrating, magical and beautiful. Based on footage I have seen 
via 60minutes and other documentaries, it seems that 
Neo-Nazi's could be into fast pulsing hard trance techno music, as 
as opposed to Mozart. However,they would most likely be moshing to most of 
it...  

--Maureen


On Fri, 22 Mar 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > >Here's a loaded question for you:  Could a Neo-Nazi also be a raver?
> > 
> > Anything's possible, although I think such a person would be turned off by
> > all the PLUR...
> 
> Y'know, a *lot* of people are turned off by all "the PLUR".  The real
> strength and magic of raving is not PLUR, it's what happens when we 
> allow the MUSIC to take us to a higher place.  PLUR separated from
> a tangible source can start to feel contrived, especially amongst
> diverse people who don't really have that much in common.  It's our
> love and connection with certain kinds of music that unites us and gives
> us the means to harmonize our minds and bodies with each other.  I 
> sometimes feel that people who are into the rave scene mainly for the 
> PLUR actually weaken it in the long run if they don't participate in 
> activity that truly creates it - namely, dancing your ass with
> everyone around you.
> 
> Lee
> _________________________________________________________________________
> lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Remember to experience the visitor from the depths of space...
a new comet.  Follow Ursa Major's (the Big Dipper) handle to the red 
giant type K2 p star 'Arcturus'.  Now visualize Arcturus as the center of a 
clock... then look out from the center between what would be 7 & 8 o'clock.
That's where the comet it tonight.  You can actually see it's tail..ah my 
kingdom for pitch black skies!  Lucky folks out at DUNE...  :) Note:  It 
is a fairly big bright fuzzy dot in the sky...very different from 
everything else in the sky...  

If you are having trouble spotting it, I can point it out for you 
tomorrow night at the Burning Man party, and sunday at Sunset...  

Let there always be light from the stars.....

--Maureen

It was great to hear from so many of you wishing me a warm welcome and
helping me find Christophe.   Now, if anyone sees him, tell him he has a very
close friend who would like to hear from him, see him, hug him, hang out (by
the way, that goes for all of you too - you've been great).

Thanks to you, taz for your insight.  We all have our ups and downs, but it
is the power of love and acceptance that ravers are known for that can help
each of us through the valleys (I bet Matt knows that more than ever now).
 Each of us has something unique to offer to the chemistry of the group.  The
world is always better when we're around, becuase it is different.  We all
get pretty bored if everything is always the same.  This may be why so many
of you are finding it more difficult to define a raver than you thought you
would.  We all have common characteristics, but we still are entitled to our
individual identities.  Hence, the variety of dress, from full tux to
Moonpup's georgeous cheeks, and the variety of ways we all like to express
ourselves (some of you think finger cymbals are bad - wait til I show up with
my tuba).

On age - Maureen talked about the 30's and 40's set lying about their age.
 Those over 12 lie about being under 12 (price break).  Those under 21 lie
about being over 21.  By the time you get to 50, there is not much more you
can lie about, and before long you want everyone to know how many years you
cheated the grim reaper.  When's the last time you asked a "senior" to a
party?

Don't let the hate groups get you in a knot.  The one thing we hate about
hate is that it brings out the hate in us.  As some of you have correctly
identified, hate breeds out of fear.  What you don't fear, you don't need to
hate (now pity is another thing).  Just as you have been enlightened, your
mission is to enlighten others.  You can conquer hate - you just have to do
it one Neo-Nazi at a time.

I'm not in your midst, but I'm not far away in Fresno (from the Armenian word
for "furnace").  I look forward to getting up to meet some of you soon.  I'll
be the real tall one who looks like Paul Bunyan (but without the beard - I
could never get used to all that facial itching) and kind of "old".

peace

pk

Subject: PJ's and BunnySlippers
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I thought I'd share something I saw at a rave that I thought was pretty funny...

I ran into some friends from Berkeley at Harmony (last month).  Two of them
left kind of early (around 3) because they were pretty tired.  A couple of
hours later I'm on the dancefloor, and I spot some anonymous dancing feet
clad in huge white furry bunny slippers!  I run over to compliment the
wearer on their most excellent rave footwear...and who is it but the
friends who had left earlier!

Turns out they had gone all the way back to Berkeley, got ready for bed,
laid in bed and realized the beat was still in their feet and they couldn't
sleep, and they decided to come BACK to the party.  But it occurred to them
that there was really no reason to change...and they returned to Harmony in
their pj's and bunny slippers, and started dancing away!!

I love it that we're part of a scene where you can just come on down in a
nightgown and curlers if you want, and probably all that will happen is
that someone will think your bunnyslippers are the coolest!  Where else
could this happen?!  :P  Love, Nancy







From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 23 15:45:13 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA05720; Sat, 23 Mar 1996 15:45:13 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA05703; Sat, 23 Mar 1996 15:45:11 -0800
Received: from [128.32.160.69] (hmfmac31.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.69]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA01401 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 23 Mar 1996 15:45:20 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130501ad7a38e8bdc8@[128.32.160.69]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 23 Mar 1996 15:44:09 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Newbie Dilemma
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tonight I may be introducing some "newbies" to the scene.   Some people who
live in my co-op have come up to me and said that they want to go to a rave
and also try ecstasy (I'm known in the house as the "ravechick," a bit of a
curiousity).  This position always makes me feel a little ambivalent.

On the one hand, I think the scene is so positive and the music so
transcendent and the experience so fun that I want to expose everyone to
it!  But when I'm accompanying a newbie I also feel compelled to kind of
direct their experience, to explain the music, to point out all the little
things that add meaning to the night.  I feel a responsibility to interpret
the experience FOR them, and I'm so worried about _their_ time that I stop
being able to totally enjoy myself.  I want others to see what I see,
because I know it's easy to only see the fucked-up kids, the ticket price,
the drugs, to hear only banality in the music.

I love the _possibility_ of the scene, the pure alternative community that
we on SFR envision.  And I feel that exposing others to that can only make
the scene stronger, IF they experience it on the deep level that many of us
do.

But I also worry that bringing people into the scene who may NOT see it
that way will actually weaken or destroy our vibe.

So, that leaves me with the dilemma of tonight.  Do I bring these four
newbies to Something Special (in my estimation, a low-budget rave but full
of vibe and delicious trance)?  Or to the full-on commercial Aborigine,
with its visuals and crowds and mainstream feel?

Are there TWO scenes - the mainstream and the underground?  Which to bring
a newbie to?  Is it irresponsible to randomly bring people into the scene?
Or should we ALWAYS strive to be inclusive and never exclusive?!

With too many philosophical questions
for just a partying Saturday night,
Nancy

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hi there,

I just read (was it Nancy's?) post about taking newbies to a rave and
whether you should take them to one of the big commercial jobbies like
Aborigine or to the kind like Something Special, and I was about to sign
off, when the thought entered my mind: y'know volt, you're a newbie too.

So speaking from the newbie perspective, (Something Special will be my first
"real" one, if I go), I think you should take them to whichever one is
representative of what raving means to _you_.  They already know you're in
the scene, so you should show them _why_ you're in it, what draws you to it,
and in what ways it differs from the "banal", drug-ridden, insidious event
typically portrayed in the media (forgive me if you don't strike me as a
person who considers raving in the same light as the media).

Anyways, that's what I think.  Hope that helps...

volt
the guy who'd have sent this thru private mail, but unwittingly erased the
original message and now has to post his response to the list

>Good point.  Many ravers it seems are turned off by all the PLUR..and 
>certainly many are not interested in the opening and closing ceremonies 
>at some parties.  Last Wednesday during Light, the opening circle 
>contained roughly an equal number of people to two other groups of folks 
>sitting higher up on the hill....The common ground is the music, the 
>dance and the trance it induces...when we are all dancing our asses off, 
>the differences dissolve and the walls come down...some permanently, some 
>a wee bit, and a wee bit more next time....


Of my four years of raving, the only time I have ever heard a raver
speak of PLUR has been on the net.  For me, the concepts are so basic and
fundemental between the Family that it is a blasphemy to "quantitize" this
into a formular like P.L.U.R.

You don't need PLUR when you look into another raver's eyes at 6 am as the
sun is coming up on the beach and you've been dancing in the dark with
them all night, the experience speaks for itself in a language that words
will never approximate.


        
                                                G

From: Marc Pfister <mjpfister@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez045207@chip.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: New Dawn?
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960323190319.4944A-100000@chip.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So did anybody else check out New Dawn Friday night? I didn't spot any 
SFR laminates, but then I wasn't there very long, had a final exam this 
morning... :(  :(  :(
Here's a synopsis for those who missed it:

It was held at the Acme warehouse. It seemed to be just about the right 
size for the crowd. Minimalist lighting, two multi-spot-type lights 
(moonbursts? Is that the trade name) and a long glowing fiber-optic cable 
(my own contribution). Some posters and other decorations. Very basic, 
not that its a bad thing at all, very underground feel.
Now, the sound : There's a jungle track called "Rivers of Bass". It has a 
good amount of bass to it. There's another called "Beyond Bass". This 
pretty much sums up the sound. The B.A.S.S crew splurged on bass bins and 
they got all the bass they ever would have needed, plus more. I'm 
surprised bricks weren't vibrating out the walls. I'd almost call it 
overkill, but they do call it DRUM & BASS, don't they? The flyer said 
"slammin bass" and they delivered.
First DJ up was Noel, he rocked a smooth set. Most of the people in were 
the early crowd and many looked a little confused, maybe not used to drum 
& bass tempos (or maybe stunned by all that bass). After Noel came on 
Stareyes, who decided to take no prisoners. Starting of with older dark 
hardcore she got the crowd moving, switching up the beats. Her set 
progressed to more of 'jump up" style (sort of a hard, 'gangsta' style, 
lots of ruffness), and the crowd reacted. After Stareyes was Evan, but I 
had leave to get some sleep...
The first 75 people in got free mix tapes and there were free oranges and 
water. Cost was 8$.
All in all it was an excellent effort for SF's unified jungle crew. This 
evidently was SF's first all-jungle allnighter (though the SFR historians 
might be able to correct me) and showed lots of promise for the state of 
jungle on the left coast.

vibin'
hannibal selecta

new dawn went off on fri. night. all dj's rocked the acme w/an insane sound
sys., especialy dj stareyes. that little girl can slam! in the middle of her
jungle set she mixed in some happy hardcore gabber and the dancers just went
nuts. for those of you who missed it, you missed it! only a couple of hundred
people showed up which was nice cuz its not that fun when you have no space
to get funky. plus free mix tapes. i've heard of free acid at the door, but
this was much better. there was also no fucking drug dealers screming out for
sales. when you need drugs that bad at a party, it must not be that good to
begin with. jungle music's so crazy you don't even need that stuff.

this music is the new underground, for real. for those who say "i can't dance
to that jungle music. i like house". well, it just takes some time to
understand it. when house and trance are being played on the radio and mtv,
don't you think it's time to get into something more deviant to the
mainstrem? that's the only way new music will progress, is if you constantly
are searching for something new. change is a beatiful thing, so don't get
stuck in a rut. 

check out any of the B.AS.S crews gigs. btw, there's a new sound sys. at
bahia so check out energi on weds. nightes.

big up all junglists! check it, check it, aawwwww yah!!
-theron

hi all,  i apologize to ppl i said i was going to contact and
didn't. one week is pretty short if you think about it.

thanks to JC for lettin' me do the show at Stanford.
Czefir, sorry i kept missing you.

I loved my spring break trip to SF so much i really do want
to move there. i am in wisconsin right now and it is so depressing.
no one smiles. the weather sucks on a daily basis. the parties
are lame.
need i say more?!

i went to MAD at the Bahia and had a great time.
then i went to the party at the Berkeley Marina on Wednesday
and almost had an orgasm it was so exciting. i have never danced under
the stars like that. it's changed the way i feel about life!


well, i'll write more later.

i love you all.

clinton
midwest guy, longing for the west coast.....

The majic with the sunset parties is still there.  The vibe was 
incredible, lots of smilie faces and great music.  A beautiful feel of 
many friendly high energy dancers.  But what was up with that drummer.  
For those of you that weren't there, this guy had a complete drum set in 
the middle of the dance floor.  I had to get right next to the speakers 
to be able to hear the music over his drumming, which wasn't always 
keepin with the beat that well.  
Other than that the day was GREAT!  I was the guy wearing the red striped 
sweat shirt, with blue sleeves.

Forwarded message:
Subj:    new venues?
Date:    96-03-22 19:45:03 EST
From:    Fork8
To:      sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello all...was thinking about the upcoming outdoor parties and wondered if
there has ever been a rave on ANGEL ISLAND here in beautiful SF bay?  Seems
great, unbestable with a permit, no locals, and crowd control as the last
boat over is 5pm or so and the first one off is 7 am or so, and what views!!
 
Or has anyone ever considered a train party?  You can rent out cars on Amtrak
trains, a round-trip rave to LA or Portland or Tahoe, diffeent DDJ in every
car, limited/controled crowd, unbustable, new fascinating scenery!  Just make
sure there is extra stable tunrtables!

Also along the lines of permit/bustable parties.....i understand some groups
in LA get permits for parties by getting a movie permit, not a party permit.
 They just have a few video camera with no tape and maybe some lights every
now and then to be safe.  They "film" the "party scene" part of the movies
that night the permit is issued!  Movie permits allow you to have lights,
sound, lots people etc....anyone ever go that route here in the city?  Just a
very creative way to make the rules work for you, instead of breaking them
and getting a party busted.

any thoughts????
peace

Date: Sat, 23 Mar 1996 13:05:51 +0000
From: Adrian Sunderland <adrian@griffin.co.uk>
Subject: Virtual Rave

Hi all,

We are currently beta testing a LIVE RealAudio dance music site, playing 
mainly house and progressive trance.  Our resident DJs Alex & Dan have played 
a LIVE set on Fridays over the last couple of weeks.  

To listen you will need a 28.8 connection and the latest RealAudio 2.0 
software, which is available free from our Web Site.

We have another live event planned for next Friday at 10.00pm GMT, although 
you can listen to music from previous events and our archive at any time.

We are also looking at creating a chat room that will be open at the same 
time as the live events.  So people from all over the world can listen to the 
same music at the same time and meet other like-minded clubbers.

Hopefully, this all adds up to being a 'large' night in, we are also 
discussing the possibility of broadcasting audio from some of the UK's top 
clubs.

And best of all, it's completely free !!  Point your browser at 
www.griffin.co.uk/music.htm, and join in the party.

Any suggestions, comments are very welcome.

Adrian.

adrian@griffin.co.uk

Griffin Internet, Derby.

> think of bein without ya'll, but I'll manage.

What do you mean by "pause"?  You probably don't mean an automatic reply
to each message you receive ("Steve is on vacation until...").  You can 
unsub by sending majordomo@hyperreal.com the message "uns*bscribe" 
(replacing the * with a 'u') and then reading the list archives on 
hyperreal when you return, or you can just not do anything and catch up 
on hundreds of messages when you return.

	Sami

 	                	C & S   
		             R E C O R D S


		            P R E S E N T

	   T H E S E    F I N E     N E W     R E L E A S E S

Ambient Abstractions 2:

	The second installment of this series plunges deeper into the 
	ever-evolving wprld of ambient, illustrating how it has mutated
	or has been deconstructed. Sculpting a design for listening that
	transends definitions and stretches musical perimeters, composing
	rich soundscapes which utilize evocative textures that stimulate
	the senses.

	from archetypal to atmospheric
	from acoustic to electronic
	from dance to dub to drone
	from industrial to isolationism
	from pro-rock to indie-rock
	from free jazz jazz to avant-garde
	ambient is all encompassing
		
Track List:
	1. Opik - Koulsoum
	2. Closedown - Real Oval
	3. His Name Is Alive - More Majic Party
	4. No Man - Angeldust
	5. Jansen/Barbieri - In The Black of Desire
	6. Poppyseed - Am I (ambient reconstruction)
	7. Boymerang - The Don
	8. Divination - Evil Eye
	9. ISO Ambient Orchestra - Splooridge
	10. Single Cell Orchesta - These Embers
	11. Transambient Communication - The River

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tranceambient Communications:

	Ambient music at it's finest. Tranceambient Communications is a
	electronical journey into the heavens with incredible textures and
	a kelidescope of sound. If you have a love for Ambient music, this
	is one new CD you will not want to miss.

Track List:

	1. Mauve
	2. They  Shoot Geese Don't They
	3. Alaska Pt. 1
	4. Ocean Waves at Sunset
	5. Iceman
	6. Alaska Pt. 2
	7. What Is Musik?
	8. The River

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ragga Jazz: Trip-Hop + Dub

	A compliation of nine visionary tracks that together form an 
	experimental collage of reggae, trip-hop, dub and jazz, utilizing
	rich multi-layered production and innovative arrangements, Ragga Jazz
	creates an entrancing unique vibe.

Track List:
	1. Up, Bustal And Out - Utopian Skank
	2. Jazzy Grooves - Superstar
	3. Ragga Dub Massive - Definitive Ragga
	4. Dubmarine - Feel The Sauce
	5. Tricky - Aftermath (Hip Hop Blues)
	6. Cool Breeze - Tik Tok
	7. Clark Gayton - Easy Jazzy
	8. Baby Buddah Heads - Morning Dub
	9. Clark Gayton - Sensi Smile

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

		Mixed By: DJ HARDWARE

	Beat Generator: Progressive Hard House Anthems
		Mixed By: DJ HARDWARE

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Something Special & Sunset
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9603250818.A22667-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


What an incredible weekend!! 
Went to Something Special on Saturday night; it was held in a smallish 
warehouse in an alleyway.  It was nice to be in a new location.  Not all 
that many people showed up, but there were enough people to have an 
**INCREDIBLE** vibe going on! :)  For the first time since the Gathering 
Anniversary party in December, I have been able to actually dance 
comfortably because it was not too hot and stuffy! :):) When we first 
arrived, the music was kinda weird and I couldn't really get into it and 
not many people were dancing.  But I remember when Joe Rice took hold of 
the decks, he brought the place together.  Great set, Joe!  But the dj's 
that REALLY stand out in my mind that night were LeLe and Tom.  These 
guys tore the place up!!  The crowd was **SO** into the music!  I also 
got to meet sfraver Nancy - you are SO nice, I'm looking forward to 
getting to know you! :):)

Then Sunset on Sunday was also great.  My new boyfriend, Demian and I 
took Porche, his boxer, to the party.  Demian had never been to Sunset 
before - he thought everyone just slept on Sunday.  Boy was he surprised 
at the immense numbers of people who still needed to dance and whoop it 
up! :) Gosh, everybody and their grandma was there.  I got to see old 
friends who I haven't in months and new people like Leslie and SDream and 
Moonpup.  I'm glad we all got pictures of each other.  I couldn't walk 2 
feet without bumping into someone I knew - I was almost kind of sad that 
I couldn't sit down and *really* talk too each person.  I want to get to 
know all of you, but in circumstances like this, it is gonna take awile!
There are certainly more people than just me that think that this is 
going to be a summer we shall never forget.  This weekend will resonate 
with me all this coming week. :):):)

love,
Amy

|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu

Mike,

        Your friends here on the list will be more than happy to help
educate you in the joys of hugging!  As far as knowing or not knowing how,
you just basically go with what feels good.  It's best to hug as many
people as possible, compare the experiences, and keep what you like best.
You can kinda judge how to hug someone by the way they hug (how intense,
when to break, whether or not to move your hands around some, etc.).  When
we meet, I'll show you what I mean :)

Peace & hugz,

- E

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: First Sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey, all!  It's the post-hound here, with reflections of my first Sunset.
I must make a point to get to these outdoor gigs earlier; arrived just
before 4pm, and I thought the thing was too short, but that's just because
there were so many people I was looking forward to seeing, many for the
first time!
Sure were a lot of dogs this time out...
It was HUGE!  Biggest outdoor party I've seen.  Everyone was so friendly
and in great spirits.  It felt wonderful to wander though the crowd and
have people see me & say "Are you Eric?"  Maybe the SHROOMARAMA shirt will
become something of an institution...
I didn't see any of the "crew," but I haven't talked with them much lately,
so I need to find out what parties they'll be attending and introduce them
to all you wonderful friends :)
The vibe was strong, especially among the dancers; I paid attention to
whether or not I could pick up on it through my enhanced bliss, and
definitely found it, though at times I slipped inside my own thang.
Couldn't get my feet to move enough, but I know why, and will adjust
accordingly ;)
I was honored to meet Diana, Nancy, Leslie, Tony, two guys from Ireland, a
big, beautiful, friendly guy named Mostafa, and Aaron (a charming,
delightful, fascinating lady!), and everyone else I met for the first time.
I was happy to see my friends Rachel, Carin, Jonathan, Troy, Nicole, and
again everyone else I've met before (Purple Tiger, Phoenix, and others).
I liked the drummer when he was on the beat, and spent some time situated
where I could hear him and the music together.  I kept being drawn closer
to the drums, as I'm a bass player.  It was a joy to have that little boy
fooling around on the kit!
I danced longer than usual this time, and the whole event went by so fast!
At the end, I was dancing close to this tall, blond, bearded guy, very
bouncy and full of glee.  We didn't introduce ourselves, but had fun just
dancing and being.
I was very honored to give Carin a ride home to the dazemaze that is SF,
and to catch a brief glimpse into her beautiful, spirit-filled home.
Driving home was challenging, but I made it in time to get plenty of sleep
so I could function at work.  Now, if I could just concentrate on
work...but I feel so good...

Thanks to everyone for the incredible first Sunset of the year, and first
Sunset for Eric P.!  See y'all again soon!

Peace,

- E

   Mike and all other (types of) virgins, 
   
   Many of us were once virgins and I like to think I'm still a virgin of 
   many things to come in life.  The beauty in our innocence is being able 
   to discover and try different ways of feeling comfortable with whatever 
   we're exploring.  In our journey, we must first allay our fears within 
   ourselves in order to have the confidence to choose when and where you 
   want to try something new.  Sometimes we learn by happenstance but there 
   are always opportunities waiting for us to discover. 
   
   So try to (er...) embrace your hugging journey until you find what's 
   best for you.  And as I think someone previously mentioned, there are 
   all types of hugs (from the "that's nice" insincere hug to the "even 
   exchange energetic hug" [where you both feel energized, happier and 
   lighter] to the full-on "I wanna get physical" hug).  You'll definitely 
   find plenty of opportunities for hugs in this scene and I hope no one 
   tells you it's lousy.
   
   Warm embraces and some more schlocky thoughts,
   Diane

to practice on. I don't have that." I'm not a very physically 
affectionate person. But I'm learning.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 25 12:45:57 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA20337; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 12:45:57 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA20326; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 12:45:51 -0800
Received: from [128.32.91.100] (mmf30.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.91.100]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id MAA04566 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 12:45:44 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130501ad7cadc5c5b5@[128.32.91.100]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 25 Mar 1996 12:44:30 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (nancy)
Subject: Something Very Special!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What a beautiful week-end!!!

I did decide to take the newbies to the real underground.  Instead of four,
only two new people wanted to come (the other two were all, "I don't want
to do ecstasy and I hate that annoying music."  Well, I'm glad then that
they didn't come!!  Raving is the collective vibe - everybody has to
contribute with their positive energy and their love.  GOOD ATTITUDE is the
only prerequisite!).

I wasn't going to pay $20 for some big faceless rave, so I took a chance on
Something Special.  I say a "chance" because I didn't know Tom and his crew
or their philosophy, whether this would be the true experience or just a
low-budget dance party.  I also hadn't heard of anyone else going and I
wasn't sure of the crowd.

We arrived with our five dollars and can of food in hand.  Newbies liked
the secret mappoint and surreptitious creep down the alleyway to enter
secret door.  When we entered the party I became apprehensive.  Maybe 50
people there, tiny place, one laser, and bad music.  Oh no!  I decided to
give the party a chance to develop into something...special.  And did it
ever!!! =) !

Within an hour the place had filled to about 150 beautiful, happy people.
The main lights were turned off, the laser was going off, and the music
turned into incredible deep booming trance.  Tom and LeLe ripped up their
sets...the energy was just pouring out of the music, and Tom was jumping up
and down behind the decks, making the crowd respond.  Darwin Chamber played
an incredible live set, creating the music, the feeling, right there.
Newbies crawled into the bassbin and stayed there for half the night,
gasping "this music!!".

Looking around, I knew what this crew was about.  Beautiful posters
decorated the space, reminding us of higher consciousness and universal
love.  A banner waved over the dancefloor with the Sanskrit symbol for
harmony - everything in the universe vibrating at the same frequency.  I
realized that _that_ is the power of this music, why it is _so_ spirtual,
so transcendental.  It creates a frequency that we all tune into, creating
harmony and symbiosis between us all, rising us to that unified level.
Whew!

The underground people there knew what it was all about.  There were many
smiles, much friendliness, many hugs.  Near the end we formed a giant
circle on the dancefloor, everyone in the place holding hands.  A huge
group hug formed.  At the height of the vibe the crew passed out messages,
telling us that the scene is about unity and love and happiness, and asking
that everyone return to that mentality to create "something special."  :)

I met a few SFRavers there!!  Amy and Shawna and Tony and Volt, yea!  This
was Volt's first party, what did you think?!  My newbies were too
overwhelmed.  One, unfortunately, had overdosed, and could only sit in a
corner.  The other was overcome with vibe - she didn't dance, but stood on
the outskirts of the dancefloor with raised arms.  She explained to me that
she was sending out energy to all the dancers. :)

The morning came too soon.   Mattresses were taken off the skylights,
flooding the room with sunlight, and everybody cheered for the light.  We
drove home in exhausted silence, dj Dutch's trance filling the car.

Thank you Tom and LeLe and James and everyone else who put on this
BEAUTIFUL party!!  This is what the scene should be about and what we all
should work for.  I thank them for going out on a limb and creating the
most special party they could...

Love, Nancy

Subject: Re: Newbie Dilemma
To: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Date: Mon, 25 Mar 1996 12:59:18 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v02130501ad7a38e8bdc8@[128.32.160.69]> from "Nancy" at Mar 23, 96 03:44:09 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2616      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> On the one hand, I think the scene is so positive and the music so
> transcendent and the experience so fun that I want to expose everyone to
> it!  But when I'm accompanying a newbie I also feel compelled to kind of
> direct their experience, to explain the music, to point out all the little
> things that add meaning to the night.  I feel a responsibility to interpret
> the experience FOR them, and I'm so worried about _their_ time that I stop
> being able to totally enjoy myself.  I want others to see what I see,
> because I know it's easy to only see the fucked-up kids, the ticket price,
> the drugs, to hear only banality in the music.
> 
I've had some trouble with this situation too... the desire to share
everything I've experienced versus their need to find their own experience.  
I've come to the conclusion that the best thing I can do is show them
my initial enthusiasm by taking them to the party and being open about my
own experiences, and then letting them go... It's hard not to try to push,
but once I finally find myself first, enjoying my own dancing and made my
peace with my own interpretation of the night, I find that they will come
back to me and tell me what a good time they're having.  It's like the saying,
If you love something set it free, and when it comes back to you, it's yours.
Well, just trust them to find the things they need to to understand what's
going on.  And just be yourself to show them your interpretation, and let
them choose for themself.

So, that means worry about yourself first.  Go to the party you think
you'll have the most fun at, be it a small party with a solid vibe or a big 
party with huge speakers and lights galore.  There are the bad elements
everywhere, and once you stop having a problem with them, your friends
will see your example and not have a problem with them either.

> But I also worry that bringing people into the scene who may NOT see it
> that way will actually weaken or destroy our vibe.
> 
It really doesn't matter if they see it or not, as long as you see it.
And it's impossible to know how someone will intrepret it all, so it's
usually best to give them the benefit of the doubt.  Everybody has the
potential to see everything, and if you let them, they will almost always
surprise you.  Our vibe is much more than our vibe... it is a fundamental
undercurrent of everything, including everyone and everything, and it
is our own judgmental nature that creates all the negative things we run
across.  Know yourself first, and everyone else will follow.

I hope you had a wonderful weekend,

-john.
http://he.net/~swoosh/

From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Sumpin Special!!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Wotta party!!

I had a great time at this party!  I really liked the space they had it 
in (I understand they were originally gonna have it at the same place 
that busted F-8 party was held, and I liked this one much better!), it 
had a nice comfy feel to it & I liked it immediately upon walking in 
the door.  The chill area was somewhat small, but it never got 
overcrowded, & the main area was nice too.  It never got too not to 
deal with, & it never got too crowded to deal with.  The music was kind 
of strange when I first got there (an emergency replacement for the 
currently laid-up Ethan. :(:(  but then Joe Rice hopped onboard & 
played a nifty set (like your stuff, joe, never heard it before!).  I 
had brought my new friend (never been to a rave, never tried anything 
before!), she had a good time too.  I didn't originally expect to see 
many people I knew there, but of course ended up running into all kinds 
of familiar faces, plus some new ones (hi michael albers, nancy, etc!)  
This was such a sweet party, maybe only 150 people or so, the vibe was 
totally there, the music was totally there, it all came together 
beautifully!  And I must make special mention to our own sfraver dj 
Tom!  He ripped the party up with his killer goa trance set, AWESOME!!  
(& of course I consider it a bonus he played several of my favorite 
songs!)  He did an immensely excellent job of really bringing the 
energy in the room into focus, I could practically feel the flow of 
energy between dj & audience, he did those great music builds that get 
everybody screaming at the top of their lungs & stomping away!  He was 
obviously having a great time & so was the crowd.  Everyone who loves 
good goa should definitely keep an eye out for dj tom, he's one to look 
for!  Tom, I hope you guys do more parties, this was awesome!

Love,
Shawna

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 25 14:33:53 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA02795; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 14:33:53 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA02771; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 14:33:31 -0800
Received: from [128.32.91.97] (mmf27.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.91.97]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA30687 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 25 Mar 1996 14:33:30 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130500ad7cc78a54bd@[128.32.91.100]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 25 Mar 1996 14:32:16 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (nancy)
Subject: Amazing Sunset!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Amazing Sunset!  I was overwhelmed by this one...at least double any
turn-out from last year.  Our scene is regenerating, my friends.  Many new
people have come in and are making it stronger and more loving - their
optimism contributing to a return to the purity of early raving.  How
comforting that we do not need old-style ravers to show us the
light...newbies are arriving with positivity and grooving on the highest
vibe...

I had a premonition as I felt Sunset's strong energy...the scene has COME
BACK, in a major way.  I think this summer is going to be another Summer of
Love - a time when all the ravers will dedicate themselves to the most
beautiful group experience they can create.  I see many more presents and
group hugs and friendliness in our future!  Let's make this as incredible
as it can be!

Point Molate was gorgeous - I watched the changing colors of the sky and
the water, the lights of the endless bridge.  The music captivated
everyone, hundreds of people dancing as freely as they wanted :) .  At
first I was distressed at a "gangsta" element, looking hard and drinking
beers.  But then I noticed what they were doing - intensely dancing,
grinning, and hugging each other.  Ahh, rave is a mentality, not what you
look like.

Met some more SFRavers!  What's up Eric and Todd?  Your first Sunset, what
did you think?  In the last week I've met about ten of you (at Light, Lee
and Peter and Angela).  I'm very glad to humanize this list - the last two
weeks having conversations with a computer screen has been rather surreal.

One other happy note: yesterday I learned to appreciate Progressive House.
A bummer for me at Sunsets last year was the music.  I never could stand
vocals and piano riffs and saxophone.  Give me hard trance!! (still my
favorite).  But suddenly yesterday I got it - the beat keeps coming on and
on.  The beat sustained me, gave me energy, and the pianos and the softness
brought me on smooth trips - perfect for a Sunday afternoon in a park.  The
vocals verbalized our highest feelings..."I feel love," "set my spirit
free."  Almost like mantras for the meditative state induced by this
amazing music.

Sunset was the perfect culmination to an intense experience.  I hadn't
slept in 36 hours - I'd spent 8 hours the night before in a frenzy to
energetic trance.  Too tweaked out to sleep, Sunday got progressively
stranger as exhaustion and afterglow intensified.  I was moving to an
internal beat all day, and then I got to Sunset, to dance out all that was
in my system.  I needed the beat, but softer, slower, easing me down.
Progressive House did the trick.  I went to Sunset with a new friend :) who
I had met the night before - a newbie raver of five months, who feels his
life has been changed.  We soaked in a hot tub for nearly three hours late
at night, ahhh... I don't even remember falling asleep, it was so deep.
Today I feel totally refreshed, rejuevanation after 24 hours of total
intensity, being truly alive.  Whew!

Highlights: people dancing with torches in front of the drummer.  People
dancing on top of the slide set.  The sunset.  Group circle, holding hands.
People yelling, "THANK YOU!!" at the end of the night.  The smiles on
everyone's faces.

Going to MAD tonight - see some of you there??

Subject: sunset
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Sunset was huge... probably a little too big.

Galen's soundsystem was really straining to push all those people.  Usually
at a Sunset the central focus of the party is the music... but the system
just was not loud enough to provide that focus.  As a result, the key element
of a Sunset, the music, was not quite happening.  Then there was the drummer
who would often times completely drown out the already struggling beat.  I
don't have a problem with druming to music... but usually people use hand
drums that are not as loud.  I think the drummer should have respected
the music more and moved away from the sound system, and played softer.
At one point he actually moved closer, until he was dead center of the
dance area...  And he could not really keep a decent beat with the music.

The area seemed pretty trashed, mostly by empty alchol containers.  I
think these people need to be reminded of what the "R" in PLUR means.

And while I am being grouchy, let me just say that, IMHO, the music was
not up to par.  It seems to be that the music was too whispy and new-age.  
It did not have enough solid beats to dig my body into.  But maybe this
is a personal problem I am having with SF music in general right now.
Again, its just my humble opinion. 

I couldn't help but feel like this was not a Sunset, but instead an ordinary
outdoor party... It was great seeing a ton of friends, but without good
music and dancing, the Sunset magic is just not there for me. 

I still had fun at Sunset... but I think I had a lot more fun at 2 previous
outdoor Gateway parties and the outdoor F&F party.

-troy

 epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson) wrote:

> I forgot to mention that it was soooooo cool that "Voices inside my Head"
> by The Police was mixed into the music (who was the mastermind who done
> that?)!

If memory serves me well (not likely ;-)) this could be "Voices" by
K.C. Flight? This already a pretty old record, starting with sort-of
African drums and the chanting of "Voices inside my head, echo things
that you said", sounds familiar?

> It's fun to unexpectedly hear something familiar in all this new
> (to me) music, and adds to my enjoyment because I can identify.  I hope
> other people dug it, too, and I hope to hear more occurances of that sort
> of thing!

Personally (my $0.02) I'm not too crazy about recycling older non-rave
songs for this purpose, many of the resulting records are pretty cheezy
(like all the Oh Fortuna crap). In my opinion, each new techno record
should be an entirely new experience, showing you new sights and ideas.
Unfortunately there's so much more music produced today compared to a few
years ago this is only rarely the case. I like samples (looped and distorted)
that contribute to the trance induced by the record, not because they
remind "the raver" of something he/she's heard before.

> OK, back to work,

I was afraid you would say that  ;-)

The Frying Dutchman

Short message for other Dutch person on this list:
(Michael Albers uit Nederland, je bent niet alleen!)


---End of forwarded mail from epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)

I am reminded of my first rave.  I went with a very good friend, some 
other newbies, and a few old-timers.  I never went expecting anything 
from anyone.  I was curious, what was it all about that some of my good 
friends were so into?  I had an absolutely amazing time, was overwhelmed, 
was learning all about what was going on, was put off by some of the lesser 
elements.  But, I really enjoyed myself AND I came back.  We were all 
newbies at one time, right?  Some ppl will like it and some won't.  I am 
not as *in* to it as some others, but I still love it for all that it can 
offer me, and I try and give back what I can.  It took me awhile to *get* 
the music, but when I experienced my catharsis, there was 
no looking back.  I LOOOOOOOVVVVVVEEE it.  But to experience it, I had to 
take that first step and just go with someone else who had gone before.  
My only regret is to not have found it sooner!  

kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*.*

"Talk is cheap..."

> Sunset was huge... probably a little too big.

I agree, Troy. I don't expect these events to last long. Not at that
size. Not with that many cars. Not with that much trash. I left a
little after the sun went down, wish I could have stayed late to clean
up, but there were still too many people there. I've got to remember
to bring trash bags next time too.

> not up to par.  It seems to be that the music was too whispy and new-age.

somewhere, but that was the best of it. There seemed to be alot of
samba type beats. I'm full-on "tainted by trace" myself, Goa trance
does me so good. I thought that the Chocolate Factory studio put out
Goa like PRANA and Tsuyoshi Suzuki? I guess they do all kinds. I still
danced for four hours straight though. There's something about dancing
outdoors on a beautiful day that just makes me
.......feel......so........real............

I hope these sunsets continue without busts.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 25 16:26:59 1996

From: James Ausman <ausman@CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199603260026.QAA16092@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friends,

Well, this was really an amazing Sunset for me. I have always felt the
sort of spiraling outward love vibe, but this time I completely fell
into it. It was better than any drug induced high I have ever been on!

It _was_ huge, and the outskirts, where people were drinking and you couldn't
really hear the music, seemed more like a barbeque or something than a Sunset.

But it was really happening on the dance floor.

What I think is happening is that a lot of diverse people are being drawn
to our community right now and are checking it out. This is both a 
wonderful thing and a scary thing. I think there is real potential for
a mass movement that could transform society. But it could just be
another "flavor of the month" for MTV. Alot of you have been around
for the last time raver visibility/popularity spiked and I am curious
what you think. I was aware of it, since I have always had lots of raver
friends, but didn't go much myself. I went to a Warfield rave in 1992(?),
and was (unsurprisingly) turned off by it. It took Sunsets last summer
for me to get it.

Most of the people on the outskirts seems to be having a good time
and were smiling, goofy, friendly, etc. But definitely making a mess!

Let's all bring a garbage bag and clean up afterwards. I often do, but
had to leave early this time. Does anyone know how much of a mess we
left behind?

Peace,
Jim

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Re: Sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sunset meant the world to me, for I had a friend there and my sister was
visiting from Buffalo (she's 18).  They were both blown away by it all (we
also went to Something Special).

I thought the numbers were fine, thought I guess parking is an issue.  That
and the fact that I love to see lots and lots of people.  The music was
good, diferent, but good, and I was happy that it kept going and going
after the sun went down.

As for the little drummer dude, that bothered me, because every time he got
off beat it sounded like a train wreck.  It can throw one off and that's no
fun.  I heard at one point a small kid was banging the drums and that was
when I felt like saying something.

I brought 10 large trash bags, and I recommend others do the same next
time.  I tied a couple to the trees and stuff to make them more noticable.
I think one of the most importnat things we can do is start picking up
trash *before* it gets dark.  Also, when you start picking up trash, people
tend to feel guilty about their area and generally pick their trash up.  I
feel very strongly about making sure we leave the place as best we can.
I'd even go so far as to suggest a little trash force (trash task force?)
that meets behind the DJ booth maybe just after sunset with bags in hand
and do a general sweep of the place.  Not crawling in between dancers or
anything, but getting piles of trash together and picking up the major
stuff.  It would at least make the final clean-up go faster.

Anyway, thanks to Pacific, the DJs and all you people for making it a most
memorable day.  :^)

Peace!

Tony

   Yeah, like most others at Sunset, I had a great time groovin' w/others 
   to the beats.  I especially liked the "hot summertime 'jazzy' sounds" 
   Joeski mixed.  He'd get me all warm and squishy with my dancing and then 
   switch us to harder grinding beats, definitely a passionate man with his 
   music.  Those NY boys ain't bad 'cause I heard them the night before at 
   Organic and they had us moving all around.
   
   Speaking of Organic, it was a pretty good space w/a nice mix of people.  
   Not too old, young, hip, clubby, etc.  Surprising for me at least!  I 
   guess I'm just a bit staid right now.  I was wondering if anyone went to 
   Aborigine.  We didn't know the map point changed and so we ended up at 
   Organic.  I'd appreciate a review if anyone went.
   
   W/r/t Lito, the drummer, he's actually a very accomplished musician 
   who's played at some clubs along with the dj's and other conga players 
   (e.g., 1015, End Up, DV8, etc.).  He was definitely outta synch in 
   comparison to hearing him in the past and though I didn't speak with him 
   afterwards, I'm sure he was frustrated too.
   
   It was good to see so many people (and sfravers) come out of the 
   woodwork for Sunset.  Perhaps this'll be part of our rites for Spring.
   
   See ya on the dance floor!
   
   Diane

The first was great!!...

I got there a little late, in time to hear all the NYC djs but I missed
pacific's crew.  As we rolled over the hill I was amazed at how many people
had showed up for this sunset..WOW.  Our family is growing in a major way
and it in't at all bad.  I met many, many people - old and new friends - I
know what you mean Amy S.  I am sorry though I didn't see or meet any new
sfravers though.  :)  I spent a lot of time up front dancing and keeping
warm.  There was sooo much energy eminating from the people dancing.
Amazing.  I was in the circle Nancy and it was great when every one voiced
their enjoyment prior to dancing individually.  I didn't go to chocolate
factory and going to sunset I didn't know what to expect from three NYC djs
but their style is similar to the sf flavour.  I even heard many popular
tracks, many I've heard Jeno spin.  I wish I had brought my camera...untill
the next.  "Thank you sunset"

Nancy wrote:
>  At
>first I was distressed at a "gangsta" element, looking hard and drinking
>beers.  But then I noticed what they were doing - intensely dancing,
>grinning, and hugging each other.  Ahh, rave is a mentality, not what you
>look like.

I noticed this too.   A bunch a guys squized their way to the front(In
front of me).  I over heard one say:"Damn no bitch'es anywhere.  Dis iz
bunk! Let's go."
Another said:"No way man.  This DJ's phat.  He's from philli or NY or someth=
in'"
They stayed.  They danced. they yelled.  They then smiled.  They
jumped/huged/and got all involved in the music.

  I thought:  This is what sunset/raving is about: The music, the love,
friendship, and your community.  I smiled when the first guy said:"Yeah
this is cool."

*snip!*

> If memory serves me well (not likely ;-)) this could be "Voices" by
> K.C. Flight? This already a pretty old record, starting with sort-of
> African drums and the chanting of "Voices inside my head, echo things
> that you said", sounds familiar?

Maybe The Police took it from an older song ... but Voices Inside My Head is 
from Zenyatta Mondatta which was released in the VERY early 80's.  :) 
i've been a Police fan for as long as i've known they existed - in fact 
they were my first concert! - but still, you could be right in that the 
ORIGINAL original was an older song.
 
> Personally (my $0.02) I'm not too crazy about recycling older non-rave
> songs for this purpose, many of the resulting records are pretty cheezy
> (like all the Oh Fortuna crap). In my opinion, each new techno record
> should be an entirely new experience, showing you new sights and ideas.

Most of the time i agree with this sentiment, but it's nice to hear 
something you REALLY love mixed in with other stuff you really love.  
When they played Comfortably Numb at Freedom (july 1/95)in the chill tent 
i was absolutely delighted.  But sometimes it works and sometimes it 
doesn't ...

k

*snip!*

> >If memory serves me well (not likely ;-)) this could be "Voices" by
> >K.C. Flight? This already a pretty old record, starting with sort-of
> >African drums and the chanting of "Voices inside my head, echo things
> >that you said", sounds familiar?
>
>Maybe The Police took it from an older song ... but Voices Inside My Head is
>from Zenyatta Mondatta which was released in the VERY early 80's.  :)
>i've been a Police fan for as long as i've known they existed - in fact
>they were my first concert! - but still, you could be right in that the
>ORIGINAL original was an older song.

You're absolutely right here, however, when I said "pretty old record"
I meant on the "rave time scale" (tm). So K.C. Flight (?) probably sampled
it from The Police. And by coincedence, they were one of the first bands
I enjoyed as a teenager, I never realized that this sample was one of
theirs.

> >Personally (my $0.02) I'm not too crazy about recycling older non-rave
> >songs for this purpose, many of the resulting records are pretty cheezy
> >(like all the Oh Fortuna crap). In my opinion, each new techno record
> >should be an entirely new experience, showing you new sights and ideas.

> Most of the time i agree with this sentiment, but it's nice to hear
> something you REALLY love mixed in with other stuff you really love.
> When they played Comfortably Numb at Freedom (july 1/95)in the chill tent
> i was absolutely delighted.  But sometimes it works and sometimes it
> doesn't ...

I do appreciate it when a good record comes along, but then mostly I prefer
the original (like Comfortably Numb) over a techno version. It takes a lot
of talent, I feel, to make something better out of something which was
already good. Many of the chill-out DJ's I've witnessed usually only play
what is "officially" considered ambient etc. We could use a bit more
creativity in that respect.

The Frying Dutchman, still waiting to hear Philip Glass while chillin'


--

At 09:14 AM 3/25/96 -0800, "Eric P. Peterson" <epaul@Synopsys.COM> wrote:
>Tonight will be the best night to see the comet.  It will be around till
>sometime the second half of April, I think.  That from this morning's
>Channel 4 News.

I went out this evening, thinking it might be hard to find in the sky.
I had a route planned in my car to find a good viewing spot, but then
decided to take it on foot.  I got about 2 minutes from my apartment
on foot, found the big dipper, and saw the fuzz ball who's tail almost
touched the ladel of the upside down big dipper with the naked eye.
It's very very cool.  Everyone go out and see it, because it'll be
a while before this comet comes around again, and it'll be quite some
time for something this spectacular.  Go see it now while the tail is
still clear.  Go go!

If I could take out the light in my parking lot, I would have a perfect
view from my bedroom window.  What I wouldn't do for a bb-gun.  :)


Cosmically,

Andrew

Received: from .best.com (volt.vip.best.com [206.86.76.239]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id AAA26996 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 00:04:51 -0800
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 00:04:51 -0800
Message-Id: <199603260804.AAA26996@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: volt@best.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 2.1.1
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Damn, sounds like Sunset rocked -- DOH!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wish I'da gone like I originally planned to.

Okay, finally hit my first rave on Saturday night (or should I say, Sunday
morning) with Something Special, and I must say, I was not disappointed. (I
don't really count the Berkeley Marina thingie even though I was there and I
liked it.)  

It was trippy for me at first, cuz the location entrance was in some small
alleyway and I'd never been to one so I didn't know what to expect.  Walking
in around 1:00am, I saw the neato laser lights, the air a touch smokey, and
loud music thumping away.  Not as many people as I thought there might be,
but still enough to make the scene happening.  I wandered about the crowd
and dance floor first to acquaint myself with the environment.  After about
5 minutes of that I kinda said "f*ck it" and jumped in the middle of the
crowd, dancing at first inhibitedly and sort of stationary, but after about
a minute of that I downshifted to whirling dervish mode and it was off to
the races from there!  I pretty much danced until my out-of-shape body
begged my spirit for a respite from the frenzied movement.

The first SFRaver I met there was Nancy (truly a pleasure to make your
acquaintance!) and after that I must have met at least another half dozen or
so people (who's names my deteriorating short term memory can no longer
produce, except for Pauly -- great meeting you too!) that are on the list
but told me they were sorta lurkers more than posters, and another half
dozen who aren't on the list but are in the scene.  They were all equally nice!

What I found most inspiring was that everybody was very kind, just there to
smile and dance and share in a very synergistic experience where a spiritual
energy just sort of flows through everybody around.  I thought I'd be tired
being up that late, especially dancing, but I wasn't.  What I did feel was
the sense of community and solidarity from the people in the crowd,
transcending limitations set both by differences in outward appearance and
disparity of individual beliefs in favor of the release of the mind and
spirit through dance and entrancing lights and sound (I particularly enjoyed
LeLe's set, and the others rocked as well!).  Basically what I discovered is
the spirituality and benevolence that seems to be lacking in the world as we
move like raindrops down a window in a storm through our daily routines.
And I'm happy to have found it here.

So anyways, I'd like to thank the people who put on Something Special, cuz
it was very much that for me, and a fitting introduction to the scene.  To
those of you I met, I'm really glad I did (meet you)!  And to those of you I
have yet to meet, I very much look forward to our meeting in the future --
yeah, that means you lurkers too!  Lotsa love to all!

Rejuvenated and reborn,

volt

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Dictionary Vol. 2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> badass          very, very good (usually applying to people)
> the bomb        really good
> candyflip       combining acid and ecstasy
> clubkid         self-explanatory
> dope            very good
> fresh           very good
> hippieflip      combining mushrooms and ecstasy
> Hella/hecka     a lot of, very
  ^^^^^^^^^^
This is a decidedly Nor-Cal word.  Everyone from So-Cal always gets 
annoyed when they hear this!! :)

> hippie crack    Nitrous
> nervous         bad, see "sketchy"
> peace!          "good-bye"
> phat            cool! (adjective, not an interjection)
> the shit        the best
> sick            1. very good (as in the best at something)
>                 2. a good track; i.e. "that beat is sick!"
> sketchy         uncertain (a bad feeling about something);
>                    description of someone on speed;
> spin            1. what a dj does
>                 2. smoking pot while drunk
> spun            coming down; not being able to sleep
> sweet           very good
> went off        was good, was "happening"
> 
> 
> can you add to the list?
>

Mime-Version: 1.0

From: geoffw@cybertribe.com (Geoff White)
Subject: Hyakutake Weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The Ancients believed that comets were harbingers of doom or disaster, a comet 
appeared in 1066 at the time of the Norman Conquest (It was Hailey's Comet),
maybe this is how the belief started that, with the appearence of a comet, 
"A King will fall".  Modern day astrologers see Comets as introducing immediate
chaotic forces of change, to most people this spells trouble but it needn't be
interpreted that way. To say the least though, in the next few months, we will 
all be living in "interesting times".

I had a good premonition about the "Rebirth of the Goddess" party, A friend knew
the woman who organized the party and I knew the space that it was being
thrown in from doing the door of a party there a couple of years ago.  I had
a friend
with me who had been to his first Party New Years eve (Acme).  I had the feeling
that this would be the kind of party that would really do the trick (for him :)
And indeed it was a fine party, definitely one of the best parties that I have
been to and the best small party of the year for me.  The space was interesting
in that you went UP a long flight of stairs into a large hall way area, as you 
went down a narrow hall there was a bathroom and a larg opening onto a "roof"
where smoking was allowed.  Smoking was not allowed anywhere else in the Party
and It made so much difference. There were turntables and candles and
decorations set up in the first room, behind that, there was a empty
carpeted room with dim lights that one could chill out or streach or quietly
chat in. Then, beyond that, stairs that went Down...
Down to the other half of the party, to the Nether World. At the bottom was
a spinning mirror ball and the entrance was always guarded by an interesting
faeire of somesort (there were many of the fair folke about that night:). The
first room was a chill-out dub room with big ass couches, and some blazing video
wallpaper supplied by Dimension 7.  Go through that and turn a corner and your
in the main dance room which PolyWog followed by Tracy completely Rocked!
With out the smoke and the pushing newbies I slid into trance so easily, though
i was afraid that I had forgot how, (it's been a long time for me), but Tracy,
as always, never let's me down, In fact, I I can't ever think of a time that
I've ever heard Tracy play a bad set.  After Tracy spun, there was a
performance by a group of fairy women which was really fine, polywog
provided the DJ back up
and one of the women did some ad-lib house vocals which were really kool.
The folks who put on the party obviously put a lot of planning into it, the
sound isolation between the rooms and the outside was really good.  This made
it easy to wonder from room to room and move into a different context each time.

I must say that there were indeed some amazing goddesses in the house that
night, Some of the women I had seen out at parties but didn't recognize them
because they were literally ... transformed.  The party reminded me of the
Your Sister's House of old but the energy was stepped up an Octave, perhapse
it was
the Comet up in the sky. If you went out to the roof area you could clearly
see it, as the big Fuzz Ball in the sky, those that couldn't see it could
definitely feel it's influence that night.  I'm told by many of my female
friends that their periods have been thrown off by this hairy star, let's
see what doom awaits us this spring.

Sunset was the amazing party that I knew it would be, Galen thank you and
crew so much for keeping the Faith and the Party alive.  Thanks for working
with the local authorities so that they see that it's nothing wrong with what
we do.  Thanks for letting those NYC DJs from the Chocolate Factory rock
SF on a Ney York Stylee, and thanks for showing my newbie friend his first
real Rave :) Yeah and thaks to Kevin,Jerry and Hector of Organic for bringing
those guys out here.

>> peace!          "good-bye"

>> the shit        the best

>>                 2. a good track; i.e. "that beat is sick!"

The original of Voices Inside My Head was absolutely a Police original.
The Police started around 1977, and nothing they released on record during
their career as a band was ever a cover.  They were masters at blending
elements of ska, reggae, punk and rock, were one of my favorite bands and
immensely popular when I was in high school, and were (& are) very talented
musicians.

Here endeth the lesson :)

- E

>                                            Black Adder

for no other reason than I didn't feel like leaving and the cold didn't 
bother me very much, I left Sun & Warren to crash in the Honda Civic 
while I made the rounds with a trash bag and no flashlight. Ended up 
staying till around 10 (?) when the park ranger kicked me out and even at 
that point I kept stumbling across random ash tray squats. We need either 
a vacuum cleaner or fewer smokers.

Ended up scoring 30 cents, 1 pipe (no pot but an OK amount of resin), and 
1 razor blade (ouch!).

This is more in regards to Eric's post of a week or so ago regarding 
raves and sex drive. Sex is one of the few "acceptable" ways for men
in our society to give and recieve affection, especially with other
adults. This is not true in our little world. So it is not really 
surprising that finding your need for affection met, your sexual 
"need" is not as strong. I find the same thing happening to me, to a
certain extent.
