>rolling   "having done MDMA" (mostly a midwest term)
>rushing         ""           (East coast)
>eein'           ""           (I think this one only pops up around Baltimore)
>on e            ""           (East coast)
>xing            ""           (i'd say this is more west/south west  US)
>stoked    anticipatory, looking forward to something, 'Hyped'

okay, you forgot florida's "blowin up" and some east coast kidz say
"trippin on e".  i didn't realize this sort of slang was regional till like
a year ago...and then once in toronto when i mentioned something about
"rolls" to someone they sed "rolls?  what the fuck are rolls?"...another
drug related term is one i wish ppl didn't have to apply to parties around
here but have to too much, and that's "in a hole"...yikes, let me say it's
impossible for a vibe to exist at a party when half the kidz there are k'd
outta their heads.  lesee...what about "zooted"?

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael

Subject: possible raving roomie? (non-rave)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, it's getting to be about that time that I've GOT to get out of the 
Concord area!!

So, for anybody who's interested, this is what I'm looking for:

I am looking to move out of my current apartment and move into a house 
somewhere in the Berkeley/North Oakland area.  I will probably begin 
looking for places in May with the intention of doing the actual move 
in June.  I'm not in any situation where I'm required to move, so this 
time around I'm really going to take the time to find the perfect place 
& a nifty roommate to share the place with.  Last time I was in a 
desperte situation to find a roommate and ended up with a religious 
Catholic fresh out of rural Minnesota for the first time in his life!  
A nice guy of course, but is not someone who is "on my level" if you 
know what I mean.  So this time I will search for & find a roomie more 
on that level with me! :)  Hence my posting to sfraves about this, a 
raving roommate would be much more to my liking!  Anyway, to begin 
with, what I'm looking for is one roommate who can afford about the 
same as I can ($600-$650 a month) so we can get a fat house!  I am 
definitely looking for a house this time, not an apartment, preferably 
with a bathtub & fireplace! :) (don't know how feasible this is, but 
something cool might just pop up, I have the time to look!)  As far as 
the roommate is concerned, male or female, gay or straight, whatever, 
is fine.  I work a normal 8-5 monday thru friday job, so I guess I'd 
want somebody who's more quiet on the weekdays (someone who probably 
works similar hours as me I suppose & thus doesn't rage loudly into the 
weekday nights ;), but does whatever on the weekends!  I have a very 
sweet cat (has not yet once made a mistake in any other area other than 
her catbox, & always uses her scratching posts!).  I have an apartment 
full of furniture, so someone with less than a complete set of 
furniture is just fine.  I would probably (due to my cat) prefer 
someone who didn't have a dog, but another cat would be fine.  Also, of 
course, would like an area that's safe for us to live in & safe for my 
cat to go outside & play. 

If anybody is interested, please email me privately & we'll talk about 
it!  I think that's about it, if I can think of anything I left out, 
I'll post it as a P.S. 

thanks!

Love,
Shawna

Received: from [128.146.24.138] (slip2-60.acs.ohio-state.edu [128.146.24.138]) by postbox.acs.ohio-state.edu (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id RAA20856 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:20:35 -0500 (EST)

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 17:34:11 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: mccusty.1@postbox.acs.ohio-state.edu (michael mccusty)
Subject: Re: Dictionary Vol. 2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Cool, thanks!  Zooted?  Don't know that one.  I wonder if any "rap" terms
>are common in the rave community, like def, fresh, hype, etc.  You down,
>man?  You wit' it?

zooted means you're having a lot of fun with the aid of mad chemicals.  (i
hate to say "fucked up" because i think that is a term more applicable to
sobriety).  there's another one, "mad", tho it's more east-coastal.  mad, a
lot, many.  example from a wu-tang track:  "niggaz i know, be runnin'
around wit mad fukkin cash!!".  "mad cash" could also be worded "tall
bank".  hip hop terms are used a lot too.  personally i use "dope" a lot
and sometimes "fresh" or "live".

comin thru again son, representin 614. act like you know, foo. ;)

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael
allroy

http://www.angelfire.com/free/mmccusty.html

"rabbit's clever," said pooh thoughtfully.
"yes," said piglet, "rabbit's clever."
"and he has brain."
"yes," said piglet, "rabbit has brain."
there was a long silence.
"i suppose," said pooh, "that that's why he never understands anything."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 26 15:13:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA28053; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 15:13:08 -0800
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA28031; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 15:12:59 -0800
Received: (from tas12@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id PAA26181; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 15:12:41 -0800 (PST)
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 15:12:40 -0800 (PST)
From: TALILLA SCHUSTER <tas12@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: tas12@orion
To: "Eric P. Peterson" <epaul@Synopsys.COM>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Goa?
In-Reply-To: <v02130534ad7e06ea4d17@[146.225.72.168]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960326150423.24527A-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Besides being a place in India, the DJ Goa Gil is an older, dreadlocked, 
fantastic master of hard trance. He's been spinning for about twenty 
years, but didn't really get accepted into the SF scene until about last 
year or so, when trance got more popular. He used to go on tour a lot, 
but recently he's been around more. He is completely amazing - sort of 
the grandaddy of trance, and the two times I've seen him were two of the 
best parties I've ever been to. He does stuff with DATs, not just records 
and travels to India and all over putting on epic parties. I know that 
some friends of mine were planning to go to India for a party; I don't 
know if that already happened. Anyway, that exhausts my limited 
knowledge, which I hope is accurate. You could try to see him sometime. 
Talilla

Received: from [153.37.82.81] (pool029.Max3.Santa-Clara.CA.DYNIP.ALTER.NET [153.37.82.93]) by sweden.it.earthlink.net (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA26042 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 16:42:02 -0800
Message-Id: <v01530505ad7da81b2281@[153.37.82.81]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Date: Tue, 26 Mar 1996 16:42:44 +0200
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: exodus@earthlink.net (Austin)
Subject: A growing family 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was kickin' back at a friends house last saturday and the Grind on MTV's
spring break came on (we were bored).  They weren't playin' the normal club
beats but rather some great house tunes I hear alot now and last year at
raves.  A few trible tracks, "disco's revenge"(only name I remember), and
some other housey beat.  At first I thought "Hey, I love these songs." but
then I realized, it's really started - House is getting very mainstream.  I
was in Tower yesterday and noticed their Ambient/Tecno section had doubled
since the last time I had been in there (a few months) and there were
several new club/dj/rave magazines on the shelves (I had never noticed
before).
   My Point: I love music, especially new music that isn't main stream.  I
got into house/techno in 93 because it was new, impresive, mind opening and
I love to dance - not because it's popular.  Growth is not all bad as long
as our family doen't progress in the wrong direction.  Sunset was huge for
me too but it seemed almost everyone knew the meaning of Peace, Love, Unity
and Respect (you can't expect everyone to help clean up some have to
go/some are too fu*ked to help - I did my part.).  There seems to be a new
influx of newbies to the sence.  IMHO I think we should all make sure we
help each other out and show the newbies the true path of what rave is all
about.  Many people are going to come into our family this year. Keeping
the vibe strong and true is the only way to keep the everyone happy and to
ensure a great year.  Keep the underground, on the down under.  On a post I
read titled "new dawn"(I don't remember who wrote it), the author mentioned
that they noticed this growth too and were moving their tastes to jungle
beats to escape the popularity of house.  I've notice my tastes move to
more break beats and goa/trance but as long as the vibe is still there I
will continue to enjoy all forms of music in our family.

Much love to SF      Lookin' forward to a great year.

Austin

end.  Sometimes it's good to feel the music not bouncing off you, but
moving THROUGH you!  That's how it was when I saw Pantera (I know, I know)
at the San Jose Event Center, when they played with Sepultura (and I just
KNOW y'all wish you were there - hehe!).  The sound really does something
to your body when it feels like that.  Maybe not goo all the time, though.

epitomize the SF flava...

will begin to understand, even embrace, what it means to us.  Then they'll
BE us!  Maybe that's long-range thinking...?

Hello All,


It's me...Marty from Fresno.  I just wanted to write, say hi, and say 
that I had an excellent time at my first Sunset.

was great to finally meet some people from the list...Kaysee, Leslie, 
Moonpup, Wille, Becca, Joe, Dave, the pretty blonde girl sitting on the 
ice chest (didn't get your name), and I'm sure others I'm forgetting.  
Forgive me :)

Anyway,  I'm on Spring Break next week and I'll definitely be around on 
the weekend coming up.  Anyone planning on going to the party on Sat 
afternoon in Golden Gate Park?

Hugz and more HUGZ...

interesting thing i learned in a looooonnnnngggg discussion of goa trance
that went on on mw-raves a few months ago (november actually i think, you
can learn A LOT from it [i sure did] so check the archives if you are
interested), the music was never actually meant to be mixed & beatmatched,
etc, it was always played track to track off of DAT in india because vinyl
would warp in the the intense heat of goa...

love, luck, and lollipops,
michael
allroy

of 21 may not read this post. All residents of Utah, and Mormons

read this post.

I know this is nonrave, but since I got most of the comet mails
from this list[ and have found myself looking upwards all along
the drive home, lately], I am posting the following poem by 
Robert Frost (a native born San Franciscan whose birthday is today!):


ON LOOKING UP BY CHANCE AT THE
CONSTELLATIONS 

You'll wait a long, long time for anything much
To happen in heaven beyond the floats of cloud
And the Northern Lights that run like tingling nerves.
The sun and moon get crossed, but they never touch,
Nor strike out fire from each other nor crash out loud.
The planets seem to interfere in their curves
But nothing ever happens, no harm is done.
We may as well go patiently on with our life,
And look elsewhere than to stars and moon and sun
For the shocks and changes we need to keep us sane.
It is true the longest drought will end in rain,
The longest peace in China will end in strife.
Still it wouldn't reward the watcher to stay awake
In hopes of seeing the calm of heaven break
On his particular time and personal sight.
That calm seems certainly safe to last to-night.



Sorry if this mail pissed anyone off!
I found all the above chasing down CNN links 
[The poems are at http://pronews.pro-net.co.uk/home/catalyst/RF/poem2.html]

regards,
-harsh deshmane
hdeshma@scdt.intel.com

>man there is always this grey ring of dirt.  I think some comes from the 
>porta-potties---YUK---and I am always scared to touch it.  I always find 
>myself in the porta-potty trying to hold up the bottom of my pants so 
>they don't get dirty.  It's pretty close to impossible, what with trying 
>to pull down your pants to go to the bathroom, squat over the gross 
>sludge, and relieve yourself.  AAAhhh, it's those times when I long for 
>male anatomy.  tee hee hee  :) :)

>kc
>
>
Hey, when you sweat, rub your eyes, pick your nose, whatever - then you
stick your hands in your pockets, on a wall, whatever, dry dust sticks to
the sticky moistness of your fingernail crevice, and, VOILA!!! It's a lot
more organic than dirt. Just FYI: thats how colds & flus get around. You
shake someone elses hand, then they get some of that virus-infested gunk and
the little guys start having another party. Welcome to the world of organic
life!!! Wet-naps would be nice at those warehouse parties....

	Hello everyone!
	Jana and I are living in a beautiful 3 bedroom house in Montclair 
(Berkeley/Oakland hills).  Two people have moved out, and we might have 
to as well, because we can't afford to stay here by ourselves (We really 
don't want to leave!).  We have two bedrooms available to share with 
individuals that  groove with us.
	The house is surrounded with trees, and good energy, but isn't 
close to public transportation.  We have a garage, washer/dryer, 
dishwasher, fireplace, deck, and 2 bathrooms.  A five minute walk will 
get you to beautiful forest preserves, that extend for miles.  Music can 
be played at all hours, however we're not looking to become a party 
house...    Rent is $1350.00  divided by 3 it's $450.00...  Divided by 
four it's $338.00,  plus utilities 
	Our personal interests are in music (trance/acid, tribal jams: 
drums, diges, etc.), organizing free events,  spirituality, and 
creativity.  We are vegetarian, loving, open-minded, honest creatures 
that enjoy evolving, and sharing.

this address (SFR mail mostly), or my other one (mostly

Once again revealing my archaic history, I must relate that I saw the
Police on their first American tour (early 1979 I think) at the Atlantis
(later the 930) in DC.  They were driving around the country in a
station wagon or something.  I met up with Stewart Copeland's brother
Miles later that summer when I went to England, he was the publisher of
Time Out at that time.  Anyway, the Police didn't sound like anyone else
then and I liked the reggae-pop stuff.  They rocked the little 930 club
*hard*.  I'm still a big fan of much of their stuff, and think that
Ghost in the Machine is one of the 20 or 30 best albums I have.

Where I would draw the line is Sting's evident misogyny, which is always
peeking around the edges of his tunes but showed up most noticeably in
"Every Breath You Take," which no matter how you decide to interpret it
is pretty straightforwardly a banal ballad about stalking.

"Hungry for You," "Demolition Man" and the rest though -- they are great.
I played "Secret Journey" to start my set at the New Moon in Forestville
a year ago, and that turned out to be quite a premonition for a rather
cinematically gripping party . . .

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 26 22:59:11 1996

Received: from LOCALNAME (pool012.Max3.San-Francisco.CA.DYNIP.ALTER.NET [153.37.100.12]) by norway.it.earthlink.net (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id WAA25154 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 26 Mar 1996 22:57:59 -0800

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Courtney Nielsen <cnielsen@earthlink.net>
Subject: All you comet-heads...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If y'all got time to read a good book or 2 or 3: 
Check these out

THE HAMMER OF GOD - by Arthur C Clarke (yes, the man who changed all of our
lives-he invented the communications satellite, ya know...)
Its a novel where everything mentioned about the past is fact and everything
mentioned about the future is intelligent prediction...Its about an asteroid
that got broken off its path and is pulled toward Earth.  It gives a great
history about past comet confrontations as wells as future political
insights (Like all the countries in the world having to get together to
figure this thing out) - I could not put the book down til I was done
reading, the main topic of the novel was how to deflect this massive chunk
of rock heading our way.

COMET - Carl Sagan & Ann Druyan 
This book is out of print but you can still find it in bargain sections and
Used book shops. It gives a complete history of comet study and tells you
everything you would want to know about comets. The 1st chapter is great -
he gives you a ride on a comet through its entire journey.  I think the most
interesting thing I learned from this book is about the hundreds of MILLIONS
of comets in our solar system (most of them are dormant, just waiting to be
pushed just a teeny bit to be pulled in by the sun's gravity).

LUCIFERS HAMMER - Larry Niven & Jerry Pournelle 
A really great novel - what would happen to Earth and us after a comet would
hit us. It's really frightening, but really cool too, cause it gets into how
geologically things would be different (like the San Juaquin Valley becoming
the San Juaquin Sea), as well as social things, like how our society would
change, after as well as before, when it was discovered that the comet was
going to hit. Author Larry Niven's a wacky guy- he likes to get everyone
drunk at Sci-Fi converntions with his Irish Coffe stand.

---------------------------------------COMET
TRIVIA------------------------------------ 

Jupiter is our natural comet deflector. If it wasn't there, a
species-destroying comet or asteroid would hit us every 100,000 years,
instead of every 100,000,000 years (whew!).

In 1908 a comet hit Tunguska, Siberia and flattened 2000 square kilometers
of forest.
If it was delayed by 2 hours, Moscow would have been flattened.

One of NASA's prime projects is comet deflection. In 2126 the comet
Swift-Tuttle will make an approach that will be a little too close-
fragments of the comet would cause 100 Tunguska-equivalent explosions in ONE
DAY. But thats a long way off. I think our next-of-kin will have something
figured out by then. :}

I just have to go on record saying I liked the music that was played at Sunset.

There were maybe a few too many people, but it was so amazing last year,
that I'm sure people talked about it all winter long.  So now, spring come
around again and everyone wants a piece.  Very understandable IMHO.

The sound system was adequate IMO.  I danced pretty far away from the
speakers and could feel the music coming through the ground up into my feet.
It was good enough for me.

The drum kit needed to go.  The guy had a few moments, but....I wish they
were the only moments.

Rick

> 
> 
> >With the couple of opinions about the music at last week's sunset, I just
> >must reitterate (sp?) my view here.  THAT WAS- WHAT IT IS!  I can't get
> >enough of that shit!  To me that defines the S.F. sound.  You felt it lacked
> >the beat, mabye it was the underpowered system, I don't know, but Man,
> >someone please back me up here.  HOUSE MUSIC ALL NIGHT & DAY LONG!
> >Steveo
> Sometimes I get tired of people dissin House-I mean I love musical
> variety,trance and the harder stuff is nice ,but my heart is with house and
> last Sunset confirmed this for me again-house,the sunshine,shoulders
> swayin, heads bouncing up&down under the tree branches,lights of the bridge
> reflecting on the water...ya the sound system was kinda small ,as it has
> been at every sunset I've been to, but this is probably a legal thing with
> the rangers ect.
> 

As I recall, I don't think I ever dissed house.  I said something
about not having beats I can dig my body into.  Goa trance, hard
trance and techno are perfect examples of this, when the beat is
too fast, I can't grove down into the beat.  Music needs to move my
body... and HOUSE (with it's million house derivatives) is definately the 
best music for this.

What I don't like is "bouncy" music where all I can do is jerk my body
to around.  I have a whole theory they was well-discussed on socal-raves
about how larger people (I'm 6-2) like slower tempo music... just becuase
we have more body mass to move around on each beat.  Smaller people can
move their body faster, and therefore may like faster music.  Remember, this
is just my silly theory, but I think there is some substance to it.

Reflecting back on Sunset, I think it was the more the size of the system,
and not the quality of the music, that kept me from getting into a deep
dancin' groove.

-troy... considerably less grouchy today.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 27 10:26:23 1996

Date: 27 Mar 96 13:23:36 EST
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Sunset continued
Message-ID: <960327182336_71165.755_GHL104-6@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

OK, three days late but here's my two cents....

I liked that Sunset was so crowded, because for the most part I liked the crowd,
and it was nice to meet so many new people ....

I also loved the music, but wish it could have been louder -- oh well, how picky
we get, don't we! Having a free outdoor party like this in March, when other
parts of the US are sitting in snow or soaking in rain... we are truly the
fortunate ones!!

Interesting feedback on the drum kit guy ... I've already voiced my thoughts on
how drummers usually distract from djs --- I wonder how the djs felt about this
guy, and what it would take for a PLUR-oriented crowd to ask someone to move ...
There were some people with tamblas (tablas?) drumming for a while near where I
was sitting and I loved that....

and I loved meeting Amy, Rick, Marty, Knucklehead, Eric, Mike -- and seeing
other sfr buds (Todd, Moonpup, Mike, etc.) = )   

I'm hearing more people worried that the music we love is becoming more
mainstream -- like that's bad or something -- I think the potential problem is
not that more people are loving the music -- don't we think it's *so good* that
everyone would benefit from it?  Let's not be selfish with the music, and let's
not think that just because something becomes popular, it becomes less
interesting.  If it's good, it's good.  Period.

The potential problem is too many people at events -- so if this trend for the
huge Sunset crowd continues, maybe it is time to change the Pacific #, go a
little more underground on certain parties -- because what makes a party special
is the music PLUS the vibe, and having the right people in the right quanties
creates the vibe.....

My 2 cents of time is up....    See ya!    Leslie  : )

Date: Wed, 27 Mar 1996 19:50:41 GMT
Message-Id: <199603271950.TAA00334@shgc.Stanford.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: piercy@toolik.Stanford.EDU (Mark Piercy)
Subject: Go'n Mainstream?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Is it all gonna go mainstream,big time, above ground or totally
comercial??-look at the UK if you want to see a bleak future; totally
coporate, label sponsorships,dress codes,rock star DJ's, 45,000 people at
$30 "raves", ect- look at Dream, Mix Mag or any dance rag from the UK and
you'll see what I mean(or go there).  Today I saw a full page add by
Moonshine in the Gaurdian-whats that tell ya..it's gettin big here too? but
maybe not..

I dont have a problem with new people, it does'nt matter weather your first
party was Get Wicked in '91 or the last Sunset, whether you like acid house
or jungle, we were all newbies once.   Ya that sunset was huge and to go
mainstream would mean the end of something great, but it's not so much how
many people are stating to go to raves, but the motivations of these people
and most important; the motivations of the people who promote the parties
we go to, make the music we love- if that starts to be done ONLY for $$(and
thats what coporations are for, (dont try to tell me anything different!) 
than it's over.  
Some things I see tell me this might be comming...."raves" thrown by record
labels (just look at all those logos on the fliers), cd givaways at the
door(should'nt  you just want to go rather than be enticed be some stupid
marketing tactic!!), same goes with fliers that promise everything under
the fucking sun ,"special treats", dancing women, world brotherhood, peace,
sorry but these are mainsteam tactics , they are regressive and cheap! 
Sure, this has been going on for a long time, but one thing is different
and that is BIG companies are getting intrested (Levis,Virgin, ect)  How
would you like to see a flier with a McDonalds, Levis, MTV and Virgin logo
on it?-I've  this in Germany.  .  It's easy to prevent this-with your
wallet, dont go to parties that use these tactics, some might say;"come on
be realistic" well  whose realism?, what exactly does it mean to be
realistic-to give up on any ideals you have?  How' bout the focus be the
MUSIC and the vibe, everything else should come naturally.
Be on the lookout!!
SEeYa
Mark

Subject: music is music is music is music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

you know I could'nt help but notice how critical some of us are......I
personally like the styles of house that I like and I dislike the styles of
house that I dislike, and I pick and choose where I would go from day to
day and night to night........week to week .......month to month........now
a party like sunset is special, it has a reputation of being positive, and
the pacific crew has done a fantastic job to work out a relationship with
the authorities that allow us to enjoy such a wonderful vibe, in such a
wonderful place. 
 
I feel that there is a time & place for trance, a time & place for deep
house, a time and place for trip hop, and a time and place for ambient
etc...etc...etc... 
 
........and no-one has a right to dog the music that any of the DJ's
played, and I think it's ticky tack to rip someones party, because YOU
personally don't like the styles played. 
 
where were you when the mess was needed to be cleaned up ?...ask yourself ?
 are you in a position to complain..........when was the last killer
outdoor party you threw ??? 
 
I think a little more appreciation for the pacific crew and their decision
to have who-ever they want to play is in order...........and a little less
critisism.......I personally couldn't hear alot of the music due to so many
people surrounding the dj and the sound system.......so it must have
sounded pretty good to someone............and in addition..........what I
did hear may not have been MY favorite style of house, but the vibe was so
far out there, that it made zero difference to me.......I enjoyed the feel
of the people.........and sometimes its about the people........not JUST
the music.......moonpup

you know I could'nt help but notice how critical some of us are......I
personally like the styles of house that I like and I dislike the styles of
house that I dislike, and I pick and choose where I would go from day to
day and night to night........week to week .......month to month........now
a party like sunset is special, it has a reputation of being positive, and
the pacific crew has done a fantastic job to work out a relationship with
the authorities that allow us to enjoy such a wonderful vibe, in such a
wonderful place. 
 
I feel that there is a time & place for trance, a time & place for deep
house, a time and place for trip hop, and a time and place for ambient
etc...etc...etc... 
 
........and no-one has a right to dog the music that any of the DJ's
played, and I think it's ticky tack to rip someones party, because YOU
personally don't like the styles played. 
 
where were you when the mess was needed to be cleaned up ?...ask yourself ?
 are you in a position to complain..........when was the last killer
outdoor party you threw ??? 
 
I think a little more appreciation for the pacific crew and their decision
to have who-ever they want to play is in order...........and a little less
critisism.......I personally couldn't hear alot of the music due to so many
people surrounding the dj and the sound system.......so it must have
sounded pretty good to someone............and in addition..........what I
did hear may not have been MY favorite style of house, but the vibe was so
far out there, that it made zero difference to me.......I enjoyed the feel
of the people.........and sometimes its about the people........not JUST
the music.......moonpup

Since I wrote the critical post of the Sunset party, I will assume the
"you" moonpup is referring to is me.
 
> you know I could'nt help but notice how critical some of us are......I
> personally like the styles of house that I like and I dislike the styles of
> house that I dislike, and I pick and choose where I would go from day to
> day and night to night........week to week .......month to month........now
> a party like sunset is special, it has a reputation of being positive, and
> the pacific crew has done a fantastic job to work out a relationship with
> the authorities that allow us to enjoy such a wonderful vibe, in such a
> wonderful place. 

Please don't think I don't have ultimate respect for the Pacific crew, just
becuase I wrote a critical review of their party.
  
> where were you when the mess was needed to be cleaned up ?...ask yourself ?
>  are you in a position to complain..........when was the last killer
> outdoor party you threw ??? 

Well, "killer" is a subjective term... but I was involved with 3 outdoor
ODP (Open Deck Parties) with other socal-raves members while in Los Angeles...
I think these parties were killer.  I could give you names of sfravers
who were there to get their opinion, if you want.  I always try to do
whatever I can to help out at a free party.

> I think a little more appreciation for the pacific crew and their decision
> to have who-ever they want to play is in order...........and a little less
> critisism.......I personally couldn't hear alot of the music due to so many
> people surrounding the dj and the sound system.......so it must have
> sounded pretty good to someone............and in addition..........what I
> did hear may not have been MY favorite style of house, but the vibe was so
> far out there, that it made zero difference to me.......I enjoyed the feel
> of the people.........and sometimes its about the people........not JUST
> the music.......moonpup 

Well, we have seen this sort of arguement over and over and over again
on rave mailing lists... the fine line between giving the scene Unconditional
Positive Support and giving honest reviews of parties.  Are you saying
that if I don't have anything good to say I should not say it all?  What
I see in our scene now is friendly competition to see who can throw the 
best free parties... it is is pushing our scene forward in an incredible
way.  I simply gave an honest review of what I thought of the party, and
I repeatedly stated that the opinions were mine.  If you think the party
was stellar, then great!  express those opinions.  But if we were never
critical of parties, I doubt you would see them improve much.

-troy

When we were at the Desert Move in & outside of Vegas last year some famous 
German DJ was spinning the hardest techno and tranciest nightmare in the middle 
of a Sunday afternoon (1:00 pm).  It was 100 degrees out, the sun was straight 
up, and pretty much everybody had been up for the whole weekend. There were about 
500 people standing around watching 10 Germans just go for it (in full black 
attire) in front of the stacks. Some of the same Germans who had earlier asked 
us, "how come ravers in the US don't do COKE?!!!" I'll never forget the look on 
my friends faces as we all preyed for for something a little easier on our souls. 
I mean it just wasn't an approporiate setting. 

 I like hard stuff too.
 There's a time and place for everything.
 Please, I've already been to hell once.
 "He/she who brought the box gets to choose the tunes."
 'nuff said.

-CS
 Solle Clothing Co.

courtney,

there are so many different flavors of jungle and goa. to pass these styles
off as being too hectic for a sunday afternoon shows me you may not have had
much exposure to the various subgenres of jungle and trance. dj flux (who is
trying to get an opening spot at sunset) spins some of the best ambient
jungle i've heard. check him out at bahia on wed. nights. his vibe is quite
appropriate for the sunset atmosphere. if the beats are too fast for you,
then follow the basslines at halftime. talk about groovin'!!! house is cool
to groove to, but it just gets too boring the way the dj's at sunset spin.
they need to cut that shit up more, use some sampling/looping, and also some
processing effects, instead of just beatmixing from one track into the other.
that style is just too basic and unimaginative. 

ciao 4 now,
-theron

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 27 16:07:16 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA01386; Wed, 27 Mar 1996 16:07:16 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA01379; Wed, 27 Mar 1996 16:07:12 -0800
Received: from [128.32.160.69] (hmfmac31.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.69]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA16342 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 27 Mar 1996 16:06:37 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130503ad7f8540471d@[128.32.160.69]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 27 Mar 1996 16:05:25 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Music and Food at Sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it just gets too boring the way the dj's at sunset spin.
>they need to cut that shit up more, use some sampling/looping, and also some
>processing effects, instead of just beatmixing from one track into the other.
>that style is just too basic and unimaginative.


I'm afraid I have to agree.

First, though, much props to the Pacific crew for all the effort they put
out to throw the most awesome weekly outdoor party ever!  I think we can
all do our part to lessen some of their burden and make Sunsets even more
outrageous...like bringing trash bags, flashlights, teams to pick up
garbage, recycling boxes, etc.  I hate to think of all of them picking up
after us ingrates after all they have done!!

But I would also love to see Sunset expand from a dance party to a great
big Sunday rave picnic/bbq/gathering kind of thing.  I know someone on this
list has a giant BBQ - it would be cool to see it at Sunset.  Someone could
sell hamburgers and veggiedogs and tofuthingies for cheap.  Others could
bring salads and fruit and cookies and we could all EAT together like a
family.  Sharing food does establish a primal bond, much like dancing.

Now, the MUSIC.  Yes, this is Pacific's party and usually THEY are the dj's
and it is their right to play the music they (and many other Sunset
devotees) love.  But PERSONALLY, I do get bored with the straightforward
house.  There's no edge, no trippiness.  Maybe they could mix up the flava
a bit - ambient to begin, house for late afternoon, some deeper trancey
energetic grooves for later on, smooth it out again at the end?

The best raves bring you on a musical journey.  I find several hours of the
exact same type of music (of anything!) to be tiresome.  Variety!  Sunset
is great, but with all of our input on every aspect it could get even
better.  Anyone know if any Pacific crewmembers are on this list?

Cooperatively,
     Nancy

Theron wrote:

>118-125. same speed as the house at sunset, but much more psychoactive with

Hey, that solves the dilemma, huh?  Slowed-down tripped-out trance for our
recuperating Saturdays or Sundays...

The SFSound has predominated for too long.  I know I've passed on many
parties when I get a flier promising "Jeno, Tony, Dan, Galen..."  I really
don't feel the same crowd response when this music plays (with the one
exception of the last Sunset!).  I search, often in vain, for mention of
Ethan or Dutch or DRC.  Goa and trance need the exposure!!

Eric wrote:
>I hope that many, if not all, people who put on the parties in these parts,
>as well as those who are thinking of getting into throwing parties in the
>future, will take all reviews as building blocks fore creating parties that
>everyone will enjoy.

Depends on the motivation of the promoters.  I bet the ones who throw free
events - the ones who give out of love - care about people's experience!
Yes, hopefully we can give and take criticism in the spirit it is meant -
to take us even higher, not to tear any of us down.


  More up-front info on what types of music will be
>spun and basic aspects of the space would do wonders for helping people
>decide which parties they should go to to get the most enjoyment out of
>their experience.  Yes?

Once people have put in some time in the scene they know what dj spins what
kind of music...so they make their party choices based on that.  Also, you
can tell from the flier where the party will be.  For instance, an
underground, tiny flier = warehouse in the city, $5-10.  A 4-color,
fold-out, 15 dj's, bigtime lasers = some arena out in the 'burbs, or a
legal location in the city, $15-20.

Also if you see a lot of verbiage about unity and togetherness and dawning
of a new age...you can bet it will cost at least $20 to get in.  Hmmm,
experiencing love and community just gets more and more expensive, doesn't
it?  Beware of opportunists exploiting our ideals to fatten their own
pockets!!

I'm also very wary when the voicemail doesn't list price...every time I've
encountered this it's been $20.  :( .

Every day I'm getting closer to only supporting the true underground.  The
last Gathering - $25, several thousand people, beefy security guards -
turned me off so badly.  How do you guys feel about the massive "raves"?

Wondering,
   Nancy

Message-Id: <v02130506ad7f8ec979cd@[128.32.160.69]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 27 Mar 1996 16:50:59 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: End of the Underground?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I hope everyone read Mark's post - we do have to be vigilant about our
scene being co-opted!  There may not be any way to hold back the corporate
kidnapping of raving.  How far off are we now anyway with  major promoters
who promise "love" and "peace" in return for your $25?  The fact is is that
some parts of the scene have been exploited by individuals to make a
profit.  Corporate America has been remarkably shortsighted in dismissing
techno, still, as a fad and too risky an investment.  Pretty soon they'll
realize that the music is just expanding.  The crowds at Sunset testify to
techno/house and rave's increasing popularity.

So, "raving" (in the mainstream sense) will no longer be our little (big)
secret anymore.  But what we CAN hold onto is the values of the
UNDERGROUND.  We need to reiterate and promote these ideals in connection
with the smaller events for people coming in.  Otherwise, if people attend
undergrounds thinking they're just smaller Cool Worlds, they will not know
to leave their baggage at the door and enter with open heart, open mind,
open arms and a big smile!

Is there a way we can maintain the purity of these parties, so that they
endure despite the arrival of newbies?  Can we structure the experience in
such a way that it will stand on its own, aside from the people?  By that I
mean an experience that is love and unity, and if someone comes in with
negativity they will not corrupt the vibe, but recognize it is not for them
and go elsewhere...?

I'm remembering the drunk guys at Sunset looking for "bitches," but finding
instead an ecstatic groove.  Now, these guys probably are not suddenly
enlightened feminists, but on Sunday they had to check those attitudes at
the dancefloor :) .

What can each of us do individually to strengthen that special vibe?  For
my part, I'm trying to remember to smile more, look in people's eyes more,
say hello first, bring presents, hug first, join a hand-holding circle,
start a group hug!  I'm also being very selective in which events I support
with my time, energy, and money.

This was at the end of the beautiful message thrust into my hand at
Something Special --
"Ravers Unite and keep our scene alive!!"

Amen.
Love, Nancy

>   Nancy

The only problems I have with the huge events are: the price (over $20 is
too much for ANY party, IMHO), and the guys with flashlights who shine
light in your eyes and say "You're pretty messed up, aren't you?" and
laugh.  You wonder if they're narcs, security, gangstas, or what...also, I
find the smaller parties to have a more unifying, family feel among the
crowd, and the djs at smaller parties strike me as caring more about how
the crowd receives what they're doing.  I stand by a statement I made a
while back: if you want to shell out the big bucks to watch a performance,
go see a concert.  I'll bet no one can find as strong and deep and
wonderful a vibe at any show as at the right party; it's so nice that what
one gets out of a party is not directly proportional to the $$ they put in.

Party on!

- E
(or is that Party on E?)

Subject: NON RAVE: Baby hamsters
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sorry, this is non rave, but the people on here are pretty cool and I'd feel 
more comfortable having some of the folks here adopt one of my hamsters than 
most people.

Yup, nature has performed it's little miracle again (dang it) and I'm now 
the proud uncle of yet another brood of baby hamsters.  Geez I wish I could 
tell these little suckers apart...  Anyway, so far I see 4 babies, but the 
night is young...  These are Russian Dwarf hamsters, about half the size of 
your average Teddy Bear hamsters.  Short hair, brown and grey with a black 
stripe down their back.  Some are albino, which I'm told is quite rare.  
Amazingly cute, very friendly, lot's of energy.

And they love to rave.  Really!

Anyway, I've got far too many of these little guys to care for.  If I take 
them to the pet store, I'm afraid they'll end up as fodder for the reptiles. 
 Please help me find them a home!  They're free!  Just take them off my 
hands!  You can have a baby, once they're weaned, or an adult.  At *this* 
point, I know which ones are males and which are females.  Take two and I'll 
give you a little Habitrail-type house to take them home in.

HELP!

Todd, 415-965-7367

Subject: sunset is sunset is sunset is sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(sorry moonpup, I had to reuse the title - it works with my point)

OK   Sunset is on suday the day after all the "great" parties.
It's a day you go out to pt. Molate or the marina and kick it w/ friends,
listen to MELLOW ambient and house and relax away the rest of the weekend.
Pacific has put on this "free extra day of partying for all ya'll".  If
someone  doesn't like the style - they shouldn't go.  Go check out the End
Up or Spundae if you want to grove to something harder on Sunday.  I have
always had a great time at sunset and I always will because - the vibe is
good, my friends are there, my 2nd family is there (all of you) and good
music is playing (it's also free).

Another thing to add - the last three dj's were from NY, not SF.  So this
shouldn't reflect on the type of party sunset is when JUST SF dj's are
playing.  I have heard some fasted, groovier, slower, and harder types of
music at various sunsets.   Go to a few sunday parties and then make
judgements and "changes" about the party.

This post is not directed at anyone in paticular but rather as a general
statment of my opinions and observations about sunset parties.

I think snoppy said it best:  "Happiness is sunsets"

Austin

I have seen Blue Beat Stompers who opened for No Doubt at the Berkeley 
Square.  The stompers were a very good, peppy ska band and had about 7 
members including horns etc. all lined up at the front of the stage in 
this wall'o'sound.  No Doubt followed and what a show!  throbbing energy 
and just a mash of happy people goin' off to discofunk/ska and it was 
just about as vibey as any old rave except more body contact involved.

From: Diana Greer <inanna@ccnet.com>
Organization: The Lab
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.0 (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SDream <SDream@tgrigsby.com>
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Mr. Bill, the hamster RIP
References: <199603280403.UAA00916@shellx.best.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Todd,

One time I had a hamster.  His name was Mr. Bill, (named after the then 
very famous clay character on Sat. Night Live.)  Mr. Bill was a 
second-hand hamster from a school friend.  He had an interesting life. 
One time he fell in the fishbowl and went swimming.  He didn't like 
swimming and I had to fish him out.  Then another time he was strolling 
around the house in his clear plastic ball.  He powered right through 
the barracade in front of the stairs, and went bouncing and rolling 
down.  Then in the summer of '80, we had a tornado.  Our house, our 
street, our side of town was distroyed.  He was lost.  I felt very bad. 
Two weeks after the tornado, a bulldozer and very big pick-up trucks 
were clearing the rubble from our property.  A worker looked down, and 
there was Mr. Bill, walking through the rubble!  We scooped him up and 
put him in a new cage.  He never talkied about those 2 weeks on his 
own in the rubble, but he seemed very happy to be back in domesticity.  
He thrived and had a happy little life.  About a year later, he stuffed 
his cheeks too full, and got trapped in the doorway of his little red 
and yellow sleeping house.  He died the way he wanted to, with his mouth 
full of food.


Diana

Subject: That Darn Comet!
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.960328021320.24880D-100000@vanbc.wimsey.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WOW is all i have to say :)  Angelika and Tracy and I all went driving to 
Lions Bay to do a little viewing.  Out away from the city ... the sky was 
unbelieveable.  I always forget how heartbreakingly beautiful the stars 
are.  The comet's tail was faint but stretched allllll the way over to 
the Big Dipper .... and through binocs it looked even better.  We ended 
up just plain ol stargazing with a chart and everything trying to see 
what we could see.  Too bad Andromeda had already set, i wanted another 
peek at M31 :)

The Planetarium in Vancouver has telescopes set up for anyone who wants 
to have a look before it's gone forever ... for people our age, anyways :)

Then i went to MaRS and had a kickin time bouncing around to Prettyboy's 
set, ut left when Donald came on.  This is the first time i've ever seen 
him (i can hear the gasps!) and i don't know if it was just me or what 
but i didn't find him all that enthralling .... oh well :) at least i got 
to experience him for a while, which was the whole point :)

gotta run now - up too late - i'm gonna PAY for this at work tomorrow!!

peacce

k

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>TRIBAL FUTURE UPDATE<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

       Time for another mountain jam, this time around we're calling it 
the "Big Mountain Boogie".  Dust off your camp gear and set your sights 
on Willits in the heart of Mendocino County. Our main crew will be 

      TONY         CARLOS         JOSH         JOHN HOWARD

          TRACY     GALEN       SOLAR      ALEX WINDSOR

   Odd hours ambience and other far out beats to be provided by

      ALIKA      ABSTRACT       POLLYWOG       DAN BARNES 

           ALLEN      ANDREW     NATHAN     DJ CRACK    

  
  That should be more music than can fit on anyones plate but if you're 
still hungry save room for free pancakes and fruit on Sunday morning at 
the outdoor kitchen. If thats not enough you can always hike to the top 
of the mountain and check out the springs and the meadow up there. 
  We'll make sure there's plenty of wood to heat the hot tubs so be 
ready for a good soak or you can always take a dip in the swimming hole 
at the nearby Eel River. 
  The music will be continuous from noon on Saturday until midnight or 
later on Sunday night. Folks with tickets who want to show up early are 
welcome to start camping Friday afternoon and and everyone is free to 
stay until Monday morning.

  The gardens are sure to be in full bloom 
           we'll be dancing under the silvery moon,
              can't wait it'll be here soon!!!!!!!! 

                   YIPPIE!!! WITH LOVE TO ALL    MARK AMEBA ;-)


  ps. tix will be at ameba and primal early next week.info@415-750-9368

Well, I've found that only massive rave I support now a days **IS** The 
Gathering.  Despite the size, Martin's raves have always delivered a 
tremendously good vibe.  He's never failed in the more than 3 years I 
have been attending his events.  But, like you Nancy, I am now supporting 
more than ever the smaller underground parties.  Just my personal 
preferance and it is kinder to my wallet. :)

Just for my quick 2 cents:  I hope raves never never NEVER NEVER 
***NEVER*** become mainstream!!!!!!!!!

I guess you just mean in our country.  Raves are very mainstream
elsewhere.

> I don't see how they would ever become mainstream, as they're drugfests

Easy: make them into cool places to just hangout.  Start serving/selling
food & drink, supply BBQ facilities.  Also invite musicians/drummers for
some freeform jamalongs.  Focus on fashions and rave accessories so
people will know what their supposed to wear.  Make sure the DJs play
the oldies, especially remixes of 80's hits.  Better yet, have DJs that
take requests so everyone is happy.  Promote sport activities like 
hackysak so all the non-dancers have stuff to do.  Encourage costumes, 
and mimes, you have to have mimes.  Alchohol and drugs are ok cause
that's cool, except that the smell of all that cooked meat will keep most 
of the real drug users away anyway, which is probably just as well.  

> much more than any concert (and I use concert here as an example of a
> mainstream event).  It just wouldn't be condoned by major corporations,

In Europe, raves are sponsored by major corporations.

In-Reply-To: <v02130500ad80abf83f25@[128.32.160.41]> from "Nancy" at Mar 28, 96 12:50:54 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

RE: "BSP" and "BP" , Nancy asked -
> 
> I feel like a newbie - what do these mean??
> 
 "BSP" is a short three character charm used to ward off any posting
purity demons on SFRaves. The letters stand for Blatent Self Promotion.
Using this in the Subject: line of the post is supposed to warn
readers that the poster has a commercial and/or ego involvement in
the topic of the posting - for example, a DJ posting about a rave
that the DJ is going to be spinning at.

 "BP" is a varient on "BSP" , meaning a post about an event that the
poster does not have a commercial stake in , but still feels strongly
about in some way.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

  My name is Megan, I am 17 years old, attend San Ramon Valley High School in
Danville, (will be attending SFSU come August).  I'm 5'7", 113.8 lbs., red
hair, green eyes, blaah,blaah,blaah.  My raving experience is limited (only
2) but I consider myself a raver in philosophy, mainly PLUR, I try very hard
not to judge people based on appearance but I will be the first to admit if
someone attractive catches my eye I only wonder if the person is nice, kind,
loving, etc., afterwards (I'm just a little shallow).  I will help anyone in
need if I can help in any way.  Am very considerate and sensitive to the
feeling of other. 

  I have lived in various locations in the Bay Area my entire life but only
recently began to appreciate what SF and outlying areas have to offer.  I
love roller coasters, music of all kinds, driving, magazines with glossy
pictures, beautiful people of all shapes and size, and sushi.  I will try
(almost) anything once and try to have a good time doing it.  I am very shy
but am prone to go wild under the right circumstances...atmosphere... people
around me.

There is my intro.  
   Hope to see everyone soon.
            Megan
                 Czefir

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Dune report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dune,  in the desert with the comet
By Crunchman - A review

Well,   I finally hooked up with a ride to Dune,  thanx to Dean who I
met at Basics the week before.

Dean arrived on Friday evening after waking up in early evening.
Dean has this nighttime job,  sleeps during the day,  so after he
arrives,  I start packing my camping gear in preparation for heading
out into the desert.    The distance was exactly 450 miles from my
driveway to where the car was parked at the gig.

We left at exactly 2 am on Saturday morning,  and got back exactly
at 2 am on Monday morning.

We drove through the night,  down I-5, one of the loneliest hi ways
on earth it seems,  taking in the most incredible views of the comet
from the central valley.   We arrived around noon on Saturday,
using the directions we got from KC,  one of the promoters.

When we arrived,  nothing was there,  which gave us thoughts that
perhaps it wasn't going to be going off,  so Dean who drove the entire
distance got some sleep while I explored the rocks and watched the
dirt bikers scrambling around,  and a few people shooting off 20
gauge shotguns for target practice.   Eventually,  a ranger from the
bureau of land management showed up and approached our car,
asking if everything was OK.   Dean was chilling in the car,  and I was
talking to the ranger who I learned was Barry.   Barry indicated
there was going to be a race,  and asked if I know the promoters,
which I said I didn't.  Barry indicated that KC had all the permits
arranged for the party,  and asked me what A rave was.   I told him
it was a spiritual dance celebration being somewhat evasive about
the other aspects of raving.   Eventually Barry took off in his pickup
and left us to chill.

An hour or so later, Barry shows up and informs us the rave was on
the other side of the rocks,  so I head over there to see the people
with the generator,  but the sound system and KC hadn't arrived yet.

I did meet a few of the other promoters,  and noticed them with
Barry,  probably informing them where the bikers race route was set
so people wouldn't get hurt by climbing over the bike route during
the race.

As the sun was setting,  the sound crew was busy at work,  setting
up the JBL Shredder sound system,  lights,  and other stuff.   We go
off to fix dinner in anticipation for raving our asses off...

At about 10 pm,  the sound started,  but there was perhaps about 40
people there,  and few people dancing.   But cars were streaming in
as we watch them out over the desert,  and the rave was filling up.

KC started out with house music,  and eventually about 500 people
showed up by about midnight.   It was very cold and windy,  but we
didn't much care because the energy of the music and dancing really
kept us all warm.

By about 1 am,  there were at least 1000 people present,  as the
party WENT OFF big time.   The comet in the sky,  along with the
visuals provided us with some great "eye candy" as well as other
candies.

I met a lot of SoCal ravers,  and was surprised to see a lot of them
knew me from visiting SF.   But despite a few people knowing me,  a
lot more didn't know me,  and being a stranger was kinda
interesting,  as it reminded me of Australia when I first arrived.
Seeing all these new faces was really great.   The vibe was excellent,
and surprising to me,  based on other people's impressions of the LA
scene.

The music was excellent...  a little slower trance than I'm used to but
when Thee-o went on at 7 am,   things really went wild as the BPM's
were suddenly increased to about 145-150,   I WENT OFF big time,
but by about that time,  a lot of people stopped dancing and were
chilling by the side.  I went completely ballistic,  getting down to
some serious dancing to some amazing Goa trance.

By that time,  the sun had warmed things up a lot,  and I shed all my
warm clothes.    I must have danced Thee-o's entire set.
INCREDIBLE...   After Thee-o,  things slowed down a bit,  so I took an
opportunity to go out in the desert and trip around.

The music kept going until about noon....   Some young girl had
apparently passed out,  as the medics arrived to take her to the
hospital.   A chopper came in and lifted her out...   Hope she's going to
be OK.  Other than that incident,  things went very well.   I didn't
even notice the dirt bike race...

We hung around and helped clean up the place,  and finally left
around 2 pm or so and headed north.

Dean had managed to get some sleep and made it almost halfway
back before deciding to rest.   We stopped at a Pickle park (Rest
area) for about 6 hours of sleep and took off again about 11:30 pm
for the remainder of the trip to arrive home at 2 am.

Crunchman

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Something Special message + (long)
Cc: aditya@mh1.well.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Nancy has commented at least twice on the xeroxed message handed out near
the end of Something Special last Sat., and I just found it again.  It's
appropos given the threads on the scene's growing pains, so I wanted to
share it (i hope the something special folk don't mind).  with my comments
it will be a slightly long post.

the original was all in capital typewritten letters, with a few words in
bold; i'm putting it in upper & lowercase with bold words in  ALL CAPS:


Why are you at this event?  The rave scene is NOT just about techno.  This
scene is NOT just about drugs.  This scene is NOT just about fashion.  It
is something special about UNITY and HAPPINESS.  It is about being yourself
and being loved for it.  It should be a harbor from our society.  But our
scene right now is disintegrating!  Old style ravers- remember when
everybody hugged all the time- not just to say hello and goodbye?  Remember
when people just said hi for no reason except to be your friend?  Remember
how good that felt?  Why don't we do it anymore?  Newcomers- you are wanted
and you should know that this scene is about openness.  We all share a
bond- the desire to groove to a good beat all night long- and no man is an
island.  Everyone needs friends and the outside world is tough enough.  We
don't need fronts and attitudes in our scene.  Open your hearts and let the
good feelings flow.  Look around you, pick a person, ask them their name,
and make a friend.  Eliminate boundaries.  Open your hearts and minds.
RAVERS UNITE AND KEEP OUR SCENE ALIVE!!!
                                *  unknown source


[  there were some fun drawings around the border of the text, including
Bert & Ernie -- maybe that's why Nancy remembers it ;) -- and on top there
was a small peace sign with a small p under it, a heart with an l under it,
and then 3 arrows going around in a circle with an r under it -- so maybe r
also means . . . recycle!  ;)   ]

lotsa food for thought. . .in my brief raving history (almost 4 mos. now),
I've been really lucky to have been exposed to many of the best aspects of
the scene, and not many of the worst.  But the vibe's different when
external forces are present, be they bodysearchers on the way in,
non-ravers without a clue at the fringes of public outdoor parties, police,
or some of the internal security folks like those I've seen at the
Gathering or that lame Evolution thing a coupla weeks ago.

Yet no matter whether we're watched or not, we have to be responsible to
ourselves, each other, and Mother Earth, and if we do a good job of that,
the outside world shouldn't be much of a problem -- creative, subtle people
find ways of doing what they want to do.

Regarding the size of the scene, like water it will find its own level.
Some new people will get it and bring in positive, new energy; some won't
and will leave.  Some old school folk will slow down or move on, and some
will continue to shine.  There will undoubtedly be some more mainstream
techno music in this country that gets popular, but that shouldn't affect
the increasingly diverse and oft-brilliant SF music scene, nor the
underground rave scene (which may have to go a little more underground to
survive, but will if needed I'm sure).

I say we need to encourage all the small-scale events we can, and the
people who have been in the scene awhile who might be motivated to put
things on themselves, in new spaces, to keep things fresh and safe.  But
then we can take the positive energy to the larger, more public events,
indoor and outdoor, when we're there, so the whole scene can continue to
move forward.


leftjab (Jonathan)


"We don't need no more trouble
What we need is love"


-- Robert Nesta Marley

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by webe.hooked.net (8.6.12/8.6.12) id EAA01287; Fri, 29 Mar 1996 04:53:38 -0800

From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@mailhost.hooked.net>
Message-Id: <199603291253.EAA01287@webe.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: music of all sorts....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

..........for those that know me or my musical history, I have played many
styles of house music, including deep, techno, tribal, breakbeat, and acid,
and have played hybrids like ambient etc......I've dabbled in trance, and
i'm dabbling in jungle, but I truly have grown to love the funky, and acid
elements, thus these days I play triphop, and more uptempo acid breakbeat
styles........I almost dont even look for "house-4 to the floor", unless
there is a special beat syncipation, killer tribal beat, or a clever vocal
sample or a fat bassline or an acid element etc........I look for the
unusual and bizzare.....the original and the sampled........... 
 
I have listened to classic rock, new wave, jazz, classical, motown, funk,
etc.....and I guess the basic point I'm trying to make is that I can't
expect to listen to the same music over and over and over again..........I
love house and I love the lifestyle house has opened up to me, but I can't
listen to house all day every day and all night every night....... 
 
just as I feel there is a time and place for house, there is not a time and
place for house. 
 
I enjoy to listen on the long drive to a gig in say santa cruz, to an
uptempo mix tape, to help get me in the mood for the night
ahead..........but on the way home I like to listen to a more mello down
tempo style that helps calm and relax me............thus said....... 
 
I feel that a DJ and it's audience needs to understand where they are
playing, at what time they are playing, and thusly pick a style of music
that is appropriate for that time and place..........now if a dj has
limited resources (she/he only plays gabber for example) 
then it's the promoters job to sort out when that DJ should play. 
 
now I know that if I attempted to play triphop in the main room at a major
event at 1:30 am, that I am not playing  the optimum music for that time
and place, and If I play gabber at 1:30 in the afternoon on a sunday in the
park, I am not feeling or working the mood that surrounds me. (with all due
repect to gabber dj's) 
 
I have heard far to many a DJ play their Sat nite hardest set during a
daytime event, as if it was an audition or something.........I like to be
set into the mood by the DJ, but I hope that she/he can understand that
outdoor elements require less hardcore elements & beats (trance, jungle
etc...) and more subtlety and finese.......and even a DJ's creativity can
create a vibe that beats any old thumpin record ever could, and people will
really appreciate your ability to sway them with sustenance and flavor,
rather than beat them over the head with hardcore thrills. 
 
I feel that it is the contrasts of the music that makes the music so
powerful. thats why we play hard at nite and chill out in the day
(generally speaking). certainly times have changed to show me that you can
rave on a wed afternoon, its not neccesarily about sat nites anymore, so
sometimes trance during the day is good.....but I strongly feel that  we
need to be more open to the styles we hear at daytime events...........I
have some records that I only play at outdoor events, and I have records I
would never play outdoors (too hard).........it's a matter of
choice...........I will probably be flamed for having an opinion, but I
felt I needed to follow up and explain a little deeper my last post
regarding my position on playing trance music during the day.....it was not
meant as a personal flame to anyones right to play or listen to trance (at
any time)                                                                  
                                                                           
                                           
                                                                           
            ..............moonpup

Moonpup basically said it all here....
I had mentioned in a previous post about hearing trance during the day 
and said that there is a certain time and setting for each style of 
music.  

So we are now wondering, what kind of music is really good for 
daytime outdoors.

Listen to Galen's mixtape "Continuum".  

This is my all time favorite tape EVER and it has outdoors written all 
over it.  The music is SO uplifting with some tribal elements and it's 
mellow sounding, but the beats are still strong.  To me that is the 
perfect recipe for a daytime outdoor rave. :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar 29 09:22:13 1996

Date: 29 Mar 96 12:18:50 EST
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: massive raves 
Message-ID: <960329171850_71165.755_GHL111-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Allissa asked...
	What was that "party" at the Oakland Kaiser Auditorium awhile
back?

	Seemed to me that was some attempt at mainstreaming "rave
culture", but I didn't go and didn't talk to anyone that went, so 	I don't
really know.

	Does anybody else out there know about it? 


Sad to say, I went to it -- Cool World --  I went specifically because I wanted
to see what a commercial massive was like, from the organizational end (how did
they handle lines, crowd control, food, water, etc.) -- and I knew that the
Wicked crew was spinning in an outside tent, so that no matter what, I could
count on being outdoors and hearing music I knew I would like....

It sucked.  There were carnival rides, people selling schlocky stuff, and most
horrifying to me, people doing tattooing and piercing in dusty, dirty open tents
(those who know me know I take these things very seriously, both in a spiritual
way and in a health-safety way) -- seeing a beautiful young girl having a flash
butterfly tattooed on her belly by a greasy looking stranger while 8 gangsta
boys leered at her caused me grief beyond belief...

It sucked.  The crowd was WAY young, looked like they'd been dropped off by
their mommy who would pick them up at 7 in the morning, thinking they were safe
there somehow -- bad drugs everywhere and paramedics running through
periodically --

Did I say it sucked?  Inside the building was a total nightmare, people with
bullhorns keeping people from stopping on the steps or in the halls, where the
lights were on bright - and such weird energy inside, I didn't stay more than a
minute...  At least they had enough bathrooms though...

This was where I had my worst whistle experience ever, with a tweaked out
whistle=man who was relentless, louder than I ever though possible, and I swear
who followed me around, I could not get away from it!

Were there ravers there?  I saw a number of people I know, but I doubt any of us
would ever go again.  Worst of all, my car was blocks away, so I had wait until
morning to walk back to it ... looooooonnnnggg night.

This party in no way was like the Gathering or other massive events... it was a
middle-American-kids night out because of the promotion of the event...  Moral
of the story?  Don't go to Cool World, no matter who's spinning - for me, my
good time is 50% music and 50% people/vibe -- 

Leslie  : )

SUBJECT: (non-Rave) Seeking Roommie(s)

  I sent this out yesterday morning but haven't seen it appear yet, so...
  here it is again (sorry if anyone gets a duplication).

                     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++
 Hello All!

 Tis the time to seek a new place to live and some roommates as well.
 I'm looking to move into a new place some time in May.
 I don't have a place in particular that I'm going to move in to
 but would like to find a place with one or more cool folks (or
 if anyone has space currently...).

 Location...I currently work in Sunnyvale and would have a preference
 to find a place in that area (or Los Altos/Mt.View/Palo Alto...etc.),
 but could consider other options.

 Without going into long detail, suffice to say for now I'm a responsible
 roommate who's fun (so I like to think anyway...:), respecting, and likes
 to rave, of course.  Some of you have met me (hopefully that's a good
 thing  :) ) so I'm not totally unfamiliar to some.

 If anyone is interested or knows someone who is, please email me
 at tbobsc@tevm2.nsc.com or call (408) 735-9699, and we can discuss.

 Thanks!!

P.S., I am willing to consider various options (location, time fram, etc.)
      just lemme know!  Taking the time to find a good too

Moonpup,

        Anyone who flames you for your opinions needs to remember the word
RESPECT!  You have valid points to make, and elaborating the way you do
helps others to understand where you're coming from.  You didn't say
"Here's the last word; if you don't agree, piss off!" so I for one am glad
you posted.
        Due to my lack of familiarity with the music, at this point I don't
think it would make any difference to me what style of music is played at
any time, in any environment.  However, you talked about the concept of
maintaining a mood or atmosphere, and that makes sense to me.  When my band
puts together a set list for a gig (like tonight's free party in Sunnyvale
- BSP!), we like to group songs by mood, too, so we can deliver some
energetic songs, then mellow and stretch out with some slower stuff, and
finish with a bang.  So, I back you up, since we are both musical artists.

Thanks!

Love,

- E

Eric P. Peterson
Financial Assistant
N&CS Materials Management
Synopsys Inc.

>Sad to say, I went to it -- Cool World --  I went specifically because I
wanted 
>to see what a commercial massive was like,  
>It sucked.  There were carnival rides, people selling schlocky stuff, and
most 
>horrifying to me, people doing tattooing and piercing in dusty, dirty open
tents 
>(those who know me know I take these things very seriously, both in a
spiritual 
>way and in a health-safety way) -- seeing a beautiful young girl having a
flash 
>butterfly tattooed on her belly by a greasy looking stranger while 8
gangsta 
>boys leered at her caused me grief beyond belief... 
> 
>It sucked.   
 
 
let me tell you a story......... 
 
.........once upon a time a coolworld promoter called me to play at their
event and as I needed work, I responded, they told me that because this was
a Donation event and that the procedes would go to charity would I be
willing to play for 1/2 price, SURE I said unknowingly.......and trounced
off to work what I thought was a cool big party....... 
.........first of all my turntables got knocked over by some doped up
asshole, right in the middle of my set (just like garth at burning man), he
was screaming "its all over shut it down now", and I'm like yeah whatever
man, meanwhile trying to find a security guard or a promoter to get rid
this asshole  or confirm it truly was over............ 
 
.........secondly when I arrived....there idea of donation was to bring a
can of food, they had no intention of paying out any money and they were
charging $25.00 each (approx 4.000 people).......so I pulled them aside and
said it was bullshit to mis-lead me into 1/2/ price scenerio......and that
normally I would never change what I had agreed to ($$$ wise), but that I
wanted an additional $100.00 due to there mis-leading statements of
charity....   well they begrugingly gave me my $200.00 total plus the extra
$100.00   I asked for and I told them there lucky I dont ask for the full
$400.00 i originally had quoted.........any way I learned my
lesson.......no more gigantic gigs, or bullshit promoters......(i managed
to never work on such a grand scale again, but unfortunately.........too
many crap promoters ripping me off that I retired from DJ-ing.) 
 
fotunately I have come back and I am happy with the level of the promoters
I deal with now........honest, caring, and about a vibe.....I have been
payed $275.00 (TOTAL) this year for over 15 gigs.............(of course I
lost my job so now I need $$$ to play sometimes)....... 
 
I go to tribal gathering in the U.K. may 4th.....30,000 people last
year......wow, I'm a little overwhelmed.......I 'll keep in touch with SFR
and try to let you know how it was...... 
 
                                                                           
                    moonpup

On Fri, Mar 29, 1996 9:20:18 AM  at Rob Jellinghaus wrote: 
 
>>With all this talk of profit motive I thought I'd point out that  
>>those hits of E people are willing to spend $25 on only cost 
>>about a buck or two to manufacture... 
> 
>True.  Of course, the manufacturers are risking years of jail time... 
>underground party organizers don't have anywhere near that amount 
>of risk. 
> 
>Rob Jellinghaus  robj@best.com 
>

yes but my friends......that is why the dealer sells e    to make massive
profits........I have never seen a e dealer pay out any $$$ to DJ's or
whatever (unless it's one of these promoter/dealer types) who only throw
raves to profit on the e and the nitrous balloons etc..... 
 
I have a guy call me from time to time wanting to know where I will be dj
ing just so he can ask the promoter if he can bring the hippy crack.....YUK
!!!!!    WRONG !!!!! 
 
the risk of jail time is minimal to the $$$ signs the e dealer see's    
they just don't wanna get a real job........so no sympathy for the poor e
dealer, I can't get a break on a hit of e to save my life.........."sorry
I'm broke, I cant afford to lower the price etc...." is what I hear all to
often, I try to exchange DJ tapes for e's with the selling line...."this
tape will last you a lot longer than that e will last me" 
 
don't get me wrong.......I like to do the occaisional e, but I don't
support the notion that these people face years of jail time, so feel sorry
for them, so pay overpriced amounts.  you get out what you put in to
life.........you deal, you risk, if you win and never get caught, I'll bet
you have a 4 wheel drive vehicle........if you lose and get
caught.......don't expect me to dole out $25.00  to help support a rave
that is to help with your lawyer costs.........         
 
I pay thousands of $$$ a year to bring you the musical
experience........and get very litte back (financially speaking).......but
the vibe I get from people who enjoy my talents is
immeasurable................                        moonpup 
 
I know we need the e.......so I'm not blasting e dealers, just the notion
we should overpay and be happy because of all that
risk.........bullshit....... 
 
some e dealers are so subtle....there vibe is right.......but most   
..........well you know the story...........

> tape will last you a lot longer than that e will last me" 
>  
> don't get me wrong.......I like to do the occaisional e, but I don't
> support the notion that these people face years of jail time, so feel sorry
> for them, so pay overpriced amounts.  you get out what you put in to
> life.........you deal, you risk, if you win and never get caught, I'll bet
> you have a 4 wheel drive vehicle........if you lose and get
> caught.......don't expect me to dole out $25.00  to help support a rave
> that is to help with your lawyer costs.........         
>  
> I pay thousands of $$$ a year to bring you the musical
> experience........and get very litte back (financially speaking).......but
> the vibe I get from people who enjoy my talents is
> immeasurable................                        moonpup 
>  
> I know we need the e.......so I'm not blasting e dealers, just the notion
> we should overpay and be happy because of all that
> risk.........bullshit....... 
>  
> some e dealers are so subtle....there vibe is right.......but most   
> ..........well you know the story........... 
>  
>  
>  
>

On Wed, 27 Mar 1996, Nancy wrote:

> A bi-weekly called Seismic is going on Thursday night in the city.  I
> picked up a flier at MAD - resident dj's are Dan and DRC, with special
> guests.  Only $5, and it tells us to bring candy and smiles :) :) .  Sounds
> like a good one!  I might be heading out to it (but that would make 5
> nights dancing in one week, a bit much, even for spring break!).
> 
> SFRaves Calendar lists the phone number.
> 
I went to Seismic last night with a friend. It was at the Acme, but with 
around 100 people there wasn't an overcrowding or overheating problem. 
They had the upstairs level set up with visuals on both ends of the 
building,DJ Dan started just after 10 and went til midnight when DRC came 
on. After that DJ Kimo, then Surge (Josh was going to close out the 
evening but we left before that so I don't know if he did). Excellent 
music all night (quite a variety mixed in), free candy passed out every once 
in a while plus oranges :)Good vibe all around. This is a wonderful 
example of the thrivingunderground we have. I'll be watching out for this 
one in the future!
