On Tue, 26 Mar 1996, TALILLA SCHUSTER wrote:

> Besides being a place in India, the DJ Goa Gil is an older, dreadlocked,
> fantastic master of hard trance. He's been spinning for about twenty
> years, but didn't really get accepted into the SF scene until about last
> year or so, when trance got more popular. He used to go on tour a lot,
> but recently he's been around more. He is completely amazing - sort of
> the grandaddy of trance, and the two times I've seen him were two of the
> best parties I've ever been to. He does stuff with DATs, not just records
> and travels to India and all over putting on epic parties. I know that
> some friends of mine were planning to go to India for a party; I don't
> know if that already happened. Anyway, that exhausts my limited
> knowledge, which I hope is accurate. You could try to see him sometime.
> Talilla

At 11:06 AM 3/29/96 -0700, sbmooc@IMAP1.ASU.EDU wrote:
>> 
>> Yeah, I'm sure Ticketmaster (Ticketbastards?) would LOVE to get in on it...
>> 
>Ticketmaster has already sold tix to (2 that I know of) events here in 
>Phoenix, Arizona!!!

More often than not, venues contract with TicketMaster.  So, no matter who
has a show at a certain place, if tickets are sold, TicketMaster is the
dealer.  That's why for certain places that have regular events, you always
have to go to a certain place to get tickets!

It's all because of contracts and the general business model.  Think about
it a bit before you hit the D key.  If a ticket agency says to a venue that
they'll be the agency for all their events, pay them $50k an event if they
can tack on $3, most venues would do that.

TicketMaster may do one-offs, but I'd think they'd be more interested in
the bigger, more frequent productions than a one time only gig.

Just my $.02.



Andrew
--
   Andrew Bennett
   abennett@hyperreal.com, abennett@cruzio.com
   http://taz.hyperreal.com/~abennett/

 I'll skin my back a few times, you'll see
 head over heals, my hands on my heart
 I'm making a promise and that's a start.

 You're leaving a trail for me
 I see you up in the tallest tree
 You're throwing things down at me
 I'm starting to climb, well I'm starting on my knees."

                                                  - Mac

I've been working on this girl for almost a year now. I saw her again for 
the first time in 2 months at the last sunset and ended up giving her a 
handful of tick - tacs. She goes "You look familar, do I know you ?" and 
I go, "Yeah, *you're* the Bubble Girl." and she goes "Oh, yeah." 
Maybe I'll see her tomorrow.

  Moral of the story?  Don't go to Cool World, no matter who's spinning -
for me, my
>good time is 50% music and 50% people/vibe --
>
>Leslie  : )


Ya, a friend of mine couldn't get tix for Begin Again and was dragged by
"friends" to Cruel World New Year's Eve.  He was appalled.  Tough-looking
guys glaring at people, looking for trouble, scantily-clad female go-go
dancers on the stage, mainstream house music, drunken hordes, negative
vibe.  He left at 2AM (not only unheard of for a "rave," but this was NEW
YEAR'S EVE!).

All we have to do is look at Cruel World to see what the commercialization
of rave looks like!

Nancy


P.S.  The gangstas strutting around the party looking for fights reminds me
of the one time I saw that at a rave - at Vision, I think, out in the
boonies, Pittsburgh.  A group of tank-topped teen-age boys travelling in a
pack, sticking out their chests and glaring at other guys.  But what was
hilarious was that they couldn't get anyone to respond!  Imagine trying to
start a fight with a bunch of idealistic, blissed out ravers on e?!  Ain't
gonna happen :) .

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 30 15:18:40 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA26919; Sat, 30 Mar 1996 15:18:40 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA26911; Sat, 30 Mar 1996 15:18:38 -0800
Received: from [128.32.160.53] (hmfmac15.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.53]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA12255 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 30 Mar 1996 15:18:38 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130508ad83672553d0@[128.32.160.53]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 30 Mar 1996 15:17:24 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Nikita Musings (long!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hmm...last 10 days: Light, Something Special, Sunset, MAD, Nikita and
tonight, Chrysalis.  Not a bad week!  But I may have gotten my fill of
raving for a while (what? Blasphemy! ;P ).

I'm not at Golden Gate Park right now at the free (and seemingly fucking
rad) Organic - I'm sitting in a computer lab in Berkeley because I can
barely move after last night.

Last night: Nikita at 1015 Folsom

I decided to check out the realm of Clubland.  Rave dj's, rave laser
company...can't be all bad, right?  The usual clubmix of clubkids and
suburbanites were there...the drinkers and the dancers.  I got my butt
pinched :( - definitely not a rave (without PLUR, there's no respect!).
But on the whole it was more fun than the average club experience - lotsa
folks were there to seriously get down, not to pick up on somebody.  There
were even a few glowsticks making their appearance.  No whistles or
handclaps or many spontaneous smiles, though.  Several instances of
anonymous guys suddenly dancing up against me when all I was trying to do
was enjoy my own experience of the music :( .  I'm starting to hate that
wherever I go, I invariably think, "I have more fun at a rave!"

 The lasers by Dimension 7 were GOING OFF in the main room - so many it
hurt my eyes to look at them!  I befriended the laserguy and got to play
with the lasers - hitting buttons to the beat, making lights jump, over
several hundred people - that was fun!  The fog machine was going full
blast all night, the stacks and stacks of speakers were booming.  The
second room featured hideous 80's music.  Downstairs was a "VIP" Room
(_definitely_ not a rave!) with some ambient music and folks who were too
cool to dance to it.

Simon and Henrik spun decent sets (it's hard to please me with house,
though).  Then "Superstar DJ" Keoki came on.  Now I've heard a lot about
his notorious reputation (his "attitude"), but also that he's the best.  He
spun crowd-pleasing deep house, with a few suspenseful crescendos, but I
swear with my limited dj'ing knowledge that he made a number of mistakes!
Some records rather awkwardly switched into the next, some samples came in
abruptly and a little off-beat, and the whole set was pretty generic!   He
did have about 15 minutes at the end that got the crowd hyped, but then it
happened!  Imagine one of the biggest clubs in San Francisco, packed with
hundreds of people, at the height of the dancefloor Friday night, with a
"superstar dj" especially flown in.  Someone hit the needle!!  Cardinal Sin
#1!  There was the longest, most horrifying SSCCCCRRRAAAATTCCHHHHH and then
dead silence.  I was at the decks watching Keoki spin, and here is when I
saw the famed attitude.  He went totally rigid, standing straight up, and
glared at the perpetrator with bulging eyes for loooonnng silent moments,
bad vibe just pouring out of him ("how dare you knock the deck of the
famous Keoki?") and then FINALLY put another record on.  I don't like to
judge people on one act, but the feeling of his response was _really_ ugly
(although I know hitting the needle is a BIIIGG NOO-NOO!  No interrupting
the vibe!).

Jeno ended the night on the decks.  He was truly masterful, seamless, but
unfortunately, I just can't stand the music!  I stopped dancing and watched
him spin, admiring the artistry, hating the tunes....(Progressive House...a
single beat for as long as five minutes, a simple layer for about as long,
and then back to a single beat...uuuhhhhhhhh....)

Some SFRavers were doin their thing on the dancefloor...what's up Leslie
and Todd!  I met some cool people and had a really good time - I think I'm
less anti-club now, but my heart still lies with the strongest unified
vibe, here in the underground :) :).

Missed Seismic Thursday night - this one sounds like a true underground
party worth supporting.  Going to try to make it in 2 weeks!

End of Report - See you all tonight at...you know where ;D.

Love, Vibe, and Stickers,
Nancy

On Sat, 30 Mar 1996, Nancy wrote:

> Why is everyone dissing Acme so hard?  Okay, it's a deathtrap - but the
> three parties I've been to there have been about the best of my life
> (Friends and Family, Harmony, and Begin Again)!  I only have incredible
> memories of old Acme Tool!

I want to preface this by saying I had one of the best party experiences 
of my life at Acme(F&F).  

I think that you will find that the reason people have little respect for 
Acme, is that I got the distinct impression that the  "owners" of Acme had 
little respect for the people going to the parties. We were just a source of 
revenue. My understanding from speaking to a couple of promoters, is that 
Acme just wanted more and more money, and weren't willing to make 
any efforts to increase the safety of the place.   

Yeah, Acme was fun, but I wouldn't want to die there.....

                                             Black Adder

would like to go. But I don't know where it will be.

Vladimirr

now, on to the bigger and better, on to golden gate park today! being as =
this was the first daytime event I've ever been to, I really don't have =
anything to compare it to, but let me tell you the vibe was definately =
in place... after a slow start due to a missing cable or somesuch, it =
went off and a cloud of dust started rising in front of the turntables =
from the dancers going for it! it was very interesting to me to watch =
people who were just at the park, tourists, and people's dogs interact =
with the people there and the music! hello to david, the only sfraver I =
saw (he had a laminate on) and megan (czefir) sorry I missed you... =
until next time...

Date: Sun, 31 Mar 1996 15:37:09 +0200
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: exodus@earthlink.net (Austin)
Subject: Re: Respect for Acme!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


On Sun, Mar 31 1996, Black Adder <blkadder@value.net> wrote:

>I think that you will find that the reason people have little respect for
>Acme, is that I got the distinct impression that the  "owners" of Acme had
>little respect for the people going to the parties. We were just a source o=
f
>revenue. My understanding from speaking to a couple of promoters, is that
>Acme just wanted more and more money, and weren't willing to make
>any efforts to increase the safety of the place.
>
>Yeah, Acme was fun, but I wouldn't want to die there.....
>
>                                             Black Adder

This is true.  I went to Seismic on Thursday at the Acme.  The owners
didn't allow the promoters to use the facilities down stares (only up
stairs).  When 4.30 am rolled around the owner came out an told Surge to
shut down the music.  I did't see the confrontation, but from what I
understand he said he wanted all the "ravers to go home" (for some reason -
I didn't hear).  They cut Surge's set short and I guess Josh never got to
spin.  We were all booted from the building. The party really ended on a
bad note =3D Surge spoke about how the owner was such an asshole, had no
respect for ravers and [the owner] didn't really care if he had promised
the building till 7 or not but just wanted everyone to go.  Everyone was
talking about "boycotting the Acme", spreading the "word" about the owner,
and telling promoters to not book any more parties at the Acme.

I personally hadn't been to the Acme since Chrystalis (or was Harmony the
last?) and I don't like to go to parties at the Acme unless they are thrown
buy people who I enjoy and like.  Reasons: It gets very hot, it gets very
crowded, it smells, it's a deathtrap and I am just not comfortable there.
True I've had great times there but if I had a preference I would never go b=
ack.

Re:Seismic

Got there when DRC was spinning some great break beat.  I hadn't heard her
in a while.  I liked some of the goa/trance she played but she spun some
abstract beat I couldnt get into.  Kimo was great and I missed most of
Surge's set cuze I went outside for awile and to Lift(DV8).  Came back to
hear the final songs and words (above) and left unsatisfied.  This was the
only party I went to this weekend because or work.  Austin T. I didn't get
to met you.  I don't know if you remember but I was the white guy-brown
hair- with a white adidas shirt w/ black stripes down the sleeves and blue
jenes.  There was a guy there with the same exact shirt and same colored
jenes too, (not my brother) but he did insist that he saw me the night
before in Safeway buying a case of whipped creme (I got a laugh out-a-this
but this wasn't me) I am happy to see some people had a good time - I
personally saw too many people tweeken and doin' crank for my taste. ( I
have a personal hatred for this useless substance).

See ya'll at the Gathering.  Can't wait.  PLUR

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 31 16:53:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA15756; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 16:53:26 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA15749; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 16:53:23 -0800
Received: from [128.32.160.69] (hmfmac31.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.160.69]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA32056 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 16:53:23 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130500ad84ccde700f@[128.32.160.53]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 31 Mar 1996 16:52:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Underground Responsibility
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night I again brought a newbie into the underground.  I wanted to
share the experience with my best friend from high school (with whom I had
made many drug-induced and spiritual explorations, at the time).  She and I
have had limited contact for the past five years, but my overflowing heart
unthinkingly wished to show EVERYONE the beauty of this scene, and I
invited her without, as I found, _really_ knowing her anymore.

I had explained what I find in the underground - the community, the sacred
ritual, the group vibe which to me proves spirituality, the energy link
between us all, one consciousness, the full acceptance.  She told me I
sounded like a Hare Krishna (I have noticed that my non-rave friends are
distinctly uncomfortable with that kind of talk.  I realize now that they
cannot understand because they haven't experienced it, and so they dismiss
this "mumbo jumbo" as something negative, either naivete on my part (one
non-raver friend warned me against being "hurt" by the scene), or bizarre
cultish group behavior.  :( .

On the ride into the city she began to spew negativity.  Saying she hated
the world, people were lame, and everyone was posers!  My heart sank - I
knew that in that mindframe she would not be able to connect with the magic
that we create.  I asked her to release her negativity and enter with an
open mind, just freely allowing the experience to show her whatever it
would.  She said my attitude was condescending and self-righteous.  (It is
amazing to me that our mindset so totally determines our interpretation of
the world, creating our own reality.  In my positivity and joy she saw a
superiority complex!  What sort of beliefs must she have to twist what
others have told me is "beautiful energy" into something that negative and
destructive?)

We got to the beautiful dance studio where Chrysalis was held.  She gave
the party about an hour, closed, not dancing, not speaking to people.  She
then announced she was calling a cab to take her away (at 2AM!) because all
the scene was was artificial connection, posers pretending to "love" each
other, the music was awful, grating, and the scene was not only just about
being trendy but also intensely boring.  I let her go with that, both
physically and mentally.  I don't recall her being this way when we were
very close friends.  I know I have grown more positive (a direct outgrowth
of rave revelations), but she has become mired in her world of anger and
negativity.  It makes me sad because it is not necessary, it is her choice
to live life that way.  I let her go because I no longer wish to pollute my
consciousness with those sorts of influences.  I need to surround myself
with people who are on the same wavelength, about opening up to greater and
greater love and generating something special for _all_ of us (not just
ravers!).  Since I have been raving I have become a more joyous person, and
I am convinced that affects all I come into contact with :).  Maybe that is
the only way to share the underground with the outside world - spread the
love.  Once they have that, they will have the mindset to appreciate and
thrive in the actual rave experience.

I realized last night that belonging to the underground is a
responsibility.  I need to be _very_ careful about who I bring into that
sacred environment!  The person _must_ have the right attitude, or they
will not only not see the transcendence but will also be adding bad vibes,
taking away from our collective possibility.  In the past I have wanted to
share this with _everyone_!  But now I feel like I cannot introduce people,
unless I see a very special quality in them.  I am feeling more and more at
home with the people already there - they are the ones who know, who
understand, who are feeling exactly what I'm feeling.

I met a new friend last week.  He came with a mutual friend with us to
Something Special.  His very first party was Halloween's Friends and Family
- so his introduction was right into the underground and for him it was
like coming home.  He and I connected on such a deep level, are on such on
the same wavelength in regards to spirituality, our mission in life, what
we experience in the rave ritual, that we were instant friends.   When we
first met, he glowed when he spoke of raving, and it was like we absolutely
knew each other, understood each other.  We've known each other now a
"week" but it feels completely timeless.  He stayed with me last night
after she left, and after the party we sat in my car and talked for 3 1/2
hours, and the whole time it was just like, "yes yes yes," - complete
understanding.  I no longer want to bring people into the scene, because
they have not been led there themselves.  I feel the bond with people who
have discovered the exact same things independent of my "guidance," and
have returned again and again, just like me.  The smiles we exchange on the
dance floor at 6 in the morning have greater meaning for me now.  Everyone
who is there at that time is a brother or sister of the spirit, I feel that
now.  One Family.

All last year I only went to big parties, but I sensed a kernel of
something true, and I kept seeking until I found it.  I think now if a
newbie wants to try "raving" I might suggest a commercial one, unless I am
sure of them.  The underground as a collective experiment requires a
certain energy level from individuals, a positive contribution on behalf of
each person there.  For it to work it requires us to give of our selves to
the collective whole, and for that we are rewarded with doubled and tripled
love returned.  But it needs people to be at a certain level of
consciousness.

Brothers and sisters of the underground, I love you all!!  :D Nancy







From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 31 17:18:19 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA18368; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 17:18:19 -0800

Message-Id: <v02130503ad84de2f7734@[128.32.160.69]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 31 Mar 1996 17:17:01 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Subject: Hey, Lurkers!  (yeah, you!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just got on this list two weeks ago, and yes, I've been an overenthusiastic
posting-hound :).  But I've thought of this list as a conversation between
the twenty or so people who post - an intimate discussion.  With realizing
there are 400 people, and random people I've never heard of recognizing me
at parties from SFR desciptions, I suddenly saw that this "private"
conversation is more like 20 people on a stage with microphones, with 400
people in the audience.

So, I would like to know who is out there in the audience!  I was wondering
if you could do us all the favor of a quick post saying your name and hi,
just so we know who is out there, listening and thinking.  I love you all!
-  Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 31 18:09:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA21725; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 18:09:26 -0800
Received: from ucscb.UCSC.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id SAA21716; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 18:09:23 -0800
Received: by ucscb.UCSC.EDU (5.65/1.34)
	id AA03222; Sun, 31 Mar 96 18:07:14 -0800
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9604010207.AA03222@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: Underground Responsibility
To: nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
Date: Sun, 31 Mar 1996 18:07:06 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v02130500ad84ccde700f@[128.32.160.53]> from "Nancy" at Mar 31, 96 04:52:08 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3410      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I realized last night that belonging to the underground is a
> responsibility.  I need to be _very_ careful about who I bring into that
> sacred environment!  The person _must_ have the right attitude, or they
> will not only not see the transcendence but will also be adding bad vibes,
> taking away from our collective possibility.  In the past I have wanted to
> share this with _everyone_!  But now I feel like I cannot introduce people,
> unless I see a very special quality in them.  I am feeling more and more at
> home with the people already there - they are the ones who know, who
> understand, who are feeling exactly what I'm feeling.
> 
I whole heartedly disagree.  Not that I don't share your displeasure with
these elements and desire clean negative-free parties, but because I feel
that the joy we experience while raving stems from the trancendance of
negative attitudes, of freeing ourselves from the judgements and confinement
of social constrictions and narrow minded perspectives.  These bad vibes that we
are trying to keep out of the party will never go away, until we accept
them and conquer them.  This doesn't mean forcing them to see our 
enlightened way, but allowing ourselves to see theirs.  When we can, we
begin to notice that our ways are actually very similar, if not the same,
and thats when we can move together into the future.  

Belonging to the underground is a responsability, but only to ourselves.
To always fight the desires to judge and not accept other people and
different modes of being.  There just isn't really any way to to grow 
until you make peace with every single thing out there, and accept it for
what it is, a reflection of yourself.  

You don't have to love everyone or bring everyone to your parties, but
you do have to accept them for who they are and welcome their presence
in your life.  That's where all of beauty comes from... that interplay.

So... don't be afraid of a little negativity, or even a lot, as long as
you remember what you're about nothing can destroy what you believe in.
Invite every single person in the world to a rave, dance and respect
the people who dance with you as much as the people who laugh at you...
That's when you'll really know that you're alive.

> understanding.  I no longer want to bring people into the scene, because
> they have not been led there themselves.  I feel the bond with people who
> have discovered the exact same things independent of my "guidance," and
> have returned again and again, just like me.  The smiles we exchange on the

It's not the leading, it's the pushing.  Everyone is led by something,
and it's all right if it's you, but nobody likes being judged.

> newbie wants to try "raving" I might suggest a commercial one, unless I am
> sure of them.  The underground as a collective experiment requires a
> certain energy level from individuals, a positive contribution on behalf of
> each person there.  For it to work it requires us to give of our selves to
> the collective whole, and for that we are rewarded with doubled and tripled
> love returned.  But it needs people to be at a certain level of
> consciousness.

no... it just needs consciousness to realize no bounds, no levels,
no separation... just freedom.  That only requires you.
Let the energy find itself, rather than seeking it out.

Regards, and good luck in your adventures.

-john.
http://www.he.net/~swoosh

Hi everyone!!  This is my first time posting on sfraves, but I am a 
"lurker", enjoying reading many intelligent, humorous, insightfu, 
messages.  I have been following sfraves for about a month and I think 
it captures the essence of the scene.  We use computers (tecnology) to 
better communicate and connect with each other, in a place where physical 
appearance truly doesn't matter.  I guess I never posted too much because 
of fear :), but it's time I stopped being a lurker and introduced myself.

My name is Tara and I'm a freshmen at UC Santa Cruz.  I am studying 
general ed and I have never loved learning so much.    I am originally 
from southern California where I first started raving about a year and a 
half ago.  For me raves have meant many different things:  a way to let 
my stress out, create love, meet incredible people, dance, hear some 
insane music, and explore myself.  I truly believe I am a more 
understanding and aware person as a result of my experiences.  I really 
like the San Francisco scene: lots of smiles, good dj's, a great city.

Anyways, I'm 18, short, and I have short bleached hair, so if you ever 
see me please say hi.  Reading sfraves makes me think about the impact 
raving has had on each individual and society.  So many people are being 
exposed to techno/house and seeing the complexity and possibilities.  I 
believe each person has their own personal idea about what raving means 
to them.  To me, we are a bunch of people coming together to dance all 
night and share sacred parts of ourselves. 

   I have no car so I don't get to go to parties often, so if anyone in 
the Santa Cruz area ever has room for another person, please email me.    
I love you all and appreciate your wisdom.  Hopefully I will have 
the guts to post more often.    

share your sunshine,

Tara

boy, what a cliche!
but it's true.


Nancy, i'm sorry you had such a bad experience with bringing your
old friend into the scene. i brought some newbies to a party in 
Madison Wisconsin this wknd and it went pretty ok.
two of them were so baked, they just sat on the floor for three hours. ugh!
we ended up leaving at 3:00am cuz of those two. oh wells.

i guess i didn't really like this party either cuz it was the first
time i saw ppl openly doing lines on the floor. i hate drug shit.

this midwest scene is really bringin' me down.
but on a lighter note, i have a cool story. this is kind of long so
bear with me:

in the airport at SFO, i got bumped off my flight from Minneapolis.
so waiting around, i saw this woman in the same gate area that looked
nice so i asked if she was going to mpls. also. she said yeah, she
had missed her earlier flight so now she was on standby for the next one
to Mpls. So we went and got lunch together.
she asked if i did anything cool whilst in SF. i said i went to some raves
and then to Yo' Mama's cafe in Oakland. She said oh, i hang out there
all the time! i said, this will be weird but, do you know this guy
(anybody else here know Mosha?). and she said, ohmigod! i totally know
him! i see him at YO Mamas all the time!


so with 3 million ppl in the bay area, i met two that know each other, in 
completely separate places at different times! i love san fran.

have a great week everyone!


clinton
misplaced Midwesterner

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 31 20:51:44 1996

	id XAA08394; Sun, 31 Mar 1996 23:51:38 -0500
Received: from [206.5.32.54] by mailhub.manual3.com
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.0); Sun, 31 Mar 1996 20:52:35 -0800
X-Sender: nathan_moser@mailhub.manual3.com
Message-Id: <v02130501ad84fe5b4cd5@[206.5.32.54]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 31 Mar 1996 20:52:35 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, nancys@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Nancy)
From: nathan_moser@manual3.com (Nathan Moser)
Subject: Re: Underground Responsibility
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Last night I again brought a newbie into the underground.  ...
>On the ride into the city she began to spew negativity.  Saying she hated
>the world, people were lame, and everyone was posers!  My heart sank - I
>knew that in that mindframe she would not be able to connect with the magic
>that we create.  I asked her to release her negativity and enter with an
>open mind, just freely allowing the experience to show her whatever it
>would.  She said my attitude was condescending and self-righteous.  (It is
>amazing to me that our mindset so totally determines our interpretation of
>the world, creating our own reality.  In my positivity and joy she saw a
>superiority complex!  What sort of beliefs must she have to twist what
>others have told me is "beautiful energy" into something that negative and
>destructive?)
>

I realize that you had the best intentions in mind, but from her
perspective your attitude was indeed condescending and self-righteous. To
her you were saying "your opinions and values are merely delusions of
negativity. Just assume my disposition and everything will be much better."
Mindsets rarely form by themselves. Ask a negative person what experiences
have led them to think the world's so fucked. It may be that a few bad
experiences have been blown out of proportion, or it may be that a lifetime
of abuse has tainted their outlook. Either way, simply hearing a few
second-hand counterexamples might give them something to think about.
Whenever I hear someone rant about the laziness of the homeless, I tell
them about the homeless guy who gave me a quarter for the phone when I was
locked out of a building.


>I realized last night that belonging to the underground is a
>responsibility.  I need to be _very_ careful about who I bring into that
>sacred environment!  The person _must_ have the right attitude, or they
>will not only not see the transcendence but will also be adding bad vibes,
>taking away from our collective possibility.  In the past I have wanted to
>share this with _everyone_!  But now I feel like I cannot introduce people,
>unless I see a very special quality in them.  I am feeling more and more at
>home with the people already there - they are the ones who know, who
>understand, who are feeling exactly what I'm feeling.

I wouldn't worry about it too much, actually. Whenever I encounter someone
with a weird/bad vibe at a party, I just flash em a big smile and keep
dancing. I think the most important thing is to prepare someone for the
type of music they're going to hear. No amount of vibe or community can win
someone over if they absolutely hate the music. After all, I've watched
line dancing on the Nashville Network - they all seem really happy,
together, enjoying some sort of vibe, and definitely enjoying the beer. But
if I had to listen to six hours of "new country," you'd find me curled up
in a ball in a corner, wheezing.

>Brothers and sisters of the underground, I love you all!!  :D Nancy

take care!
-nate
